text: Red Winter is an entertaining suspenseful read that gallops onward page after page and hardly allows those to catch their breath before another action packed scene charges the reader's vivid imagination. Set in 1920 Russia the reader is immediately introduced to the ghosts that haunt our narrator's mind. Returning from the blood soaked fields and passage of battle, all Kolya desires is his family and the comforting sounds of civilian life. Sick from the images and realizations of war he returns only to find his village eerily silent and his home empty. It is only when the bone-chilling night falls that Kolya begins to suspect the silent woods beyond the village may hold more secrets than answers to the mystery of the disappearance of the inhabitants of Belev and that folk tale monsters may be real...In the end, this was an entertaining thriller that mixed atmosphere with action and pulled the tale of Koschei, The Deathless into a mystery that had this reader sneaking away from real life to her kindle at any available opportunity. The dramatic styling of The Child Thief (another novel by Mr. Smith) continues in Red Winter. Whereas the reader was entranced with the grisly collaboration of a kidnapping, the consequences of unleashed paranoia and the tale of Baba Yaga in The Child Thief; Red Winter takes on the realizations and horrors of war, the limits of a father's and husband's love with the tale of Koschei, The Deathless. Set in similar time periods and the snow howls and screams across the pages in both, Red Winter is completely different than The Child Thief. Different in many positive ways but still the disappointing negatives I found with The Child Thief were again found in Red Winter mainly predictability, repetitive actions or thoughts and a lackluster ending. Still I eagerly look forward to sneaking away from real life and joining another journey into the snow encrusted pages with another cleverly blended tale of Eastern Europe and Slavic Folklore from Mr. Smith.*I would like to thank Pegasus publishing and Edelweiss for the opportunity to read and enjoy Red Winter

Everyone loves a villain and practically everyone loves ice cream, so what a perfect combination in this a life revisited through the words of a woman who is dubbed The Ice Cream Queen of America and yet in the early 1980's is a celebrated pariah who is about to face the tabloids, the all too eager accusing public eye and critical fight to salvage her image, career and life. It is open season on Lillian M. Dunkle as the courtroom and papers play out as a bad scandalous episode of "This is Your Life" and her once brilliant empire of cold whipped butterfat, milk substitute and corn syrup seems to melt before eyes, but wait this is not a tragedy oh no Lillian stands with her own crown of dignity and tells the reader her side of events before they pass judgment. So picture it darlings a back and forth tale of struggles, humble tragic beginnings and rise from obscurity with an extreme and unconventional narrator who uses blunt and sometimes crass wicked humor to relate the moments of her life. Who knew ice cream played so much an integral role in America during the 20th century (at least according to our anti-heroine), with sharp wit and candid access the reader is privy to this hard to ignore magnetic being who seems to have more than 36 flavors of personality and stories to tell. So pull out your favorite ice cream out of the freezer, try to ignore the summer heat and enjoy a real treat with The Ice Cream Queen of Orchard Street.In the end, the unaccustomed weather is what drove this reader to sample The Ice Cream Queen of Orchard Street and I am very happy I did, this was a wonderful entertaining treat that helped me ignore the mugginess outside. The integral whipped combination of history and unconventional narrator had me sneaking away to my kindle at any available moment and I finished this title very quickly. Lillian Dunkle was a charismatic personality that reminded me of Sophia Petrillo-Weinstock (played by the beloved late Estelle Getty) with all the spunk and ease of spinning an engrossing story with a pearl of wisdom hidden deep inside. In Lillian's case though more profanity, wicked humor and manipulation is whipped into her story and also combines the drama and negative publicity of: Joan Crawford, Martha Stewart and the extravagance of Zsa Zsa Gabor and Leona Helmsley to create a believable character that dares the reader to judge before her side of events are shared. I loved the history and details of the fanciful field of ice cream, it seemed more of a confessional behind the locked gates of Willy Wonka's factory learning the secrets of the trade and what drives the consumption and desire of the public. And the forgotten theories on the devastating disease Poliomyelitis were fascinating from a medical standpoint and really pulled this reader in further. Not only a funny read there are also pages of sadness and transformation that caused a few tears to fall (especially at the end)- Ms. Gilman's has a talent with description and building a heart-rending scene. Overall, I would recommend this read for those who need a good laugh, the outrageous scenarios are sure to surprise or cause a smile and you may learn something. So enjoy!I would like to thank Grand Central Publishing and NetGalley for the opportunity to read and enjoy The Ice Cream Queen of Orchard Street

Don't judge this book by its cover. Succession may seem a benign rendering of history told by the dual perspectives of Margaret of Anjou and Margaret Beaufort purporting all the surrenders of romance, fettered views of the rise and fall of the Lancaster and York houses concentrating on frivolous trappings and precious else during 15th-century England but Succession by Livi Michael is actually a compelling tableau of history that is sure to excite history enthusiasts or those who appreciate a brilliantly delivered story. Presented in a distinct clever style Succession combines imaginative dialogue, rich description, a touch of lyrical prose and brilliantly depicted historical events to weave a tale chocked full of: premeditated treachery, all consuming greed, loss of innocence, murder most foul and the strong personalities that dominated the sides of the dynastic Wars of the Roses.Whether the curious reader is unfamiliar with the years or events that led to and followed the uneven rise and fall of the houses of Lancaster and York that historians delight in debating to this day, they are sure to be swept into a convincing tale that not only focuses on views of the 15th-century court but also pulls brief narration from the common man and woman. Machinations that consumed minds and corrupted hearts and its further consequences are shared with the reader in a concise fashion that fully captures the monumental events that affected the rich, poor and left a country torn with loyalty to either the red rose (for the house of Lancaster) or the white rose (for the house of York). Characters are divided by their houses (at times even representing both), cast in multifaceted light and dark shadows of personality and alliances and are heralded in chapters with the red or white rose insignia to aid the reader in understanding the character the chapter focuses on. Chapters are also introduced in a scholarly fashion with a selection from a chronicle, register, calendar roll or ballad that then is spun into a tableau of that event for the entertainment of the reader following a central character and continuing the time frame of events cleverly moving the story along without the need to backtrack and explain a journey or lesser battle. Although, Succession could even at times confuse those familiar with the history, events and central figures and even share in excess certain scenes and over dramatize at times- this is still a compelling title that is sure to entertain and encourage further study. If the reader desires more, it is clear Succession explains only part one of the events of the Wars of the Roses and there is still much to be told.

What is it about the story of the Fitzgeralds that draws many of us like moths to a consuming fire? Is it the fascination with the excess and frivolity of the era the golden couple dominated, the fine line of eccentric brilliance and unbalance they both danced or is it just human nature to want to read about tragedy and misfortune of others? With so much material to mold and conjure into a striking portrait of Zelda Fitzgerald and F. Scott Fitzgerald during their rise, ultimate fall from grace and arguable codependent relationship, I'm so sorry to say Z: a novel of Zelda Fitzgerald disappointed this reader.I thought this novel had been waiting long enough on my to-read list and on a whim purchased it, I wish now though I read more reviews or did more research. Ultimately I never lost myself in this story like I hoped. With a broad expanse of topics to cover that made up the years of 1918-1940 I understand that a lot of topics had to be explained and brought into Zelda's narration but for this reader it just became muddled with anachronistic dialogue, terms, and misplaced facts to point of frustrating distraction. Certain topics were also forced into the narration and became irksome to see in continuous pages. In regards to pacing, I found it sadly slow and tedious to the point of almost giving up.In the end, I am so sorry to say I think the central focus and time setting more than the choices of the direction of characterization kept me engaged enough to finish. However what disappointed this reader may fascinate and charm many enough to ignore the negatives. I wish those have a wonderful reading experience but it may help others to learn from my folly and maybe sample this novel, read a couple more reviews before their final decision or perhaps wait to read at your local library.

The Hatmaker's Heart is a lovely read that will take the reader from the millinery shops of New York City to across the pond and back again. Set in the early 1920's the reader will be introduced to the high pressured world of fashion where the final embers of elegance and status of the Edwardian period are competing with the scandalous flamboyant Jazz Age. Where instead of steeped tea being served in halls, gin flows freely into dainty teacups, hemlines move up as fast as the length of current hairstyles and arms and legs swing to the Charleston. 1922 New York City is where the reader is first introduced to Nell Marchwold, who dreams of being a hat designer. But in a cut-throat world that is dominated by connections, margins and a designer's career could be over in a New York minute-what will it take to make it to the top?With historical detail that charms along with a vibrant cast of characters and offers a lively jaunt into the commercial and fashion world of New York City during the early 1920's this novel can quickly capture a reader's full attention and become a pleasant escape from real life. With an easy comparison to Clara and Mr. Tiffany and even a nod to Agnes Grey, The Hatmaker's Heart can also be comfortably taken as a tale of caution, a story questioning what is really important in life. Enough of a cozy quick read to satisfy those looking for a historical or lightly religious themed novel but also with a few surprises for those who desire an interesting twist and mystery with their reading.*I would like to thank FaithWords/Center Street Publishing and NetGalley for the opportunity to read and enjoy The Hatmaker's Heart

It has been said that home is where the heart is, it is also been said that a King's home is his castle. Ms. Valentine has spun these phrases and a lesser known German fairytale into a ducky read featuring New York City during the roaring twenties in all its intoxicating brilliance. The tale opens with a gawker's view of the large group of women who flock to the dance halls and turn all heads when they arrive, the mystery of the dancers continues when they are simply dubbed "princesses". The reader then is gradually introduced to each of these princesses with charmingly titled chapters and a unique combination of storytelling and movement that reflects the popular dances of the time period; the tempo can sweep the reader into a Charleston with the action and drama but then slow to a romantic Waltz with just a few chapters. Although an overall upbeat novel, darker themes are introduced and briefly explored but what would the Jazz Age be without a little scandal?  So hear the music and be sure to keep your dance card open for The Girls at the Kingfisher Club, an imaginative step back into the 1920's for those who love history and a little whimsy.I would like to thank Atria Books and NetGalley for the opportunity to read and enjoy The Girls at the Kingfisher Club

Take it as it is a small collection of some of the strangest tales you will read about the Tower of London, Hampton Court, Banqueting House, Kensington Palace, Kew Palace and a few other locations. In these tales history, modern pop culture references, myth and legend blend into a quick read about the aforementioned locations between 1078 and 2013. In this concise book the reader will encounter amusing tales about: a disappearing bear, bold escapes from the tower, deadly jams and preserves, a misplaced scepter, a wild child, legendary spiders, the embarrassing complications of lady's fashion, and a reattached head for a long overdue commemorative portrait. Of course there is much more to explore and these are indeed some of the strangest tales you will read about London's historic palaces.In the end I just decided to take this small book as it was-a quick and entertaining read. Finishing this read in one sitting I enjoyed the time spent and learned some new tidbits of trivia (and phrases). I was however looking for a more comprehensive read but then again it is nice to let my curious mind to just relax with a light collection of facts. Overall this book is a nice collection of fascinating trivia and opens many new windows of study for the reader, so have a little fun with history with London's Strangest Tales: The Royal Palaces: Extraordinary but True Stories.*I would like to thank NetGalley and Pavilion Books for the opportunity to read and enjoy London's Strangest Tales: The Royal Palaces: Extraordinary but True Stories

The Hurlyburly's Husband is a unique love story that takes the reader on a bizarrely wonderful ride through 17th-century France with a king, a mistress and a cuckold as the main attractions. Dark humor, tragic romance, interesting although vile details (concerning 17th-century hygiene habits and sanitary conditions) and raunchy passages (you may never want to wear a strand of pearls again) create this salacious romp, that the reader is certain to remember days later. The Hurlyburly's Husband is a love story about a cuckold (Louis Henri de Pardaillan de Gondrin, marquis de Montespan), who is humiliated by the King of France (King Louis XIV) when his lewd favor falls on FranÁoise-Ath√©na√Øs, marquise de Montespan and alters the marquis de Montespan's whole perception of France and the monarchy. His undying love and devotion to his wife becomes a central theme as the husband battles for the return of his wife and revenge against King Louis but when the glittering palace of Versailles weaves its wicked charms on Fran√ßoise will she want to return to her simple life? What else can the king possibly do to further ruin the marquis de Montespan's life? The answers and the steps Louis Henri follows in the fervent hope of being reunited with this beloved and show his defiance to his sovereign are sure to shock the curious reader. So if the interested reader has a unique brand of humor, is interested in the crude parts of history that few references will note and enjoys a well crafted story about a bizarre love story- The Hurlyburly's Husband is your next read.*I would like to thank Gallic Books and Edelweiss for the opportunity to read and enjoy The Hurlyburly's Husband

The disappearance of a small child and the traditional structure of upstairs and downstairs collide in this Neo-Gothic tale shrouded in mystery and hidden secrets. Tyringham Park takes the reader into the complicated hive of the fictional ancestral Irish estate of the Blackshaw family where the staff may charm guests with obedience and structure but conceals behind closed doors sinister thoughts, poisonous gossip and dark resentment. Immediately the novel opens with the disappearance of the Park's darling little miss, the confusion that follows leads the reader to be marched from each station introducing them to each member of personnel and their whereabouts at the time of the child's disappearance. The observer soon becomes privy to the complicated relationships of those who share the prominent walls of Tyringham Park, the facade of privilege and status quickly falls and the misery and pettiness is exposed that reveals that something is horribly wrong within this grand house.The mystery continues to deepen and July 1917 soon becomes the 1920's, 1930's and finally the 1940's as the story follows the lives of those left behind to pick up the scattered memories of the lost Blackshaw child and the story travels from Ireland to the Australian outback and back again with swatches of time lapses and flashbacks to the history and origins of certain characters. Tyringham Park confronts many different subjects and depending on the reader may enjoy this twisted dramatic story of what happens behind closed doors of those seen born with silver spoons in their mouths.In the end this reader was somewhat disappointed. I sorely wanted to love this Gothic inspired read but found this novel was a little overly seasoned with predictable and unrealistic drama. Although the novel shined at certain points and I loved the complicated relationships that dominated the characters and the daring venturing into certain taboo topics; there was just something that overall lacked in the delivery of the eras the reader was shown and the presence of foreshadowing revealed numerous major points too early in the novel. Still Tyringham Park provided an interesting experience that I would recommend for those readers who love a historical fiction novel that takes drama to another level and blends mystery and complex relationships with the magnetic aristocratic world of former eras.*I would like to thank Atria Books and NetGalley for the opportunity to read and enjoy Tyringham Park

This imaginative re-stitching of 13th-century historical events uses the fictional confessions of King Edward I's lead court jester and fool to sit the reader in a dark corner of a monastery and listen to a story of the making of a king and tale of a shrewd fool. Through the mists of time Hamo Pauncefoot reveals his involvement in historical events from 1253-1274 to a monk he has hired to document the story of his life. The narration takes on dark eloquent styling and magnificent character representation; characters are magnified by this narration and of course embellished for the sake of the story and the narrator's royal benefactors. If readers are familiar with The Lymond Chronicles by Dorothy Dunnett or Bernard Cornwell's Warlord Chronicles then you may find another antihero in Hamo Pauncefoot. The reader is taken to this fool's humble beginnings and then witnesses Hamo's all consuming obsession of advancement of life and status which he believes can be obtained by providing his distinct set of services to the young prince Edward.Set to the backdrop of England during the mid-13th century the reader is privy to the intimate complicated relationships and manipulations of the court of King Henry III. As the story progresses the locations thunder on from battle fields, to towns, to clandestine rooms of taverns, to the holy crusade and back again with always Hamo Pauncefoot under the table or in a corner collecting vital information for his advances. This narration takes on a delicious dark phrasing that leaves more of a convincing representation of the mid-13th century, characters are painted with flaws and very few are described as faultless. Piety and virtue serve little in this story, greed and lust for power reigns over this storyline.In the end, although a few anachronistic terms in the dialogue briefly pulled this reader from this striking narration and the middle sagged with the different excursions, these can be forgotten with the twists and surprises that leapt from the corners of The Chronicles of Pauncefoot and Longshanks: The Making of a King. The footnotes at the end were a creative touch that leant more validity to the beginning claim that this story is true and recently discovered in 2007; all research and implantation was explained and (to this reader) showed superb attention to detail.  Finally the sometimes awkward formation and execution of showing time and births to the reader were seamless in this narration (a very hard thing to accomplish).  Overall this was gem of a read, an original story that I highly recommend for those readers who enjoy a more realistic view of this time period, those who enjoy reading about the machinations of a mind born into misery and desperation and another game for the control of England. The ending clearly indicates a sequel and this reader eagerly awaits the next installment about this shrewd narrator.* I would like to thank Troubador Publishing Ltd and NetGalley for the opportunity to read and enjoy The Chronicles of Pauncefoot and Longshanks: The Making of a King

Amazon Basics nails it with their updated version of the lightning cable for charging and syncing Apple devices. Great tight connections, nicely soft and flexible, and 100% Apple certified so you don't get those pesky warnings that your cable might not be working. Best of all, this new version of the Amazon Basics brand cable features a nice thin profile connector so it plugs in no matter what protective case you've chosen to use. A great cable at a great price!

What a simple idea! It's exactly what we needed for our bathroom as we have no counter space (just a pedestal sink). The hairdryer was either continuously sitting inside the sink or sitting on the floor. This nifty little invention looks great and gives us a perfect holster for our previously "always in the way" hairdryer. This should be standard issue in all smaller bathrooms. Love it!

Though I normally enjoy Wrangler jeans, these shorts are oddly proportioned, so much so that I couldn't even successfully get them on. The sizing runs way too small (at least a size to size and a half) as compared to similar products by Lee, Old Navy, Gap, and American Eagle. The cut is very tight through the seat and thigh. Though they seem to be quality made, sadly I will not be wearing these. Only for those with a thin physique and not very well developed thigh muscles.

I am admittedly not a huge fan of this new "pacs" packaging that's happening in the detergent aisle, but I must say that these work really well. The pac seems to dissolve better than others I've used, so no weird glop of goo left over after washing stuck to your laundry. Truly free and clear - this stuff has no coloring or detectable fragrance - yet it powers through stains just as well as regular "All", if not better. We've got one memeber of the family that has super sensitive skin and this detergent passed his test. No irritation whatsoever. It's great that something can be so gentle yet so effective. A great product. Highly recommended.

Fresh, clean, and invigorating - this shampoo and conditioner leaves my hair looking great and my scalp invigorated and fresh. Cloudy green in color, this shampoo pours out thick and fresh smelling. Very botanical, light, and pleasant, with a hint of mint. After it's lathered up, the mint really kicks in with a eucalyptus-like tingle on the scalp that gets stronger and stronger the longer you leave it in. It rinses clean, not heavy or oily like after some conditioners, yet still managed to keep my hair looking nice and behaving manageable. One of my favorite Axe products so far. High quality. Behaves like a shampoo three times the price. Highly recommended!

Quite nice and sturdy feeling, heavy, and larger than I anticipated. I installed this above my garage entry door and it's been working like a charm. Very bright without being blinding, this is a great task light to help you see the your keyhole at night, or works well as a security light to scare off unwanted guests around the exterior of your home. I am going to get another one of these to install above our trash cans for added security. Easy to mount, weather proof, and solid build quality. A nice value. (One added word of advice: The sensor does not work through glass. I tried installing this inside my foyer pointing out to the entryway through a pane of glass and the only time it would trigger the light was when movement was detected as a reflection from the inside.)

I purchased this toaster three years ago for our vacation home. It still looks brand new as it has seen very little use. In reality, probably not been used more than 50 cycles in three years. Though the look of the toaster is top-notch and it seems well-built on the outside, the lights have stopped illuminating correctly. Press the bagel button, and though the toaster still toasts the bagel as it should, nothing lights up to let you know it is actally in the bagel toasting mode. Quite annoying for a relatively expensive appliance that has seen very little use.I contacted Breville and they offered to fix it for $59, which is almost half the cost of a new toaster. I'm not at all happy with their customer service or with the longevity of their products. This experience will definitely keep me from purchasing further Breville products as I think they are a company more concerned with outside looks than inside quality and durability and refuse to fully stand behind their products. This is clearly an issue of initial workmanship and a lack of quality control. I am shocked that a company that sells premium priced products won't stand behind their workmanship and quality. Very disappointed.

A nice quality shirt with a cool design, but i find myself not wearing it that often because the graphic is printed crooked and off center. Perhaps you will have better luck with yours, but I was disappointed with the lack of attention paid to actually placing the print correctly on the shirt.

If your dog is a fetcher and not a chewer I highly recommend this toy. However, if your dog likes chewing, this ball will be toast in a matter of minutes. My dachshund loved it, but it seriously lasted about five minutes before being totally destroyed.

What you really want to know is "Are these batteries as good as name brand batteries?" In a word, "Yes!" Amazon does it again with their house brand of batteries that bring great performance, quality, and long-life together with unbeatable value. I don't see myself returning to major name brand batteries any time soon.

As a restaurant professional, I can tell you that when working in the kitchen, a quality knife is your most important tool. It can make all the difference between a daunting task and an easy preparation. This German-made blade performs flawlessly and makes working with meat a delight. Chicken, Pork, Beef... no problem working right up to the bone. Working with fish, where a super sharp ultra flexible knife is key, is an absolute joy.Made of German stainless, weighs just under 4oz, and is delightfully narrow and flexible. This is a high quality blade, well-balanced in the hand, that performs like blades many times its price. Dishwasher safe too. Highly recommended.

I was admittedly skeptical about this countertop ice maker, but after a week of using it, i'm sold! All you do is add water to the internal reservoir, and this little machine gets to work. The first batch of ice was ready in about 10-12 minutes. The ice is a very nice bullet shape and can be set to three different sizes. The internal tray holds the ice for dispensing and quite cleverly, any ice that melts drips right back into the reservoir to be made into ice once again. The machine is ultra quiet, does not put out a lot of heat, and is great as a stand alone ice maker or as a supplemental portable way to make ice. Truly amazing and well worth the price.

Great for use as a mother sauce for any Asian inspired cooking. Flavors of sesame, garlic, soy, and even a bit of hoisin come thru this delightful sauce. Great for sirfry, as a dipping sauce for pot stickers, or mix in to your fried rice or noodle dish for extra added ooomph. Quite strong and very flavorful, so be warned, a little of this stuff goes a long way. All in all a very good, high quality, culinary-grade sauce.

How absolutely fun to have these in the pen cup here at my home in Key West. What fun for our guests to use these great tropical colors for writing postcards to those back at home. The usual great PaperMate quality you expect in fun vivid tropical sunny colors. Crisp lines as always. A winner.

I am always skeptical of these kinds of products. I mean, it promises a lot. Freshen my dogs breath? Really? But yes, I must admit that this product delivers exactly what it promises. Three drops in my dogs bowl daily and within one week his breath was back to sweet puppy breath. Now as a word of warning, if your dogs breath is foul due to poor dental care, this isn't going to do a thing for it. But, if your dog's teeth are clean but breath is stinky, this product is the solution to your problem. Doesn't hve any odor or off-flavor the water. My dog has no idea it's been added to the water dish, and he's got quite the acute sniffer!

An excellent, mild, yet very effective men's face wash for daily use. I have been a regular user of Clearasil's Daily Face Wash, but this new wash from Cetaphil might just make me switch. It leaves the skin feeling very clean, and totally oil-free without harsh astringents or burning alcohol. My only complaint would be that the consistency of this product is a bit like runny hair gel and totally clear, so I feel like I might be using more than is needed in the shower as it is hard to tell how much is in your hand. I'm getting used to the fact it doesn't lather too, but lather or not, it works very well at clearing the skin. Smells great too. I'll be buying more for sure.

Great fitting,long for my 6'6" frame, lightweight, moisture wicking fabric shorts. Great for lounging, sleeping, and all sorts of other activities. Unusual color is like a bright mint creme. Love these shorts!

Finally, a lemon extract that actually tastes like lemon rind and not like floor cleaner. I used this to great success in my lemon pound cake recipe, both in the batter and the lemon icing. It tasted as close to real lemon rind as you could possibly expect out of a bottle. Excellent product with top notch ingredients and great baking performance. Perfect.

A very good "mother" or base sauce for a variety of asian inspired cooking. Stands up pretty well as a stand-alone Szechwan sauce for stir-frys or you can add your own touches to this sauce to add more of the flavors you desire. I find that the addition of fresh garlic or ginger makes this sauce really snap. Great in dishes where onions are generously used. It has a nice peppery spice to it, and a very well-balanced Szechwan flavor profile.  I've also tried heating this up and adding it to admittedly mediocre carry-out Chinese food for added spice with great success. Highly recommended.

My love for all things "Gorilla" tape continues. Wide shipping tape so you truly only need one strip, and talk about sticky strength! One strip of Gorilla shipping tape seals your shipping box without the need for any additional tape nor worry about it coming undone during shipping. There is seriously no need for any other shipping tape than this one. Perfection.

This cable works great and is an identical replacement for the cable that comes with the Astro A40 headset.Amazon seems to be the least expensive place to get it, if you have free shipping with Prime.It is way, way overpriced  everywhere and goes bad fairly quickly. They seem to only last about a year, but if you use the A40 headset, you need it. As far as I know there is not an off brand replacement for it.

I was having a problem with my wireless mics cutting out and having a generally weak signal. I was about ready to purchase an entirely new set of mics, but decided to try a new power supply. I'm happy to say that it fixed the problem. Apparently the old one was putting out funky voltages. Considering the price of Shure equipment, this power supply is a great deal!

Simply the best controller for a windows PC. Not many people know this, but it it the ONLY controller officially supported by steam at this moment. I know there are less expensive alternatives, but just choose this one. I have tried many and wish I had just gotten this one to start out with.It feels and functions exactly like an Xbox 360 controller. it feels and plays good.,

Of all the sardines on the market right now, these are my favorite. Tiny, nice looking fish packed with lots of flavor. The cracked pepper flavor is great, not spicy in a "hot" way at all.The tails of the fish are leathery like jerky. I just break them off.
There is not much to say other than it works. If this is the capacitor you need and you cannot find it locally, Amazon can get it to you in a reasonable amount of time.

It is a Lego  base. What more to say? You need one if you are going to make something big.They are expensive for what they are, but Amazon has them for a good price. My local toy store has them for almost twice as much.

I install these in the classrooms of a private school. They last about a year (depending on the grade) before the gears wear out. For the price they are a good deal. I have tried $50 pencil sharpeners that do not last much longer.The all metal construction is nice. It is easy to mount and sharpens pencils very well.

If you compare this mouse to a $100 mouse, then you will be disappointed. But, compare it against any other $20 mouse and it is head and shoulders better than anything out there.I purchased the wired version and am thoroughly impressed. The cord is braided fabric, not rubber, making it very flexible. The buttons are crisp and responsive. The mouse itself fits my hand very comfortably. It has a nice weight. A couple ounces more would be better, but like I said before, for less than $20 it is great. The scroll wheel is smooth and clicks into place. It is very precise at pointing. I can select individual pixels with ease.My only complaint is that it is loud. You get a very noticeable click when you use it.

I wanted a decent gaming keyboard and was prepared to spend $100 or more for one. After reading the reviews I took a chance on this one.I'm glad I did.This keyboard is smooth, responsive, and quiet. I really do not care about the lighting affects, but my kids love them! It comes with eight blank keys and a tool to replace them with. I did not care for these blank keys (they allowed too much light through for me), and ended up just re-installing the originals.The lights can be turned down to barely a glow, or up quite high. It is easy to change between the different colors.

Despite what the product description and picture says, Raisin Brand is not included. My shipment included:6 Apple Jacks6 Fruit Loops8 Frosted Flakes4 Corn Pops3 Mini Wheats3 Rice KrispiesThis made me so happy! I think Raisin Brand tastes like a fart. However, if you like Raisin Brand, you may be disappointed.

I needed a cheap scanner to test out Library software for the school that I work for. I got this one thinking that I would only use it a few times, and then buy a better one when we implement our new library system.I think I'm going to stick with this one. It works great, reading every bar-code, even old, beat up ones.It worked right away in Windows 8.1. No drivers to load.The USB cord is about 6 feet long. it is very light and makes a nice loud beep when it scans.The user manual is not great. It is basically just a book of bar-codes. You scan the bar-codes to change the settings on the scanner.  However, the description on each setting change is cryptic at best. It is easy to scan the wrong setting and then not be able to figure out ow to change it back.All in all, this is a great scanner. Especially if you just want basic functions,

This is a cute set. My daughter was very excited to get it. She never plays with it. She tried and tried, but it is "kinda crappy". Her words.It is almost unusable as a play-doh toy. The problem is with the Mrs. Pots. You are supposed to fill her up with play-doh and "pour" the play-doh into Chip by pressing down on her lid. The problem begins with the fact that her spout holds more play-doh than her body. So, you have to push down her lid, fill up the spout, add more play-doh, and push the lid down again before anything comes out.The amount of playdoh that does come out of the spout is small. Smaller than a marble.Also, the lid is hard to push down, taking both hands for me. My 4 year old has to use all her might.The left over play-doh in the spout is ridiculously hard to get out. If you forget to clean it and the play-doh dries you are sunk. It's not coming out.Chip does nothing. It is just a cup. You can put play-doh in it, but the cavity is so small the play-doh gets stuck and has to be scraped out.It comes with a play mat. Pure garbage. It lasted one play time. The play-doh sticks to it. try to peel the play-doh off and the mat rips.The little plate is tiny and useless as a play-doh toy. It adds nothing to the experience.The only thing we liked about this set was the nice shade of pink and yellow play-doh tubs. The tubs were tiny, but the colors were nice.Oh, and the knife. We love the knife. It is our favorite knife.If this set was marketed as simply a "Mrs. Pots and Chip figurine set" it would be cool. It is almost as if the play-doh part was an after thought. Like someone said "How can I sell these figurines better? I know! Add play-doh!"

Oh my! These are yummy! Very good little sardines.Unfortunately, they are unhealthy compared to other sardines. 567 calories per can 51g of fat. More calories and almost twice the fat of a McDonalds Quarter Pounder with cheese. I eat sardines as much for their health benefits as their taste. You can find much healthier sardines that taste just as good.If you just want a tasty treat and don't care about health benefits, then go for these!

I use this to clean my copper pots and pans. It is basically magic in a tub. When you rub it on the copper instantly becomes shiny. Very little effort is involved.I polish my pots every third use. Longer than that and it takes some scrubbing to get off all the tarnish spots.

This is a quality hub with on big flaw.It takes a lot of force to plug in my USB devices. Almost to the point that I am afraid that I am going to break the USB jack. On the plus side, they are not going to fall out!Other than that, it works flawlessly.

I use this to keep all of my old video game consoles hooked to my LCDTV. It works flawlessly.The cables are a little cramped in the back, but not impossible to plug in. The switch buttons have a nice, healthy click to them when pushed. I do not notice any video quality reduction.

This bulb does work and is a drop in replacement for many Epson projectors. I'm not sure what this bulbs wattage it is, but it is not nearly as bright as the 4000 lumen bulb that came with the projector.

Once it is properly connected, this coin mech works great and is very inexpensive. I installed it on my MAME arcade cabinet.Unfortunately, the documentation on how to get it to work is almost non-existent. I ended up having to add a relay and figure out what wires went where using a multimeter.It needs a 12v power source to work. It will only accept one type of coin at a time. you can set it to accept just about any type of coin or token out there. The coin selector is very easy to set up.

This is an awesome tool for de-soldering the occasional thing. After putting a few hours of use into it, the suction began to drop and the tip began to warp.Cleaning it is tough and time consuming. If it is not clean it will not work and can make a mess.Sometimes the recoil of the suction piston would cause the tip to bounce onto the circuit board I was working on, damaging a trace.For occasional use it is great! If you need to de-solder often, spend the money for a vacuum de-soldering station. That is what I did.

I got these for the office. The fire marshal in my city said they violated fire code. He also said they violated code for residential buildings and could void our fire insurance. Check your local codes.They work great and are an awesome idea......if they are safe.
This does not fit model 2. End of story. It is smaller and has a different pinout.  Amazon needs to update this description.

This is the same O-ring for Sloan valves everyone sells. The only difference is that most of the time they are sold in packs of 12 or 24 for about .75 an O-ring. This comes in a package of ONE! over $11 for one O-ring.The only reason to buy it from Amazon is if you need it tomorrow. Thier shipping speed is awesome.

This book would have been a good introduction to geocaching if several of the ideas presented were not so glaringly bad. It is against geocaching rules to bury caches in the ground. However, this book recommends doing this several times.  It also has some bad ideas like putting up fake "no hunting" signs with caches hid behind them, or disguising your cache as litter. This could get you in trouble and gives geocaching a bad name.If you read this book, be sure to read the official rules and ethics of the game. Also, be sure to check your local laws on geocaching.

I give my daughters glow sticks at bed time as rewards for doing extra chores or on special days. They get them about once a week. So, Ive gone through  hundreds.These kind of stink.They glow bright for about an hour, then dim noticeably. Other brands will glow all night and into the next day. Not these. They are totally dead by morning.My girls don't care. They are bright until they fall asleep, so they are not all bad.One was broken open and leaked over the rest when they arrived. It was a mess.I will be buying another brand next time.

This bed arrived today. It took me an easy 2 hours to assemble. I used a cordless drill to speed up the process. It was very, very simple to assemble. Probably the easiest piece of furniture i have ever assembled. You will need at least a philips screw driver, but a cordless drill made it effortless. The directions were clear.There was no damage do to shipping. The finish to the bed is very pleasing. It is 100% real wood. No fiber board or plywood.The box is long and heavy, as should be expected. I carried it by myself, but it is really a two person job.It is very sturdy. It should last for years and years of use. Like all wood furniture, I'm sure if it is abused it will break.The ladder is a little slick due to the beds nice finnish.I will be adding some gripping tape to it.I could not be more pleased. A similar bed in a furniture store would cost twice as much.

This lure is well made and is a good price.I have not caught fish with it in any of the southern Virginia lakes I fish. No one I know has caught a single fish with an umbrella rig around here. In fact, the consensus is that it scares them away.This would be a great lure if it works in your lake. Just be aware that this technique is not effective everywhere.

I've tried half a dozen stylus' and this one is my favorite. Its tip has lasted a year and is still very accurate.I did make one modification. I opened the top and added lead pellets to make it weigh more. This helps a lot, especially with handwriting.

A year ago our commercial refrigerator died. Instead of spending $5000+ to replace it, I used this to convert an unused commercial freezer into a refrigerator. After a year it is still working perfectly, while maintaining a steady temperature.You could not ask for an easier install. This thing is awesome!

My wife got this for her iPad. It looked nice at first, but after a year has begun to wear and looks ratty.It provides protection from scratches, but that is it. It does not add any noticeable protection from drops or other impacts.Installation  is easy if you are careful.

This is a good flashlight to send to bed with kids. I like that there is a little screw that keeps them from removing the battery. Although, this is very annoying when the battery needs to be changed.The battery life is not super long. I expected longer life from an LED flashlight.It puts out enough light for them to see that there are no monsters in the room, but not so much as to wake up their sibling.

After finishing the cliffhanger ending of Pushed, the first in the series, I couldn't wait to get my hands on this book.  You need to read Pushed before starting this one. Believe me, it's going to be worth it. This is one series you do not want to miss.I found myself quickly caught up in the story again by the end of the first chapter. My emotions were all over the place.  My heart was breaking for Leila.  I hated Brody. Jaxon is just my hero.In my opinion he was way more deserving of Leila's love than Brody.  That is, until he started doing some pretty hurtful things. I really had trouble with Brody's actions at the end of Pushed. He has a lot to make up for.I can't wait to read more in Torn, the third in the series. I will be reading it as soon as I can get my hands on it.

Holy crap! That's what I actually said out loud more than once while reading this book. I don't know any other way to describe the intense emotions that I was feeling just from reading this story.  There were so many unexpected twists and turns (and a couple expected ones) that I just couldn't put it down. I got so caught up in the story that time seemed to stop. I read it all in one sitting and never even left the recliner.My heart just broke for both the characters. You could sense their attraction, but both were denying it for different reasons. They both had things from their pasts that they needed to deal with in order to give themselves fully to the other.There are so many things I want to tell you about this book, but I want you to experience it as I did, going in with nothing but high expectations. Besides, there is no way I can do this book justice with just a few words in a review.I highly recommend this book to anyone who loves a great romance story. I look forward to reading more from this talented author.

This is one of the amazing books you can read in one sitting. For all the longer it was, it packed one heck of a story. I was easily able to connect to the characters, Blake and Lara. Their connection was undeniable, but Lara needed a little push to be willing to give her heart away.It was fun to see what Blake was willing to do to get Lara's attention. Rigging the company's Secret Santa was just the beginning of it. Once he had her name, he needed to get her a gift. He had to get to know her a little more to know the perfect gift that would wow her and make her see him in a different light.I just wanted Lara to allow someone in so she could heal and enjoy life again. She is still suffering from the loss of her fiance. Even though so much time has passed, she still feels committed to him. It's hard to put her feelings aside and move on. Blake needs to be a patient and caring man to understand just how hard this is for her.I would highly recommend this holiday book for anyone no matter what the season. It's just a perfect read.

I don't believe I have read any of Ad Ellis's book. I was drawn to this one because it is M/M, a genre that usually interests me. After finishing this book, I have to say, this will not be the last book I read by this author. I just have such a warm fuzzy feeling from these characters. Everyone is just so supportive of each other, you could just feel their love.In my mind, I divide this book into 2 parts. The first part of the story really focuses on Sawyer coming out to his family. It really focuses on Sawyer making the decision to tell all his family, who are really close, and him dealing with the aftermath. Not everyone was accepting, things were said, feelings were hurt. But in the end, family prevailed. It's just how I would imagine someone in my family coming out. Some would be accepting right away, other's would need some convincing. It wasn't easy, but being accepted for who you are is worth it.The second part of the book was more about Sawyer and Luke's relationship. The connection between the two was immediate. Their emotional journey wasn't an easy one. Luke had to deal with his issues from his past. Sawyer was such a patient man, seeming to know exactly what to do to get Luke to find himself.Even if you don't read M/M books, I would encourage you to read this one, especially if you have enjoyed others by this author.

This was one quick read and I loved every minute of it. Knowing it was short, I planned to read it in one sitting and was able to do it with no problem. I was left with the feeling of wanting to know more, much more. I know it was designed as a novella, but the characters drew me in and I really wanted more.This book deals with the days they are stuck together in a cabin during a snow storm, nothing more. But during that time, things really change between them. Sparks fly and a relationship starts.Being too short would be my only complaint, but I knew that going in. I was surprised by how curious I am about what happens with Sierra and Bentley after this trip. That tells me the characters are pretty well developed, showing me the talent of the author. I look forward to reading more by Madison Collins.

The Gray-Haired Knitting Group is at it again. They just can't let a mystery pass them by. Nor can they pass up the chance to meddle in someone's love life.Poor Dee is their focus in this story. She has no clue what she is in for when she comes back to live with her grandmother after leaving her abusive husband.  She puts up one heck of a fight, but in the end she realizes that there is no stopping this group of grannies. Their natural nosey-ness comes in handy again when they try to figure out who killed Dee's husband, working against the detective in charge who is dead set on Dee's guilt. Their antics kept me laughing out loud while the little hints we get about Brock's murder kept my interest enough to put off doing everything else for the day.I loved Tommy. We were introduced to him in the last book, Jack Gets His Man, as the guy the Granny Group tried to fix up with Jack even though he wasn't gay. As much as he didn't want them meddling, he fell for Dee and was willing to be patient until she was ready. To me, his patience showed me the type of man he is, wonderful.This is the second book in the series that I have read. It could be read as a stand alone, but the dynamics of all the characters would be better understood if you read the others first. This is a fun read that I would recommend to anyone.

The synopsis doesn't do this story justice. There is so much more to this story than a woman who isn't looking for a man in her life or a man who thinks he's found the woman he's destined to be with forever. Their emotions run deep, but it was slow getting there. Ellie has been through a traumatic  event and needs time to heal. Jax is there for her every step of the way. I loved reading about their story and watching their relationship grow.I only had one issue with this book. It says that it is stand alone, but when I started it, I was REALLY lost. I felt that there was so much I was missing, but since it was the first in the Him series, I assumed it would be discussed throughout the book, so I kept reading. After getting about 25% through it, I finally went to double check my information. One of the other reviews stated that this book picks up right where Until July ends. After a little more digging, there are many characters from other books that make appearances in this book. I realize that it is a spin off, but if it is to be a stand alone, I needed more information about the characters and how they met.  If you have read Until July, you shouldn't have this issue at all.Even thought the first part threw me off, I kept reading and truly loved their story.  I've enjoyed it enough to start reading some of the the other books that I missed. I have read some of Aurora Rose Reynolds's books but missed Until November and Until July. I have added them to my TBR list and moved them to the top. I can't wait to read more about the characters that I have be introduced to in this book.

There isn't a word out there to describe this book, but addicting comes close. Once I started it, I had a tough time putting it down. Even after 3 days and having read another book, I still catch myself visualizing parts of the story. To me, that's what made it so fantastic. I felt like I was there, experiencing their relationship.There were times that Leila's reactions seemed a little immature. Women that run instead of dealing with the situation can be annoying to me. It wasn't enough to make me stop reading though.I was so caught up in their relationship I didn't see the ending coming. This ended with me wanting to throw my kindle across the room. Brody really disappointed me. After what he did, I'm not sure there is anything he can do to get into my good graces again. Leila deserves better than him. It's going to take one heck of an explanation to make me like him again.I am torn as to whether or not I want to read the next in the series. In my head, I have an idea of how I want Leila and Brody's story to end. I'm not sure I'll be happy if the author's ending doesn't match mine. I'm 'torn' as I am sure Leila will be.

This is one of those books that I hate to love so much. I didn't expect it to be such a psychological story.It's not often that I hate one of the main characters (I think the last one was Gone Girl) but I REALLY didn't like Paxton. He was just to arrogant and controlling for me to think that he deserved any devotion from Gabby or his girls. He really just gave me a creepy vibe. Throughout the story, he seemed to change some, some people could have actually liked him for a while. But I didn't buy it for a minute. I was just waiting for him to become an ass again.Gabby seemed like to much of a pushover to put up with Paxton all those years. I wanted her to grow a pair and stand up to him. Or at least take the kids and leave him while he was at work. I actually celebrated for her when she finally broke his rules when her sister appeared.There were so many twists and turns in this book I had to keep reading. As frustrated as I was with the characters, I couldn't stop reading.  Then there was the ending...... GRRR! It's been a while since I found a book with a cliffhanger ending that made me want to through my kindle like this one did. I'll be getting my hands on the next one as soon as I can.

The opening of this book will suck you in immediately. It's not very often that I have tears in my eyes in the first couple of chapters. It takes some wonderful writing to get me that emotionally vested in the characters to draw that kind of emotion from me. My heart just broke for Jeremy.Watching Jeremy struggle with moving on from the death of his husband was difficult. I couldn't imagine being in his position. When he meets Kai, though, the attraction is immediate. I love seeing two people who are destined to be together find strength in each other to overcome their own emotional hurdles.This book is a part of a series. I have not read the first book yet, (but I plan to) and didn't feel like I was missing any of Kai and Jeremy's story. Jace and Carey, the focus of the first book, do make an appearance when they get married in this book. I could also easily figure out who will probably be the focus of the next book because he played an important part in Kai's life.This book is written in third person POV which usually makes it more difficult for me to connect with the characters. However, after that opening, it was hard not to be connected to Jeremy and Kai was just perfect.

I make no secret that I am a huge fan of Jenna Galicki. I have loved this entire series, but I think this is my second favorite in the series (it would be impossible to be better than The Prince of Punk Rock). Jimmy has been the wild card in the band all along. I have been waiting for someone to tame his wild ways, someone he felt was worth respecting himself for.I was a little more than surprised to find out that Audra was that woman. Audra and her sister Kira have been involved as fans from the first book. Being the boss's daughter and the band's tour manager, she should be off limits to any of the band members. Of course, she has to be the one Jimmy is attracted to. I loved seeing how Jimmy proves himself worthy of her. He made a lot of life changes in a very short amount of time. I kept waiting for him to screw up, fall back to his old ways. Then that bi**h shows up and I thought it was all over. Just waiting for it all to fall apart kept me from putting this book down. I tried to go to sleep before finishing it, but it wasn't happening. I needd to know what happened.One thing I truly enjoyed about this book is that, although the book focuses on Jimmy and Audra, we still get a lot of all the characters I have come to love. We get to follow the band when they are not on tour, seeing their creative process at work. It made me realize just how close they are, like their own family. I can't wait to see what they are up to next.This book is written in third person POV but is almost felt like alternating first person because Jenna switches focus and writes so well you think you are there. It is part of a series, but could probably be read as a stand alone, but I would recommend reading the others first, after all, their all amazing.

This book caught me a little off guard. I was expecting a book that focused on the M/M romance with a little mystery thrown in. But it ended up being a light-hearted mystery with a little matchmaking thrown in.I just had to love the ladies in  the Knitting Crew. I could just picture a group of little old ladies who are sticking their nose in people's business with the best of intentions. Their antics made the story so fun to read it was hard to put down.And what's a bunch of old ladies without a little meddling into someone's love life. Jack is the victim in this story. I just had to laugh. Just the idea of a crew of little old ladies being so accepting of his sexuality that they would try to set him up was comical. It was nice to see so many people be so accepting of everyone. Jack's personality really showed in the book. I could hear the sarcasm in his voice so many times.This book is a part of the series, but according to the synopsis, it can be read as a stand alone. I have not read the first book, Murder, Mystery, and Dating Mayhem. There were several times while reading that I wish I had read the first. The antics of the Knitting Crew from that book were referenced a couple times and Izzy and Noel play key parts in this one. I think I will be reading it before I read the third book, Love in the Time of Murder, due out in October 2015.This book is written in third person POV, focusing on Jack's thoughts and actions. It is a stand alone with no violence.

I was supposed to write this review for the release day, which was 2 days ago. I just couldn't do it. I needed time to process this amazing series. I tried to write my review, I really did, but I just couldn't put sentences together. I'm still not sure I can do the book justice, but I'm going to try. Griff is one character that has puzzled me from the beginning of the series. I just wasn't sure what was going on with him. I learned quite a bit about Griff, all of which helped me understand him better. His book has made him one of my favorite Storm MC members.I loved Griff's Aunt Josie. She is such a little pistol. I could see her being anyone's grandmother. You could really feel her good intentions. Her meddling brought a smile to my face, and the fact that she thought Griff wouldn't figure it out... priceless.Of course, getting Griff to finally get past his issues and give Sophie a chance wasn't easy. However, I loved that once that happened, there wasn't any relationship drama.But the tension getting there was almost too hot to handle, but I loved every minute. Sometimes it's nice to read about a couple who are just happy to be together, like they are meant to be.There may not have been relationship drama, but there was a lot of drama with Storm, a lot of it involving Griff.  I've grown attached to all the members of the club and am waiting with baited breath to see how all their issues play out.This book is written in dual POV. It is part of a series and you should read the series in order, Sophia and Griff's relationship would be OK as a stand alone, but the Storm parts of the book needs a lot of background you only get from reading the rest of the series. There is some violence, but not anything more than I would expect from an MC book.  This is one series you do not want to meet. I can't wait to read more and find out more about what's going on with Scott and Harlow.

This book blew me away. I loved the interactions between Carter and Julia. They just had a fun way to communicate. Their light-heartedness really balanced out the more series parts of their lives. I just felt like I was a part of their lives. They could easily be a couple I would love to be friends with.I will admit that the very beginning threw me off. I felt like I walked into the middle of the story, which in a way I did. Carter found out some life altering news right off the bat. Since I didn't know the characters yet, it was hard to understand what part that played in the story. However, it really caught my attention and I needed to see where it was going. After reading it all, I wouldn't change a single word of it.At the end, I found myself putting my hand over my heart and just sighing with contentment. Their story was absolutely perfect. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a great love story.This book is written in dual POV. It is a stand alone. It wasn't until I read some of the other reviews that the thought that it could be part of a series even crossed my mind. I didn't put the characters together at all.

This suspenseful book had me on edge many times. I had trouble putting it down once I got started. I got to know a little about Kate in Self-Destruct (the first in the series) but I really got to know her in this book.Kate is hiding something that only her twin, Cameron, understands.  Even though Kate is an amazingly strong character, she feels she can't fight her past and wants to run away from it to keep everyone safe. Eventually the secrets were revealed and Reed and Kate's other's friends are there to support and save her.Reed was absolutely perfect. He is patient when he needs to be and pushes just enough when he has to. There were so many times he showed just how amazing he is.Everything about this story was just wonderful. I loved watching Kate finally allow Reed in and allow their relationship to grow and develop. The suspense keep me on the edge of my seat with a tight grip on my Kindle many times. I enjoyed this book a little more than Self-Destruct because I was more caught up in the storyline.This book is written in dual POV. It can be read as a stand alone, but I highly recommend read Self-Destruct first, mainly because it is an equally good book and it's always best to read books with common characters in order. With each book, the characters become more developed. After reading this one, I am really looking forward to reading the next book in the series.

This book was a little harder to read. Mainly because both characters come with so much baggage that I focused more on figuring them out than I did their growing relationship. I love reading books about broken people so this book really held my attention but I didn't feel their connection until further along in the book although they felt it from the beginning. Given their pasts, there has to be issues in their relationship that they have to overcome.I really felt bad for Becca. Given her reaction to men, you could tell something traumatic happened to her and that she hasn't recovered yet. As the story went on, my heart just broke for her. Those that were supposed to support her didn't. As a result, she didn't handle things well. The more I learned about what happened, the angrier I got with her family. But then my attitude changed when Becca finally addressed the issue with her parents. I can't imagine being in either of their shoes, either being the victim or being the parent knowing you couldn't protect your child. It was just heart-breaking.This book is written in alternating POV. It can be read as a stand alone but I want to read more about them and the other secondary characters in the book. This book does address sexual abuse of a child and may be a trigger for some readers.

What and amazing read. I devoured this book in no time at all. I just couldn't put it down. I couldn't wait to see what would come out of Chance's mouth next. He perfected sexual innuendo comments.  He was absolutely perfect, the title of the book fit him perfectly. He was so cocky, but he was so sweet too. His personality was just a perfect mix.The best part of Chance was that he knew how to push Aubrey's buttons and really enjoyed doing it. I loved seeing her all riled up. She must have enjoyed it though, because she put up with him for their entire trip.I loved this book from beginning to end. There were so many different twists and turns that I didn't expect that I was captivated the entire time. There were so many times I was laughing out loud or just covering my mouth in shock at the turn of events. I just can't describe how perfect this book was. It's one I will enjoy re-reading soon, something I haven't done in a long time. I just haven't found a book worthy of re-reading for a while.This stand alone is written in dual POV.

This is one of those books where you'll want to clear your schedule to read it because once you get started you will not want to put it down. I got so sucked into the story that I read it in one sitting.Alex was such an arrogant jerk in the beginning. I wanted to smack him a couple times. I really wanted to see him put in his place or at least make him realize what a jerk he was being and take the time to make it right. As I got to know him more, it was hard not to like him, even if he did act like a spoiled brat sometimes. He's at a crossroads in his life and is feeling a little lost.Oh to be Natasha. She's had a crush on Alex, as lead singer of Steel Roses, since she was a teen. Now, she has the opportunity to work up close and personal with him. Who wouldn't want to be in her shoes?  At least she didn't get all starry eyed and allow him to walk all over her. No, she hid her crush was strong enough to be able to put him in his place when needed.I don't feel like their story is over. There are still some things about Alex and Steel Roses we don't know yet. I can't wait to get my hands on the next book to see if we find out more.This book is written in Natalie's POV. There is no violence. Although there is no cliffhanger ending, however, the story isn't over. It ends by saying "...how bad could it really be? I'd have to wait and see, I guess."

This book had me from the very beginning. I was drawn to it because Claire is a teacher and I love reading books involving teachers (personal connection). Add to that, a sexy actor and I'm all in.I loved the interaction between Claire and Daniel, they were so fun together. Their witty banter had me laughing out loud many times.  Everything about their story was so realistic. I felt like it could happen to anyone. They didn't jump into bed immediately... Claire's parents weren't the support parents everyone hopes for...Claire makes some choices that have devastating consequences for her career,Of course, their relationship can't be all fun and roses. Claire runs into some trouble and needs to find herself. Seeing her get the strength to trust herself and follow her dreams was worth waiting for.After reading this, I want more Claire and Daniel. I just felt so connected to these two that I want to see more of their HEA. I'm sure their careers can lead to enough issues for another book about them (Hint Hint!).This book is written from Claire's POV. It is a stand alone. There is no violence, abuse, or drug/alcohol abuse.

I absolutely loved this book. I have not read any of the others in the series, didn't even realize it was a part of a series until I came to write this review and read the blurb.Being famous can have its perks, but it also has a lot of downfalls. Gavin made me realize that being famous isn't all that it is cracked up to be. Not only does he have a stalker, but someone is always telling him what to do. There was always some expectation for him to live up to, he couldn't be himself in public. Even growing up, he had to hide his sexuality from his abusive father. Watching him and Mitch overcome so many adversities to finally be a couple was amazingly hot. Their interactions were so funny at times I just had to shake my head. At the beginning they were the perfect example of "there's a fine line between love and hate".Throughout the entire thing, it was the suspense that was killing me. I wanted to find out who was Gavin's stalker. I knew it was going to be a whopper, and let me tell you, it was. I was not expecting that plot twist. I enjoyed this book so much I will be reading the first two in the series and can't wait to get my hands on the next book.This book in written in alternation POV. It is book 3 in a series of 4, however it can be read as a standalone without any issues. There is some mild violence, but it isn't described in graphic detail.

This was a great book that I just couldn't put down. The author has such a way with words, she has you feeling the anxiety and stress of the characters as they follow another investigation while finding the Happily Ever After they deserve.Maryann has combined the characters and event from her Love's Series into her Alvarez Security series. I highly recommend reading those books first.  Tony and Sherrie's story started in previous books, you won't feel the connection between them if you don't read about how they met. They get together pretty quickly in the beginning of the book. Not saying their relationship started easily, it didn't. Tony has a heart-breaking past he has to deal with before he can move on.Characters from the other books which I have come to love also make appearances. Together, they make one very happy family. They were there to support Tony during the worst days of his life, and they continue to support him now.I look forward to reading the next in the series... there's still a couple single Alvarez Security team members available.There is some violence in this story, but lots of action and suspense. It is told in third person POV.

I was totally blown away by this book. It was exactly the type of story I expected from Melissa Collins. I have read every book she has written, all of which are 5+ star reviews to me.The thing that drew to me was how she writes emotion. You can feel the love between Liam and Parker. It's easy to get caught up in their emotions and forget that this is a M/M love story. I got so engrossed in their connection, two people who need each other to breathe. That's a connection you don't see often, but when you do, it's beautiful.The turning point of the story, when we find out what Liam is running from, was so heart-breaking. He was so lucky he found Paulie who gave him a job and treated him like a son. His life could have been so different if he hadn't.Parker comes off as an arrogant jerk right from the very beginning, putting Liam off right away. I was so relieved that Liam was able to see the man underneath the lawyer.This book is a stand alone. It is told in alternating POV. There is minimal violence described as part of sexual abuse of a child.

What an emotional read! Jett and Presley's relationship is one heck of a ride. Things are not easy for them, throughout the entire book I questioned whether or not they would get their HEA. There were so many things they had to deal with I wasn't sure they would survive. Then there was the BIG event. I thought for sure Presley would move on.This is one of  those books you'll need to have tissues nearby. Not only because of relationship difficulties, but because of events of a secondary character's life. You know it's well written when you are crying like a baby for a secondary character.I was also drawn to Van, another band member. He's a moody SOB, but there are glimpses of a wonderful softie under it all. Something was up with him and I'm dying to know what. I hope to see more of him...and West... and...This is another one of those books that once I started, I couldn't put it down. I finished it in just one day.This book is a part of a series and you should read, "All Your Reasons", before starting this one. It is told in alternating POV. There is no cliffhanger ending, but want more in this series.

This is the first book by Rie Warren, but it won't be my last. Kinkaid's life is complicated enough. He's a stripper and he's trying to keep it hidden from everyone, including the MC club he's trying to join all while trying to take care of his grandfather. The last thing he needed was being caught at work by his best friend, Sadie.The story really focuses on Kaid's personal life and his stripping life. There isn't much of his MC life explored. Since this is part of an MC series, I was really expecting more of a focus on the MC part. I think that lead to this book being more of a fun read. I found myself smiling at the ball-busting all the guys at the strip club did. The book wasn't all fun and games though,  there was a part where I had tears rolling down my face. My heart just broke for Kaid.I really enjoyed hearing Kaid's side of things. That moment when he realized he that Sadie can be more than a best friend, that there was an attraction there all of a sudden. Crossing that line between friends and lovers isn't an easy one, you put your friendship on the line. It wasn't a decision Kaid made easily.I really enjoyed the story and look forward to more from this author. Although this is a part of a series, it can be read as a stand alone. It is told from Kinkaid's POV. There is no cliffhanger ending.

This book sucked me in from the beginning. I had trouble putting it down for long. I highly recommend that you one-click this book today.I will admit to having an issue with the cheating. Lucky for me, the author didn't describe how hurt Flynn was every time Lucky went back to her boyfriend. That would have shattered me. Flynn was the character I connected with the most. You could feel how much he loved Lucky. My heart just went out to him. He has a heart of gold that shines through in so many ways. I just wanted him to find his happiness.I also helped that I didn't like Dylan in this book. He just seemed like an egotistical jerk. Lucky was better off without him. She had a crush on him as a teen, but he's not the man that was on the poster on her walls.  My guess is that they only lasted a year because he was on tour for most of that time.This book part of a series, but it can easily be read as a stand alone. There is no cliffhanger ending. There is cheating/love triange, but no violence. It is told in alternating POV.

I knew someone was going to be shattered in this book, but I didn't expect it to be me. Haven is trying to deal with a past no one should have ever experienced. Unfortunately her way to deal with it is to try to ignore it. Luckily she has so many people that love and support her, even if they don't know her entire story.In past books in the series, we have been given a glimpse of horrific things that Haven has been through. Throughout the story, we learn more of the events of her past. That's what shattered me. She has been through so much, all of which helped her to become the strong woman she is today. She's determined to not allow her past to determine her future.Lucky for her, she has Crisis, a member of her brother's band, to help her when her past rears it's ugle head. In this story, we get to see more of Crisis's protective side. I just loved him more and more with each page turn. He is perfect.This book is a part of a series that you need to read before starting this one. It is written in alternating POV. There is no cliffhanger ending. Drug use, rape and other triggers are described.

I have to admit that I was not looking forward to this book. I just wasn't ready for Bea and Hawke's story to be over. I'm not ready to let go of the characters that I have come to love. Even after reading this final book, I'm not ready to let them go, which is why I plan on re-reading the series now that I have all the books and I can read it uninterrupted.Bea still drove me nuts even though she has grown so much throughout the series. She still referred to Nicholas as a billionaire, telling me she is still hung up on his money.  At least she's figured out Hawke is the man for her, that he's the one that meets all of her needs. She has everything, but then she lets her insecurities get the best of her and she almost loses it all.Hawke needs to prove to Bea, one last time, how much she means to him, a grand gesture. He's been so patient with her, so understanding. he knows she needs to overcome her past demons in order to move on. He does some amazing things to help her move on.Nicholas is my favorite supporting character, I'd love to know more about him...maybe a spin-off (Hint, Hint). He's a little different, but there is a very caring man underneath it all.You definitely need to read all the other 11 installments before staring this one. It is written from Bea's point of view. There's lots of hot sex (sigh) and no violence. There in no cliffhanger ending.

Wow! Another great story by a very talented author. I have read all of the Love Series books in the series, but this one is by far, the most emotional. I cried several times throughout the book. My heart just broke for Jaylinn so many times. I just kept thinking that I was so glad she had Cooperto lean on when she needed it.  Together, they can get through anything and their relationship ended up stronger because of it.It was Jaylinn's relationship with her brother Hunter that worried me the most. He was so hurt after he found out what happened to her and he wasn't there to protect her. Now, given the devastating news they have received, Hunter needs to put it all aside so they can be there for each other.It wasn't all sad though. We finally get to see Mason and Hailey get married. I love how the author brings in all the characters from the other books. With each new story, their family changes and grows.You should read the first 4 books in the series before starting this one. There is no cliffhanger, but there is some foreshadowing for the next book. This book is told in alternating POV.
