Wow! What an amazing read.  I love how Emma and Jai got together for a one night stand. It took a little push from Emma's friend, Megan, but it was worth it. From there, it just got better and better. I was quickly sucked into the story and didn't put it down until I was finished. Lucky for me, this was a short book.I loved the characters from the very beginning. It's odd for me to feel so connected with the characters in such a short story. But the talent of the author shows. Jai was such a character, I have no words to describe him. Emma's being forced into having some fun for a change, taking that first step to get over her last relationship. What neither expected was the connection they felt.At this point, they have no idea they will be more to their relationship. Part of me says that if you don't like the "taboo" relationships of step siblings, you will still enjoy this story. It's just two strangers getting together for a one hot night of lovin'.This is book 1 in a 4 book series. I have been lucky enough to read all four books already and let me tell you, this is one series you do not want to miss. If you don't like waiting, get this today, one-click the rest when they come out, and enjoy them all at once.

This was a great conclusion to a wonderful story. Not only was it a story about about Ace and Max, it was a story about their family. It really shows how important family is. Always having people there that want to support you no matter what, people who always want the best for you. Ace needs her family. She needs to heal.This story was almost overwhelming. It was such an emotional read for me. I have grown attached to Ace and I experienced her struggles right along with her. The whole time, I kept hoping that Ace and Max would be able to overcome everything and get the HEA they deserved. It was such a long road to get to the end, but it was worth it.

I really struggled with how to rate this book. I wavered between giving it 4 or 5 stars. In the end, I decided to go with 4 stars for a couple reasons.First, Hadley didn't impress me in the beginning. She kept saying she supported Reed completely, but her actions were telling me otherwise. At times, she acted like the typical spoiled little rich girl. Turning to drugs when things got tough. That surprised me given her career choice. Then she really allowed Reed's leaving to completely destroy her. I just wanted to say, suck it up already.Reed's actions threw me off too. If he loved Hadley so much, why did her choice to leave her like he did? He left her with no way to contact him, he just dropped off the face of the earth. That was completely unfair of him. His actions were just speaking louder than his words... in the beginning.Then things changed for me. Once Reed got his head out of his ass and finally came to his senses, I got so into the book that I couldn't put it down. I kept hoping things would work out for them. Communication is definitely their issue, and one they REALLY need to work on. Both kept secrets about their time apart that ended up hurting their relationship. I knew something big was coming, but I wasn't prepared for the big plot twist.I can't wait to see how all this plays out. I will be reading the next book. Fighting to Stay, as soon as it is available.Contains: Alternating POV, Cliffhanger ending, Violence, Drug use.

I absolutely loved this story. I was so caught up in the beginning that I was crying before the end of the third chapter. I was so sucked in and attached to Roman that his life experiences affected my in such I way that I was taken off guard. It's not often that I get that emotional at the beginning of a book. It takes true talent on the author's behave to evoke.Have you ever thought about how the one person you were meant to spend your life with comes into your life. Sometimes fate has to intervene more than once for you to realize your destiny. Sometimes the circumstances aren't the best. but love can conquer all. This story gives you hope. Even after everything that Roman has been through, he has been able to find his soul mate in Melanie. After all the life altering events, he knows that there is someone there that will support him every step of the way.I ended this book with a contented sigh and a smile on my face. This author has become one of my automatic one-click authors. I look forward to reading more in this series.This book is written in alternating POV and does not contain a cliffhanger.

Nothing prepared me for the start of this emotional book. Zach has recently lost Gina to a tragic accident. Now, 4 months later, he's still trying to pull himself out of his depression and get on with his life. He's been lucky that he has had so much support from those around him. His sister even found a great nanny for him to help with his son while he is on the road.I love a book that pulls you in so much that you can't help but experience the emotions of the characters. This book evoked so much emotion it was hard to contain. There were parts where I had tears gently rolling down my face, but there were other parts that just tore me apart. The alternating POV's made the emotions even worse. By getting both Kate and Zack's POV, my heart broke twice. I knew both were hurting and I just wanted to make everything better for them.Throughout the entire story, we still get to see the characters we have come to love from the series. I love getting little glimpses into their lives. Sawyer Bennett has a to write that allows you to revisit characters of the series without taking away from the main characters story at all. Their lives  intertwine in a way that only good friends and family can.If you haven't started the Cold Fury Hockey series yet, I highly recommend that you do today.This book is written in alternating POV and does not contain a cliffhanger. It is a part of a series, but I feel it can be enjoyed as a stand alone. The characters from other books make appearances, but their plots have very little impact on the story of Kate and Zack.

As I was writing my review for my blog post, I went to Amazon to get the book links. Turns out, I forgot a very important detail. When I first saw that this book was a combination of 2 of Molly McAdam's books, I knew I wanted to read it immediately. However, by the time I actually read the story, I had totally forgotten that little tidbit of information.Since I forgot about the combination, I read the story like it was a stand alone.  If you haven't read the others, you will not be missing anything in this wonderful book. I absolutely enjoyed it from beginning to end and I highly recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good romance novel. Just be warned, once you start reading a book by this talented author, you will want to read more of her books. Her writing can quickly become an addiction, as they are an automatic one click for me.This book evoked just as much emotion as I expected. I laughed and I cried right along with the characters. I felt like I was right there participating rather then watching it from the outside.  I even cried for Kira, Kennedy's twin sister. She and her long-term boyfriend Zane had to be separated because of the circumstances. Even though their relationship was a secondary plot, my heart just went out to her. Molly writes in such a way that you can't help but experience the emotions.This book is written in alternating POV and has no cliffhanger.

I was sucked into this book right from the very beginning. I usually take notes while I am reading so that I can remind myself what I like and didn't like about the book. However, with this amazing story, I never stopped to take notes. I was so wrapped up in their story that I totally forgot to take a break.My heart went out to Dax from the very beginning, His dad is a total uncaring, jerk (not the word I want to use). He drilled his "rules" into Dax from a very young age, encouraging all the anger and violence he could. But inside, Dax has a beautiful heart. He just needs to get away from him environment for it to show. Kate has shown him that maybe things don't have to be the way they are. She gave him the inspiration to be better.I"m not sure how I feel about Kate. She's a runner and that personality type bothers me. It seems rather immature to run every time something doesn't go your way. To me, she had a lot of maturing to do throughout the story. To me, it's hard to trust that a relationship will last if one of them is a runner. However, by the end of the book, Kate convinced me that she was in this for the long haul.I loved watching these two grow and mature into an amazing couple. There were so many times Dax could have said "screw it" but he always seemed to make the right choices in his live.I highly recommend this amazing story to anyone. It's one of the best reads so far this year.

I will start by saying that have not read any of the Rock Gods series but I don't know that didn't stop me from completely enjoying this book. If you are a fan of Rock Gods, you get to see more of all the characters of that band throughout this book too.All of the members of Rock Solid have grown up together in the shadows of their famous parents. Lucky for them, they are just as talented and are able to benefit from it now.This book focuses on Annie and Ashton. Annie is the adopted daughter of Colt and Lia (who I thought needed slapped a couple times for poor parenting decisions). She's known all along that she was adopted. It affects her in so many ways, mostly her view of herself. That definitely had an impact on her relationships. Because the story starts when the kids are only 13, you get the opportunity to watch them grow up and mature into young adults.I was able to experience the story not just read about it. On more than one occasion, I had tears running down mu cheeks. To me, that's a sign of a good book.

OMG! I have no words to describe this book. I absolutely loved it. If you haven't started this series yet, you need to go get book 1, The Way We Fall, immediately. You do need to read book 1 before this one in order for things to make sense. This book starts where the other ends.This is not just a book you read, it's a series you experience. The emotions the characters are experiencing, you are too. I could feel just how much Houston loved Rory. He was willing to do anything to get her back. He's so patient and understanding, absolutely perfect. I liked him a lot better in this book.My heart broke for Rory though. She knew that Houston made her happy, but life was getting in the way. Waiting for things to work out for them was excruciating.  This is one of those stories that kept me up all night. I just needed to know how it ended.I can't wait to get my hands on the next book in the series. I will be reading it as soon as I can.Trust me, you will not regret purchasing this series.

I love second chance at romance stories. This one caught my eye right away. Not only was it a second chance story, it's also a 2 worlds collide story which I also enjoy. This book lived up to my expectations in so many ways.I expected great writing because I have read some of CD Reiss's books in the past. She has a way with words that has you experiencing the story right beside the characters. I felt like I was right there watching all the action, watching their relationship develop from the very beginning.My heart went out to Laine, She had a rough start to life, being passed around through the foster care system. To escape, she made several poor decision. However, once she realized how lost she was, she became determined to do something better. I really liked her strong sense of independence.  Even though she's in a much better situation, she still has a lot of insecurities to overcome.Michael disappointed me a couple times. He just didn't seem to put Laine first all the time. There were many times that he did, but there were a couple times that he didn't. It made it difficult to feel the connection between the two. I just wasn't sure that Michael was as committed to the relationship as he needs to be in order for it to last.For that reason, I also would have liked the story to be a little longer. I need just a little more reassurance that Micheal is as committed as he needs to be. That, and I wasn't quite ready for their story to end.

Holy crap! That's the one thought that comes to my mind after reading this book. It has a little bit of everything a reader could like. It's a collection of some very HOT scenes of some upcoming books by some amazing authors. It's a perfect collection to find out which books you want to read more. It's perfect if you are the type of reader who loves to re-read all the good parts of a book.Some of the stories are second or third in a series, where they characters and their relationships are established and we're just following their lives. Some of the stories focus on new attractions, even their first sexual experience together. There's some BDSM scenes, some menage scenes, and some just plain vanilla sex. I was able to get a feel for the characters in the short snippets, others I couldn't quite get a read on. Some of them left me wondering how things were going to turn out for them, while others I just knew things would fall into place for them. The one thing that they had in common was they were all hot.I really enjoyed getting a little taste of so many author's writing styles in one place. It will help me decide which books I will be reading in the future. Unfortunately for my bank account, there were several I liked.

I have mixed feelings about this book.Separately, I really liked Heather and Justin, They are great characters, well developed, and Justin's really likable. Justin is the kind of man you hope to find. He's kind and considerate, always there when you need him. Any man would be lucky to be called his boyfriend.I also like the fact that Heather and Justin have been friends since they were in school. Justin has always been gay and was the focus of a lot of bullying in school. Heather was always there to support and protect him. Given that background, I can completely understand their protectiveness towards each other.However, Heather and Justin's adult relationship drove me nuts. They are so co-dependent that it seemed unhealthy. At times, they can't seem to do anything without the other. She even went as far as to refuse to allow her husband to look at a cut on her leg, Justin and his boyfriend had to rush over to take care of her. Heather was just so needy. How they were ever able to find someone that was willing to put up with their relationship floors me. Many times, they acted more like lovers than best friends. It was just confusing to me. I know I wouldn't be able to tolerate their relationship.Overall, I enjoyed this book. The M/M and M/F scenes were hot, good enough to overlook how crazy Heather drove me. I enjoyed watching them develop and find their HEA's that are willing to accept their relationship as it is.

Be prepared for a rather longer investment of reading time than a book this short usually takes. It's fairly strongly academic in style, and ranges now and then into economics and philosophy. It will reward the interested reader with some interconnections not commonly made. Reader alert: some of the illustrations (all in black and white) may disturb some readers. The author says in the preface that the first chapters are analytical rather than prescriptive, but all the chapters have a detectable bias against industrialized animal farming. The last chapter is prescriptive, offering suggestions to improve what she clearly sees as an immoral, dangerous and environmentally unsustainable industry.The first chapter looks at some history, rather superficially I think. The chapter on industrialization of livestock production (chapter 2) and the chapter on industrialization of slaughter and processing (3) are the core chapters in terms of information. Chapter 4 looks at consuming animals as food and 5 looks at fallout from the process (such as animal manure equivalent to 5 tons yearly for each and every American. Yes, that is tons.).The book is wide ranging. One section discusses employee health--working in the industry is rather more dangerous than construction or mining, and the violence in the slaughter process seems have psychological consequences, which may include increased violence. Another examines government subsidies that allow meat to be cheaper than it perhaps should be, particularly agricultural subsidies. She also covers "institutionalized forgetting" which means more of less that meat eaters would just as soon be disconnected from actual animals that they eat, which in the US would be something like ten billion animals per year (a huge number of chickens accounts for much of that total). Then there are the eleven states that have laws (difficult to enforce) against public criticism of agricultural products and recent laws making filming or photography in processing plants a felony (these are the ag-gag laws).So, my point is that while this is not a particularly easy read, and in some senses a disturbing one, it is worth

This is a solid book on an obscure subject. Here's a quote that says what the book is really about: "First and foremost, American progress was built on the backs of people deemed second class citizens at best. Its dark underbelly was punctuated by grueling labor, low wages, suffering and survival. Not only was railroad building and canal digging physically demanding, but these occupations were inherently dangerous and violent."  The book falls into several categories, one of which is the history of labor, but also social science in looking at the question of why laborers have consistently been seen in negative terms.Dearinger has some interesting material, but at several points some academic concepts get in the way. These laborers also labored to "build masculine identity."  Presumably any such workforce was already masculine in its identity. Certainly workers might find common interests as opposed to managers or the farming communities through which they built and dug, which appears often to have been expressed in hard drinking, hard playing and occasional violence. Throughout this era, the yeoman farmer was valued as the personification of American, and workers in cities and elsewhere seen differently, perhaps because so many were immigrants and perhaps because so few owned property.The book discusses such work generally in Chapter 1, and in Chapter 2 looks at the Indiana, Wabash and Erie Canal, which resulted in state bankruptcy in 1850 (and was paying down debt on it until 1909). Chapter 3 examines both the Illinois and Michigan Canal and the Illinois Central Railroad, in which financial irregularities sometimes resulted in wages not being paid (one can imagine workers being even more surly). Chapter 4 discusses the transcontinental railroad, examining in particular Mormon work crews--who were then considered essentially an un-American fringe group. This is the best chapter, with the portion on the Mormons being outstandingly well done. Chapter 5 looks at the Chinese, being the second best chapter.One major point is that when the projects were done, celebrations celebrated managers and American ingenuity, not the work or workers. The famed photo of the completion of the transcontinental railroads meeting in Utah has lots of people, but no Chinese, who largely built the section from California to Utah.

C'mon, people, where are the reviews? The subject is grim, but this book deserves more readers. I read it this morning and found I had to pause after each chapter, to reflect on whether it has any resonance for American society today. If nothing else, it makes plain that the view that slaves were happy and that slavery wasn't so bad is a lie.Snyder's book is well-written, with a slight tendency to academic style in some sections. Among other details, she emphasizes that the sources must be used with care, and that slave suicide was a constant element throughout slavery times. There is no way of estimating the toll, save that it was sizable in the Middle Passage--one study she mentions found about 7% of embarked slaves killed themselves during transit. The toll of slave suicides must have been many thousands, but more than that is likely impossible to know. Slaves might kill themselves to avoid execution, to avoid torture, or as a consequence of families broken up for sale (infanticide and abortion is related but not described in this book), or from despair.Her thesis is that suicide was a way for slaves to assert some control, and it forced reactions. For one thing, a slave suicide was a lost investment. For another, suicides were noticed and in the long run served the purposes of abolitionist propaganda well. There seems to have sometimes been a grudging respect for suicides as resistance. There was also anger: a suicide's body might be decapitated, burned or left to rot. Slave owners feared that suicides could be contagious--and they seem to have been on board the slave ships.Chapter 6 examines slave suicide in literature, largely the impact a poem called "The Dying Negro," written in the 1770s about a real incident in which an American slave hoping for freedom in Britain was caught and about to be transported back to slavery in the colonies. This had huge impact in the propaganda wars between proponents and opponents of slavery. Another chapter discusses how slave suicide made a large appearance in fiction and theater of the day, making it seem like a morally proper and admirable act. There's also some discussion of how suicide is regarded in the Federal Writers' project of the 1930s interviewing former slaves; they regarded it as matter of fact and sometimes brought it up without it being asked about.Overall, this is a difficult but important subject.

I expected a much different book, more along the lines of natural history and conservation. Those are covered but rather briefly. The book mostly considers cultural use of orangutans, mostly European and American (the book portrays peoples living near the apes as not particularly interested in them). What I mean by that is the chapters examine the European debate about apes and the relationship of apes to humans, starting early in colonial times (Dutch colonialism in Indonesia--the apes are native to Borneo and Sumatra--began in the early 1600s).There were all sorts of interpretations, some of them using orangs as metaphors for human traits, some using the apes as elements in satires and novels. Science gradually came to a better understanding of them.The story the book tells is largely of human use of orangs, as much the idea of orangs as anything else, especially in popular literature (which continues as "Planet of the Apes" sequels continue into the 21st century). Living and dead orangs and dead orang parts were popular in the cabinets of curiosities on the 1700s and the natural history exhibitions of the 1800s, which gradually shaded over into modern zoos, and the sense of show gradually became that of education and conservation. Orangs seem to have been for a time popular figures in plays, acted by men in costume.Among the sections of the book that readers may find of interest are chapters 5 and 6, which examine orangs as characters in fiction, and chapter 7 which does the same for orangs on stage and screen. The chapters can be a little tedious. Chapter 8 looks in a general way at zoos and chapter 9 at extinctions. The latest survey, says this book, in 2004 found about 7,000 orangs in Sumatra and 57,000 in Borneo, but given extensive forest fire events and heavy harvesting of timber, that number is probably considerably less.Chapter 10 looks at conservation, with some pessimism, and also examines the idea of the great apes having legal rights.

This is a brilliant summary of something like 10,000 years--a long summary, and a bit slow in spots. The sheer length, almost 500 pages, may deter some readers. It took me most of the day today. Readers interested in specific topics might find particular chapters more rewarding than reading the whole thing. Cunliffe is one of the grand old men/ women of archaeology in the past fifty years, so this book brings in some archaeology and other aspects of scholarship. It also has a lengthy guide to further reading.The photographs are very good, though mostly of landscapes to get a sort of mood of them, as well as of some art objects and sites. There are lots of maps, and these are highly readable, and pleasantly, are located in the sections where the text discusses them, rather than in a section at the front where so many works have them. The maps are, well, the best I have seen in a grand survey such as this. In a sense a major theme is also the possibilities posed by environmental parameters, so environment is constantly in the background (as is geography). This is a grand narrative history of the kind not much written these days.The central theme of the book is how the steppe has been a connector between the Europe and the general Middle East/ Persian area in the west and China in the east. There's some discussion of India, but South and Southeast Asia is mostly unmentioned. There's also a little of Africa--Egypt, the Muslim regions of the Maghrib, and Axum, but mostly the continent is unmentioned, too. The focus really is Eurasia. The extensive sections on the steppe are the best I have read anywhere, even if group after group, leader after leader, state after state, empire after empire gets a bit confusing.The steppe has been a cultural highway, and among its passengers have been domestication of the horse, the idea of the chariot, artistic trends, religions, crops, the plague, pilgrims, diplomats and pillaging armies. However, some of the text concerns events in the more developed regions such as the long confrontations between the Romans/ Byzantines and the various empires based in Iran; the book is quite good on these, There's also a lot of Chinese history. Bothe these can be a bit tedious but reading about them in parallel so to speak helps one realize the continuity and connectedness of it all, rather than the usual consideration in isolation of each other.

This is an odd book. The text is well-written, as far as it goes, and the photographs are excellent, some superb. But the whole book has a sort of adult gee-whiz-this-is-so-cool tone. The only secrets are that at magnification and with Gary Greenberg's sophisticated techniques, the sand is revealed to be the opposite of the uniform feeling of sugar granules underfoot. There is every conceivable shape and color. The sand is diverse--from volcanic and barrier islands, river sandbars, desert dunes (and some dunes in the US, such as the Lake Michigan dunes), freshwater lake shores. The creation process of various sands is briefly described--abrasion by wave action, river currents, rain, wind, glacial action and more.I was hoping to read more about the geological processes at work in places like beaches and sand dunes. This book disappoints in that regard. It's really a picture book with fairly good commentary. It's a slender book and can be read quickly. The various sand pictures will remind some readers of modern painters, particularly Jackson Pollock.

This is an extremely good book for what it is. It covers a number of fascinating aspects of the "commons" and discusses economics and the commons, most especially the work of Elinor Ostrom (who won the Nobel in economics for her work). It's some fairly heavy reading, and the style is rather academic, with substantial in-text discussion of theories and economists, all this in a rather short work. Reader alert: Wall's conclusions will frustrate and perhaps anger people who are in any way free-market fundamentalists.The first part of the book is the most useful for a general readers, examining various approaches to the commons, and concluding that there have been many types and many have worked and are working--such as Boston Commons (now a park and urban greenspace) and the internet--the internet is a global commons and just as in the age of enclosures in Britain, there are attempts to close off the internet commons, too. Wall describes several kinds of commons, and notes that many were common in the sense they were commonly used but subject to agreed-upon rules that were enforced by local custom, with outsiders kept out, eliminating the "free rider" problem. A current example would be the Maine lobster fishery, in which locals quite emphatically enforce informal rules, using considerable violence if needed.Wall examines the Garrit Hardin essay "The Tragedy of the Commons" and finds it very influential but deeply flawed. The logic was perhaps too elementary, assuming everyone makes choices based on self interest, which Wall says is hardly the case in many commons, such as Swiss pastures (still a commons in the 21st century). He notes that the American native peoples usually regarded nature as a commons (but often limited use to particular groups such as clans or families, and kept others out); the invading Europeans saw the commons as empty and seized it by force, so Wall sees that as related to Scottish lairds throwing crofters off the land in favor of sheep.This may seem to be a small technical argument, but Wall is really talking about the global environmental commons and whether it can survive  extractivist use (a term I have not seem before but a useful concept). Wall is really saying that economics is as much about power and politics as it is about science. For Wall, there is clear evidence of commons management working and quite clear evidence of extractivist economics destroying the commons and causing social injustice.

I found this book when I was looking for information about Bhutan. This is an atlas with a lot of commentary.  It's a fairly fast read--probably 4/5 maps and photos. The maps are excellent and many of the many illustrations are exceptionally good. That said, the problem is that it's not complete, probably due to political conditions. It covers in particular Nepal and Bhutan, India and a little of Pakistan. But where is Tibet and China? The maps do show some of those areas, but the commentary does not. In addition, the material is a little outdated, given China's recent very large programs of dams and road building.There are five sections: The regional setting (which as noted doesn't have much about Tibet); the natural environment; society; exploration and travel; resources and conservation. I'd rate the environment section as the best. The section on exploration has a little on Chinese and other Asians, on pilgrim routes, but is primarily concerned with Europeans, in which folks from the Raj are the major players (including some Indian assistants who did some remarkable geographic work).

Wahlman has written a book with what are really case studies and a consideration of US military doctrine regarding cities. His examples are Aachen (1944), Manila (1945), Seoul (1950) and Hue (1968). In each he considers the same factors, but if I read them correctly, the critical factor is that US units have been allowed to respond to local situations, and that US troops have done well, with the proviso that US commanders in these cases used firepower and machinery rather than lives. The accounts are well done and informative, but I think adding a couple more would make the book have more resonance in the present: Baghdad would be the obvious, and perhaps New York on 9/11 since defending a city from a major operation seems as likely in the future as storming into one.There is some intriguing detail about weapons and characters of the enemy. In Aachen, the US troops storming into the city were outnumbered 3 to 1 by German defenders, but the quality of those defenders was mixed and Americans displayed exceptional adaptation. In the Manila example, it took two US reinforced divisions to clear the city, with heavy civilian casualties: it is debated but Japanese intransigence and atrocity probably was more at fault than very heavy US bombardment. The Japanese troops were mixed quality but determined. In the Hue example, the city was stormed by North  Vietnamese regulars as well as guerillas, so in a sense the US response was defensive. In the example of Seoul, the Marines were exceptional. I think the example could have been elaborated, because the city was the scene of more than just the 1950 operations (the operations described followed the US landings at Inchon).Wahlman does cite some mistakes. In Achen and Seoul the cities were not completely cut off, so substantial enemy forces were able to escape encirclement. Overall, the book is better written than most military history, and the sections where he writes of doctrine are less dry than is typical.

I was library browsing and happened on this book, and am glad I did. I have read a number of books on South Africa, but the San people were not much covered (Note: "San" is one of several names for these groups of hunter-gatherers, but is used to avoid negative connotations attached to other words such as "Bushmen").There were about 30,000 San in the Cape Province when Dutch colonialism began in 1652; the San had been pushed into the arid interior by Khoikhoi and Bantu peoples arriving about 2,000 years ago. Dutch colonists began venturing into the interior for grazing around 1700, and immediately ran into opposition; the Dutch grazing disrupted the environment (as did their hunting patterns). Dutch "commandos" (the word seems to be derived from Cape Dutch, and originally meant armed expeditions, something like a posse) would gather to punish raids by San and this author says, from 1770 through the 1790s annual commandos went out to kill San, forming essentially killing squads; all San men and most women found were killed and children taken to raise up as servants. The chapter on these Dutch depredations is the core of the book. Another chapter concerns the British, who were much less violent but tried to settle the San down and Christianize them, so if not murderous these policies were still aimed at destroying traditional culture. The destruction of the San was not only at the hands of colonists; herding groups such as the Griquas also hunted down and killed San.The book does not go much past the early 1800s. The last chapter is essentially an academic essay on was it or wasn't what happened to the San genocide. Adhikari concludes that it was. Apparently the topic gets little attention (save denial) in South Africa. This is a useful read, particularly on the fairly detailed chapter on the trekboers (the Dutch migrating inland), but the discussion of whether or not it w as actual genocide seems to be to be fruitless. The San way of life, once dominant in large areas, was essentially destroyed.

Another entry in the "Animal Answer Book" series. This is a formulaic short book, but the writing is good and the material interesting. It might be of special interest to teens with an interest in natural history, though the target audience is an educated readership. The weakness is that all the photos are in black and white, even the section of gecko coloration and vision.I knew little about the animals and found out a good deal. I had no idea they can live substantial lengths of time--the maximum known span for a wild gecko is 37 and for geckoes in captivity, 34. There are 1,400 species, ranging from a half inch to almost a foot and up to a pound in weight. I suspect most readers live in zones too cold for geckos, but Floridians like me see them daily--and nightly, as a population of Asian geckoes has come to inhabit urban areas in my part of the Sunshine State. They're cute little guys, and the book says geckos have sharp eyesight, which experience tells me is true.I was aware that geckos can vocalize, but unaware of the variety. The Giant New Caledonian gecko can growl and whistle. Not much is known about many species, apparently. One species is known only from one stuffed specimen, a century old--Delcourt's Giant Gecko from New Zealand. Some seem to have a limited ability to learn, and at least one species is all female, the mourning gecko.

Not a book one loves, given the premise of battle which is to kill other ships. The photos are as promised, unusual (and include some drawings of revisions) and in a way nostalgic. There's not much technical detail, but the photos might help someone making models, as details of decks and that remarkable pagoda control center on most is displayed.The photos are all black and white, some a bit blurry. The fates of many of these vessels is listed, so often sunk by US aircraft or submarines. While impressive, I can't help thinking of the tens of thousands of Japanese sailors who went down with these ships, to be largely forgotten save by historians and people interested in old naval encounters.One interesting detail is that some of the ships captured from the Russians in the 1904-1905 war are shown. Some were raised from where they foundered or were sunk.

This is a fascinating read. Charney's writing is clear and lively, and his expertise is impressive. The graphics are well chosen and there's a handy list of up-to-date investigative tools at the end, heavy on technology but clearly explained. My only complaint is that the font is a small size and that makes it harder to read. This book is full of fascinating detail and has some amazing stories about forgers. It's heavy on European art crime, and has rather little on Asia or Latin America--surely there are master forgers in those places, as well.I have a little difficulty in seeing the difference between fakery and forgery. He says that a fake is a period piece falsely and deliberately presented as something other, like a 1700s painting by a minor artist being somewhat altered and presented as a lost work by a major artist. But isn't that also forgery? Charney says forgery is one made up in the present and using the impressive range of fakery technology to be presented as older work. This book is primarily about the art of art forgery, which includes not just the work but forgery of the work's provenance. He gives some extremely impressive examples of master forgers. There's also an element of arrogance and inertia on the part of experts and museums. An expert who authenticates a work later shown to be a forgery loses a lot of his or her reputation, sometimes to the point of career destruction, and museums have strong motives not to admit they have bought a fake--the shame of spending donor money, the loss of professional repute and professional pride. The prime example in the book is the Getty, although there are other museums with similar histories.Among the interesting details are that the most popular artists to forge are Picasso and Dali, and that the artwork most stolen has been Van Eyck's The Ghent Altarpiece, with parts of the work stolen 13 times over the centuries. There are complexities: Michelangelo forged some works and that helped his early career. There's also the point than many old masters presided over studios in which assistants did much of the work; is the apprentices do most of the work and the master signs it, is it a fake?Punishment for forgers exposed seems almost always minimal, and some of the most notorious have written books, including one who wrote a book on how to forge art (the man was later murdered in Rome). Movies have been made of such people, so the usual negative views of crime seem to color art forgery only lightly. My favorite from Charney's  stories is the American forger Mark Landis, who forged many works and, under an alias as a Jesuit, father Arthur Scott, donated them to schools and museums, not in it for money but perhaps for pride or an interesting s ense of humor.Near the end he considers other forgeries of a literary nature, such as the poems of Ossian, the Hitler diaries fake and a Shakepeare lost play discovered,

Let me start by saying that this is Winchester's best book. As in all his books (at least the four I have read) this means a story well told, thoroughly researched and informed by extensive personal experience traveling in the places he writes about. Now, I need to add that some, perhaps many readers, will be puzzled by the structure of the book and by its tone. His chapter on American treatment of Pacific islanders is one that should shame Americans, but may rile some readers because of its rather anti-American policy tone (but not fundamentally anti-American; do remember he is British). The book also powerfully evokes change, in particular what academics might term a loss of hegemony--the French loss of Indochina, the British retreat from Asia, the rise of Chinese power sufficient to challenge the United States. The book is also hopeful of the growth of respect and understanding (the last few pages articulates this sense, using the story of the Hawai'ian ocean-going  canoe Hokole'a. The book is somewhat chronologic, but the intent is to give a sense of complexity and interconnection, because a literal history would be at minimum several volumes.Winchester covers history rather well in a backstory sense, but the book starts with January 1, 1950. This is the defined date for the "present," in the sense that a date of say 3,000 BP now means 3,000 years before 1950. The chapters start with short historical or human stories and segue into larger topics. For example, Chapter 10 starts with the eruption of Mt Pinutubo in the Philippines, destroying two major US bases, then segues into another volcano, growing Chinese economic and military strength, including the extremely effective Chinese strategies now unfolding in the seas adjacent to and extending from China's coast. This chapter, by the way, should be required reading for anyone interested in China's military.His introduction is, I think, superb. Read it and perhaps that will decide you to either read or not read the rest. Chapter 1 concerns the atomic and nuclear era, in particular nuclear testing. This is the section that discusses some quite shameful American treatment of islanders, a shame continuing into the present. It will probably anger some readers. Chapter 2 is more benign, describing the rise of Sony and its famed transistor radio. Chapter 3 may interest readers with little interest in the rest of this book, because it describes the rise of surfing into an international sport.Chapter 4 tells the story of an American officer who used a grease pencil on a map to suggest the 35th parallel as the border of influence between Soviet and American occupations of Korea. This has some wonderful (and quite strongly biased against North Korea) writing about the Koreas and is one of the best chapters. Chapter 5 starts with the burning of the liner Queen Elizabeth in Hong Kong, well past her glory days, and segues into the recession, so to speak, of Hong Kong to China. This has some interesting discussion of European recession from Asia as well, the French and British, especially. Chapter 6 starts with the 1974 typhoon that destroyed Darwin (in Australia) and segues into weather patterns; I really liked this chapter, but readers who do not credit global climate change will be very upset at Winchester's  assumptions. It fits with the rest of the book in the sense the Pacific is an ocean but is also connective tissue, connecting the Eastern nations (on the ocean's western rim!) and the Western nations (on its eastern rim!)--we're all in this climate change thing together, this chapter says.Chapter 7 is largely Australia, and I suspect that many US readers will yawn as they read this section, which is too bad. Chapter 8 looks at the submersible Alvin and the discoveries of what have come to be called black smokers and white smokers, hot deep ocean vents. Something that will surprise many readers--it did surprise me--is that these vents offer a wealth of minerals that will soon be mined, the technology is being developed now, and the ecologic and environmental effects may be huge. But who are we Americans, considering all we have done, to tell Asian nations to cool it on this, asks Winchester. This chapter is a bit pessimistic in tone with the sense that the resource is rich and will be exploited because it will make people, some people, rich.Chapter 9 is more strongly environmental, discussing coral bleaching and other problems--reefs, including the Great Barrier Reef, may be gone in this century. But he also has some encouraging counters that give the chapter a sense of, a small sense of, a positive future. The 10th chapter is as noted above mostly about the rising Chinese power.

This is a book I started years ago and never finished. I just read it all over the last day and am glad I did. Dinerstein's writing is extremely good, and as a scientist with vast field experience he knows what he's writing about. The book's style is participant-narrator, so to speak, rather like much science writing or journalism, but more informed.The book may be somewhat dated. It was published in 2012 so the field experiences he relates are before that, and endangered species can experience huge change in a short period, such as poachers wiping out a reserve's elephants. Each chapter centers on similar species and usually specific locations. I most enjoyed his discussion of Kirtland's warbler, which considers why the bird is rare and why it is so picky where it nests. The warbler is likely to be a ward of the state forever, because only controlling numbers of the parasitic Brown headed cowbird has allowed the population to improve its position somewhat.He writes about the greater one-horned rhinoceros, down to a few hundred animals, with its horn in 2010 worth $100,000 a kilo, and how after mild recovery it was devastated by political turmoil in Nepal--in the absence of enforcement poachers cut deeply into the population.  Another chapter considers Brazil's cerrado, a rather large area being converted to soybean production, with animals such as a giant armadillo, a large anteater and the maned wolf. One aspect I was not aware of is the use of scent dogs to find animal scats, which can then be analyzed for DNA and other contents, to yield a lot of data for species difficult to observe or census.Two other chapters I though especially good. One is on the birds (and some plants) in Hawai'i, and another, the last chapter, on Bhutan. The chapter on Bhutan makes one optimistic, as the country seems determined to protect its natural resources--Dinerstein is also optimistic about Namibia. Another fascinating chapter is on Vietnam, with a focus on the mountains usually called the Annamites (the Vietnamese name is different), which apparently remain storehouses of rarities, albeit under growing pressure.

I am somewhat disappointed in this book. The selection of posters is excellent, and it really is rather global in coverage (mostly India, China, Iran and Palestine, with a few other locales in addition to the dominant European and American coverage. The writing is good but the overall text is not nearly as good as the posters shown. It starts well but then veers into a bit too much art and design; by this I mean the focus shifts from a history of posers, I think, to a consideration of posters interacting with artists and designers. This isn't all bad, but it's a bit too academic for the general reader.There's more, of course. Guffy does devote a lot of space to the political poster, particularly of the USSR and Mao's China, which found posters a useful media for exhortation--and also apparently displaying posters of Mao in one's home was a wise investment, demonstrating one's orthodoxy. There's interesting discussion of posters in Cuba and also--this will likely rile pro-Israeli readers--some discussion of martyr posters, which desktop publishing has made quite sophisticated. Among other discussions topics in the book is an Iranian artist, Reza Abedina, whose work is really interesting, a theme of which is liberating Iranian posters from Western typography.There's maybe too long a discussion of posters from the 1960s. The book has some striking designs from then, including a very famous Bob Dylan poster, but I think if the discussion had been a bit shorter more space could have been used for the political posters of 1968. I also note that Latin America is mostly missing and that there's no mention of Australia. There's a short mention of US federal art programs using posters, which sounds interesting.

For a long time I avoided books in a question-and-answer format, but tried a couple and found they may have lots of solid information that doesn't require reading a tome. So, I decided to read this book, bats being an interest of mine. This is a short book, a fast read and it's a good summary of bats, their biology and behaviors. With some 1,400 species the book can mention only a few in detail (the 1,400 is a detail from the book!). The organization is good and the writing is very good. There is a section of color  photos at the end, quite well done but there could be more. There are a number of photos in the text, as well.Here's some things that the book left with me. One bat is known to have lived to 41 in the wild (banded), 6 species to 30+ years old and 22 more at 20+ years. The "bumblebee bat" AKA Kitti's hog-nosed bat weighs about the same as a US penny; there are some fruit bats that top the scales at three pounds, and may appear on the dinner menu in some parts of the world. The banana bat lives inside furled banana leaves. Vampire bats need about two tablespoons of blood a day. The African false vampire bat can hear a beetle walking in sand from six feet away--one wonders who found out that detail.Intriguing is evidence that bats can in effect say things to each other (of the same species, that is) and appear to have enough intelligence to cope with changes in their environment. The book didn't mention it in any detail but bats apparently can learn.The sheer variety is wonderful. Some bats eat fish, using echolocation to detect ripples in the water surface--and some bats can swim. The book notes that a fruit bat can peel a mango--and has a photo of a bat enjoying the fruit. Then there are African wooly bats that may live in webs of colonial spiders.Note that this is not a children's book but teens with an interest in nature would probably like it.

This book deserves as many readers as possible. I can't believe mine is the first review! Khan's writing is excellent, and the book will help any reader better understand what India (in the sense of British India, including present day Pakistan) and all its peoples went through in the war. What Khan does is remarkable: she establishes that India was vital to the war and that the war is vital to understanding the rapid political evolution that resulted in independence and the 1947 split. I can't emphasize enough that this is a new and highly informative take on a part of the war, one far more complex and far more important than most American readers know.The book covers a great deal, some of it necessarily briefly, and points the way for other writers. In no particular order, this book covers the Bengal famine, two million Indian soldiers abroad, the Burma campaigns, hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing the initial Japanese conquest of Burma, Japanese bombing and fear of bombing, hospitals, recruiting, the Indian National Army (under Bose, nominally fighting with the Japanese against the British), demobilization, censorship and more. The more includes black American GIs (22,000 of 150,000 total Americans in India during the war), white American racism against black Americans and black Americans finding sympathy with Indians.There's some detail I have read nowhere else. About a forth of British merchant sailors were Indian, and scandalously they were paid far less than white sailors. German propaganda aimed at Indian soldiers (in North Africa) and German broadcasts were rather more effective than the usual histories indicate, and Japanese propaganda also more adroit, of course in both cases focusing on quite real facts of racism in the Raj. There was an influx of European refugees, including thousands of Poles, and apparently there were Indians who learned Polish in the course of interactions (and the reverse of course), Thousands of poor white people seem to have acted to discredit the rigid hierarchy of the old Raj, which was shaken during the war. The account of the Bengal famine is superb, by far the best I have read. Then there's Herman Perry, an American black GI serving with troops building the Ledo Road to China, who murdered an officer and deserted; he was sheltered by a Naga family, and married a village girl in the year he was free before he was caught and hanged. There are other individuals who make Khan's history come alive.

In the Introduction, Norwich writes "today is my eighty fifth birthday." This is perhaps the final book by a grand old man who has lived a full life and with a good portion of that life concerned with Sicily. It's popular history, well written and informed by his own half century plus of seeing change in the island. It's a fine introduction to a quite complicated history. The book is best on particular eras; I rate the sections on the Romans and Carthaginians, the section on the Normans (and the related Hohenstauffen kingdom), the Napoleonic era, and the era of Garibaldi as the most informative and most interesting. I read it a few chapters a night over a week.There's more, of course. He rather overdid the Admiral Nelson- Lady Hamilton business, an interesting but sad footnote; Nelson was involved in some of the politics (partly as a force the British diplomats could call in). But the number of pages he devotes to it seems excessive. Another intriguing section is the invasion of Sicily by the Allies, and the American use of important mafia figures in that campaign. The book essentially stops in 1945, although he does note that over the past decades, even while the mafia retains significant, Sicily's condition has improved and life for the mass of Sicilians has never been better.

Covering primarily the Canadian Arctic, it does consider Arctic conditions elsewhere, including Svalbard and Greenland and some in Alaska. Struzik is primarily concerned with the connected changes posed by energy development and climate change. There have already been significant impacts on the Arctic, including Pacific salmon being caught in Greenland, and killer whales in some numbers feeding on beluga, narwhals and seals (once very rare). The news isn't uniformly bad. He notes that barren ground grizzly bears, Wood buffalo and musk oxen may do very well as a consequence.The most pressing threat isn't climate change, it's energy development, specifically the oil sands in Alberta, which uses a huge amount of water; the Athabaska system, ground waters and lakes. This is south of the Arctic, but polluted water can flow north into the Mackenzie river system, which is Arctic and is huge. Given the likelihood of much more shipping in the Arctic, an energy infrastructure is already developing. Oil exploration, diamond mines, ores and other mineral exploration, and development is coming. Not so many people appreciate the delicate ecosystems, the importance of the Arctic to weather patterns and the complexities of permafrost. The resources soon to be available are huge. The potential problems are, as well.Struzik's book is full of information, and he draws on his decades of what might be called Arctic journalism (he lives in Edmonton). Much of the narrative is a sort of participant narration. Chapters are fairly short and look at largely one topic each, such as birds, polar bears, water, within the general context of the Arctic. He's harsh on the Canadian government (as of this writing the Conservatives he lambasts have just lost an election). As an American used to a prevailing anti-environmentalism in government, it is odd to think the Canadian experience has been worse, with the same blend of energy-sponsored denial of climate change and the same climate of deregulation of corporations. He praises some American aspects, including a large groundwater agreement in Texas. He doesn't exactly condemn the energy industry but seems to think they will cut corners and have done little of the basic research for Arctic development.One detail I had not known about. He writes that in 1949, there was a plan to test atomic weapons in an area west of Hudson Bay--these would have been British devices, based on the understanding that large areas of  land was scarcely populated and had little value.The book is short enough to read in an hour or so, and the writing is excellent, both entertaining and highly partisan. The information is current and solidly researched, but given the pace of change could be outdated in just three or four years. There are some photos that help make the point, but more would help the reader.

I only discovered this series recently. Sanderson has written an interesting book on small cats, defined essentially as not one of the 6 or 7 large cats. The science is easy to understand, and the descriptions good. It is written in a question and answer form, and is appropriate for any interested non-scientist, including bright high schoolers. Some sections are a bit dry, such as the evolutionary relationships and the bone structure. The book describes some species I had never heard of such as the Bay cat (Borneo) and the Flat-headed cat (parts of Africa). The weakness is that all the photographs are black and white, making details of coat patterns difficult to see (but it probably made the book cheaper).One thing I noted is that details on some of the cats are simply not known. A lot is inferred from studies on domestic cats,  The book has a lot of interesting detail. The guigna cat (Chile, parts of Argentina) is at three pounds way smaller than most house cats. Cats have a remarkable sense of smell, house cats 15 time more sensitive than we humans in scent. Cats are dichromatic, having two kinds of cone cells in their eyes rather than three, so they see different colors differently than we do, but they have far more rod cells for night vision than humans do. There is an interesting discussion on vibrissae--whiskers and such hairs in other places, that give cats a remarkable sense of their relationship to space and objects around them.And! The author notes that the world's only cat museum is in Sucheng, Sarawak. Why there must be a story in itself.

This is essentially a case study in changing human use of a resource. Tanoaks were widespread on the Pacific coast, and acorns provided a mainstay for many tribal peoples. A mature tanoak might provide 200 or more pounds per year and an old growth tree, a thousand pounds. One grove might sustain a village. The arrival of the Spanish changed things some but the tidal surge coming with the gold craze quickly altered the old patterns. White rancher and farmers used the oak as a kind of commons for hogs and cattle, while wiping out the Indians on a near-genocidal scale. Open land seemed to settlers to be an indication they were unused and free for the taking. So, they took. Tanoak bark became a major resource for the tanning industry for "heavy leathers," such things as harness and industrial use. This wiped out much of the resource. Now, tanoaks are being eradicated as weeds by industrial forests, because tanoaks grow quickly after disturbance and outcompete he desired softwoods. A tree has gone from a gift of god for the peoples' sustenance to a hated weed.Bowcutt writes this story beautifully. There are a generous number of photos related to all this, including indigenous people using the acorns. The last chapter, "Partnerships" considers whether native tribal peoples can work partnerships with others to help the trees survive. The chapter introduces the concept of "food sovereignty," which I had not heard of before but strikes me as intriguing.The future of the tree is not only in discovering new uses and extending old uses, but survival. Sudden Oak Death is infecting many areas  where the tree grows, and threatens to annihilate the stands (other oaks are also at risk). There is no cure in sight. New uses might include craft furniture and other objects, because this is a useful hardwood, but the cost of processing it into usable timber is excessive.Bowcutt has written in this book a model case of environmental history continuing into the present. To do so in this short of book, with great detail and clarity is uncommon. It deserves a wider readership than it's likely to actually get.

This is an admirably short, thoroughly researched and nicely written account of privateers. It's an aspect of the War of 1812 that tends to be thought of in a sort of swashbuckling aura, as if they were upscale pirates, but they were a thoroughly capitalist enterprise on all sides. Navy personnel suffered the same hazardous conditions with the addition of harsher discipline, but had less potential for reward--the luck few privateers made some investors, owners and officers wealthy.There were two kinds of privateers, cruise and voyage. The first cruised for prey, the second were really armed merchant ships that might take advantage of opportunity, but carried on trade. Kert has found evidence for about 600 American privateers who among them took about 1,900 prizes. Her book also looks at privateers from Canada who preyed on American shipping. Privateers obtained letters of marque from proper authorities (the whole business had paperwork galore especially if prizes made it to port to face the admiralty courts for disposition of the ship and cargo). Her chapter 2 has a nice discussion of the origin of the privateering system and its legal situation.More than 100,000 Americans crewed these ships (a ship might cruise more than once with different crews).  Half never took a prize and of the prizes taken, many were retaken and some lost at sea.  A few privateers took dozens of prizes (the top one she lists was Canadian, with maybe a hundred prizes). Chapter 5 details some of the successful privateers, their cruises and some of the cargoes--a couple borderline bizarre.A couple of things had consequences. An American privateer was trapped in the Azores and taken by a British force, but put up a stout fight and caused numerous British casualties. The British force was to have reinforced the invasion forces that landed at New Orleans, so it helped Andrew Jackson. In another case a British privateer took an American ship en route from Italy to Philadelphia, carrying among other things somes crates of paintings for the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. That institution went to the British courts and the surprising result is that the paintings were released, the case establishing that cultural goods belong to civilization as a whole and are not subject to being spoils of war--a principle still important. A few American privateers operated out of French ports, outraging the British, and a few sailed in the Pacific cruising Chinese waters, with the British Navy after them. There are some movie plots here, I think.The privateers collectively were a moderate success, some not recouping the cost of outfitting them, some greatly profiting the people and local ports they sailed from (Salem had more than 40 privateers, for example). They were calculated gambles for profit, that happened to be of use in wartime. Kert notes that the most important effect was a boost in morale and pride.

Metcalf has a great topic here, but could carry it out better. He divides American history into generations, backfilling from the recent Gen X and all that. These seem somewhat forced. The Republican generation 1742-66; Compromise generation 1767-91; Transcendental generation 1792-1821;  Gilded 1822-42; Progressive 1843-59; Missionary 1860-82; Lost generation 1883-1900; and so on. These are the years people were born and grew up and used words he lists. His selection is quite arbitrary, but interesting and should please anyone interested in words and jargon.Most of his selections lasted a few years to a few decades but some remain. Okay, for example, remains nearly as common as "like." Some words change. Pioneer, foe example, originally had a military meaning, something like advance guard. The deadline comes from a line drawn in the sand which, if prisoners crossed at Andersonville they were shot--this one is contestable. Dude goes back to 1883 meaning a foppish young man.This is not a particularly serious book, it's light reading. Buy another book if it's Christmas and you've got a serious etymologist in the family.

This is an agreeable book on a topic of considerable interest, but it doesn't really have much in the way of answers. Does the moon have an impact on life? The answer in this book is on some species, yes, but on humans, maybe or maybe not.Naylor looks at some cultural understandings. For example, the Maya didn't see a man in the moon, they saw a rabbit in the moon. He also discusses some biology where there is an impact. There's evidence that some fish respond to moonlight rather than tides, rising or descending in the water column depending on the light, and there appears to be a tie-in with breeding in some species. Night hunting activity is suppressed by bright moonlight for some species of predators. And my favorite, African dung beetles cab use moon to figure out direction.That's what the book left with me, some interesting trivia and history.

I've read many books on immigration and on Asian Americans. Overall, this is the best. Lee manages to cover two dozen ethnicities over several centuries, and paints a wonderfully informative mosaic. One important aspect is that Asian America is not a single entity; Hmong refugees and Filipina nurses have as little in common as immigrants from Bosnia and Nigeria. One reason this is such a powerful book is perhaps her own family's experience in the complicated history of Chinese immigrants to America over the last century.The focus is the United States, but Lee also explores relevant history in Canada and especially Mexico. The famous Manila Galleon trade over 250 years made a connection between Asia and New Spain that brought tens of thousands of Asians to what is now Mexico, as slaves and sailors, including a wide range of Asians, not just from the Philippines. She covers Chinese labor that built much of the transcontinental railroad, but does not appear in the iconic photographs. There's also discussion of the infamous and little known "coolie trade" in which Chinese labor was brought to places like Cuba and Peru, under conditions often little different than slavery. There's some violent history few Americans know about, including a vicious massacre of Chinese in Wyoming, terrorism in the California gold fields and mobs running Asians out of many Western towns. It's not just American racism: in Torreon in Mexico in 1911 some 303 Chinese were massacred.The story has many variants. Some Sikhs came to California a century ago, and with state laws against Asians marrying whites, married into the Mexican American community to found a vibrant community. There were Bengali immigrants to New Orleans, Korean migrants fleeing Japanese occupation of Korea, and many more. For me the most troubling portions of the book were the laws against Asians becoming citizens or owning property, leading into the World War 2 internment of more than 120,000 people of Japanese origin; some of these were from Latin American Asian communities, in effect arrested by US authorities. The story is of sustained effort, enduring optimism and eventually more acceptance.Key events were World War 2 when China was an ally, and the 1964 Immigration and Naturalization Act, which changed our history. Among other elements, tens of thousands of war brides came to the US from Japan, and over the years tens of thousands from Korea. The Southeast Asian War was another huge factor in that the eventual Communist triumph brought hundreds of thousands of refugees. One chapter looks at the experience of the Hmong people, enlisted virtually as a people in the US secret war, and coming to the US as a shattered tribal people. This last is on-going and with successes have come failures. Also fascinating is the story of immigrants from South Asia (India and Pakistan)An intriguing chapter is on transnational and global immigrants, a current phenomenon of what might be called multicontinental families using the media of today to maintain both immigration and background. These are often Indian or Chinese families and may be the immigrant pattern of tomorrow. A final chapter summarizes current trends: Asians are the predominant immigrant group (immigration from Mexico has dropped sharply), and oddly, Asian Americans are over represented at both ends of the economic scale, large percentages are affluent and larger percentages are poor than the national norms. And racism remains a formidable obstacle.The book has an excellent bibliographic essay. The photos add considerably to the text.

This is an excellent overall account of billfish (marlin, swordfish, spearfish and so on). It's a "Wormsloe" book from this publisher, which seems to guarantee quality (I've read several). Ulanski writes clearly and mixes science with culture in a way that informs both. This book discusses billfish biology, life cycle, prey and migration patterns, along with the development of a major sports fishery--with one chapter on billfish fishing tournaments. Swordfish are treated in a separate chapter, because they have long been fished for food, with other species fished largely for the sport.Two literary figures are important, because both had a mania for fishing--Zane Grey and Ernest Hemingway. Both has a lot to do with the development of the billfish sports fishery, which by now involves many thousands of fishers and quite large amount of money as prizes in tournaments. Catch and release prevails now, and apparently if done with care, most of the fish survive.There's some interesting discussion of long-line fishing and how it impacts these fish, primarily swordfish, as well as discussion of currents, water temperatures and currents, with how the fish use these phenomena. I found the best chapters to be 5, on blue marlin (it has a good section on the mechanics of the fish swimming), and 6. on swordfish. The chapter on swordfish also looks at how this animal is endangered.

I just reread this book after reading it several years ago. Environmental history is a major interest of mine, and looking at the Civil War through an environmental lens, as Brady puts it, is interesting. War and the environment is an emerging subfield. I think I better understand her point after the reread. Brady sees nature as an important historical agent, an agent without intent or consciousness but still an agent. This is an arguable point. Having "agency" usually means both intent and conscious use of whatever power the agent has to affect something. Brady makes a case for it, not entirely convincing, but interesting. Nature is not static, and this may affect military operations. This would mean rising and falling waters, weather, temperatures, mud, and such, things that change.Brady also posits the landscape is a mix of nature and human activity. It seems to be this rather than nature as a whole that she's looking at. She uses the term "agroecosystem" and certainly the North made war on the Southern landscape, notably in Sherman's marches through Georgia and the Carolinas. Structures were burned, crops destroyed, domestic animals killed or carried off, the infrastructure damaged as much as possible. Brady looks at Grant's Vicksburg campaign, in two chapters, Sherman's march, and then Sheridan's campaign in the Shenandoah as case studies.

This book deserves a wider readership than it's probably going to get. Rogers describes a too-little known ecological crisis by looking at a variety of plants and trees under threat, and they really are stories. The stories include how the plant was discovered by botanists, where it grows, something of its historic range and what that is currently, as what threats there may be. She also discusses efforts to prevent extinction. The overall story is that American forests are in deep, deep trouble, due to epidemics of fungus, beetles, climate change, timber harvest and development. And my own take is that part of the danger is that so few people are aware of the dangers, but we're losing tens of thousands of thousands of square miles of forest in the American West and could lost most of it. This is solid science, particularly botany and ecology, but she has written the book without all the notes that characterize an academic study; she wants to reach a more general public. Rogers' prose is graceful and clear.Chapters include a considerable variety, from Mead's milkweed to the Feikeisen and acuna cactus to the Whitebark pine. Each has been chosen as an example and taken together, give a reader a sense of the problems and a sense of how they are being addressed. As a Floridian, I found the chapter on Florida Torreya to be especially interesting; this tree is rare and native to the slope ecosystem along the Apalachicola river in Florida's Panhandle area. I had never heard of this before and was entirely unaware that the area is a botanical hotspot or that there was such a thing as slope forest.There's much more. The Fraser fir is endangered in the wild, with mature trees wiped out. This is important because 95% of the Christmas tree crop in North Carolina is Fraser fir, the total crop worth in excess of $100 million per year. Then there's the Parachute penstemen, discovered in an area in Colorado only in the 1980s, and it's endangered by development of shale oil resources in its preferred ecosystem. And there's the Whitebark pine, an important tree in subalpine environments, gravely endangered by fire suppression (many conifers are adapted to regular fires), byfungus and beetle epidemics and by global warming--this is important because the tree is a base element of that ecosystem and iconic for hikers.One chapter examines three plants and their associated animals,  in the sense of coevolution; running buffalo clover and bison, for example. Another is fascinating, "Lost in the Wild," referring to plants found in the wild and not seen since; an example is the Franklin tree, found by William Bartram in the 1700s in Georgia and not seen in the wild since (although a widely domesticated species). There's a chapter on northern plants, mostly Canadian and the author reminds us that the North is a carbon sink but could easily turn into a carbon source if warming continues. The last chapter is grim in a sense because Rogers says that while any species has inherent value, inherent value doesn't make it as an argument with any economic impact. Only if a species can be shown to have real or potential value will it be widely seen as worth saving, the value in terms of potential medical use or genes that might be useful in GMO crops.

Coates has written a book that is going to outrage some readers and puzzle others. He's also written a book that I think will become as much of a classic as The Autobiography of Malcom X. Coates' writing is superb, and informed by both passion and tragedy. The book is in the form of three essay letters to his son. There's the tragedy, by the way, no matter how much love or how much promise, all it takes is one moment of sassing an officer or angering some advocate of stand-your-ground.  I fear for Coates himself; he indicts police officers as representative agents of a murderous system, and an officer who has read those comments who has Coates' car pulled over, well, you can imagine the rest. That's what he's writing about. What I have just written may make no sense until you get well into this book.He's writing about more than just the American institutions of structural racism. He describes a visit to Paris where he felt no animosity directed to himself or his family, but notes the French have their own version, with Algerians and others. Whether this is the same level of omnipresent fear inculcated into all American black communities is not clear. At the very end he indicts the "Dreamers" (this refers specifically to the people who think they are white, the term he uses in the book--itself derived from a poem) for not just consuming and killing black bodies but the body of the Earth as well. You may not agree with me, but there's something magnificently Old Testamentish about this.Reading reviews or other kinds of comments isn't going to tell you much except that Coates  has touched a nerve and riled a lot of people up including those he says are "obsessed with the politics of personal exoneration." Read it.

I wish I was better versed in this fine art--literally a fine art. What looks effortless is achieved by a deep aesthetic and careful gardening over time. The gardeners maintain the shapes conceived by the original designers, painting with gravel, stones, moss, foliage, trees, bamboo, as well as perspective, concepts such as asymmetry and sounds such as water. Rain and snow and seasonal color by flowers or fall leaves also enter the picture. Gardens were and are for contemplation and strolling, but also as a focus of concentration such as raking patterns in gravel, a physical articulation of religious concepts. In a sense they are uniquely Japanese, but as I viewed these photos, I was reminded of photographs of an Appalachian spring.I suspect that for Japanese visiting these gardens, the experience is something like visiting the great Gothic cathedrals in Europe is for others, a calming and contemplative activity (at its best, my guess is tourists with phone cams may sometimes muddy the concepts). Kyoto gardens still have the majesty of time, and this book allows an armchair traveler like me to get a taste.

This is an interesting book, although it may be of limited appeal, mostly to readers interested in modern Tibet, the Himalayas, and the Cold War. Khan writes well, and this book is actually entertaining, a marked contrast to the usual book based on someone's PhD dissertation. It's short, pithy and does not have the typical scholarly "apparatus" of vast numbers of citations. The book is partly based on interviews, but also on archival material recently declassified (and he notes, recently reclassified). One gripe: the man loves long paragraphs, some of them more than one page. The writing is good, but I'd break up those paragraphs.Khan's thesis is that Fourth World people (nomads, villagers, mountain peoples, not really members of a formal nation) in and around the Tibetan border forced the People's Republic (agents of the Taiwan Chinese are also players in the book) to go from a loose form to a tighter form of control. Khan used the term "Empire-lite" to describe the era 1949-1959 when Tibet was not so harshly ruled. He sees China as a real empire (as he does the USA) because it has multiple ethnic groups, some held in by force, and Mao extended control over non-Han Chinese areas that had been part of the Qing empire (the old name was "Manchu"). I find that mildly interesting but the "Empire lite" seems a bit contrived.Tibet has of course long been a nation but one that had only feeble control of much of its spread, and the borders with Tibet, Nepal, Sikkim, India, Pakistan and Bhutan were fluid and people might have roots in more than one place and in effect more than once identity.
