The intensification of Chinese rule in and after 1959 forced people to choose. The best part of the book looks at these groups of people. Interestingly while the PRC imposed rule on Tibet, the Taiwan (formally Republic of China) regime also acted strongly diplomatically to prevent the UN or other organizations from recognizing Tibet as a nation separate from China.The maps are excellent. A few photos of what the areas looked like and of some of the people would help the reader, I think. One thing the book does is make plain that Tibet did not exist in splendid isolation in a mountain fastness--trade was lively and there was a great deal of traffic in and through the mountains, whether of family or pilgrims or merchants.

The photographs range from excellent to superb. They are a fine evocation of a region, one part of my family has lived in since the late 1700s. I somehow missed this book before, and just read it. There isn't much text, and you can get through the whole thing in an hour. However if you have some association with the region, whether it's family, travel or hiking some trails, the photos may get you going down memory lane.Most of the photos can be described as landscape. Aside from trees, mountains, flowers and streams (a lot of waterfalls), there isn't a human or animal, save for one black bear. The photos show scenes from a number of areas, although Tennessee, North Carolina and West Virginia have the most.

This is a complex book that really mixes several themes. One of course, and the best one, is the story of how Polynesian voyagers discovered and settled Hawai'i. The second is Kirch's autobiographical story of starting as a young archaeologist in his home state, and gradually becomes an archaeologist of international reputation, and with that, he also tells the story of developing techniques in the field, from digging in a gridded site to sophisticated tools that can tell where a basalt adze comes from. The other story is more or less a case study of Hawai'i, isolated from the rest of the world after the end of voyaging, for several centuries, evolving from thinly populated settlements to densely populated kingdoms. This is what Kirch calls an "archaic" state, and the example of the kingdoms (culminating in Kamehameha's united Hawai'i kingdom) becomes an example in such fields as anthropology.There's also a bit of fiction, in the sense several sections describe the creation of a voyage of settlement, including building the canoe, accumulating supplies, and the voyage itself. This is based on the facts of archaeology as we understand them at present, but also on the accounts written of Hawai'ian legends and stories, written down in the 1800s by native Hawai'ians and by others who came to the islands and were in a position to understand the tales--actually more oral history and social memory than legends.

This is a compelling book, written with passion and understanding. It is partly written in first-person, as Neiwert is a kind of participant observer, living in the same area where the orca pods he describes live. This is primarily about several groups of orcas in the Puget Sound up through British Columbia coastal and island waters. These orcas bore the brunt of a decade or so of capture of orcas for aquariums such as Sea World--they suffered a sizable chunk of their populations lost to these captures, and have not yet recovered. Part of the point to the book is an exploration of whether and how these animals can live in such close proximity to several million people.One thing for readers to note is the small populations, something like 300 orcas in this sizable area. Also important to note is that the population is comprised of "residents" who eat salmon and other groups that travel widely, and eat sea mammals; these are essentially subspecies that do not interbreed. The latest studies indicate that there are perhaps ten subspecies in the killer whale complex, with different prey, that do not interbreed and socialize with their own kind. This book focuses mostly on the resident population, which has been closely studied for several decades now; interviews with the people who do the studies is an important part of the book, studies of behaviors, diet, vocalizations. The book does have a short section detailing the differing orca subpopulations.Niewert's book combines natural history, biology and most particularly, relationships with humans, which range from a New Age sensibility through hard science, politics and environmentalism, environmental ethics and a growingly popular whale watching industry that clogs the seaways. His point of view is very strongly  environmentalist influenced by solid science (which includes assumptions of evolutionary process and global warming). He discusses SeaWorld and other such businesses, and is uniformly harsh about them, accusing at least one of outright lies to the public (Orcas, with one rare exception, live much shorter lives in aquariums than in the wild). One fascinating chapter is titled "Free Willies," discussing that particular whale as well as several others, concluding that release of whales born in captivity is probably not good, but the wild-caught ones probably should be released). The intricate politics of the whale "rescued" is bizarre, and SeaWorld comes out as the baddie.Near then end an environmental issue intrudes. The huge deposits of energy in Canada's tar sands represent a huge opportunity for exports, and the industry wants to set up a huge terminal near Port Vancouver to export the oil, which would bring large numbers of large tankers through the areas inhabited by the resident whales. Aside from the quite dangerous nature of the oil in the event of a spill, ships make a lot of noise that can interfere with Orca communications and their hunting. The issue has not been resolved yet, but given the very, very large sums of money that would be earned, it looks like tar sands oil 1, Orcas 0. The very strong environmentalist movement in BC may yet stop it.

The sheer number of reviews in just a few months means this book has drawn some attention. Obviously the Civil War still matters to a lot of readers. Rather than add to what must be many thousands of words in other reviews, I'll just put a few notes here. One, McPherson is one of the grand old historians, with a career of more than fifty years.This is not really a book about why the war remains important. It's a collection of McPherson's essays about the Civil War, with only the first (where the book title comes from) written especially for this book. Some of them first appeared in the New York Review of Books, which is the premier venue for book reviews in the US (it also tends to be a bit smug about that fact); these essays are readable and fast to read. There's a lot about Lincoln, about slavery and some about how in this new century the war still reverberates.One detail is that he cites the new accepted total for Civil War fatalities, 750,000 or more, rather than the long-cited 600,000 plus estimate. I'd rate several chapters as best. Chapter 4, "Death and destruction in the Civil War" is a good discussion of a grim topic. Chapter 5 looks at the Union and Confederate navies in the light of British neutrality. Chapter 9 discusses Lincoln's growth from a military novice into a superb Commander in Chief.

This is a powerful and sometimes moving book. It intermingles current science with Safina's personal experience and some very strong opinion (Sea World might want to sue, given his comments about their maltreatment and misinformation about killer whales). It is not a systematic exploration of all animals. Safina looks in great detail at elephants in East Africa, wolves in Yellowstone and killer whales in  Washington-British Columbia waters. There are also briefer looks at crows, whales and a few other animals.For me, the book built slowly and packed both emotion and understanding in the last hundred pages about killer whales. I learned a lot, much of it entirely new to me. I did not know that there are essentially several varieties of killer whales (or "orcas"), which don't mix and have different specialties--fish, marine mammals, sharks, whales and so on. The animals overall have a complex social structure, subtle communication, excellent memory and apparently both humor and self awareness of some kind.Other reviews have sufficiently established the quality of this book. Here are a few of the things that most surprised me. The section titled "Where the Wolf Birds Lead" concerns crows and ravens and discusses their tool use--astonishing. A sad and angering detail: hunters in Wyoming outside Yellowstone shoot wolves, but there is a way to eavesdrop on wolves with study collars on, find the radio frequency and then them and then kill them (killing part of a study as well as a wolf). At least two species of grouper recruit moray eels or other fish to help them get prey out of tight spaces.Then there is what US Navy sonar and weapons testing does to whales. Overall, this is Safina's finest and most powerful book.

This is an intriguing book I wish I had read when it came out. Greene examines literal horse power, horses in US cities from the later 1800s through several decades (horses continued to be used in a few urban areas well into the 1930s). The book is well researched and excellently written. Here's a quote that gives the theme: "Horses were workers as well as machines that labored in partnership with humans. As horse populations swelled,  nineteenth-century America became more than a society that used horses; it became a society of horses and humans living and working together."It discusses much more than horses doing work such as powering machinery by treadmill. Chapter 1, "Why Horses?" discusses the advantages of the horse over other animals such as oxen and camels. Oxen were extensively used but not so much in urbanizing America. This has details of horse bone structure and other details that do explain why horses. Fascinating stuff. Chapter 2 examines landscapes and horses. The connection may seem vague, but horses require food and a great deal of farmland was needed to grow it. The urban horse also needed an infrastructure just like automobiles would later--stables, stalls, harness makers, horseshoes and nails, drivers, what passed then for vets, wagons and carts, as well as sanitation--horse manure could be in hundreds of tons per day for a big city. Chapter 3 is "Making Horses," which looks at horse breeding and how it became more elaborate as the 1800s went on, breeding larger horses for heavy city work.Chapter 4, "Civil War Horses," digresses somewhat, but is fascinating. Both sides relied on wagon trains for supplies, as well as the huge needs for cavalry and artillery horses. The discussion of the ways the Quartermaster Department went about finding and supplying horses is absorbing.  Chapter 5, "Horses as Industrial Workers" is really the one closest to the book's title. This looks at the Pony Express briefly, as well as public transport (horse cars and later urban horse railroads), hauling in cityscapes and more. There was increasing technology as the century progressed, but despite what one might assume, the number and size of horses sharply increased, reaching its peak between about 1890 and 1900. Urban transportation was the largest single category (she doesn't mention it much, but horse transport gave rise to synonyms for "taxi," such as cab and hack).Chapter 6 discusses increasing study of horses, what made them tick and how to maximize work from them, including Muybridge's famous photos and engineering design for vehicles more efficiently using horse power. The increasing professionalization of veterinarians is also noted.  Chapter 7, "From Horse Powered to Horseless" is for me the most interesting chapter. This discusses the rise of vehicles such as the bicycle and automobile, which dovetailed with Progressivism. This movement is extraordinarily complex, but regarding working horses it gave rise to groups protesting cruelty to animals, which saw the automobile as less cruel. Parts of the movement concerned with public health pushed for cars rather than horses, because a city like Philadelphia had 500 tons of horse manure a day in 1900. Greene describes other phenomena, culminating in the streets changing from, as she tellingly puts it, spaces in neighborhoods to spaces through neighborhoods. The streets were too chaotic for Progressives, and Progressives sought solutions to chaos such as to moving children to playgrounds, and putting police on the streets, and systematizing traffic rules. They also thought cars would be much safer and cleaner.

I had been meaning to read this book for a couple of years, and just got around to reading it this week. It's fairly short, barely 200 pages, so you can read it in less than a day. The writing is excellent, the maps fairly good and the illustrations interesting. I take some exception to the title; it was less an age of exploration than political and military adventuring into the Indian Ocean. These were rather large scale and it is surprising that the Portuguese survived; luck and ruthlessness, perhaps. Much of the story Casale relates concerns Ottoman viziers, appointees in Egypt and naval commanders. It's mostly from the Ottoman point of view, and anyone interested in Ottoman activities in the Red Sea, Yemen and beyond will find this book well worth the read. Casale's major point is that the "Age of Discovery" histories are usually told from the stance of European discoverers, with all the other "Others" seen as victims; this book shows, as intended, the Ottomans as no victims but a major player in the age.Casale has some discussion of how the Ottomans had little knowledge of wider world geography--not much of a large body of recent works in Arabic were available to them, and he argues that it was indeed an age of discovery rather similar to that of Portugal. I'll leave that aspect for a reader to decide. The book has much to offer aside from that thesis. The Ottomans took Egypt and became responsible for the safety of Mecca and Medina, and were as much pulled into the region of the Red Sea and impelled by an urge to discover. They used the Egyptian port of Suez as an armory and base, and managed to construct a number of fleets there, despite most naval resources (especially wood) having to be imported from rather far off. They found themselves in a contest with the Portuguese, and the confrontation lasted decades, and extended from the Red Sea to the coasts of India and even further, as Aceh on Sumatra was allied.Ottoman conquests included much of Yemen, some of Eritrea, and with their conquest of Iraq, from Basra at the head of the Persian Gulf, expeditions were sent to combat the Portuguese in a number of areas. Casale argues that the Ottomans became principals in the spice trade (heirs to the earlier Egyptian Mamluk patterns). There were a lot of interesting sideshows. There was a proxy war with the Portuguese in Ethiopia, in which Portuguese aiding the Ethiopians fought against Turks in the service of Ahmed Gran, and Ottoman forces went to and some settled in areas in India, to affect local politics for some time. There were a couple of Ottoman expeditions down the Swahili coast, and Ottoman soldiers and artillery were sent to Aceh. Some of these adventures were fairly large scale: Hadim Sulieman Pasha's expedition to India (from Suez) had 10,000 soldiers and sailors and nearly seventy ships.

This is a superb book. The writing is outstanding, the book is thoroughly researched, the photos are unusually good, and overall it offers a new perspective on Germany and Germans during the war. It's over 500 pages, and Stargardt's ideas take some time to develop, so this is not an easy read. It's another book that the "I love it" phrasing with 5 stars is not very helpful; this is not a topic one loves, as a great nation engages in a destructive and evil war, on a course to catastrophe.I find it not so easy to tell why I think this is a superb book, and why it stands out it a category of books that must total in the thousands (I've read scores of related books). Some of it is the wonderful way the story is told. Stargardt uses period letters and journals to follow a number of actors through this story--their story and Germany's story. The author manages to integrate large-scale events with the personal, and the result is a deeper understanding of what it was like for Germans engaged in the war than any other book I have read.  It's also the range of stories. There's a good deal of discussion of how German religious figures related to the war (mostly fatalistic patriotism, for lack of a better phrase). There are some touching stories: a soldier writing home to a deeply loved spouse is touching, even if the soldier is fighting in an evil cause. This last is an important point. Stargardt pulls no punches, and this book in no sense attempts to mitigate German atrocities--he even makes a solid case that knowledge of the atrocities (including mass murder of Jews) was rather widely known. What the book does is humanizes people caught up in a pending catastrophe not really, for the most part, of their own making.Stargardt says that when the war broke out it was deeply unpopular in Germany. There was little of the wild enthusiasm that characterized 1914. Instead it seems most often to have been a grim recognition of the necessity of responding to aggressive enemies, particularly Britain--propaganda helped create this view, but so did memory of the "stab in the back" and the second war was apparently widely seen as a necessary correction to reclaim German greatness. The book's analysis of all this, and of propaganda, is superb.The Nazi state was of course coercive, but Stargardt makes an excellent case that coercion was not the main element. The idea of most Germans as victims of a murderous regime, forced into a war, is an old argument that has lost its force. Germans fought willingly, for the most part, not because they were forced to. The regime was admired by some, loathed by others, but until well into 1944 there was little sense that it was an illegitimate government. Hitler was widely admired and the ideology of world Jewish conspiracy was widely shared.Here's one of the many stories contained in the greater story, one I find fascinating. Anton Brandhuber, an Austrian, got tired of fighting and decided to stop. He managed to travel west from the front, 3,000 kilometers to Switzerland and spent the rest of the war there, surviving into very old age. That is not the kind of story one expects from a terroristic police state.Some of the chapters are fascinating. Chapter 5 looks at how German soldiers sent home luxuries from France and Belgium--some plunder, some purchases, aided by clever manipulation of currency. The same chapter discusses more blatant plunder, of apartments and goods taken from Jews sent to the camps. A detail I can't quite comprehend is that it was common for soldiers to have cameras, and the rolls of film were sent home for developing. Many soldiers took photos of executions and murders, and knowledge of these would have been spread to the photo processors and people at home. There was also surprising frankness in solders' letters home, so again awareness of the conduct of the war (and the problems that soldiers experienced in Russia, such as cold, lack of equipment, savage fighting) was common--this in a state I had always thought had a rigid censorship.One chapter is especially touching. Chapter 10, "Writing the Dead," includes stories of wives and family members of dead or missing soldiers continuing to "write" them in the form of journals and other writings. Another chapter details in an intriguing way the Katyn Forest massacre of Polish officers by the Soviets, discovered and used adroitly for propaganda purposes by the Germans (in this book, Goebbels is portrayed as a master manipulator).I could add more and more detail, but you'll have gotten the point by now. The master story is partly comprised of a number of overlapping stories of real people caught up in the larger story of Germans at war. Particularly engrossing is the last hundred pages or so, dealing with impending collapse and then catastrophe, how people managed to live with their world collapsing around them.

This is the last book by an author with a long career; Flood died before this book came out and he was in his 80s, so criticism can be more lax. This is not a good book in the sense it is well written, and the pattern really is jumping around with no real system. It is not a history so much as a sampler of the Americans who flew for France, many of who were not in fact in the famed formation--which seems to have been formed partly for public relations reasons, perhaps to popularize the war in a still-neutral USA.That said, the book is conversational in tone, like a favorite uncle telling stories. And some of the stories are wonderful, from the lion cubs bought as mascots to how a one-eyed man became an exceptional pilot. The dangers of flying those machines comes through, as does the fact that some of the Americans were educated sons of quite affluent (sometimes quite wealthy) families, what once might have been called "playboys" who decided that fighting for France was the honorable (or challenging?) thing to do. Some of the men who later became pilots first joined the Foreign Legion (they could that way perhaps not run foul of the American restrictions of serving in a foreign army, because Legionnaires swore allegiance  to the Legion rather than France). Of 269 Americans serving a pilots in French service, 42 were killed in combat or died of wounds, 21 died in accidents, and several from disease or suicide.There is no systematic focus. The many people's stories told in the book include some combat, some training, lots of camaraderie, social exploits, back history before the war, some later lives, some death stories and some somewhat veiled sexual escapades. In total, it does give this famed formation a human face.

This is an excellent little book by a Swedish scientist, an odd book full of information, but written with many first-person sections, such as doing research in Tunisia or Nepal. His specialty is mycorrhizal aspects of fungi, especially as symbiotic with trees and plants. The science is current and the writing is very good. There are some diagrams and a number of excellent photos. Typical of the information: one gram of soil from a temperate Swedish forest can contain hundreds of meters of fungal hyphae and more than 10 billion bacteria. There's more diversity of species in a shovelful of that forest soil than the total animal and bird diversity in all tropical forests. Soil really is another world.The chapters are not numbered. They cover what a longer and boring textbook would cover: definition,  description (pore space for example, is important), life in the soil. water, nutrients, erosion and so on. It's done here well, with wit and admirably briefly. He brings in his specialty of course. Here's an example. In Tunisia an acacia species is important and can draw waiter from 40 meters underground, but has mostly been cut for animal feed and firewood. Wallander investigated what changes in the soil are occurring (each species of tree has relationships with fungi and other species so the impact is much more than the loss of a tree.One chapter considers terroir, on wine and tomatoes, that is, the impact of soil on taste; given the vast complexity of soil ingredients, for lack of a better word, this must vary considerably. Another chapter is on "biological warfare," how many species produce substances that discourage or kill competitors, or may increase symbiosis. These substances sometimes have medical value, such as penicillin and cyclosporine. We have barely investigated all the possibilities, so here is a frontier of medicine worth following. Another chapter discusses life in the soil, of remarkable complexity and not fully understood. Another chapter considers soil and climate, that is, the impact of climate (temperature, rainfall and so on).There's all sorts of incidental information. European worms, for instance, are beneficial in European soils, but in Minnesota, have had quite negative impact on the soil ecosystems--admittedly it may be difficult to think of worms as invasive species. There's an interesting few paragraphs on why people eat soil and clay; it can neutralize stomach acids, and if mixed with acorns makes them edible by neutralizing the tannin content.Overall, this is a highly readable, pleasant book that brings in a scientist's vast experience in almost a conversational way.

This is one of the best books I have read about the Pacific. It is extremely well-written history, concentrating on the eastern Pacific, largely from Baja California to Russian Alaska, and focused on the span from Captain Cook's voyages to the starting days of the California gold rush. He emphasizes that the Pacific is a connector not a barrier, and looks at a number of voyages of several kinds of ships--merchants, whalers, explorers, and the US Ex Ex (the United States Exploration Expedition). One theme is how the eastern Pacific becomes the American West. He uses journals and travel accounts (some published well after the actual experiences) extensively, and interweaves a number of lives to form a mosaic of connections.Chapter 1 examines the "Sea of Commerce." This explores many aboriginal trade systems, as well as early trade venture to the Northwest coast, the Californias and Hawai'i, linked of course to Canton. Some of this is done through the story of William Shaler (1802-1804). The number of voyages seems to be known fairly well, and between 1786 and the Gold Rush, at least 953 ships from at least 20 states (not all were nations at the time, for example Hamburg)traded on the California coast. Chapter 2 examines "Disease, Sex and Indigenous Depopulation." This is the best account of a widespread and unpleasant phenomenon I have read. Much of the sex trade was forced prostitution, and partly through that sexually transmitted diseases became widespread, with baleful impact on native populations everywhere. He also discusses other diseases introduced such as tuberculosis and smallpox. This web of negatives is also part of the ocean of connections.Chapter 3 is about hostages and captives, with some interesting stories about several Russian captives of Northwest tribes. Taking hostages appears to have been routine, but arbitrary and often as a means to get native people to return something allegedly stolen or to return deserting sailors. This chapter has some grimness to it as well.Chapter 4 is on "The Great Hunt." This describes the Russian hunt for sea otters, and more general (later mostly American) hunts for whales. fur seals and other furs. They would be sold in China. Again there are many stories, including from the journals of the wife of an American whaler captain, Mary Brewster, a total of six years at sea. By 1850 there were some 700 American whalers in the Pacific, with Hawai'i as a main port of call. The chapter is particularly disconcerting on the massacre by whalers of grey whales in the Gulf of California (although the whales killed some sailors).Chapter 5 is "Naturalists and Natives," and has some fascinating stories of naturalists. In one, a German/Russian naturalist on a Russian ship became close friends of a Micronesian man, member of the crew, more or less. Igler notes that these scientists were in the service of nationalism, of patrons and of international science, but also had some baleful effects--such as publishing accounts that told where resources such as sandalwood could be found. Chapter 6 looks primarily at the US Ex Ex, and the experiences of an important American geologist.Overall, what Igler paints is a picture of exploitation, an excitement of exploration, and of reluctant accommodation on all sides. Crews tended to be complex and the mixing of people and cultures was extraordinary. It also establishes that American whalers, merchant ventures, explorers and missionaries (in Hawai'i from the 1820s) all but made the West coast officially American before the Gold Rush, even while British, Russians and Mexicans were active as well.

This is another book that makes me wish Amazon had a 5-star with something other than the phrase "I love it." This is a good book, but the general prognosis for the future is not very hopeful, and it's not something you love, even if you find the information to be valuable.This rather short book is another volume in an interesting series, all written in the same question/ answer format (and all slightly repetitive). I read it straight through, but a reader can choose one or two sections, because each can stand alone as a topic.There's a bit of history, which for Ukraine is complex, located at the historical intersection of Polish, Russian, and Tatar worlds. One thing the book does is discuss how the heart of Ukraine has not been Russian very long--Great Russian, the Muscovite state, so to speak. Ukraine was Polish-ruled for centuries, and the portion called Galicia was Hapsburg until the end of World War 1. This is important because the main Russian narrative is that this conflict is really an internal matter among Russians. Russian rule of all of what is now Ukraine was short, the Soviet period--and, much of what is Ukraine was part of Romania, Poland and the Czech Republic until 1945, so the "Russian" rule was really 1945 to the break-up of the USSR. That may seem convoluted but is a main point. It's not Russia trying to recover lost areas of Russia.The current situation stems from a popular sort of revolution that ousted a pro-Russian president. Putin's Russia did not like that situation and the conflict has ensued. A large chunk of Ukraine in the east has a substantial and in some areas majority of Russians, although this gets complicated. There are many Ukrainians whose mother tongue is Russian, so Russian-speaking does not equate with being Russian. The matter of the Crimea is somewhat different; historically Russian (since it was conquered and the Tatars subdued) and given to Ukraine by the Soviet government. The existing Tatar minority apparently faces discrimination whoever runs the place. The author discusses how many, perhaps most Russians see the downfall of the Soviet Union as a disaster, and many are livid that former satellites are joining NATO. There's also the matter that Russian Orthodoxy (church, that is) is newly militant and than historically Ukrainians are Uniates, sometimes called Ukrainian Catholic (Orthodox but accepting the Roman Catholic pope's authority in some matters). So, the conflict has a toxic brew of nationalism, resentment and militancy on the Russian side. Russia's military forces are recovering and are now again formidable and above all, for Ukraine, close. That means that Ukraine may suffer more, perhaps being split into two parts with the east being annexed to Russia. Those areas, conveniently for the Russians, have quite valuable resources.The author pulls no punches. He's strongly anti-Russian but also caustic about corruption in Ukraine itself. Whether a young democratic movement can emerge or whether corrupt oligarchs recover control is not yet clear. Nor is the Russian intent. To paraphrase a Mexican bromide, poor Ukraine, so far from Washington and so close to Moscow.

This is not really a history of an epic battle. Rather, it is a history of the memory of the battle over the century since it took place, and compares the differing importance in differing countries whose soldiers fought there. It's minor in Ireland, because there is nothing to celebrate about an English defeat. It's minor in French memory because the French focus on the Western front. Although not covered, it seems to mean little in India (some of the "British" were soldiers from India). It's celebrated in Turkey both for the victory and because the founder of modern Turkey, Mustafa Kemal, was an important commander in the battle, and it's most important in Australia and slightly less so in New Zealand. The book considers the meaning of the battle; clearly ANZAC ( Australia-New Zealand Army Corps) Day predominates in the importance and intensity of observance.The intensity of observation is also important. Macleod discusses how the meaning of the day has changed over the years. One obvious change is that as veterans died, the celebration shifted from personal memory to the more abstract.  She observes that military history is bound up in national stories. Irish soldiers at Gallipoli were part of another country's story (the civil war following World War 1 has something to do with that). The soldiers on both sides were multicultural. There was a 500 man Zion Mule Corps (Jewish). There were Ghurkas, soldiers from Ceylon. The French contingent included Foreign Legion troops, French, and Africans from French colonies. The British soldiers included Newfoundlanders from Canada. The Turkish troops included an Arab regiment, and some Jewish, Armenian, Kurdish and other soldiers.The book begins with an excellent summary of the battle before it starts discussion of the meaning of the battle in different nations. The discussion of the several national memories of the battle could strike some reader as tedious because it includes local politics, most intense in Australia. Australia's memory of the battle is tied up in some complicated understandings of what it means to be Australian. And says the author, Gallipoli is a pivotal moment in Australian nationalism but in New Zealand it is remembered more as sacrifice for England. I liked the overall discussion of national stories and memory. I'm not sure it fits, really, the concept of a Great Battle series.

This book is notable for very many photographs (the authors seem to be affiliated with the Cornell Ornithology lab). The photos range from there merely good to superb. For those alone the book is worth its price. The text is mostly captions on the photos and some connective text. It's a fast read, but the photos are worth looking through again.It's essentially a look at the family life of 50 species of common American birds, such as the Blue jay, the American crow and others. The photos cover courtship and mating, nest building, egg laying and hatching, and fledging of young. There are some wonderful photos of fledglings, obviously my favorites.There are some intriguing tidbits in the text. Rock doves (commonly called "pigeons") have been known to live 30 years. American crows bond for life and the young from a previous year may become helpers with the latest nestlings. And a how-the-hell-do-they-survive thing: In 1996 in Tower, Minnesota, the lowest temperature ever recorded in the state was noted, minus 60 degrees F. Black-capped chickadees, which weigh a third of an ounce, survived nicely. And Red-breasted nuthatches use tools--bits of bark, to spread resin (obtained from conifers) around the entrance to their nests.

This is a fairly short, nicely-illustrated and well written book. It is agnostic as to whether there are or are not such things. The chapters are fairly wide-ranging and consider a good range of culture, mostly in the sense of the kinds of conceptions of ghosts that people have come up with in folk tales, stories and religions. One detail I can't get over--apparently Thomas Edison thought there were ghosts and tried to devise a machine to communicate with them. Not much detail is provided on this, but there's an idea for a film.It starts with a discussion of ghosts in the classical era of Greece and Rome and their worlds, and while it's a bit rambly, the intro chapters are full of information, and particularly rich on the movement called Spiritualism. One illustration shows a real estate disclosure form, which asks the usual questions about are you aware of a death or violent crime on the property, but includes "or allegations that it is haunted." I suppose that might affect home value (there's another film idea, someone who plays the market by fabricating hauntings, to get caught by a real one).My favorite chapters are these. Chapter 4 "The Hungry Ghosts: the Eastern World" discusses ghosts in Asia, mostly China and Japan, and includes legends but also contemporary film. I like the idea of ghost money, fake high-denomination bills burned so that family ghosts in the netherworld can buy some comforts. Chapter 5, "La Llorena and Dreamtime" discuss ghosts in Latin America and Australia. Chapter 6, "The Quest for Evidence" doesn't provide much in proof or disproof, but does describe what seems to be a thriving phenomenon of people who consider themselves some form of ghost busters, with lots of equipment available online, including lasers, thermal cameras, appropriate aps for smart phones and so on.Other chapters are still interesting. Morton discusses short stories, novels, and film, including both the obvious ones and some less well known.

This is an intriguing book that really intermixes two different but related stories. One is told very well and one is less absorbing (unless you are a real fan of paleontology). Thewissen is a good writer with wit and a talent for storytelling. The best part of the book is Thewissen describing his field experience in Pakistan and India; this is doing science in the field, and is vivid and in an odd way, fun.The other story is the aspect of doing science by slowly piecing together the fossil evidence and interpreting that evidence. The science story in this book is finding some of the "missing links" between land creatures and whales, and establishing a transition phase. This has a subtext in providing evidence that whales did in fact evolve from land animals, therefore providing evidence in support of evolution and ammunition for Darwin's defenders. There are several illustrations of what some of these creatures may have looked like--interesting creatures. This part I personally found to be somewhat tedious. The interpretation of fossilized bones from the ear and aspects of skulls and teeth really is very important in understanding past life, but not compelling for the non-enthusiast. I also understand that these fossils are important. but I thing the book could have better told me just why that is the case.I think Thewissen should write another book, concentrating on his experiences in the field. He does that exceptionally well in much of this book.

This is a remarkable look at North Korea. The overall theme is that the regime is still in charge, but it has had to tacitly allow a shakily vibrant brand of free market activity in order to survive. The details this book provides show a level of complexity associated with the word "byzantine" (the book does not use the word). The official exchange rate is wildly volatile, and bureaucrats make the dollar equivalent of maybe $1- $2 a week, so corruption is massive, otherwise the country would not be able to feed itself. Apparently if it doesn't challenge the regime in any way, the regime turns a blind eye to the activity. Bribes and knowing important people become a form of insurance, and there are sharp differences in urban-rural ability to skirt the laws. The long Chapter 2 in the book details this in absolutely amazing detail. Rather than the faceless and helpless victims of brutal ideology, North Koreans show remarkable creativity and ingenuity,  in a sense giving the lie to some anti-North Korean propaganda stereotypes.The book describes a number of current phenomena, including the creation of a cell phone network by the government, but the phones can also used to access Chinese cell phone systems if the user is near the Chinese border, with major consequences for the economy. The regime is still arbitrary on culture and now and them has rounds of arrests, but a sizable fraction of the people have access to Chinese and South Korean radio and tv (the TVs and radios for sale are supposed to be preset for approved domestic media but this apparently can easily be corrected). In particular "USB sticks" as the authors describe them allow access to recorded South Korean tv shows and movies from the US and elsewhere. As for the fashion described in the book's title, there are still quite strict rules against much fashion but often ignored particularly in the capital city. All of this blends together to quietly reshape the country's culture.This is important stuff, not just the story of  people managing to survive with at least a little luxury. The vaunted North Korean army, say the authors, is poorly trained, poorly equipped, poorly led and poorly fed. Consequently there is not the slightest chance they will give up nuclear weapons, it's the only deterrence left. That, and small numbers of special forces. The army is used often as a free construction force for various projects.Just as seriously, the Kim Jong Un described in this book is not the merciless Stalinist dictator of propaganda, he's very powerful but not in total control; in some ways he is a figurehead of a collective leadership made up of family, powerful officials, powerful military and some others. One short chapter describes crime and punishment--North Korea has what are essentially regular jails for regular criminals as well as other systems. This includes quite brutal camps, the extreme of which will work prisoners to death. The system is arbitrary but does not amount to a Korean gulag in the sense that sustained propaganda has led many to believe. There is a sort of collective guilt premise, so that if one person displeases the regime, family and friends and neighbors may be affected. There also seems to be an assumption that family reliability is deeper than just the living; if grandfather was a problem for the regime, the grandchildren may have opportunity for success substantially reduced.A main premise of the book is that the severe famine of 1994-1998 was a kind of tipping point, in which somewhere between hundreds of thousands and several millions of people died of starvation. Their point is that in order to survive, the regime had to adjust, loosen the chains and rein in the ideology, with the practical results the book surveys. They conclude that most people in North Korea do support the regime and that all the changes actually have made it somewhat stronger, so the idea that the state may collapse is likely an error.There's a fairly large section of photos. These show what seem to be confident and fairly happy people, but there also some that seem to show a truer version of the countryside. Readers can make their own decision as to what these show. Overall the book rings true.

Hannnigan explains in his introduction that he set out to write the kind of general history he wishes had been available when he first traveled in Indonesia. That's exactly what he has done. This is one of the best histories of any place in Asia that I have read. The writing is clear, objective (he does seem slightly biased against the Dutch), informative and provides a solid framework for future reading (something else he set out to do, as he explains in an unusually lively introduction). The section of plates is rather good and they have outstanding captions, not something one ordinarily notes. The maps are helpful.Hannigan covers a huge amount of history, but much of the focus, and the best writing in the book, is on Indonesia from about 1900 on, and is especially good for the independence struggle, the Sukarno and the Suharto years. Not so many Americans are aware that this is a huge country, 3,274 miles from east to west and with 250 million people, or that it is the largest predominately Muslim country (in population).The book uses the term Indonesia only after the Dutch began their domination, a process that lasted into the 1900s; instead he uses the term Archipelago, which may be a better term for the wide range of cultures. I found his account of the ethnic origins fascinating--Austronesian, moving from Taiwan, on through the island arcs, and eventually including Madagascar in the west and New Zealand in the east, from about 6,000 years ago.Some of the peoples, especially in New Guinea, have been there far longer, some tens of thousands of years. Hannigan brings in accounts of visitors, including ibn Battuta in the 1300s and Tome Pires in the 1500s. The first couple of chapters describe the influences from India and the variety of political entities.The third chapter, "Saints and Wanderers," is an account of the coming of Islam, and it is a fascinating account. Chapter 4, "The Spice Islands" is superb, although many readers will be familiar with much of the information. Chapter 5, "The Clash of Civilizations" describes Dutch expansion, the brief but important British period (when the Netherlands was a puppet of Napoleon) and some of the resistance, such as that by Imam Bajid and Diponegoro. Chapter 6, "Rust en Orde," is largely focused on the expansion of Dutch control and the infamous "Culture System" imposed on many parts of Indonesia. It includes an interesting discussion of the British scientist Alfred Russel Wallace, and the conquest of fervently Muslim Aceh.Chapter 7, "Brave New World," starts the 20th century, the rise of nationalism and while centered on Sukarno, it's informative about the general sense of what might be described as Indonesian-ness. This sets up Chapter 8, "Freedom or Death," including the Japanese conquest and occupation, and the struggle for independence. This is the best overall account I have read about either the occupation or the independence movement.Chapter 9, "The Year of Living Dangerously," is about the consolidation of the Indonesia state and especially about Sukarno. The title is from a Sukarno speech, in which he used this phrase taken from a speech by Mussolini. This chapter discussed the massive violence in 1965 and 1966 against the communists and ethnic Chinese, in which somewhere around a half million people were murdered (it may have been much higher). This is also the best account I have ever read on this gory era. Chapter 10, "A New Order," discusses the long Suharto era, rising prosperity, near collapse and recovery. Chapter 11, "Indonesia Rising," covers the recent years, and is quite optimistic about the future of the country.Hannigan obviously really likes Indonesia and its people, but the book does not show much bias. He is objective about the mistakes of Sukarno and Suharto, including corruption, the orchestrated killings in 1965, the business in Timor and the difficulties in western New Guinea. The book perhaps necessarily focuses on Java and Sumatra, with not so much about Borneo or outer islands. There is a good deal about Bali.

I recommend this speaker even for those who do not need a sturdy waterproof speaker for outdoor use. I've been using it indoors, and I find the sound quality to be much better than that of my smaller portable speakers. It costs about twice as much as my smaller speakers, but given the sound quality, the long battery life, and the excellent protective casing, I think it is worth the cost.

This sturdy cable charged my iPhone 6 quickly, with no error message. The 6-inch length makes it easy to carry in the little bag that holds my phone, but it's a little too short for some of the places in which I like to charge my phone. As of this writing, the cost of this 6-inch cable is more than the cost of the same cable in a four foot length. That doesn't make sense to me.

I have been seeking an alternative to the Kirkland (Costco) crew T-shirts. Despite their sturdiness and comfort, my husband finds them too heavy for summer wear and also too bulky in a carry-on bag. These Fruit of the Loom T-shirts are perfect for those purposes. They are quite thin, and they probably won't last a long time, but if the price is right they can be an excellent choice for those wanting a light and comfortable undershirt. The soft fabric, longer length, and lack of a tag are all very nice features.

This can be a good file for large calluses, and possibly for some small ones, depending where on the foot they are. It is too large, however, for small calluses because it will end up removing too much non-callused skin. This is probably best for people with large rough patches on the heel. From the photos on the packaging, it looks like that is the intent.

These bags are sturdy and attractive. Because they are 100% cotton, they don't have the bad plastic smell that most synthetic bags have. My complaint is that the base of the bag is smaller than that of the standard grocery bag, which makes the bags less than ideal for grocery shopping. The description suggests using them for laptops, but because there is no padding and the top is open, they are not the ideal laptop bag either. Still, I think there are many other uses for this size of bag. I plan to use them as book bags.

I have gone through many vacuum cleaners, and I have rejected most of them due to heavy weight and difficult maneuvering. I finally settled on a Shark, which I was happy with until I tried this Eureka. Now I have a new favorite vacuum cleaner. This is cheaper than my Shark, and much more powerful. It sucked up more dirt than I thought could possibly exist in my carpet. Even though I am exceptionally weak, I found that this machine was light enough to carry up the stairs. Oh, and it was super easy to assemble. Quite frankly, I would have thought it was impossible to sell such a powerful and lightweight machine for such a low price. The only thing I can't vouch for is longevity, but I will include updates if there are any problems.

Joseph LeDoux makes it clear that Anxious is not intended to be a textbook, but in my opinion, it reads like a textbook. I don't mean this as a criticism, because I actually enjoy reading psychology textbooks. This book addresses history, philosophy, animal research, human research, and practice. It contains 130 pages of endnotes plus bibliography. It reads like a dissertation written by an extraordinarily thorough and conscientious author.Unfortunately, I can't recommend this book, either to the general public or to professionals. I think it tries to cover too much territory, and in too much detail. This level of breadth and depth might be acceptable if delivered in a compelling or easy-to-access manner, but I found this book to be very boring. It is written in academic language. Concepts that could be communicated in clear, simple English are sometimes obfuscated by turgid academic prose. (-;  I will not include quotes (as requested by the publisher) but suffice it to say that the book uses terms like "qualia" and "autonoetic," and "neurocomputational adaptations."  I think even academics might find themselves wishing for a more engaging delivery of the wealth of information contained in this book.

These packing cubes are sturdy and attractive, but I prefer the ones sold by Rick Steves which are all mesh, making them lighter and see-through. Best of all, they are priced at around $18 and they often go on sale.

I had never heard of Etgar Keret; I chose this book based on the glowing comments of writers I respect. After reading The Seven Good Years, I am now so in awe of this author that I can not find the words to adequately describe his writing. These concise essays are beautifully constructed, entertaining, and profound. Each little autobiographical essay felt like a jewel. Some brought me to tears. Almost every chapter is worth savoring and contemplating, but each is so good that it is hard not to keep reading. I think this book may earn a place on my desert island book list.

I really like this shampoo. I seek out shampoos without chemicals, and this line of shampoos gets a very good score on Environmental Working Group's Skin Deep database which rates beauty products based on the safety of the ingredients. The fact that it is organic makes it even better. And while I prefer unscented products, the strong pina colada scent is reminiscent of both the drink and of certain suntan lotions, so I enjoy the associations, if not the actual smell.Regardless of the safety of the ingredients and the smell, ultimately a good shampoo has to do a good job of cleaning hair and leaving it soft and manageable. I am very pleased with the results of using Natures Baby Organics Shampoo. I usually have to use a lot of conditioner in order to be able to get a comb through my hair, but this shampoo left my hair relatively untangled, so I was able to use less conditioner. My hair also felt very clean.I deducted one star for the high price, but I did notice that I could use a relatively small amount, so the ultimate cost per shampoo might not end up being too high. If cost is not a major factor, pineapple and coconut smells are not offensive to you, and safety and effectiveness are important, this shampoo is worth a try.

This is an attractive cover for a shower curtain, but it requires a waterproof liner, which must be purchased separately, to serve as an actual shower curtain. When it arrived, it had a bit of a synthetic odor, and I had to air it out for a few days before it was odor-free. I also noticed that the bottom is not finished. It is just cut, which gives it a bit of a raw look. As many others have mentioned, it can be easily shredded by cat claws, and is probably best in residences without cats. Despite these reservations, I think it is a reasonably priced and fairly attractive shower curtain cover for those who like the look of lace.

I have been using Pantene conditioners for many years, and this is almost identical to the one I normally use, which is for curly hair. My hair is very tangly, and I have found that Pantene is the only conditioner that efficiently removes tangles. For this reason, I continue to use it even though I try to avoid products that are loaded with chemicals. I periodically try conditioners that have more natural ingredients, but so far, I haven't found anything that is as effective as Pantene.

This is a large pan with a very good nonstick surface. Eggs slid easily out of the pan, and cleanup was a breeze. I think for the price it should include a lid. Also, I share the concern others have expressed about the warning to avoid very high heat because the pan can release fumes that are lethal to birds. In fairness, I think this is true of all nonstick pans, but the claim of being PFOA-free led me to hope that the coating is less toxic than teflon. It may be, but there is no way to know, since there is no information about what chemicals are in the pan.

This is an excellent series. I thought Season 2 was even better than Season 1. The various plot lines keep it interesting, and the acting is top notch. I would say this is good enough to pass as an HBO or Showtime series.

This book contains a collection of very short essays on various aspects of relationships under the headings Dating, Commitment, Breakups, Weddings, and Making it Last. Many of the couples described are people interviewed by the author as part of her job as a wedding reporter for the Washington Post, although she also interviews couples who have been together for many years. In addition to telling stories about a variety of couples, the author shares advice she gleaned from a small assortment of academic researchers who provide information on the factors that contribute to marital satisfaction and longevity. Finally, the author weaves in some of her own story, which doesn't really add much to the book, but which also isn't much of a distraction. Ellen McCarthy is a good writer, and the book is an easy read.I have been a couples therapist for many years, and I was evaluating this book to determine whether it provides useful information about how to choose a good partner and how to be a good partner. I think this book includes enough good advice to be worth recommending to women under 35 or so. I specify women because it seems to be directed to women, which makes sense because men seldom read books like this. I specify younger women because this book doesn't address most of the issues that middle-aged and older people have to deal with, and I think it might seem simplistic to some readers. It is imbued with the optimism, and perhaps some of the naivete, of a young, happily married woman. There is a lot of advice about choosing a partner, planning a wedding, dealing with disappointments, and making a marriage work. There is very little advice on breaking up (mostly just sympathy and encouragement), and almost nothing on divorce other than advice about how and why to avoid it. This is where the deficiencies of the book became clear to me. While I agree with all of the advice about how to make a marriage good, I disagree with her position that staying in a marriage is almost always preferable to ending it. She urges partners to lower expectations and "Accept As Is (Unless 'As Is' includes abuse or addiction.)"  But it's seldom that simple. Lowering expectations is helpful, to be sure, but I think most people would agree that abuse and addiction are not the only justifications for divorce.Despite the limitations of this book, I enjoyed reading it, and I think it offers some good suggestions for ways to make a marriage better. I plan to buy a copy for a newlywed in her 20s who I think will find it engaging and enlightening.

I somehow lost the microfiber pads for my well-used Shark steam mop, so I was pleased to discover I could order replacements. These are as good as the originals, and much cleaner than the ones I misplaced. (-:

I deeply appreciate the willingness of Henry Marsh to share his experiences as a neurosurgeon. While it is clear that neurosurgeons have to be extremely self-confident in order to do their work, it is the modesty of the author that makes this book so valuable. While he describes many complicated, and usually successful, surgeries, he is also willing to write about his failures, and his feelings about his failures. Woven throughout the book are descriptions of his frustrations with the British health care system in which he works. This provides a context that makes the accomplishments of doctors, and the endurance of patients, poignant as well as impressive. His writing style is modest, straightforward, and imbued with a gentle humor that makes the book very enjoyable to read, even when he is describing the details of removing a brain tumor.

There is magic in Kent Haruf's writing. I can't figure out how his spare style manages to be so deeply engaging and full of depth. I have not yet read his other books, but after reading this novella I am eager to read the previous works by this gifted author. Since the simple plot has already been described by other reviewers, I will not include a description other than to say that it is about an unconventional relationship between a widow and a widower who are neighbors. The book is full of many seemingly ordinary but compelling moments, as well as some interesting surprises. It is a small masterpiece. I am so sorry that it is his last book.

He had me at the preface. Here is the first paragraph (from the advanced reader's edition):"A Sea change is beginning to occur in the mental health system. An international movement to break down the boundaries among the different schools of psychotherapy to find common denominators is occurring. These common denominators are brain based. The new integrative model subsumes the relevant contributions of the past and discards the purely theory driven cul-de-sacs based only on the tight confines of a particular school."Here is the close of the first section of the preface:"This book attempts to normalize psychological disorders and their resolution so that you can explain and make more tangible recommendations to your clients. We must leave behind those countertrends that pathologize normal human reactions to life stressors."I do not know the author, and I have nothing to gain from this recommendation, but I think this book should be required reading for all therapists, from novices to experts. While it claims to focus on helping clients overcome resistance, I don't really see that as the focus, since a client doesn't have to be resistant to benefit from the interventions offered in the book. Unlike traditional therapy training, which usually focuses on a specific approach (psychodynamic, cognitive-behavioral, etc.), these interventions are based on neurobiological discoveries about the brain that were unknown when most of the popular psychological approaches were developed. Parts of the book are highly technical, with lots of scientific information about brain functioning, but this scientific information is accompanied by simple suggestions for interventions that can be easily explained to therapy clients. The book is peppered with little boxes labeled "Neuroscience" and "Client Education," so it is easy for the reader to quickly hone in on one or the other, although I found both very interesting. The text outside the boxes is a refreshing deviation from typical therapy texts because the author is not selling any particular approach. He is simply offering suggestions for explaining to clients the logic underlying change-oriented therapeutic interventions, based on what is known about how the brain works. This book should be valuable to any therapist, regardless of theoretical orientation, who respects science.

I am not a fan of historical fiction, but I am a huge fan of Elizabeth Berg's previous novels, so I couldn't resist reading her latest work. Like some other readers, I enjoyed the earlier part of the book more than the later part. I think Berg did an excellent job of portraying Sands' childhood, and I found many of the descriptions quite evocative. Reading about her life in the French countryside, I was reminded of how I felt watching the early seasons of Downton Abbey. I got a vivid sense of a life very different from anything we know now, and I felt almost transported to that time. I also really cared about the characters and I found them all interesting. As the book progressed, however, I found myself becoming detached in a way not unlike how I felt about the later seasons of Downton Abbey, when the plot had to change to accommodate the reality of various cast members deciding to leave the show. I found myself becoming less involved with the characters, and more aware that there was a writer pulling the strings. I felt the quality of the writing deteriorated. With the exception of Sands' one relationship with a woman, her affairs seemed boring and repetitive, and the writing about these relationships was much less compelling. Perhaps it was an accurate portrayal of Sands' lack of growth and insight, and her unconscious repetition of old patterns, or perhaps she just didn't prefer being with men. If either was true, maybe it was harder to write about these relationships in an emotionally gripping manner. Since I don't know what is historically accurate and what is the product of Berg's imagination, I don't have any insight into the reasons for this change in tone. For all I know, it might have been a book deadline. All I can say is that the latter part of the book did not engage me as much as the earlier part. I might have stopped reading, but I kept looking forward to the introduction of Frederick Chopin. I was ultimately disappointed at how little of the book was devoted to that relationship, but perhaps he just wasn't as major a figure in her life as I thought he was. Since this is historical fiction, there is no way to know what is factual without doing some research. But as a result of reading this book, I am left with no interest in George Sand.

It's hard to rate this first aid kit because I got it for free, and there is currently no price information available on Amazon. The basic issue with all first aid kits is whether one can assemble a better one for much less money than it costs to get one that is pre-assembled. This is an individual decision, but it can't be made without knowing the price.What I can say is that I do like it better than my other first aid kit because it includes scissors, which are nice to have. I tried the bandages, and they are fine. This seems like a good kit to keep in the car or in the office. Again, it all comes down to price.

This is a very powerful vacuum with a nice detachable unit for doing carpeted stairs, but it is way too heavy for me to use, even in a small area. I also find it very awkward to maneuver. I am surprised that a relatively compact vacuum cleaner is so cumbersome to use. I do not recommend it.Update: The beater stopped working twice. The first time I took it to a shop for repair. The second time I decided it wasn't worth trying to fix.

For those who like a retro look, this audio system is an attractive, albeit overpriced device. The sound is pretty good, but not great. I can't evaluate the radio reception because we have pretty poor radio reception in our area, and this device didn't pick up any stations. The controls are not all intuitive, at least not to me.

These are my favorite shoes. They are beautiful and extraordinarily comfortable. My feet are very odd, with high arches, wide toe box, and a narrow heel. Aside from my Brooks Addiction running shoes, these are the only shoes I own that never hurt.

In my opinion, the key to essentialism is knowing your core values and goals, and then pruning away everything that does not support what is most important to you. This allows you to focus your efforts on what matters most. While this book does a good job of preaching essentialism, it is not a good example of putting this practice to use. It could benefit from better editing and organization. It reads more like a collection of blog posts than a coherent, well-organized articulation of essentialism in theory and practice.That said, the brief chapters, seemingly designed for the busy business reader, offer good examples of how to reduce wasted time and effort. There are lots of good suggestions about how to narrow your focus and devote your efforts to top work priorities. There is also occasional mention of considering priorities other than maximizing work success, although work is clearly the primary focus of the book.I don't think this book has much to offer to people who already grasp the basic concept of focusing on what's important and eliminating the distractions. It also isn't the ideal book for people who have priorities that trump (no pun intended) business success. But for readers who want to maximize their productivity, and who are distracted by external forces, this book might inspire a useful shift of focus.Note: I recommended this book to one of my clients, a young woman who wants to succeed in business. She found it extremely helpful, and she told me she has recommended it to friends. So I guess it's just important to match the product with the right consumer.

This is a very attractive guidebook, with a variety of photos, illustrations, and maps. I have not yet been to Rome, so I can't evaluate the accuracy, but it seems like a good book to carry around while touring the city. In comparing it with other popular Rome guidebooks, I would say it falls between the Eyewitness Guides and the Rick Steves guides. It is less beautiful than the Eyewitness Guide, but, if my other Eyewitness books are any indication, it is much lighter, which is a plus when carrying it around all day. It is much more beautiful than the Rick Steves guide, but it does not have nearly as much practical information. (I would never visit anywhere in Europe with my trusty Rick Steves tour book.) This book includes a small assortment of "insider tips," and "off the beaten path" excursions, but most of what I read seems pretty conventional, which is fine for someone who has not yet seen the major sights. There is a subway map inside the back cover, and a street map inside the front one. Both covers have flaps for marking a place in the book. The photographs are helpful in deciding what sights to see, and they make good souvenirs after the the trip is just a memory. I have a feeling that this book will make a round trip with me when I visit Rome.
This was recommended by my physical therapist, and I really love it. When I am wearing the belt I can be much more active without harming my SI joint. I highly recommend this for anyone with SI pain.

Although I agree that they tend to run a bit small, and they aren't very warm, these gloves are great for touchscreen operations. Since I have very cold hands, I sometimes use these gloves as liners underneath heavier gloves or mittens. This allows me to remove the heavier glove when I need to use the touchscreen, but still have some protection against the cold. I also think the gloves are fairly attractive, although they are probably more suitable for women than men since they are a bit sparkly. One caution: when they touch velcro, they stick like glue, and I have to carefully remove the gloves from the velcro so I don't harm the gloves. That said, I still think it is a good product, and I would recommend it to others.

I have been using Cetaphil every since a dermatologist recommended it many years ago. I love that it is odorless and really easy on sensitive skin. I was hoping that these would be individually wrapped, which would make it easy to tuck a few into every purse and travel bag. Instead, the packaging is more like what I've seen with baby wipes. All the cloths are in one compartment, which means they all travel together. I suppose that wouldn't be a problem for a lot of people, but I don't tend to have room for something this big in the bags I carry. Still, I am giving this a high rating because I think Cetaphil is a great product, and I think I will find a use for these pre-treated cleaning cloths. I just haven't figured out exactly what.

I had read that Krill Oil was a good alternative to fish oil, and I was impressed that this product had been independently analyzed.Unfortunately, one whiff of the odor emanating from the container was enough to convince me that I could never swallow something that smelled so bad. I see that others have had no problem with the smell, so obviously it depends on olfactory sensitivity and personal preference, but I could not tolerate the strong odor.

I've never bought an inverter before, so this is my first one. I needed it to run my laptop in the car on a round trip 20 hour car drive. This ran flawlessly for 20 hours.There is some light fan noise, which would be noticeable in a quiet environment. In a car, you would NEVER hear it.The cord is short, but it's easy to find an extension DC cord.I like this guy a lot.

This product is NOT natively supported by Win 7 or 8. It requires special drivers and install instructions from the manufacturers website.There is a NEWER version of this (GlobalSat BU-353-S4 USB GPS Receiver (Black)) that is native.This does, however, work perfectly once it's installed. I had no issues. I wish I had known about the newer version though.

Ordered this to keep in my garage at home. It's a good medium sized extinguisher that will work on all types of fires. It comes with everything you could want in the box: mounting hook, fire extinguisher sticker sign with arrow, testing record, and instructions. No need to order or buy anything additional.I'm a fan.

This was required by my nursing school. I have never ever ever had a problem with math. I like math and I'm good at it. This program will make sure you know the math (it doesn't teach it, but if you don't know it... you'll need to learn).The problem is: You spend more time figuring out how it wants you to type in your answers than actually learning. It's a picky program. I wrote down all my answers on paper for the tests, figured out which ones were wrong, and had to go back and reformat my answers until it accepted them.

I've been putting off spending the money on a battery backup UPS for quite some time. I have a rack with 3 servers running my home and small business network. My web hosting is provided by a 3rd party so my servers aren't mission critical and I didn't want to dump $350+ on a battery backup.This spring we've been having power issues (bad for computers obviously) and I took the dive to protect my hardware.I rack mounted this heavy UPS in under 10 minutes and got things switched over. It has 2 battery packs, each supporting 4 outlets on the back of the unit. Distribute your devices across the outlets so not all are on one side.Con: I connected the UPS to my server, originally using the included serial cable. My Windows Server 2012 R2 system did not detect the battery backup. I did not troubleshoot further. May have been driver related. Nothing was seen in Device Manager.Pro: When connected via included USB cable the system recognized the UPS immediately. No installation issues.Con: There is only 1 USB port. To the best of my knowledge (maybe over the network?) there is no way to shut down multiple servers connected to the one UPS. Maybe best practice is one UPS per server? There is no network connectivity for the UPS so if there is a network shutdown it's got to be done some other way.Pro: The software is now Windows Server 2012 certified and has been working without issue. There are tons of options, few of which I've tinkered with so far.Con: Runtime is 8min with 3 servers connected. Power draw is a total of 280 watts from the 3 servers.Pro: Run time is a whole 8 min! Not bad if you're dealing with short power outages or just waiting for a standby generator to kick in.Con: This isn't true sinewave power. I doubt that the simulated sinewave does much for you.Pro: Costs a lot less than a sinewave supply!Con: costs more than a desktop UPS.Pro: It can be rackmounted OR used on the desk. The desk brackets are very sturdy. Everything that came in the box is quality. It all feels heavy duty and was packaged very well.Summary: For my non-mission critical (and probably for most people's mission critical) needs this is an excellent value. It's affordable and a quality product. It doesn't have every bells or whistle, but it's got most of them. There may still be some hiccups in the software, but at least the software is new and up to date with current operating systems like Server 2012. I'm a big fan of knowing my server hardware is now safe (as it should have been years ago if it weren't for my stinginess).Doug BuchanBuchan Consulting LLCIT Consultant

I used this as part of my 2010 aftermarket stereo installation. Easy to use and completely functional. The wires are well labeled, easy to strip, and easy to twist. I can't think of any issues with it.Doug

This product is a good fit for the '10 CR-V that I installed it in. I replaced the head unit with a bluetooth capable unit and used this cradle kit to get it to fit.The kit is easy to install (took about 20min). I didn't damage any OEM parts in the removal. The Metra kit went in well. It's not as sturdy as OEM, but it's good. If you bend the metal brackets that come with the DIN unit into place, you'll get a pretty solid unit.This is the 4th Metra unit I've installed and all are functioning well still.DougBuchan Consulting LLC

It's been years since I've watched this, and it was on TV. Watching it with all the profanity and shenanigans added in is really worthwhile. It's a cast of real winners and a story line as funny as the actors. It'll probably be a while before I watch it again. But it truly is a classic.

I spent a lot of time debating whether or not to invest in Tstak vs Toughbox vs none of the above. When I went about upgrading my DeWalt line to the 20V MAX line of tools I purposely bought the full kits. Not only because I needed the batteries but I wanted the hard kit boxes that come with them. I figured I wanted protection for my tools so every one should have a kit box.As I accumulated more and more tools I realized I was making 4 or 5 trips out to the car every time I needed to load up for a job. This got old quick (5 trips from house to car, 5 trips to unload at job, 5 trips to re-load, 5 trips to unload at house). So I started looking at Tstak and Toughbox systems from DeWalt. I liked my kit boxes because I could grab JUST my drill or JUST my saw and head out the door. The Toughbox system seems large and cumbersome to use. The wide dolly would have its advantages but I thought the bulk of it in my Honda CR-V would not be a great plan. I also discovered that DeWalt is releasing a Tstak Dolly the first quarter of 2014. So I figured I have upgrade potential in the future if I want a dolly.SO I PICKED Tstak. I love it. The base is sturdy with no wobble in the wheels. It's not meant for job sites outdoors in the dirt or mud. So know that ahead of time. But I can roll it over paved terrain or indoors smooth and silent. It's easy to stack boxes on and to move around as well as detach for the car.The DeWalt Tstak system has been excellent for consolidating my tools into kits, putting the accessories with the tools, and getting them from A to B and back again with far less hassle.Strong work DeWalt.Doug BuchanBuchan Consulting LLC

I'm loving my DeWalt 20V MAX Oscillating Multi-Tool. It's a great tool with awesome accessories! I bought two packs of this sandpaper for drywall and wood sanding.The sandpaper work GREAT on flat surfaces. That's probably 90% of the use cases for most jobs.My only complaint, and it's a cross-complaint between the sandpaper and the hook & loop pad they attach to, is that on rounded surfaces the edges wear down very quickly and damage the pad. So I was sanding a hole in a wood board to smooth the inside edges of the hole. As I sanded around the inside of the hole, which of course forces you to sand on an angle, the side of the sandpaper really wore down fast because that was the only part in contact with the wood. What I didn't realize until it was too late was that I was also ruining the hook & loop attachment pad as well as the sand paper.So while I shouldn't expect a product to do something that it probably shouldn't do, like sand un-even surfaces, I'm still docking 1 star for it. Use it for what it's meant for, flat surfaces, and you're good to go!Doug Buchan[...]

Simple and effective. This wood cutting blade is great for wood and drywall. It's easy to put on my new favorite tool, the DeWalt 20V Oscillating Multi-tool. Once it's on it's a breeze to use. It cuts drywall like butter. Wood may or may not take a little more work depending on thickness and type of wood, but the cutting is consistent. Keep in mind, it's not replacing a reciprocating or circular saw necessarily, it's more for detail work. But it works well for that.The flat aspect of the blade is great for lining up flush cuts. Plunge cutting is great.Really love the tool and the blades.Doug Buchan[...]

I became a vendor for Ooma Office when the system was first revealed. Theoretically it sounded great. Heck, their old pricing structure was certainly affordable. But from the time I got my Ooma (which yes, even as a vendor I had to pay for), things went downhill fast.Pros:-Costs less than some VOIP /IP /POE phones.-Allows you to use your existing "normal" non-IP phones.-Yup, that's about it.Cons:- Changed their pricing structure within months of launch. It WAS $19.99/mo per phone line. Extensions were free. So for my small business I wanted 3 or 4 extensions but only needed 2 phone lines. That's pretty affordable. NOT ANYMORE.
