After all, I really don't do anything but sit through a professionally conducted show, and nobody misses me if I don't show up.Thankfully, the folks who brought us the Holman Christian Standard Bible have fixed an error that seems to have been made in every English translation up to now. They've inserted the word "worship" in Hebrews 10:25, so now it reads..."not staying away from our worship meetings, as some habitually do, but encouraging each other, and all the more as you see the day drawing near."No other translation I've ever seen has the word "worship" there, and now preachers everywhere can put this on a big powerpoint slide and say to their congregations something like "ya, you say you don't like church, but the Bible says [insert condescending exhortation here]". (That's how I found out about this new "translation")  Now that's the kind of Bible scholarship we need!Thanks to the HCSB, the "Christian standard" corporate meeting is now canon! Now I know where I'm supposed to go every Sunday, and why!  I see a lot of PowerPoint slides with scripture-bytes and Twila Paris in my future.

That's about what the quality of the print is, but the show shines through anyway.  I wasn't much of a fan back then since I was a child and way to young to appreciate this show, but I did remember the infectiously cute theme song almost note-for-note since watching it on TV back then.It just made me sad that I'm finally grown-up enough to appreciate how brilliant this show was, but I have to watch it like through a rainy day window, not on a sharp and crisp 13" Hitachi portable color TV like I had access to back then.And let's not just heap blame on Shout for this.  Perhaps the original prints weren't stored properly, or they were lost or thrown away.  Perhaps this really is a Beta-max video tape transferred to disk.  Who knows.  Shout has brought some great stuff from the sixties and seventies back, and let's be glad they did at all.

It's not cast in sun.  It's cast in plastic.  And nothing puts the bummer in summer faster than a hosed hose cart.This may be great if you have just a little, lightweight hose and a small yard.  I have a heavy, high quality hose of about fifty feet (far shorter than the supposed 225 foot capacity of one of these) and over time the stress of just that hose was too much for a plastic piece-of-carp hose cart.  Mine just slowly came apart.  And, those little look-like-rubber-but-are-really-molded-plastic wheels do not make this cart easy to move.  I decided to take mine to the dump (now that it's fallen apart) and pony up and get a hose cart that is made of metal.  Should have done that at first.

That's really all I ask: to be able to put a two dollar frozen pizza in a toaster oven, set the temperature and time, walk away, and when I hear the buzzer pull it out evenly cooked so I can split it in half and feed each of my kids dinner for a buck and then let them go back to "screen time".  This toaster oven does the job.  It's the fourth one our family has owned.  I just hope it keeps working for a year or two.  Nice going Hamilton Beach Division of Chinese Small Appliance Manufacturing Inc.

The artwork and drawings are great, but the instructions -- though verbose -- lack a complete and explicit example of an entire round (or "day" or whatever) of gameplay.  Also, I watched the half-hour video by the games creators, and it was not complete either.  The did not show the "drafting" stage but rather just talked about it, so I still haven't seen how this works, so after reading the instructions and watching a half-hour video, I still don't know precisely how to play the game.What I do know is that there are a myriad of different combinations of point scoring possible, and that one must continually be counting and recounting points with every card played, and many cards can be played per meal (or "round" to translate to normal-card-game-speak).  To make matters worse, many of the cards' unique instructions are not precise about what they are supposed to do, as I learned through watching the video.  Did the creators of this game bother to test it on people who don't work for their own company?This is just like true geeks, so self-absorbed with their own cleverness and creativity that they cannot perceive any need to put themselves in the place of someone who doesn't already know what they know and start from the very beginning.  Nice puns and artwork, but a tedious game most suited to accountants who love food.Thankfully my son and I dumbed the game down a bit (removed some complexity) so that we created a fun version for ourselves to play without so much counting and recounting of points with every card played.  So, my son had a fun time and wants to play again.  I've given up on ever determining what the game's creators ever really intended.

I just played this game last night with my nine-year-old son.  We both had a great time.  I'm not going to duplicate what other have already written, but I will say that this game combines just enought strategy, randomness, and action to be genuinely fun without becoming tedious.  Perhaps not the most addictive game my son or I have played, but I have a feeling we'll be visiting the Forbidden Island again soon, and hopefully with more family members.

First of all, congratulations to the design team that finished the job on the venerable apple slicer.  The plastic piece that you push after you flip over the slicer really does push the apple out of the slicer.  Amazing it took so long for someone to figure this out.That said, there are two design flaws that may haunt you after you get over that giddy feeling of total apple slicing control.  First, the slicing blades are made of sheet metal that are folded in at the "core" of the slicer, creating numerous small openings for apple particles to lodge in ways that are very difficult to clean, except with a toothbrush.  Second the little corners of the slicing blades are exposed around the outer perimeter of the metal slicing assembly.  They are very sharp.  If this utensil is grabbed the wrong way, perhaps out of a sink full of dirty dishes, the potential for a nasty cut is there and could easily happen in my opinion.  Pictures of these design flaws will show up if you select to "view and share related images."So, just after the return expiration window has passed I'm throwing it out.  Bummer.

I could have seen them live, once for about a hundred bucks a ticket not too long ago, but now I get to see essentially what they were on that recent tour for about sixteen bucks and I can see it over and over again.  There's a lot of music here, and the sound quality is good, but it sort of makes me sad to see them now compared to what they were even ten or so years ago.  That's life I suppose.  I would have added another star if this DVD concert wasn't peppered with so much carp off their most recent "Funplex" release which I really don't like.  The price is right, however, and the classics are here.Now to drag my own over-50 body over to the treadmill,light up the monitor, and crank this thing up.

I just wanted to speed up a one-time-only job, not invest in another "system" with all the proprietary power supply, sand paper cut-outs, etc.  Seems well made, but overkill for me (should have read all the notes) so I'm sending it back.  If you do not already have a Proxxon power supply transformer, you will be unable to use this product.  Guess it's back to elbow-grease sanding for me.

First, decide which media device you want to watch these episodes on.  If you want to watch them on your computer, you get the view-on-demand option that lets you watch on your computer -- but not your TV of course (unless you can run a cable from your computer to your TV) -- or you can get the "burn on demand" option here that lets you watch on your consumer electronic DVD player but NOT on your computer.  Seems like a scheme the gophers would come up with.My kids love this show, and do their "screen time" on the computer, so there's really no need for this.  If you are a dedicated consumer electronic DVD player person, then these work, but it looks like there are no special features.  Just be sure of what you're buying before you click "buy".

What's going on?  Why should I care about these characters?  Then I found myself asking why I even care how it ends.  Seriously, try to see this movie without any additional incremental out-of-pocket expenses before you plunk down real money and take up valuable DVD shelf space.

I bought this rack for temporary use.  I have a large collection of home made VHS tapes that need to be digitized or thrown away, and this rack looks good, is safe with the wide feed at the bottom, and holds DVDs and VHS tapes well.  It was easy to assemble, and it came in black wood.  I am rather amazed that a product like this can be manufactured and shipped to me at such a price.

It seems that these aquarium ornaments are made for people to look at and not for fish to live with.  There were so many sharp, jagged little areas on this ornament that I ended up having to extensively sand it just to get rid of those areas because I was afraid of what would happen to a fish that swam too close the wrong way or too quickly.  Well, the snails have something else to crawl on at least.

I own a powerful Ryobi dual string trimmer that can bring down a small jungle, but maintaining the spool and the string is a nightmare, so I bought this simple little trimmer thinking I could use it for a quick trim around my grass.It's not quick!  It's underpowered and the cutting swath is about two inches less than I really need.  It got the job done, but I didn't save any time, and in the long run that means I didn't save any money.  The only thing saves were the lives of weeds.This is great if you've got a little postage stamp lawn with wimply little grass that just gets out of line on occasion and you have to trim it back.  If you have any serious crabgrass you need to get under control, forget it and buy a real weed whacker.

This review is for the Algae block not the grazing block.  The Algae block package has a catfish on it, but my catfish didn't eat this stuff.  The adult and fry mollies ate it; the snails loved it, but the critter I was trying to get to eat passed it up.
Not much more to say than that, but if you think you're getting some American craftsmanship for your well-over-200-bucks you'll likely have another thing coming.

I had some experience with web design and Dreamweaver some 10-12 years ago, and needed to refresh my knowledge and bring it up to date when it comes to HTML5 and use of CSS. There are two major books on the current version of Dreamweaver, "The Missing Manual" and this one. I read both. I found some advantages and disadvantages in both, but overall I found that "The Missing Manual" is superior and is a better value for time and money.The Murach's book has a great idea behind it: it is written concisely, but not excessively so. It is half way between a tutorial and a reference book. There is always a page-long explanation of the subject on the left-hand side and screenshots with a brief summary on the right-hand side, sometimes with extra details. So you end up reading about the subject and then reading the summary one more time. I found it is a great way to memorize the material. There is an effort to provide details which are important and useful in practice (one example is a brief but clear explanation how to make a drop-down menu with CSS). At the end of each chapter, there is a list of keywords which were introduced and a relatively short exercise. Exercise files can be downloaded from the internet.The book does not go as deeply into details as "The Unofficial Manual", and it is not quite as targeted at readers at lower level. There are some things which are covered in "The Unofficial Manual" and not covered in the Murach's. There are subjects which Murach's explains better, largely because Murach's always has to explain each subject on one page or less.  The Murach's book requires a higher level of knowledge of HTML and CSS than "The Unofficial Manual", maybe on low intermediate level. The Missing Manual is accessible to anyone, including beginners.It is easier to use the Murach's book as a reference than The Missing Manual because it has a more transparent structure, which everything broken into small sections, 2 pages each, and table of contents is very detailed and specific.Unfortunately, the execution did not quite follow the idea. The editing job of the book is positively not up to the mark. To begin with, this book was written about the earlier version of CC,and then updated to CC2014. This versions have differences in user interface, e.g., different buttons, etc. However, many screenshots were not updated, and text oftentimes refers to the older version of  Dreamweaver. The result - you look at your screen, do not see what you are supposed to see, and have to figure it out, somehow.  The editor clearly started "running out of steam" (or out of time) by the time he or she reached the second half of the book because instructions in tutorials become increasingly unclear and when you follow them, nothing works. Depending your your mindset, you can either consider this a challenge and figure it out yourself, or just get frustrated and call it a poor editing work.Likewise, references to resources outside of Dreamweaver are oftentimes outdated. For example, reference to Adobe's Business Catalyst should not be there because Adobe discontinued that service quite a while ago. Several references to third party applications are also dated and probably migrated into this version of the book from versions prior to CC.The bottom line, both of these books are good and in many aspects complement each other. It is good to read both. However, I would rate The Missing Manual 5 starts, and Murach's 4 stars. If I had to chose which book to buy and could buy only one, I would buy The Missing Manual.The last comment: at the time of this writing (June 2015), Dreamweaver CC 2015 has been announced. It is not a major update, but there are quite a few changes and improvements, including changes to user interface and fluid grid design. We should expect that both of these books will be updated by the end of summer to cover CC 2015. Hopefully, Murach's will be better edited in the new revision.

People not familiar with the various Festool dust extractors may get confused what this extractor is and what it is for. It is designed primarily to be used with Festool drywall sander, the Planex. It is the only Festool dust extractor which is not HEPA certified. In its standard mode of operation, it is used with 1 micron filter and without a dust collection bag (because the bag can get clogged with the drywall dust). Instead, one uses a plastic liner (which costs the same as the bag; it is a plastic bag shaped as the dust bag, but open at the top). Auto-clean mechanism shakes the dust off the 1 micron filter and into the liner every few seconds. The cleaning mechanism is not just mechanical shaking of the filter, it is some tricky way of creating differential pressure which creates a shock wave through the whole vacuum, but it works just the same. While one can in theory use regular dust extractors for small jobs with hand sanders, the amount of nasty drywall dust which can be created by the Planex is too high for a regular dust extractor to cope with and requires this extractor. If one uses a regular dust extractor, its bag may get clogged too soon, plus small dust particles may clog and "kill" the pricey HEPA filter.With some additional investments, one can use this vacuum as a regular dust extractor for woodworking, just as any other Festool extractor. Bags from a regular, non-autoclean CT36 fit (by the way, one even gets one bag with the new CT 36 AC). One can swap the included 1 um filter with a HEPA filter from CT36 (they are exactly the same size) to improve small dust collection efficiency (but this would not make the vacuum HEPA certified for lead mitigation jobs; it probably would pass the certification, but Festool has not gotten it tested and certified this way). Finally, the vacuum hose which comes with CT36-AC is specifically designed for the planex (has a locking ring at its end) and will not work with the handtools which require hose end to slide into the dust port. It would work with some tools which require a hose to slide OVER the dust port. So you will likely need a new hose. Any Festool hose would plug into this extractor.  Once you get this all, you can turn the autoclean off (it cannot be used with a HEPA filter, and does not need to be used with the bag), and you will end up with a regular dust extractor which works exactly as CT-36 (minus formal HEPA certification).Due to a difference in price compared to a regular CT 36, it makes sense to buy this vacuum ONLY if you own a drywall sander, or plan to buy one in a not-so-distant future. CT 36 AC has no extra features, other than drywall dust autoclean, which would make it more beneficial or more economical for regular woodworking. In contrast, it lacks some accessories required or beneficial for woodworking (see the list above).Finally, size-wise, CT-36 is quite large. In my mind, it may make sense to use such large extractor only in a professional workshop. For home use, it is too large, in my opinion. It has exactly the same suction as a smaller CT-26, and almost the same suction as the compact and handy MIDI. It just has a much larger dust container, but bags for it are also more expensive, so it is only the matter of how often one needs to swap bags. No real cost savings coming from the size. In Europe, one can get CT 26 AC, but in the North America we are not blessed with a smaller/cheaper extractor with the autoclean feature.I own a MIDI, two CT-26, and a CT 36 AC. Once I am done with my home remodeling project, I will probably sell the Planex along with CT 36 AC and will buy another MIDI instead. With Planex, however, it is invaluable and, as reported by professional drywall contractors on various forums, is very robust and efficient for what it was designed for.

These stretches are nothing like what you have seen before. They only look similar to what you know as stretches.In order to understand the purpose, meaning, and value of these stretches, you should look at this book in a historic perspective. The author, Bob Cooley (B.C.), was unfortunate to get into a major accident which lead to a long path of recovery and regaining flexibility limited by consequences of the trauma. In the book, he describes his path of exploration of stretches and their relationships to the Chinese medicine, yoga, and spiritual world. This is an evolving knowledge. At the time when the book was written, B.C. knew from his personal experience and experience of his clients that his stretches work, but he could not quite explain why. In the 10+ years since this book was written, the understanding of what they do and why they work has increased significantly. His web site contains more details on this and (for a fee) offers access to videos with (at the time of this writing) of 197 stretches (compared to 36 stretches described in the book). The book is a great introduction but not the complete story.HOW THESE STRETCHES ARE DIFFERENT. B.C.'s stretches are not something that you likely saw before. They are resistance stretches. In order to achieve a resistance stretch, you go through the range of motion of a fully tensioned (contracted) muscle. For example, if you wanted to stretch your biceps, you would bend your arm in the elbow (all the way, to the position with the wrist almost touching your shoulder), would tension your biceps as hard as you can (as if you wanted to bend your arm in the elbow even more), and would use your other hand (or an assistant) to gradually and slowly extend your biceps against its resistance. You do not need to go to the fully extended position, and you never reach the condition of the "pull" on the fully extended muscle known from traditional stretches. It is not about reaching the limit of the muscle's range of motion or pulling the muscle to make it longer, it is about creating a lot of tension within the muscle within its comfortable range and stretching this contracted muscle against its resistance. As an added benefit, you can combine stretching with strength training as you contract a muscle and counteract this force at the same time.HOW DO THESE STRETCHES WORK. This was not covered in the book, but is discussed on B.C.'s web site. The trick is in the part of our body known as "dense fascia". This notion was totally unknown in the world of fitness and exercise until some 6-8 years ago. Now, there are even annual international symposia on fascia, and many training schools known as "fascia stretching" or "facial stretching". Just Google for them. Fascia is a connecting tissue which forms a network in our body which also envelopes our muscles. It is strong and flexible and it is an important part of our body which keeps it connected and strong. Fascia has many forms and "faces" and is a very complex medical / anatomy subject. For the purpose of stretching, dense fascia formed within our muscles is important. As we age and as we accumulate consequences of microtraumas, overuse, and injuries, deep fascia starts growing between the fibers of our muscles. It prevents the fibers from sliding freely along each other and both, reduces the length of the muscles, and reduces their ability to contract. This leads to a reduced flexibility. This type of fascia has no sensitivity associated with it. It is also much stronger than our muscle tissue and very hard to stretch. When we put our body (e.g., leg) in a stretch position, reach the limit of the range of motion, but feel no usual "pull" sensation in any muscle as we try to go further, it means that this motion is limited by dense fascia. When we have asymmetries in flexibility in our body, there is also a good chance that a past injury to a certain muscle resulted in preferential growth of dense facia in one muscle of muscle group on one side of our body. Traditional stretches will fail because dense fascia is too strong to be stretched by traditional means. In fact, it is 2 to 8 times stronger than the muscle fibers (which traditional stretching techniques focus on). Resistance stretches use the huge strain inside of the contracted muscle while it is stretched and extended against its resistance to dislodge and break apart this detrimental dense fascia and get rid of the scar tissue. Traditional stretches do not work against dense fascia (and consequently do not work at all if you are limited by dense fascia) because the stretching force which can be safely used in traditional stretches of relaxed muscles is not sufficient to break apart the dense fascia in your muscle. You can pull strong enough only when you contract your muscle.While dense fascia can grow anywhere and can affect any of our muscles, our legs (especially upper legs) tend to accumulate the most of dense fascia.  This is why lower back and legs, especially in people past their teen-age or after minor or major injuries, could greatly improve in flexibility when resistance stretches are used.The only other way to reduce tissue density and affect fascia (that I know of) is foam rolling. Dean Somerset has excellent lectures on how fascia impacts our mobility and how to handle fascia related issues through form rolling.HOW THESE STRETCHES ARE SIMILAR TO OTHER TECHNIQUES. Only visually. Yoga exists for thousands of years, and Yoga asanas evolved to put our body in a position which enables us to maximally elongate certain muscles along their path from contracted to extended. Traditional stretching drills overlap with many yoga poses. B.C.'s stretches oftentimes use same or similar positions, but the action is completely opposite to what you would do in Yoga. Also, complex Yoga asanas are not used in B.C. techniques. Many yoga poses put you in a position in which you just can't contract your muscles enough, which contradicts the idea of resistance stretching. Most beginner and intermediate stretches are easy enough for everyone.ASSISTED STRETCHES. The book has a total of 36 stretches. The web site has a total of 197 stretches, 31 of which are assisted. In regular stretching, assisted stretches are risky because the muscles are held at their extension limit and too much pull from the assistant (who has no immediate feedback and do you feel the level of pain in your muscles) may lead to injury. With resistance stretching, the muscles are not extended to their limit, the majority of stretch happens in the beginning when muscle is contracted, and assistance is safe. Your assistant only exerts force when you resist and he feels how much you resist. Since assisted stretches enable one to generate more tension in the muscle than you can do on your own, they are considered very efficient. However, there are plenty of stretches (the majority of them) which one can do on his own.  Out of 197 stretches on thegeniusofflexibility web site, only 16% are assisted.CONNECTION TO THE EMOTIONAL WORLD. B.C. discovered that when he gets his muscles through their range of motion in fully tensioned condition, the energy dissipated in the muscle and the effort creates effect similar to point massage or acupuncture. It stimulates the energy meridians known for thousands of years from traditional Chines medicine. The effect is even greater than in Yoga or traditional stretches. While it is not the ultimate purpose (flexibility is), B.C. wants his students to be aware of these connections. He personally values them so much that he even groups the stretches not by the muscles which they stretch but by the associated energy meridians. The first thing which I experienced when I started doing his energy series was not the flexibility change but immediate and remarkably pronounced reduction of craving for food and sugars and weight loss. I did not believe any of this emotional/mental stuff, and was shocked to find out that it actually worked.The idea that stretches can affect energy meridians is not entirely new. For example, Shiatsu uses massage and stretches (some of which match stretches in B.C.'s system) to stimulate points along the energy meridians to affect health condition and well being of a person who is not medically sick yet, but out of balance, energetically speaking.WHAT DOES THE TITLE MEAN? "The genius of flexibility" is not the name which B.C. calls himself (and it is not his picture on the front page), despite the impression which some of the reviewers of this book who flipped though the pages think. B.C. associated 16 energy meridians with certain personality types, certain traits of character, which are present in different degree in all people and can be developed. He calls these types of character "geniuses". Since resistance stretches provide a way to impact all of them to a certain degree, by helping our body to develop the desirable features, he puts flexibility sort of on top of this system, as a unifying factor, and calls it the 17th genius, "the genius of flexibility". This is a reference to our ability to be flexible.COMMON MISUNDERSTANDINGS. You need to read the book carefully and, if you can, watch the videos on the web site to understand how these stretches work. You do not go to the end of range of your muscles. You do not feel the usual "pull" on the muscles. But you need to generate as much tension in your muscle during the stretch as you can. It is difficult to achieve on first attempt. You've got to continue practicing the stretches for at least a couple of weeks to get the feeling of what developing this full tension means. It is not difficult, it just totally opposite to the traditional idea of stretches in which one needs to relax the muscle instead of contracting it as hard as one can. The harder you contact and the stronger is the resistance, the more efficient is the stretch.  It is very easy to do the wrong thing (or rather not do what you are supposed to do) if you try any of B.C.;s stretches without knowing what you need to do, or if you apply your "standard" understanding how stretches work and just go through the range without resistance.Some people dismiss this school because B.C. claims that stretches could cure certain health conditions. There is some truth in it, but only partial. Resistance stretches can cure to the same extent as acupuncture or point massage can. It is the same as homeopathy. It may be able to help with some persistent but not life threatening conditions which are annoyance to you. But it does not replace medical treatment in serious situations. B.C. claims that he was able to stop development of appendicitis and avoided surgery. This was his personal experience, he does not push it on other people and does not promote in the book that everyone should do stretches instead of going to a doctor.SIMILAR SCHOOLS AND SOURCE OF INFORMATION. "Fascia stretching", "Facial stretching", and "Resistance Stretching" mean more or less the same thing (or at least the same basic idea), and it is a quickly developing way of thinking about stretching. Still a minority, but growing rapidly. You can get on Amazon two DVDs with Dara Torres who is B.C.'s student and follows his school. I watched the first DVD in that series, it has a good explanation on how the stretches should be done. You can also find some videos on the internet using these key words. These videos may be of certain value. However, B.C. remains the "father" of this stretching technique, with more experience than anyone else. As I mentioned before, there are connections to traditional Chinese medicine and shiatsu when it comes to energy meridians.SHOULD I USE IT? I got the impression that it is a great addition to any stretching routine. If you are limited by dense fascia, no traditional stretching will help you. This is the best source of information available. In contrast, if you do not have too much dense fascia related mobility restrictions (which especially applies to younger people), you may find that yoga or traditional stretching is as efficient or (I think but do not know for sure) maybe even more efficient. By any means, this book is about a unique stretching method which can be complementary to anything else that you are doing, but does not overlap with or duplicate any of these traditional stretching methods.OVERALL OPINION AND SOME WEAKNESSES OF THE BOOK. It is a very honestly and personally written book. A very interesting read on its own. Quite inspiring.  Plenty of "food for thought". Makes you think about a bigger picture. Worth a read regardless of whether you will use these stretches or not.It is has some weaknesses, either real or conceived. Many people, myself included, get the impression that personal views on life and emotional impact of stretches and the model of 16 meridians / geniuses overshadow the discussion of basics (stretches). B.C. could've described the stretches better. He probably could've explain what they are for much clearer if he had written this book last year and not in 2005. The system has evolved quite a bit beyond the book, as one can see from his web site. Everything in the book holds true, but there is much more to it than the book covers. However, the book is a necessary start to learn the system, and the only available in print comprehensive source of information on resistance stretches. Weaknesses of the book in the area of description of stretches can be compensated by the explanations on geniusofflexibility, in videos available on B.C.'s web site and to some (smaller) extent in Dara Torres's DVDs.Another aspect which many people find inconvenient is that all stretches are categorized by the associated energy meridians rather than by muscle groups which they stretch. It goes against the traditional way of looking at stretches. The reason for this is the importance of the energy flow sequence in B.C.'s "world". It appears that he thinks not in terms of the muscles, but in terms of the energy meridians in the upper and lower body. The irony is his trainers featured on the videos on his web site do make regular references to specific muscle groups along with the energy meridians, probably because they recognize that for most people it is easier to think that way. Web site does contain lookup charts to link stretches to muscle groups. So, the idea of references to the muscles does fit into his school, but did not find place in the book. It is confusing, at least initially. Not only you are not expected to feel the usual "pulling" sensation during the stretch because you do not actually pull the muscle at its extension limit, but also noone tells you what muscles you are stretching (or removing dense facia from). It is not difficult to figure out, though. After 2-3 weeks, the logic falls back in place. One realizes that the links between muscle groups are so complex that one has to go through all muscle groups anyways (or at least upper and lower body groups), and classification by the meridians makes it much more manageable. There are 16 meridians, which limits the number of stretches which one needs to do to cover the whole body to a reasonable number which can be accomplished within 35-45 minutes. Imagine what you would have to do if you had to stretch each of 100 muscles one at a time referring to each of them by its name and how long it would take? Meridians have a fairly good association with a certain location on your body (e.g., front of the thigh, front-outside, front-inside, inside, outside, etc.) and are easy to use with some practice.P.S. I am not a convert or a devoted follower of Bob Cooley and I never met him in person. I am experimenting with several methods in parallel, including Yoga, Pilates, and Paul Zaichik's kinesiological stretching method. I read books written by other well known flexibility experts, like Pavel Tsatsouline and Thomas Kurz. They are all different (distinctively different, if you read in depth) and I see value in each of them.  But I do believe that this method must be an integral component to any efficient flexibility program because it addresses the limiting factors which no other program does. Five star rating is well deserved in this case.

This is a 28 minutes long basic stretching routine. This DVD is a part of the "age-defying workout series", and it is definitely meant to be lame. It uses no props, does not put you in any yoga-like positions, and does not suggest that stretches be held for extended time. It is a decent routine for elderly people. Everyone can do all stretches from this class, regardless of the flexibility level. It probably will not make you much more flexible, but at least will keep you energized.Since I am only around 50, I found this routine too easy and a little boring. I went through it once and I doubt that I will get back to it any time soon. However, I can see how it can work well for some people.The quality of video is average at best. Too many compression artifacts. The length of advertisement and promotional clips exceeds the length of the useful content, but fortunately one is not forced to watch them as in modern blurays.

Poor quality control. I am glad I bought it from Amazon and could use its replacement policy. The first drive that I got could not be formatted by Windows (fatal error). The replacement one works fine. Design is good (I'd say, somewhat Apple style). Kingston definitely needs to improve its quality control.

Did they really have to make it so small? I bought it with the only purpose - to be able to connect 4 thumb drives to my TV. The plan was to save my fitness videos by category to 4 separate USB flash drives and switch between them as needed. This would enable me to overcome the limitations ob the built-in player in my TV (it can see only a small number of files on a drive). Guess what? The distance between the 4 connectors is so short that USB sticks do not fit next to each other. One can only plug in 4 USB cables, but not 4 USB drives.  A couple extra millimeters between the ports would've sold this problem. Now, I have to buy short extension cables to be able to achieve my goal. Why not do it right from the very beginning?Otherwise, the price is good and it is good that a hub with switches is available.

We picked it up at the local Harbor Freight Tools store for $12.99. Usually, one can find a 20% off coupon in flyers that come in mail (which would get the HFT price down to $10.39) but we did not have it this time. This is a very basic piece of equipment, two plastic parts, a spring, and a switch inside. You plug in your tool into the pedal, plug the (fairly long) cord from the pedal into 120 Volts, press the pedal, and the tool runs as long as your foot is on the pedal. Very useful attachment which makes work with various tools which do not have a power switch right at the tip of your fingers a little safer.The drawback is that it is a kind of "do it yourself" kit. The bottom of this pedal is a slippery plastic, and the pedal slides under your foot. I am not the first who noted it, and the solution is well known - screw it to a piece of plywood. The pedal has two eyelets for the screws to do just that. I do not know why they did not simply attach a piece of rubber to the bottom. This would prevent slippage just the same. Anyhow, you buy the pedal, then find a suitable piece of plywood, screws, "do your homework", and then happily use it.This was the reason why I ranked it three stars. It is OK, but I prefer things which I can use without having to modify them straight from the box to make them useable.The good part is that one cannot beat the HFT price. This is one of these super simple things which one can buy at Harbor Freight without worrying too much about traditional for HFT low end design and low-end-made-in-china-grade built quality.  It is so basic that it is hard to make it wrong, and even if it does not last long, it is just a little over ten dollars at any HFT store in the neighborhood, so not a big loss.

Here in the US we are not "blessed" with a wide selection of saw blades compatible with European sizing (in this case, 30 mm arbor and 260 mm in diameter). To my knowledge (even though I can be wrong), only Oshlun makes compatible blades. Festool makes excellent quality blades which cut cleanly and stay sharp very long, but with Festool's policy of fixing prices in the US market, they are also extremely expensive because they are always sold at MSRP and no dealer is allowed to offer discounts. Pretty much like Apple products. A single blade for Kapex from Festool costs about 3 times more than the Oshlun blade. It is probably not 3 times better, but some people believe that Festool blades are better.  For the cost reason, many owners chose to send their Festool blades for sharpening to local blade sharpening shops instead of buying new ones. In case you want to have spare blades, buying this set is a good way to cut down the cost of the new original blades.Owners of non-Festool saws should remember that there is a good possibility (almost certainty) that these blades will not fit their arbor and will not be the right size.

This is a small adapter... which just does what it is supposed to do. There is not much to say or to add to what was already written... Except, perhaps, a comment that it can be used two ways. Bosch non-electrostatic 35 mm hose comes with a connector that has the same end as Festool 27 mm hose. With either these two hoses, you stick the narrow part of this adapter into the 1 1/4" dust port on your tool, and stick the connector of your vacuum hose inside of the wider (larger diameter) side of the adapter. It works quite well, and friction fit allows one to disconnect the tool, adapter, and the hose easily.With Festool 35 mm hose, which comes with a larger diameter connector, you can use the tapered shape of this adapter to your advantage and still use it if you flip it and slide the wide part of the adapter on top of your 1 1/4" port, and then slide the 35 mm Festool connector over the narrow part and on top of the wide part of the connector.  In this configuration, the narrow part of the adapter goes into your vacuum hose connector, and the wide part is used as a spacer of sorts. It is not how this adapter was meant to be used, but for what it is worth, it works.I like it better than Fein 921072 adapter which can be used for the same purpose.Obviously, only those who use vacuums with hoses that are made to European metric standards (which would be Bosch, Fein, and Festool dust extractors) might need this adapter. It is of no use for owners of shop vacuums purchased at the local hardware store. They need an adapter which is made to ASE units standards.

The good news is that this Star USA / Gigatoner cartridge prints, which is way better than my previous purchase of similarly priced refurbished cartridges from V4INK which did not do even that (and went straight into garbage). The bad news is that every time when you start printing after a pause, the first page looks like a zebra, with black horizontal stripes across the page. Sure, it is very cheap, but what's the use of even a cheap cartridge if it works so poorly?Recommendation: do not buyUPDATE April 19, 2015: By the tax day, when we had to print more than average, it became really annoying. Now, there is a vertical line in addition to intermittently appearing thick horizontal line. Downgraded to one star - JUNK.

One should think about this cutter as a specialized router bit with a fancy screw-on shank.  This puts its pricing in the right ballpark for "comparable" router bits. The tip of the cutter is very hard carbide, the same type that can be found on good router bits. The trick about this bit / tool is that it not only rotates, but also oscillates If oscillating bit hits hard surface (even wood) before it can cut it, the power of the tool may break it. It is very important to make sure that the Domino is stable and held firmly before engaging the cutter. In the very beginning, as I was learning to use the Domino and was on my 10th or 15th mortise, I made the mistake of pushing the cutter in before the domino was firmly in place and was still moving relatively to the work piece. A little extra torque on the oscillating cutter broke off its tip in no time. I learned from this experience and made adjustments to my work flow: I push the cutter in slowly, move it out of mortise also slowly, and make sure that the Domino is firmly in place before cutting and cannot move while I am pushing in the cutter. One has to learn to separate the functions of the left hand (which holds the Domino in the position) and the right hand (which engages the cutter).  With this, after 350+ mortises in maple, it still cuts as new. Very sharp, very long lasting. By the way, it arrives in a nice plastic container similar to those in which Freud router bits are shipped.

I use this hose to connect my Kapex to CT26; initially, I used it to connect it to my RIdgid vacuum and bought this hose because Festool hose was not in the budget at that time. Now, with the knowledge of its limitations, I probably would not go the cheap route.On the vacuum end, it has a friction connector which happens to be universal size across US and Europe (it is a conical friction fit connector, and 2" in US happen to be within 0.8 mm from 50 mm in Europe, the difference being small enough to be absorbed by the conical design of the connector). It fits into US vacuums with a friction fit (most Shop Vacs), or could be connected to the end of the hose from my Ridgid vacuum with a 2" connector from a Home Depot which looks like a short piece of 2" pipe. It goes right into all Festool dust extractors (including CT26 and Midi) as well.On the other end, it has a connector which has limited compatibility with Festool, and you should mind the differences if you decide to buy this hose to use with Festool. It is very similar to the connectors which 27 mm Festool hoses ship with, but it is shorter (or rather, its diameter increases sooner than on Festool connectors). Consequently, it would not fit into HL850 planer dust port (it is not long enough to lock inside of the port). Note that all Festool 36 mm hoses have connectors which go on top of the dust port - this one, however, has a 27-mm like connector and has to go inside of the Kapex port, thus creating a bottle neck - a narrow opening in the air way. Finally, even though it might slide onto 27 mm dust ports of sanders or other portable tools, the hose is too large and heavy to replace the 27 mm Festool hose. The solution to make it work at its best with the Kapex, and to make it work with HL850 planer, is to buy "Festool 487721 Hose Sleeve, Reducing Sleeve For Antistatic D 36 Hose" and replace Bosch connector with a proper Festool connector. It is very easy to install, the hose screws right into it - just note that you have to rotate the hose clockwise to get it out, and counterclockwise to get it in (which is just the opposite to what you would assume). After that, it becomes a non-electrostatic hose just as Festool non-electrostatic hose.This Bosch hose is nominally rated 35 mm, whereas Festool claims that its hoses are 36 mm, but my experience shows that Festool connector fits Bosch hose.SUMMARY: Can be used to connect Kapex to Festool dust extractors or US vacuums, but connector is narrower than on Festool hoses of the same diameter. Does not work with the Planer at all. Not convenient to use with Festool portable tools (the hose is on the large and heavy side). Festool 36 mm connector can be purchased and installed instead of the Bosch connector, which makes it fully matching Festool non-electrostatic hose, but this shrinks the price gap with Festool non-electrostatic hose to the level at which one can as well buy a Festool hose.

This is a fairly rare example of a very useful, but under-engineered Festool accessory. Since most people who own Festool tools are usually fairly well equipped, it does not take long to modify it to make it the way it should had been made, but it is aggravating to get a "do-it-yourself" kit for this price. This is an attachment to OF1010 router which provides a wider area of support and an additional handle for the router. This comes extremely handy when working on edges of the work pieces, e.g., rounding them with roundover bits, or when routering a groove (dado) close to the edge. The purpose of it is to add stability. It consists of a guide stop (the part which glides on a rail) and a fiberglass base. One can attach it with rods (not included with this part, but included with OF1010), but this setup would not work with an edge guide (rods are not long enough). The only way to make it work with the edge guide is to remove the fiberglass runner from the bottom of OF1010 and attach this extension table with screws. This where one runs into a problem - the original runner is attached with 6 screws, whereas this part has only 2 holes predrilled for the screws (you cannot see them on the picture, but they are there, near the top edge), and fiberglass is too thin to keep the router firm and steady when it is attached only at the outside edge. So the first thing you do, you drill 4 more holes for screws to properly attach it  to the router. With this, it works way better. Then, depending on the diameter of your router, you drill a larger hole in the center since the table comes with a quite small hole. After that you wish you had a set with several diameters of holes for different bit diameters, or perhaps a hole of the diameter which matches cover ring, just as in the standard runner. I actually contacted Festool and asked if fiberglass part is available as a spare part - and was told "no".In my opinion, a well engineered part would have 6 holes pre-drilled for mounting (instead of just 2), and would be offered as a set of 3 fiberglass parts with different diameters of holes and one guide stop.Otherwise, it is a great attachment which immensely improves stability of the router.

It does what it is supposed to do. It is a replacement blade for Festool HL850 planer, for the smooth (flat) cutterhead. Don't get confused by its slightly curved shape - since the surface of the blade is not parallel to the axis of the cutterhead, the 3D geometry plays out in such a funny way that the blade has to be slightly curved in order to cut along a flat surface when installed. The material appears to be a very hard but brittle high carbon steel or carbide. Hitting a nail with this blade will leave a deep dent or might even chip off a significant part of the edge (don't ask me how I learned this). (I kept a Makita planer with HSS blades for the case if I need to flatten a floor or studs where there is a risk of hitting a nail - with Festool blades, it is just too expensive as you basically need a new blade after each encounter with a nail).Festool planers use a single blade, not two blades as other brands, so the price of this one is not much higher than the cost of carbide blades for other brands. Due to its shape, it fits only Festool, and only Festool blades fit Festool planer.If you own a Festool planer, you know what it is.

I used these bits to make maple trim pieces for my stairs using OF1010 router. Very nice bits, cut maple without effort and leave behind very smooth finish, both when cutting along the grain and across the grain. The box feels like economy grade plastic, but it is perfectly adequate for storage. I really liked storage in a foam insert because getting bits out of tightly fitting holes in wooden containers (e.g., a set which I got from a Chinese brand Woodland USA) or plastic (Freud - nice bits, nice looking individual bit boxes, but hard to get sharp bits out) can be a challenge. The bits arrived coated with protective layer of thin gel/plastic type compound which was easy to remove (no sticky oily substance as on cheaper brands). Beading set of smaller bearings is a plus, even though I did not need them.The advantage of having 5 different sizes in a set was that I could make samples using each of the bits, and then my wife and I decided what would work best. Compared to pricing of individually sold roundover bits available at woodworking stores, there is no much of discount for buying a set, but no premium for top of the line bits either. Highly recommended.

This scaffolding is designed to be an easy to transport, easy to assemble unit for basic interior repairs or paint jobs. However, it is so poorly designed that I cannot understand how someone can rate it five stars.My story is that I have 12 ft and 17 ft ceilings in several rooms which I had to paint. I thought that scaffolding could be a good idea, and a stack-able scaffolding would enable me to reach the ceiling easily. Just to be on the safe side, I started by ordering one scaffolding and a set of guard rails, with the intention to buy the second scaffolding later, after I paint the 12 ft ceiling.The delivery was quick, the unit arrived nicely packaged with just a few minor shipping or factory damages which make no difference. Assembly process was very easy. The first thing that I noticed is that this thing is designed and built with huge tolerances. Round tubes go into square tubes with large (1/8" to 1/4") clearances. This enables the low end Chinese factory produce these scaffoldings in a way that all elements fit together without any special requirements to precision or quality control. The downside is that nothing is firm, all components wobble within quite significant range. My first task was to set it to 5-6 feet height. I assembled it and climbed on it using a ladder. The thing was so wobbly that I could not stand up on it. Luckily, I had matching guardrails in my garage, purchased separately, with the idea of using them on stacked scaffolding. Well, guardrails wobble just as much as the scaffolding itself: when fully inserted, they can easily tilt by about 15 degrees in either direction. I ended up using a rope to tie them to the scaffold. This made them fairly sturdy. With this setup in place, I could stand on the scaffolding and work off it, but never felt comfortable.In contrast, when I lowered it to about 2 feet from the floor to work on windows, the scaffolding was remarkably stable and convenient.After the first experience, I dropped the idea of buying the second scaffolding and stacking them. I hated standing on a wobbly scaffolding at 5-6 feet level, and I totally did not want to experience the same or more wobbliness when I am at 12 feet. I ended up using a long pole with a paint brush or paint roller to reach the ceiling.On the positive side, wheels are large and sturdy; the scaffolding is easy to roll around when wheel locks are disengaged. Wheel locks are a little hard to disengage, but overall locks work well.  The unit is easy to assemble and disassemble and each individual part is relatively light. And it is cheap - it costs about as much to buy as to rent it for a week at a local home improvement center.It is rated, I believe, at 800 Lbs, which I kind of doubt, considering the fact that the frame of the platform bent someone near one side from my weight (which is a little over 200 Lbs). I can easily see this thing breaking apart and folding under full load.In the end, this scaffolding helped me to do my paint job, but there was not a moment when I enjoyed or simply liked working on it. It was more like: "it is my only option short of using ladders, I have to climb on this thing now, but I hope I will not have to do it again".There are three variety of such "baker style" scaffolding, sold under the names of Pro-Series GSSI, Werner, and Metaltech. They cost about the same, and look so remarkably similar that one can guess that they all produced in the same factory in China, with just a few minor modifications. For example, Metaltech sells with extra pins to lock the platform in place for safety, while this one does not. I ended up ordering such pins separately from Amazon.In summary, a scaffolding may come handy when reaching high ceiling, but one has to realize what it is and be prepared to stand on a very shaky "ground". I cannot imagine how someone can use it at 6 ft height setting without guardrails. In contrast, if one needs a low platform (e.g., 2-3 feet) to work on relatively low (i.e., standard) ceiling (e.g., install drywall), at low height it is way less wobbly and can be used with confidence and without guardrails.

One has to take this in perspective. It is a combination of music mixed in surround with a computer generated images. If I had no reference to compare with, I'd say it is a nice example of 3D imaginary with 5.1 music. Some kind of a modern impressionism, if you will. However, by coincidence, I watched it on the same day and right after I watched Lichtmond 2 - Universe of Light. The difference in artistic level, quality of music, and quality of computer generated imaginary is striking.  After the beauty of Lichtmond, the music of this album sounds simplistic, and 3D graphics feels outright boring and primitive. This is a disk which is worth seeing, but it is not the best in its genre.The video is not even an attempt to create an imaginary world. It is some kind of fractal design video, which shows 3D patterns which follow a certain structure and shape, but appear to be fairly random.I was not impressed.

I just finished writing a review of Lichtmond 3, and everything I wrote there applies to Lichtmond 2. This is an amazing, unbelievable blend of music mixed in surround sound with computer generated worlds of phenomenal beauty, which, when combined, immerses you into a world of fantasy. There is no particular story, but the music is so pleasing, the 3D is so unbelievable, and the images are so gorgeous, that no words can describe it.  You have to see it to believe it. This is an album which must be seen in 3D on a big screen, surrounded with 5.1 or 7.1 speakers. This is a truly amazing video - just as Lichtmond 1 and Lichtmond 3. If you wanted to own just one Blu-Ray to show your friends how impressive a 3D home theater with surround sound can be, one of the Lichtmond albums is that disk.

Lichtmond 1 (Monnlight), Lichtmond 2 (Universe of Light) and Lichtmond 3 (Days of Eternity) are three phenomenal albums, nothing short of amazing. It is an incredible synergy of music mixed in surround sound and 3D computer generated videos of imaginary worlds, all perfectly blended together. I cannot decide for myself which of the three albums is better. The 3D is one of the best I've seen, the surround mix is one of richest I've heard, the colors are beautiful, and the music is very pleasing. There is no real story (the artists' web site has downloadable documents with a write-up of the story and lyrics, but I see no value in it) - it is nothing but a audio-visual feast of incomparable beauty. I've never seen anything like that before. No words to describe it. One has to see it. It is a pity that Lichtmond is not widely available in the US; in Europe, as one can learn from the musicians' web site, these albums collected all imaginary awards - Best BluRay music album, best 3D music album, etc.If you built yourself a surround sound 3D home theater with a big screen TV and were looking for just one Blu-Ray which would enable you to fully show the potential of your system, any of the Lichtmond albums would be a perfect choice. Not Avatar, not any of the Disney 3D movies - Lichtmond. Nothing gets even close to it.Oftentimes, the first album or movie in a series is the best, the sequels are weak. Not with Lichtmond. Lichtmond 3 is just as good or better than Lichtmond 1.

It attaches to Makita KP0800K planer with one screw and replaces the existing nozzle (which is nothing but dust reflector). Planer connected to a vacuum works way, way better than planer which ejects dust on the floor (with the exception of cases when you work outside). I am puzzled why it was not a standard part of the kit.Diameter of the nozzle follows metric standard using in Europe (or Japan), it is 50 mm outside diameter (slightly less than 2 inches). US vacuum hoses are typically 2 1/4 " and their connectors are too large for this nozzle. In contrast, connector on my Festool 36 mm hose fits into it perfectly, it is exactly the same dust port as on the Kapex or on the HL850 planer. For those who do not own Festool vacuum / hoses, the only option is several layers of painters tape on top of the nozzle to achieve a tight fit. Adapters sold in stores are made to ASE units and do not readily fit metric sized nozzle, neither inside nor outside, although one user in the "answers" section reported that he was able to make one of the standard adapters work.I rated it 5 * because the planer is much more fun to work with when you are not covered with wood shavings and do not breath in wood dust, and because I could use a flexible Festool hose which I had at hand, but many other users will probably be frustrated with its sizing and mismatch with their vacuum.With this nozzle and vacuum, efficiency of dust collection is excellent. I did not compare it to Festool under all conditions (I use only Festool for any fine work), but when it comes to flattening the floor, both Makita and Festool perform the same in terms of dust collection, with the same vacuum. There are barely any shavings left on the floor.Added in July 2015: Bosch makes an adapter "Bosch VAC003" or "Bosch VAC020", for conversion of 35 mm to 1 1/4 or 2 1/2 inch hoses. These adapters can be purchased for about $7 on Amazon. Both of them can be used to connect this nozzle to a US-sized vacuum hose. Note, however, that 2 1/2" hose is way too big and ridgid for use with a hand tool. It will be more of a struggle than a benefit. You also can buy a Bosch vacuum hose VAC0005, it is long (5 meters) and has a friction fit connector on the other end which plugs into any US-standard shop vacuum with friction connector. It is just the right size for use with a planer.
Excellent account by a great lawer.
Everything lacrosse balls should be

Don't Buy This, it's a Counterfeit. Someone took the contents, which are in the public domain, and used the Penguin Cover to pass this off as the Penguin edition. This is likely a violation of the Lanham Act, and is a big inconvenience for those of us who ordered this thinking we were getting the Penguin edition. Will contact Penguin to apprize it of this. Meanwhile, Amazon should be alerted to what it's selling

I spent my 20s and much of my 30s in the gym. I loved it. I got great results. Now, after a long hiatus, I went back, in my 50s, intending to pick up where I left off, with bodybuilding. I discovered, though, that I don't have the same interest now in "hugeing out." In fact, when I see guys who walk around showing off their muscles, I kinda feel the way I feel when someone drives down the street in one of those tanklike cars with the windows open, blaring music. Besides, maintaining big muscles is a full-time job. So, I decided, what the hell, why not learn Olympic lifts? Sure, I should have learned them when I was fifteen but I didn't and so I'll learn them now. I have no intention of climbing on a platform and competing, I get my kicks elsewhere, but I want a workout that I can enjoy, and look forward to, that's challenging physically and mentally, and that will provide a great workout.Now, there are supplemental exercises for the Oly lifts. Plenty of them. And while there is a lot of technique in Oly lifting, you also need strength. And that's where 5-3-1 comes in. I ordered it, along with Starting Strength and few other books, and decided to start with it because it has the fewest pages, it's fairly clear, and it fits with what I'm doing. The system calls for working out 3-4 days per week, and focuses on four exercises, one of which I don't do (bench pressing) as my coach advises against it for Oly lifters, but the principles can be applied to virtually any assistance exercise--from the military press, which is covered, the squat, also covered, the deadlift, also covered, to nearly anything you care to build strength in.As a post-50 lifter, I'm considering tinkering with the reps he recommends, reducing them from three sets of five to three sets of three, particularly since strength is my goal, not hypertrophy. But so far this seems like a highly sensible program. I just started using it for military presses, front squats, and snatch grip d'lifts. I'll update the review in a few months.So I recommend this book as a good way to approach building strength. Is it the best program? There is no such thing. Every body is different. It's worth a try. And, despite some of the reviews whining about organization, I just bought the sequel.

Kubik is an amazing specimen. Which is important, because he can do all that he writes about. He's set records in (natural) powerlifting events, and he's a lawyer, which suggests he's analytical. He's also over 50 and still cranking out the reps with heavy weights in Olympic lifts and the ancillary exercises. The problem with most books about weight training is that they're written for a reader in his teens or twenties. The volume and frequency of training is not geared for the post 40, post 50, or post 60 lifter. This book is. It explains the adjustments that will be helpful to avoid injury, overtraining, and burnout. It has plenty of cycles including cardio-based cycles, cycles for those who want to do a lot of Oly lifts, and cycles for those who want to keep to the standard compound movements. It's a wonderful and needed addition.

The book is all about classic methods and approaches to strength training that will develop strength throughout the body, with emphasis on compound movements like the squat, training the grip--which is considered essential here, and using unwieldy objects like thick bars, sandbags, beer kegs along with barbells and dumbbells. The methods have worked for the author. They will likely work for nearly anyone given enough application. The info here is hard to find elsewhere in one source and this book is a bible of strength training. THIS IS NOT BODYBUILDING. The author has contempt for bodybuilders and the exercises and methods they tend to use, and he displays it. Bodybuilders would likely enjoy some of the ideas but this is about how to lift very heavy weights. It is also not necessarily about functional strength for, say, fighting, though many of the exercises will develop that in spades. If you understand what this is and is not, and it's what you want to learn, it may be the best book on the topic.

Meredith uses postures from the Cheng Man Ching tai chi form as static postures for energy cultivation. Nothing new there. What's different is his way of getting into and holding the postures, emphasizing relaxation and energy pathways. I haven't felt the rush of ecstasy he promises but will certainly keep trying. Priced to move, it's a worthwhile companion to his book, Juice, which is excellent. Meredith is a very bright guy, an MIT grad who has much to teach and deserves to be taken seriously. I thought there'd be a bit more here than there is, which is essentially the admonition to hold each posture with the very least amount of tension possible and exercises to help you do that. He does chart the energy flow, and is insightful about the body mechanics vs energetics of tai chi. Worthwhile.

Bob Boyd claims that he learned the Yang family's insider's tai chi method, called Snake Style. I have no reason to doubt his account. This book is a presentation of that method, which boils down to several physical adjustments, all of which seem like they could be very beneficial. The problem is the explanations are not very clear and there are few drawings and fewer photos to aid the reader in grasping the adjustments. For example, Boyd writes that "Hollowing the chest to raise the back is the steam engine that drives the tai chi train." It's done by "drawing the hip joints upward, the lower abdomen...inward, the ribs and thoracic vertebrae upward and backward, and the sole of the foot upward while the ball and heel press downward (rooting.)" No drawings of incorrect versus correct posture are provided to help the reader understand what's required, which Boyd says is not a fixed posture but "a pumping action." No exercises are offered to help you understand how to do this.This is a somewhat lazy effort, in my view, lacking in clarity and drawings and photos that would have been most useful. It's worthwhile for the dedicated tai chi practitioner, but frustratingly unclear at times on points Boyd says are essential. It's also a bit overpriced but, as the first book I've seen to emphasize these various adjustments to how one normally performs the tai chi form, worth reading. Although it's clearly geared to the Yang style its principles could be applied to any style of tai chi.

I started learning tai chi in the late 1980s. I'm still learning it. I've had some wonderful teachers. Never have I seen, in one place, the depth and clarity and detail presented here. There is more than enough here to keep you interested and edified whether you're new to tai chi or a highly experienced practitioner. For example, the concept of coiling, which is supposedly a key part of Chen style but I've never seen it discussed, let alone emphasized, in Yang or Wu styles--here, Dr Yang puts the coiling back where it belongs. Energy flow, body mechanics, and a truly detailed presentation are all present. I do want to note that if you are used to Yang style tai chi this version might be a surprise as it is rather different in many respects from other versions I've seen; however, I find it extremely gratifying to practice though I'm still in the early stages of learning this particular version of the form. I have several of Dr Yang's books but never gravitated to them. Seeing this, I'm going to study those books. He is truly masterful and most importantly, he gives you the key to grasping the internals of this "internal" martial art.

This book teaches Olson's version of the seated Eight Pieces of Brocade. I have had little experience with that qi gong set so I can't comment on its efficacy, whereas I have experience with the standing version, and think it's great. Some books, like those by Yang Jwing Ming, teach both for the price of one, and with more clarity than Olson offers. He TRIES to explain the exercises, and most of them are simple enough that there is no problem learning them. But when movement is required, it's sometimes not possible to get a clear idea from the book and the scant photos. He has a DVD and you can see samples on his website, and that's likely clearer, but frankly I think they should be sold together or either should be sufficient. So my issue is not with the quality of the info but the clarity of the communication. He knows the theory and he knows the practice but there are books that are better for the 8 Pieces of Brocade including Yang's and Lam Kam Chuen teaches the set in The Way of Energy, but only the standing set but with great clarity.

The Encyclopedia of Zhan Zhuang would be a good title. This book is the most comprehensive, detailed book on this form of qi gong that I've seen. It's a highly recommended addition to your library if you practice zz or are considering it. Hand positions, feet positions, weight distributions, it's all covered, with very good explanations and good photos. Is it perfect? What is? It's also the first edition. There are a few things that could be clarified, e.g., do the hands touch the body or are they slightly separated from it when practicing the zz positions for the various organs? My copy came without page numbers--a small quibble, it was easy to put them in. I'm already looking forward to the second edition. Along with Diepersloot, Lam Kam Chuen,  Cai Song Fang, and Fong Ha's monograph, this is already a classic and, perhaps, the best of the bunch.

Am a huge fan of the show. Vol 11 and all previous volumes play in my DVD player. The player is a Panasonic, only about a year and a half old. These discs won't play. I sent them back. Amazon sent a replacement right away. The new ones won't play. I called the number on the box for Fox Searchlight. They said the haven't heard other complaints like this. Will keep you posted.

It just got here, easy to set up, light enough to be moved easily around the desk, good light, doesn't get warm. But I noticed when I read the instructions you can't replace the bulb. The Amazon specs say you get 35000 hours out of it. Which is 4 years if, I suppose, you turn it on and leave it on day and night. Longer if you use it intermittently as most of us do. However, I try to avoid buying disposable things, and might have gone with another model or brand had I known but I'll worry about it in four or five or six years.  UPDATE:  my wife just told me I'll be dead long before this bulb dies. She's probably right but she's an optimist.

Fleeting interviews with an intriguing assortment of writers and, in most instances, the author's synopses of the various writers' careers. Norman Mailer in five pages, Marilynne Robinson in three, Mo Yan in two and half. The pieces are frustratingly superficial. This is the kind of book you keep in the can for when you want to flip through and get the briefest lowdown on William Vollman, or David Foster Wallace. Tidbits do slip through. And it's at least as good, and likely better, than wikipedia at giving you the rough and ready on Dave Eggers or Amy Tan or Toni Morrison. But not by much. At $15 retail it's overpriced. Buy it used, put it in the magazine rack by the sink, and make toilet time fun and edifying.

Whether you're new to pressure cooking or a veteran, this book offers great advice, tips, and fantastic recipes. I recently became vegan, and I find the recipes easy to adapt; often she gives vegan or vegetarian versions. Like all of her cookbooks, and I have most of them, this is clear and easy to follow and the results are magnificent. Five big stars.

An annoying but not wholly useless addition to the shelf. As another reviewer noted, the book is sloppy. Steps are left out. A recipe for Curry Chickpea Bisque tells you to rinse and soak the dried chickpeas for eight hours. Then it tells you how to cook the other ingredients and says nothing more about the chickpeas. Do I add them to the pressure cooker? Do I cook them separately? Do I drain them and eat as is? Do I sautee them? Use them in my nephew's slingshot? Come on, folks. Many recipes use the pressure cooker for only part of the ingredients, the rest are sauteed or broiled. And, weirdly, the pasta recipes call for you to pressure cook the pasta. The rest of the ingredients are usually sauteed. Now, according to the book it takes about seven minutes to pressure cook pasta. Add about five minutes for the pressure to rise and you don't have much of a time saving. Worse, I like pasta al dente. This requires frequent checking during cooking so you can get it into the colander in time. How do you do that in a pressure cooker? You can't. The book is not carefully thought out. The good news is it's inexpensive. And there are not that many vegetarian/vegan pressure cooker books. So it's okay, I wouldn't sent it back, but it's a C at best.

I was told after an annual physical that I was on the cusp of diabetes, a disabling disease by any measure that usually requires medication, daily blood testing, etc. I turned, first, to this book, which I was familiar with, having tried to implement its recommendations once before. The regimen works. It will likely reverse heart disease, obesity, hypertension, diabetes, and various other illnesses that can be cured through dietary changes and exercise. I give it four stars not five because the regimen, for me, is too strict to be practical long-term, and life long changes are what have to be made. Specifically, Furhman emphasizes leafy greens and legumes. Grains are not exactly minimized but frowned on. (In a later book, Furhman nicknames his approach for diabetics as "greens and beans."). I simply could not adhere to that regimen. I felt exhausted and deprived. To his great credit, Furhman lists books by other doctors in Eat To Live with similar but "less aggressive" approaches. Among those listed is Dr. McDougall's book, and, I think, Drs. Ornish and Esselstyn, each of whom is a leading light in the reversal of various diseases through diet. With McDougall, I hit upon the diet that, in less than two months, helped me drop 12 pounds, get my A1C out of the danger zone, drop my total cholesterol by 18 points, and reduce my LDL. I probably should review McDougall's book, and I will. But I want to say that without Furhman I might not have heard of McDougall and Esselstyn, and reading their books lead me to Forks Over Knives and a whole universe of healthy habits that have been life-changing and really delicious; I don't feel deprived. So if you can stick to Furhman's regimen, do it. If you're contemplating making the kinds of changes he prescribes, this is a great book with loads of info that will edify and inspire, but also read Ornish, McDougall, and Esselstyn, and even Pritikin, the granddaddy of 'em all.

Lawyers know that you can put an expert witness on the stand and she'll explain why the science supports a certain side and eviscerates the other, she'll likely have good credentials, etc. And she'll be answered by the other side's expert, who'll have good credentials and preach the opposite conclusion. Thus it goes with the low carb/high protein/high fat Atkins group vs the high carb/low fat/moderate protein China Study groups including Ornish, McDougall, etc.Having tried Atkins, and really having adhered to it to the point I was checking my urine with strips to ensure I was in ketosis I can tell you--anecdotally--I lost very little weight. My cholesterol shot up. Triglycerides were high. And I was cranky too. But that was MY experience, and I quit the diet because I just got grossed out with the menu. This book is an update of the standard Atkins regimen. It allows a few more carbs but it's still the high protein high fat diet Atkins recommended. Now, keep in mind that Atkins himself had significant heart disease when he died, and he weighed 258 pounds! See [...] (last visited 9 July 2013).If you want to try this approach New Atkins is a good presentation of it. But do yourself a favor: get your blood drawn before you start. Get it drawn again six weeks later. Then six weeks after that. If you lose weight and your cholesterol, tryglycerides, etc. are improving, you know this is probably safe and healthy for you. If not, get off of it. It's too dangerous to undertake ANY radical dietary regimen without checking your blood, particularly one where you chiefly subsist on protein and fat.And remember--despite all the scientific-sounding hocus pocus about insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome and the overworked pancreas--losing weight remains simple math. Ingesting more calories than you burn = weight gain and vice-versa. It doesn't matter whether the calories are from butter or brown rice. There ain't no way around this.Finally, also look into the Krebs cycle which, put very simply, means that the body burns fat for fuel efficiently only when there is adequate carbohydrate in the system. In practical terms, this means that the quickest way to burn fat while exercising is to keep the dietary fats low, the complex carbs fairly high.

I ordered a set of these bowls, small med and large. This is the small one. The other two are great. They're made in Italy. This one is made in France. Don't know if that matters. But in the bottom of the bowl is a sunburst pattern of scratches about two inches long each. They are within the glass itself. However, there was a noticeable nick in the bottom of the glass that you could feel. I sent it back. Today the replacement arrived. Same sunburst pattern but at least no nick. This is a ten dollar item. If it were more, I'd send it back for a refund. Let me put it this way, if I saw this in a store I wouldn't pay ten bucks for it. Otherwise the bowl is a good thickness, good weight. But come on guys, don't sell defective products.

the recipes are not low in fat. Oil is used liberally in nearly every recipe. I started eating a plant-based whole food diet using McDougall's plan with some Fuhrman influence, and the emphasis is on avoiding adding fat to your food, and sticking to whole foods. This book does not pretend to follow those rules, and so if you're looking for a way to lose or control weight, or improve lipid profiles, modify the recipes, which are fantastic and plentiful

Swami Sivananda has a number of disciples, including Swami Satchidananda of Integral Yoga, Swami Radha, and this book's author, Swami Satyananda. Swami Sivananda remains one of the greatest yogis, and his disciples continue that acuity and purity. This book is a valiant and successful effort to provide anyone with a sincere interest in yoga, whatever their motivation, with a complete course that will take them from basic asana (posture practice) to advanced meditation techniques leading to concentration, absorption, and that ineffable state called samadhi. It's written for someone without a guru as a very clear by the hand manual. It is superb. I know of no other book to equal it.
