One reviewer cautioned that the Kriya Yoga methods taught here differ from those taught by Lahiri Mahasaya. That's true. And this book emphasizes the meditation technique called Kriya Yoga as an efficient path to samadhi. It also explains that the exact source of the group of techniques called Kriya Yoga is unknown. What's important to note is that this book does approach and teach the Kriya techniques quite differently from the Lahiri-Yukteswar lineages, which differ from Yogananda's streamlined version taught now through Self-Realization Fellowship. This book's approach is derived from Swami Sivananda's approach, and the author notes similarities between Kriya Yoga and other systems like the microcosmic orbit technique from Taoism, as well as differences. My point is this: practice it the way it's taught here. If you want to learn another approach, great. Try each. Use your intuition to decide which you prefer. There are various approaches to what's known as Kriya Yoga and I don't know that anyone can demonstrate that one is more effective than another.Also, this book keeps asana and pranayama in perspective, as supporting techniques to prepare you for the higher practices rather than being ends in themselves. This is valuable in an age that often views asana as the whole of yoga.The book offers a wonderful non-sectarian approach that is user-friendly and comprehensive. As the author says, "Whatever your situation in life, whatever you believe or do not believe, whatever you want from life, yoga will help you because it changes your whole being and hence your relationship and attitude to life itself." Yes it does. This is a wonderful map that will take you there.

I've been practicing yoga asanas since about 1991. I've had the good fortune to have taken classes with K. Pattabhi Jois, some master Iyengar teachers including the magnificent Gabriella Giubilaro, and I have acquired a fairly good library of books on asana, pranayama, meditation, and various aspects of yoga philosophy. Dancing the Flame of Life really surprised me. It's a significant addition to the literature. Holleman, whose background is Iyengar-based, adds invaluable information that allows me to really make use of principles I knew of but didn't really understand, or simply didn't know about. For example, take a simple thing like padha bandha. I had never heard of it. Mula Bandha, Jalandhara Bandha, but Padha Bandha? Well, it's quite simple but it has changed the way I stand in the standing postures, and that change has enhanced my posture toe to scalp. Her mental approach to yoga is worth the price of the book, with her emphasis on a highly attentive but somewhat passive, or watchful approach as opposed to the "no pain no gain" approach that's crept into a lot of asana practice. I haven't listened to the CD that comes with the book yet but I will, soon. I do think that this book is better suited to someone who at least has an understanding of the fundamentals so they can fully appreciate the refinements and distinctions on hand but I would recommend this to everyone who has more than a passing interest in hatha yoga. It's that good.

This book takes nothing for granted. Every concept is explained in detail. Occult principles and made clear. Practical advice is given. There are a number of excellent books on pranayama. This belongs among them. The only reservation I have is that it's probably better for someone who has a basic understanding of pranayama than a novice, but if you are a novice, buy this, and get something a little more entry-level as well.

A wonderful account of the making of a guru, including the part you don't often hear about--the early doubts whether or not Sivananda was the right guru for the author, or even anything special; and a very non-romantic view of rugged conditions in the ashram that had the aspirant struggling to adjust to the lack of creature comforts, and eventually learning to see god in everything. This is a wonderful narration of her inner transformation at the knee of one of the greatest gurus ever. Indispensable for anyone interested in deeper practices of yoga.

Almost two hundred dollars for a kettle? Well, yes, if you consider that Alessi is the only game in town if you want a high-quality 18/10 stainless steel kettle that's not made in China. And believe me I've done the homework. Some Le Creuset kettles are made in Thailand and others of theirs are from the People's Republic of Questionable Safety. I have nothing against running shoes made in China or ballpoint pens made in China or computers made in China but I don't boil water in those things, and when you boil water in a metal container, impurities leach into the water. So I sprang for an Alessi. It has a whistle that's not a screech and will alert me without annoying me. It's not so loud that I can go down to the basement or up to the attic but if I'm in the next room, it's fine. The spout pours beautifully. The interior is easy to reach and clean. The handle doesn't get so hot you burn your hand. And if the bird breaks or you lose it they sell replacements. Some have complained that it's hard to remove the bird without burning yourself. The instructions tell you to wait until the steam stops escaping. I haven't had a problem. And it looks beautiful, the kettle. Five stars, bravo.

Pros: It looks good. The handle mechanism that opens the lid on the spout works great. The handle doesn't get too hot.Cons: The interior of the lid has a silicone or plastic gasket, and I never like plastics in proximity to boiling water or food. The kettle imparts an odd chemical smell to the water. When making coffee, the coffee conceals this. Tea, too. But I wonder what causes that. Am suspicious of the purity of the 18/8 stainless steel of this Chinese-made item. The whistle was very faint, then it stopped working after a few days.Unfortunately, there are no longer any stainless steel kettles made in the USA, and only one company makes them in Europe. Scarcity increases price, and the cost of non-Chinese made stainless kettles is high. However, when you boil water in metal, impurities in the metal leak into the water. Given what's coming out of China these days (radioactive stainless steel pet bowls, for example), I'm taking one for the team and springing for an Italian-made stainless kettle that has its fans and detractors but will give me peace of mind that we're not drinking heavy metals with our afternoon cuppa.

The kettle arrived beautifully packed in a cloth drawstring bag and I took it out, took the lid off, looked inside, and saw massive corrosion and the absence of plating in many places, leaving the base metal exposed throughout portions of the interior. This would be inexcusable in a $10.00 kettle. The Simplex cost $179 on Amazon and is supposedly hand made. Where is quality control? I took photos I was so shocked. I sent Simplex an email. So far, no response. Amazon customer service was unable to put me in touch with the dealer who sold the kettle via Amazon, at least, not by phone. I am unwilling to spend the money on a replacement. If they let kettles leave the factory in such appalling condition, Simplex is not a company I want to buy from, nor is the retailer who sold it through Amazon.Now for some background. My wife and I decided to avoid buying cookware made in China. The last straw was the recent manufacture of stainless steel pet bowls that are radioactive. Low levels of radioactive metals got into the steel and--this is amazing--the manufacturer said not to worry, the levels are probably low enough to be safe.When you boil water, impurities including heavy metals will leak from the steel or whatever it is into the water, then into you when you drink the tea or coffee. Unacceptable. Here's the really bad part. THERE ARE NO STAINLESS STEEL KETTLES FOR SALE NOW THAT ARE NOT MADE IN CHINA with the exception of some Le Creuset kettles that are made in Thailand, and, the sole exception, Alessi kettles, which are still made in Italy from 18/10 stainless steel. And they are expensive. Why has my country, and the whole of Europe, stopped making something so simple as a tea kettle? The answer is money but it's disgusting.Long story short, if you really want a good quality stainless steel kettle, you have two choices. A vintage kettle from ebay or elsewhere, or Alessi.Update: The Simplex company responded to my email. They were shocked by the photos. They think the kettle was boiled dry and then resold. If you want a Simplex I suggest you buy directly from them.

I love my Garmin 305 but I lost the heart rate monitor that came with it. I bought this to replace it. It worked for the first run. Then it started giving bizarrely low readings. My heart rate was 130, the monitor said it was 56, and so on, throughout the run. I adjusted the strap, I made sure the conductors were wet. No dice. I assumed I had a lemon. I ordered a replacement. The replacement worked for the first run. Then the same problem. I was panting up a hill, my heart rate was nearly 150 based on my taking it with my finger on my pulse but the monitor had it at 73. I don't know what the problem is. Garmin generally makes good products. Also, before every run you have to pair the monitor and the watch so they interact, which wasn't the case with the heart rate monitor that came with it. I could live with that. The inaccuracy is a deal breaker. I'm sending them both back for a refund.

I started studying this art in the late 1980s in Taiwan, then continued when I got home, and have been practicing ever since, with many lapses. I have read at least a dozen books on taiji, probably more. Juice is the first book I've read to deal directly, concretely, with the art's energetics, the patterns of energy flow, and energy cultivation. The author has a Ph.D from MIT, and it shows. His explanations are free of the New Agey "let your qi flow!" feel good stuff that's useless. On the other hand, he eschews the trend to dismiss all discussion of qi in taiji in favor of pure physics and body mechanics. In very detailed language he explains how to get the qi (chi) into your taiji through correct use of the form, rather than auxiliary nei kung/qigong. I learned a great deal in the week that I've been working with the book, and can feel the results. But this is experiential. You can debate it, you can agree or challenge it, but you have to give it a try and see if you can feel it. I would go as far as to say it's the most important book on taiji I've read, and I don't know the author, I'm not a shill, just another taiji nut.

I started running to lose weight. I took some workshops on correct form. I run with a midfoot strike and a slight forward lean, at least I try to. Despite being careful about form, runs longer than five miles tend to cause me plantar fasciitis. Which sucks, as you know. Until now, the best shoe I'd found was the Mizuno Wave Musha, though I also liked the Brooks Racer ST5 though it does have a more substantial heel. In a book about correct form and running shoes I saw a reference to Altra and tried the Instinct 1.5. No more pain. The shoe is very comfortable. It is not heavily padded at all, in fact, it feels kind of like running shoes feel when it's time for a new pair--very little cushioning. But it works, for me. It is not what most would call a "minimal" shoe, you don't get a great deal of ground feel, it's not a Vibram, its far more substantial. P.S. I tried the Torin, another model from Altra, and hated it, felt like I was about to teeter over. The Instinct 1.5 is my new fave.
You can get free weather apps that are excellent but for .99 cents this is great with a beautiful interface and the ability to check the weather in multiple locations.

Mo Pai nei kung has attained cultlike status among qigong rats, and with good reason. As any student of Economics 101 learns, scarcity increases value. Information about true mo pai training is very scarce. Jim McMillan details his meetings with a remarkable man, John Chang, who became his teacher, and he presents a warts and all portrait. This is no hatchet job, it's an affectionate account, and best of all, it's filled with hints about mo pai. The author does not disclose the actual techniques, but he tells you that up front. This is a remarkable account of this form of nei kung by one of Chang's most advanced students and, for anyone interested in mo pai, it's a must have.

As a first time tablet user, it was difficult to figure out whether my kindle fire hd was using the battery charge faster than usual and i sent my first one back for a replacement. Someone recommended this app and it's great. Tells you the amount of time left for each activity like music, reading, movies. Diagnoses battery health. Gives you how long a full charge will take. I liked the free version and bought the pro version. Both are excellent.

I wanted one of these critters, they look so sleek and plush. On line. And since I live in a big city I figured I could go around and see them in person, check the colors, etc. Well, it was hard to find them. Filofax has discontinued the line. Apparently Filofax does not have but a few perennials. The rest are marketed for fixed period then discontinued. Anyway, I found two stationers that had these. And in person, they looked shiny, and cheesy, and cheap. I mean, so bad that if you gave me one, I would return it. The leather looked shiny and cheap. The photos make it look rich and of good quality. Unfortunately, a lot of the other Filofax models also looked cheesy, like they've outsourced the manufacturing to China. I know, China makes some great stuff, etc. But I got my first Filofax in the late 1980s, and let me tell you, it looked truly beautiful. Still does. They don't make 'em like they used to. The other reviews love this model and it's a matter of taste, but if I had ordered this on line, as I was tempted to do, I would have been hideously disappointed at what was in the box.

A brilliantly designed series of programs for people at varying levels of fitness, and a terrific assortment of exercises are the book's strengths, along with a clear explanation of the value of bodyweight exercises. I bought the kindle version and ordered the paperback as it's hard to flip back and forth on the kindle to see the explanation of the exercises. The other books on bodyweight exercise (and on using weights) that I recommend are written by Ross Enamait, and sold directly by Ross, but they are not as user-friendly, and seem geared toward a more hardcore crowd. This title with Ross's would give you a complete library of bodyweight exercises and routines. It's superb.

I used to hate mayonnaise. Then i tried Duke's. Whereas Hellman's is kind of sweet and cloying and nasty, Duke's is brash, tangy, and clean, it doesn't clot on the palate. It also has no sugar, unlike Hellman's, and sugar, as another reviewer said, has no business in mayonnaise. This stuff is great, and if we who live above the Mason-Dixon line had any sense, we'd insist stores here carry it. Thank you Amazon.

This is my first tablet. My wife has an iPad but I haven't used it. Overall, I'm very pleased as I wanted a tablet chiefly for books. I started with the entry level Kindle, liked it, and upgraded. Even though I am an Apple user, I didn't want to spend the money on an iPad and I didn't need a million apps. This has a really nice display. It's great for watching movies, and I now use it for email. Music is also excellent on it, though you'll want headphones or external speakers as the speakers in the device, while quite good, are not going to give you the nuances you want. I really love this device. But I can't give it five stars because (a) the battery life is somewhat short. I find that I pretty much have to charge it daily, though I do use it a lot. (b) it does not support flash player, and I'm not sure what that is, but I know that without it certain cites won't work, and there is no good reason for it not to support flash, prior models apparently did. (c) the browser is okay but slower than it could be. (d) bizarrely, whereas you can create various categories for books on the basic Kindle, you can't on this one. There are apps that supposedly allow this but the two I downloaded sucked. I deleted them. Consequently, I have dozens of books of various types, such as fiction, nonfiction, historical, foreign languages, exercise, etc., and no way to organize them by category so I can go to a specific folder where all the books on yoga are stored, another folder for books on lit crit, another folder for fiction, etc. Why the 79.00 Kindle allows this but not the Big Kahuna is bizarre. I recommend that you get an app that monitors battery life, as an Amazon user suggested to me, if you buy one of these since the battery tends to drain fast. All in all, it's a great device, and it was wonderful to have when I was bedbound with the flu. As a Prime member I watched movies for free, read, listened to music. I tend to take it wherever I go. The shortcomings are minor. In fact, it's probably the best $200 I've spent ever.

The book's focus is on the Southern Wu (as opposed to Northern Wu) style of tai chi, as taught by a well-known Hong Kong-based teacher who made some changes to the form, none of them controversial, and whose chief contributions included the teaching of a set of qi gong/nei kung exercises that had not been taught outside the Wu family, and emphasizing the practicality of tai chi for self-defense and even tournament fighting. The book is chiefly useful for Wu stylists, and tends to disparage the other two main styles of tai chi, Yang and Chen. The book boasts photos of the author doing the long form. Unless you know the form, or have access to it on DVD, you will never figure out how to move from posture to posture, and tai chi is about movement. If you are learning the form or know the form, the book is useful if you want to check the sequence. The author includes a few photos of his teacher doing the form, and the difference between the two is remarkable. The author's teacher, even in a still photo, seems vibrant and relaxed, alert and poised. By comparison the author looks as if he's holding his breath. Which suggests that his teacher's book, which he co-wrote, might be more useful, [...] though I haven't seen it. There is an annoying tendency throughout the book to refer to "secret" teachings available only to students who have quite literally taken an oath of allegiance to the author and his style. Thus we have mention of the "six secret words," secret push hands and fighting techniques, and above all, the qi gong/nei kung exercises which the author praises as imparting nearly supernatural physical powers, but which are  not disclosed--you have to join the club to learn them, along with, perhaps, secret handshakes. There is a chapter on tai chi weaponry, and a chapter on self-defense which is interesting. The bottom line is that this book is chiefly useful for people with a keen interest in the Wu style and this popular variation on it. The chapters on the history of the art are fine, but not worth the price of admission. If you're looking for useful instruction and are not keyed to the Wu style, there are books that offer more bang for the buck. If you have a keen interest in the Wu style, this is an interesting addition.

I was looking for a true liquid rollerball refill to fit a Delta "rollerball" that only takes Parker style refills. My local pen shop recommended these. I liked them at first. Smooth flow, as the name implies. But it's a ballpoint with a thinner ink, and like all ballpoints the line has streaks in it, little clots of ink hit the page, etc. It's a good ballpoint refill but it's far from the vibrant smooth liquid ink of a true rollerball.

I have the Dolce Vita Oro medium "rollerball." It's a pretty pen. A bit flashy--it's all orange--and I wouldn't bring it to a typical business meeting, but it you like orange, as I do, it's fun. Here's the problem. Delta calls it a rollerball. It ain't. It takes standard Parker ballpoint refills. There are gel ink refills that will fit, but to me a rollerball is a specific pen with a specific, usually liquid, ink, with a specific feel. There is no way this is a rollerball. So if you don't mind using gel ink refills, fine. I'm annoyed because they really should not be misleading. They make a ballpoint that's cheaper and probably a bit smaller, and when I pay more for a rollerball I expect a rollerball with rollerball liquid ink refills. This ain't that. Shame on Delta for misleading advertising.

I've had great experiences with Avery products in the past -- they consistently deliver a quality product.  In this package, you get (30) sheets of Letter-sized 8.5" x 11" matte card stock that has perforations for you to tear out (2) 4.25" x 5.5" (half a letter-sized) notecard-sized cards per sheet-- in total you get (30) notecards, and (30) envelopes.Unlike most Avery products, each sheet does not have the product ID# printed on it.  However, you can use the Avery #5315 to look up the template in MS Word, or download/design your notecard on Avery's website.The paper you get is basically your standard card stock with a single tear perforation to split the cards in two, and has a... (not sure what the correct word is, but has basically similar to a perforation) line that makes it easy to fold in the correct spot.  What I like about this card is that there is no wasting paper -- the full page is utilized.  There is no other markings on the paper that are to be torn and thrown away.  With that said, if you want to go the cheaper route, you could create a similar product on your own -- just print on standard card stock, cut it in half, and purchase some envelopes.  However, what Avery does is make things easier -- at a cost (though not bad at a current cost of about 26 cents per notecard + envelope)!This is a nice product for those that want to print customized note cards, and not go through the hassle of cutting individual cards, and purchasing a bunch of envelopes.

I've had great experiences with Avery products in the past -- they consistently deliver a quality product.  In this package, you get (50) sheets of Letter-sized 8.5" x 11" matte card stock that has perforations for you to tear out (2) 4" x 6" postcard-sized cards per sheet-- in total you get (100) postcards.Just like most Avery products, each sheet has the product ID#, and a reference to which template to use in popular word processing programs like Microsoft Word.  If you're unable to find a template there, you can go to their website and either download a template, or design your postcard there.Though its not the complete fault of these cards, but due to the thickness of the product, it may jam in certain laser printers.  I found the thickness similar to about 85-lb card stock.  This doesn't seem to be as thick as postcards I would find outside.  Additionally, these cards are matte, so if you're searching for a semi-glossy or glossy finish similar to what you see on photo-postcards, this isn't the product for you.  After printing, you simply need to fold and tear at the perforations.  The perforations did its job -- the result was some cleanly torn edges.This product is ideal for those looking to print the occasional customized postcard, or just a basic notecard, and I would recomend it.

I've heard about BLU and their affordable line of smartphones before on sites like Engadget.  If you need a smartphone that won't break the bank, you should certainly consider one of their phones.  I've been playing with this particular unit for a few weeks, and my impression is that the two major selling points is the large size, and price.Below are some pros/cons of the device:PROS:- Size -- its very large, and makes it easy to watch movies on the go.  Especially good for those with kids!- Android 5.0 (Lollipop)- Minimal bloatware- Unlocked -- not tied to any particular carrier.  However, it can only be used with GSM carriers (e.g. AT&T & T-Mobile.  Cannot be used with Verizon/Sprint).- Smooth performance.  Haven't experienced any hiccups yet while watching movies or playing games.- Includes a charger, screen protector, and headphones- Though it only has 8GB of internal storage, it has a microSD slot capable of handling upto 64GB.CONS:- Low sound -- my Galaxy Note 3 sounds considerably louder- No flash.  Besides using a flash for the rear camera, I often use it as a flashlight.  No such option on this phone.- Poor camera image quality.  I set the camera settings to the highest, and yet most images appear grainy.- While the screen is large, and IPS, its colors appear to be a bit washed out when compared side by side with an iPhone or Galaxy Note3- Relatively wide bezel.- No LTE support -- with the prevalence of LTE these days, I would have thought this would be standard by now.On the size aspect, this phone is huge -- I have a Galaxy Note 3, and the Studio 7.0 is massive in comparison.  As a tablet, this seems like a decent size as it is very lightweight, and can fit in some pockets, and easily fit in bags.  However, as a phone, this thing is far too large -- its nearly the size of my head!Though this is phone is very far from perfect, at the price point, I can't expect to be WOW'd.  For the price, I give it a solid 4*'s.  The phone targets cost-conscious consumers that want something large.  It would be unfair to compare the quality and features of a $130 phone with flagship devices from Apple or Samsung -- its in a separate class!  For those that want a large phone/small tablet for movies, and games, and not rely on a speedy LTE network, this may fit the bill perfectly fine.  For those that simply want the best out there today, look elsewhere.

This is one basic polyester table cloth.  There is nothing notable about it -- though the design looks nice, it does seem rather thin.  If you're in need of a casual table cloth, just to dress up the table a little, this will do.  If you want anything more out of it, like protect your table, and absorb liquids, then don't set your expectations too high.  Additionally, for what you get, the price seems rather high.  There are similar, if not better, quality table cloths sold on Amazon for 1/3rd of the price.  At the current price of over $30, I cannot recommend this product.

I purchased the GermGuardian AC4825, 3-in-1 Air Cleaning System with True HEPA, UV-C and Odor Reduction, 22-Inch about 6 months ago and have been very happy with the performance.  The reason for the purchase was to clear up a bad stench coming from a room where I have the cat litter box placed (and of course where the cats do their business).  The GermGuardian AC4825 did the trick.  With this GermGuardian AC5300B, I was expecting similar positive results, and it did not disappoint.The AC4825 unit stands at 22-inches, is intended for small to medium sized room, and has a Clean Air Delivery Rate (CADR) rating of 100+.  The AC5300B unit stands at 28-inches, is intended for medium to large sized rooms and has a CADR rating of 125+.  [CADR rating can be verified online.  However, for whatever reason, I could not find Germ Guardian's products on the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers (AHAM) website.]Both units touts a 3-in-1 filter -- that is, it has a HEPA filter to capture 99.7% of airborne particles, a charcoal filter to capture odors, and a pre-filter to capture large dust particles, lint and pet hair.  Additionally, it has a UV-C light that kills bacteria and viruses, and helps get rid of odor caused by smoking, cooking, and pets.As this model is intended for a medium to larger room, I have this placed in the kitchen/dining room.  In my household, we sometimes eat durian and stinky tofu.  The smells tend to linger a bit.  With this air purifier on, the odors went away quicker than normal, and the aroma didn't spread to the entire house!This air purifier works well, and is relatively affordable for what it does.  I would recommend this product.

This is a basic shaver that does that one thing, gives a good shave at a very affordable price.I have used other shavers from Norelco and Panasonic that are 3 to 6 times more expensive and I can honestly can't say that those shavers are any better at shaving.  Sure those have other bells and whistles but if you just want an easy to use cordless shaver this is a good choice.There is a single led above the power button that gives you the status if the battery; green is good, red is bad.  It can't get any simpler then that.One useful perk, it does have a pop up trimmer.  The included head cover/stand I found useless.

For babies that experience gas & colic, this is certainly a bottle that you should try.  In my growing extended family, we have three newborns.  All three babies took to the slow-flow nipple well and seemed to experience less gas than with other bottles.One feature that seems to be unique to this bottle is their "self-sterilizing" feature.  This requires putting some water in the base, placing the nipple in the base, screwing it into the bottle, and placing it into the microwave.  After a few minutes, you have a sterilized bottle.  This is very convenient for when you may not have a dishwasher, or sterilizer handy.  If theres anything bad that can be said about this is that it results in more pieces!  Lose one and you may have a bottle that doesn't work as intended.For those interested in purchasing the MAM bottles, , MAM does have bottles ranging from 5 ounce, 8 ounce, 9 ounce, 11 ounce, in different colors.  Though these bottles come with the slow-flow nipples (for newborns), they also have medium, and fast flow nipples available.
