I've been using a Crock Pot slow cooker for years.  The one I had previously used is still being used regularly for soups, stews, and congee.  This unit is serving a similar purpose, and is just like my Crock Pot brand slow cooker, but is just a bit smaller.As a slow cooker, the features on this unit seem to be pretty basic and standard.  On the control dial, it has the four settings -- OFF, LOW, HIGH, and WARM.  The lid is made of clear tempered glass, allowing you to take a look at whether your food is boiling.  Though the food contents tend to be hot, the handles remain relatively cool, making it easy to move the entire unit to either the dinner table or another place on the counter.  The removable liner makes it easy to cleanup.  This 4.0 qt size is a bit on the smaller side of what is available, but I find it is suitable for a party of 4.This is an excellent slow cooker, at an affordable price.  There are no bells and whistles on this unit, but does what its supposed to well.

I've been using this air purifier for about a month now and have been pleased with the features and performance.  What sets this apart from the others on the market is the "smart" features.  If you're into the smart-home craze, this may be the air purifier for you!This is my first WeMo device, so I had to download the WeMo app to set it up.  For those that do not know, WeMo is like an ecosystem -- if you find a device/peripheral that says WeMo, it should be able to be controlled via the WeMo app.  It'll let you monitor, measure, and manage devices.  The WeMo app is available for download on your respective app store (iTunes, Google Play Store, Android).  For more information about this, you can check out their website (www.wemo.com).  Upon installing the app, I was able to search for the air purifier, add it, and begin managing it.With the app, you now have a fancy remote control that will enable you to fiddle with settings, check the status, and turn on/off the device from anywhere with an internet connection.  I was able to set a schedule of when I wanted the device to automatically turn on/off (I set it to turn off when I know I'm at work, and on just before I usually get home).  You can have separate schedules for each day of the week.  You can also set it on low/med/high/auto/off, and toggle whether you want the ionizer on.  The app will alert you when it requires some routine maintenance, and when to replace the filters (as I've said, I've only been using this device for nearly a month.. so I haven't received any alerts. but if it works as advertised, alerts will be helpful as I often need reminders to do this sort of stuff!).  One feature that should not be overlooked is that the air purifier has a sensor to detect the air quality, which you can see via the app (one feature that is lacking on all my traditional non-smart air purifiers).In the event the app isn't work, or you don't have your app/phone near by, this air purifier works well via the old-school manual buttons on the top of the unit.Whats great about this unit is the availability of different types of filters, which allows you to mix/match the use of filters depending on your specific needs.  The four different types of filters available are:  Allergen Remover, Total Air, Odor Eliminator, Smoke Grabber, and the Carbon Filter.  The unit comes installed with a allergen remover filter, and a odor eliminator carbon filter.  The average life cycle of these vary depending on how much you use it, and the type of filter.If you're in the market for a "smart" air purifier, then this is a solid performer, and I would recommend this device.

As I manual nasal aspirator this works great compared to the blue bulb aspirators that you typically see.  The shape of the tip seals nicely to the baby our child nose and provides a good seal.To increase the auction, this I've has a tube that connects to the back of the bulb so you can create a auction with your mouth.  I like how this one has replaceable filters to help isolate the about that can get sucked out.Unfortunately these two methods for aspirating mucus and fluid from the naval cavity is almost useless compared to using aspirators that are vacuum assisted.We were introduced to the arianna baby vac that uses a connector that attached to most vacuums so you have a strong and constant suction to really help clear out thick mucus setup in the nasal cavity.

This is one decent lightweight upright commercial vacuum cleaner.  The vacuum comes with just a few pieces -- the main vacuum base, the handle, and a 35' standard extension cord.  Assembly is very simple -- just place the handle in to the main vacuum base, and screw it in with the supplied screw.  Plug in the extension cord into the short plug.  The zippered section that stores the vacuum bag appears to be made of a nice nylon material that some nice backpacks are made of, and should stand up well to wear and tear.The one commercial vacuum that I have, and can easily compare to is the highly rated Carpet Pro CPU 2t Commercial Vacuum Cleaner:>> ASSEMBLY:  Not a big deal since you only have to do it once... but the Hoover was a cinch to assemble -- only one item to screw in.  The CarpetPro2T wasn't difficult, but took a few more minutes to get up and running.>> FEATURES/ACCESSORIES:  On the Hoover, the use of an standard extension cord versus a long attached cord is nice -- in the event that 35' isn't enough, you can replace it with a longer extension cord, rather than lug around two separate cords.  This is also great in the event the cord is somehow damaged.  However, this Hoover vacuum doesn't have any options for hand tools/accessories, so is limited only to the open floor.  The Carpet Pro CPU2T on the other hand has a hand tool that come in handy to reach hard to reach places, and areas above the ground.  Where this made a huge difference is in the office, under desks.  Though the Hoover was light, it was difficult to vacuum under many desks, and other hard to reach places.  The Carpet Pro CPU2T also had issues, but could overcome it with the hand tool.Comparatively, the Hoover is quieter.  This may be important for some in office environments.The Hoover vacuum bag is self-sealing.  When you remove, it seals itself to prevent the dust flying out.  Not the case on the CarpetPro.>> WEIGHT:  The Hoover is lighter than the Carpet Pro CPU2T.  Some people like the extra weight, so this is more personal preference.>> PRICE:  At the time of this review, the Carpet Pro CPU2T is about $30 more.  Standard vacuum bags for the Carpet Pro costs about $1.66/each.  For the Hoover, they have a few different bags -- BAG-Q standard (model #AH10178PC) retails for $1.39/each (pack of 25), Bag-Q Alrgn (AH10021) $1.99/each (pack of 10), and the HEPA bag (model 302982002) from 3rd parties cost about $2.50/each.>> DOES IT "SUCK"?:  The performance of both units were comparable, as both handled any debris i could find on carpets.  I did not have the opportunity to test on hard floors as my office does not have any.All in all, this is a high quality commercial vacuum.  If you plan to vacuum a lot of floors in the open, then this is a solid choice.  However, if you have a need to vacuum under furniture, etc., look elsewhere, as this isn't vacuum isn't designed for that purpose.
Thick and soft, great attributes for crib sheets.  As long as they remain that way and are durable enough to withtand repeated washings, this sheet would be a great buy.

I have used PediaSure products before and was hopeful that this smoothie mix would continue with the quality of their products that I have experienced in the past.  I was happy to find that the smoothie wasn't overly sweet and had a pleasant strawberry and banana aroma.  Of corse overly sweet tasting, so you have to keep in mind the powder still has 8 g of sugars per serving and once mixed with the milk the package estimates each serving to have approximately 17 g of sugars.  Once reconstituted, there are also small flakes of strawberry in the smoothie.  I would say that is hit or miss depending on the kid drinking it.I used a shaker bottle and it was very easy to incorporate the mix in with the milk.  3/4 cup to each scoop of powder.  I find this a good serving size that will satisfy toddler aged kids.  Each package makes 8 servings so this isn't cheap by any means.  Each of the packages also come with a measuring spoon so it makes it that much easier to measure out the proper amounts.  My only concern is that with such small packages you end up with many extra measuring spoons that will get tossed out and end up in a landfill somewhere.Overall i am pleased with this product and wouldnt hessitate to try other flavors that are available

The main reason I am only giving this carrier 2 stars is because the 5 point straps are inconvenient to adjust.  They adjust only from the back of the seat (near the release lever) and can not be reajusted on the fly.  The straps are also not interconnected so it is possible to have them improperly adjusted for each side if the infant isn't sitting straight.These straps are always supposed to be left snug where you should only be able to get a couple fingers underneath otherwise the straps are too loose.  Having the straps preset is makes it difficult when the child often wears different types of clothes and makes for straps that will inevitable be too tight or more seriously too loose. Every other infant carrier my family has owned have always had some sort of front accessible tension device that makes it easier to put the child in and take them out as well as adjust for the child on a daily basis and as they grow.  I acknowledge that seat belts work best when they are placed snuggly on as few layers of clothes as possible but anyone that has taken care of kids now that it is not always possible to have them in a onesie in the car seat and then put all other layers on them after they get out of the car.  This s especially true of children that still ride in carriers.  My experience is that infants will be dressed in varying layers depending on the outside weather since they will likely stay in the carrier for extended periods of time.  Loosing the ability to adjust the straps quickly and easily is a definite deal breaker for me.Aside from that, it does seem like a good seat and i do appreciate it's lightweight.  That s definitely a plus as the child grows past 20 pounds and trying to carry them in and out of the seat base.## CLICK vs CLASSIC -- The term Click Connect is Graco's newer series of car seats that will give you an audible "click" sound to know that you have secured the the car seat to the base or stroller.  On the Classic Connect system, you would snap in the seat to the base and then utilize either some straps or levers to secure the seat to its base.  Both the Click Connect and the Classic Connect are Graco's product lines designed for infants.NOTE however that these two systems ARE NOT COMPATIBLE with one another.  This isn't a problem if you're starting from scratch and getting an entirely new system to outfit your vehicles.  However, if you're dealing with hand-me-downs, or got a new addition to your household, this may pose an issue  Graco's SnugRide line predates the ClickConnect series, as the SnugRide name was also used for their Classic series.  If you're trying to look for strollers or other accessories compatible with this car seat, etc., be extra careful and MAKE SURE it explicitly states that its compatible with the CLICK connect system -- if it doesn't, its likely that its only compatible with the older CLASSIC Connect line.  If you're looking to use the car seat with another manufacturer's stroller, you may need to contact the manufacturer to see if they have a compatible adapter.

The ExoLens 2 Lens Kit is made by ExoLens, which according to the box, is owned by Fellowes.The kit comprises of two compact lens (165 degree wide angle lens, and a 3x telephoto lens), telephoto lens hood, inner/outer lens caps, the bracket with built-in tripod mount (you still need to get the tripod itself), and the lens bag.  The kit feels light, but does not feel cheap at all.When using this lens kit, you should have a reasonable set of expectations -- this is a camera-phone that you're using after all.  The phone hardware and software was not designed to accommodate the external lens.  The two lens does give you some added features, but it would be unreasonable to expect it to perform on par with SLRs and the like.  What you get here are two good lens that perform reasonably well.The wide angle lens works very well.  After some usage, I've found I like using this more than messing around with the panorama setting on the phone.  It expands your field of view by about 35% than without.  I've found this great for family photos in tight spaces, and the occasional selfie.The telephoto lens gives me the ability to better zoom into an object, rather than relying too heavily on the iPhone's digital zoom.  The results looks good, and seems a bit clearer than the digitally zoomed in photos on the iPhone.This is a nice kit for those that want just a bit more from their iPhone camera.  The lens are not too bulky, and can easily be swapped in and out as the need arises.  For me, this is a kit that I may bring out to special occasions and on trips, but not something that I'll be bringing with me on a daily basis.  Is it worth the price?  For me, though I like the results, I don't see myself taking this out with me often enough to justify the price.  However, it is a well built kit, and may be worthy of your hard earned money.

The Antec Note is a relatively small portable bluetooth stereo speaker, that also includes a built-in microphone.  The package includes the following:- Antec Note bluetooth speaker- approximately 20" Micro-USB to USB cable (the same cable used to charge most non-Apple smartphones)- 14" 3.5mm male-to-male auxiliary audio cable- Quick start guide- Warranty booklet- Model #/Serial # stickersPairing and setting up this bluetooth speaker was easy despite the horrid instructions.  After charging the speaker with the included USB cable for a couple hours, I toggled the power switch to ON.  To pair, I turned on the bluetooth feature on my phone (Samsung Galaxy Note 3), and held down the PLAY button on the speaker for 3 seconds, which put the speaker into the pairing mode.  The speaker immediately showed up on my phone, and was paired.To use the speaker, in addition to turning the device ON, you need to open the leather-like flap of the speaker.  If the flap closes, the speaker turns OFF, or goes into STANDBY mode.  After the speaker was on, I proceeded to play some music from my phone.  The sound was louder than my phone's speakerphone and laptop speaker, loud enough to fill up my bedroom.  The sound was what I'd consider adequate, but certainly wouldn't meet the stringent requirements of an audiophile.As this has a built-in mic, I proceeded to make a phone call.  The other party heard me clearly, and I heard the other person.  However, the sound I heard coming through the speaker was a bit muffled.  Switching the call back to my phone, the sound was a bit more clear.The Antec Note works well for what it is.  Its not going to replace your larger speaker system.  It is an ideal accessory to accompany your smartphone or tablet.  Though it'll work as a speaker/mic for your smartphone, the sound quality heard from the speaker leaves a bit to be desired.  If you're getting it as a bluetooth speaker, then the Antec Note seems to provide some decent value.  If you're buying it to use as a bluetooth speaker/mic to make calls, then look elsewhere for something specifically designed for that purpose.

This George Foreman grill is versatile in the sense you can use it indoors or out.  The grill is an excellent (and I believe healthier) alternative to the charcoal or propane grills as it is lightweight, doesn't coat your food in harmful carcinogens and doesn't require picking up those alternative fuel types.  Using electric vs those other fuel types also gives you more control over the amount of heat as well as a more even heat over the entire grill.  As it is portable (and pretty lightweight), it also makes it easier to clean.The package comes with large grilling surface (this unit has a 200 sq. inch surface) that is advertised as a 12-serving grill.  If this isn't adequate for your needs, they also have a larger one with a 240 sq. inch surface advertised as a 15-serving grill.  While I haven't seen the 15-serving grill, I'd say this 200 sq. inch surface is plenty big for most families.  It also comes with a 4-legged pedestal that is about 2 ft in height.This key differentiating feature of the model of the George Foreman Grill that you're looking at, the GFO201RX, versus the GFO201R and most other George Foreman grills is that the surface is ceramic instead of teflon-coated.  It is advertised as being more 5x durable, though I have no basis for comparison.I tested this grill over the weekend and was pleased.  I used the grill outdoor on my deck.  The large grilling surface was able to handle about 6 large steaks and 13 burgers at once.  The food was evenly cooked and juicy.  The grill has a drip tray to rid away all the excess fat that can be easily emptied when full.  Cleanup was a snap as I was able to wash it down with the hose.All in all, I have come away pleased with the results, and would recommend this to anyone in search of a grill.

This review is for Belkin's Conserve Insight Energy Use Monitor, not for the other 5 products that this product page seems to be bundled with.This energy use monitor is a simple user friendly product that will help you measure your energy usage.  It is an easy way to measure how much energy your power hungry devices are using whether its on or "off," and whether you should consider completely unplugging, or purchase a more energy efficient product.  The device will give you readings on how much power is consumed, the average cost per 30 days or 365 days based on average electricity rates, as well as the estimated CO2 emissions associated with powering the device for 30 days or 365 days.When I first plugged my laptop into the device, the readings were all over the place.  It fluctuated significantly.  Leaving my laptop plugged in for at least the recommended 45 minutes, the device is able to gather enough data points to provide more accurate averages, and is better able to project usage over the 30 days or 365 days.I have previously used a competing product, the P3 P4400 Kill A Watt Electricity Usage Monitor.  While the information provided is similar, I've found the Belkin easier to use for one simple reason -- theres a cord.  The Kill-A-Watt device plugs straight into the wall, and gives you the reading.  If your outlet is near the ground, you'll need to crouch down to view the screen.  This Belkin device differs in that it has the control and the the readings on a display screen that is attached via a 3-ft cord.  This makes toggling the buttons and reading the display much easier (especially if the outlet you're plugging it into is hard to reach).  Additionally, the buttons are larger, making it easier to press.Though this device costs significantly more than the Kill-A-Watt device, this device seems to be easier to use, and I would recommend it to those in search of a simple energy use monitor.

I've been using an electric shaver for years and shave once every 2-3 days.  My current shaver has served me well (or so I thought), over the years.  However, there are some spots that would require at least 5-10 passes to track down some elusive hair that somehow seem to dodge blades -- and in the process causes some skin irritation.  This Norelco Shaver 7300 is a welcome change and has seemed to do a better job of trimming those hairs.For the purpose of this review, I put off shaving for about two weeks.  After charging the shaver up, I began by first using the trimmer (requires removing the shaver head, and putting on the trimmer attachment) to whack through the growth -- the trimmer seemed to work pretty well.  After the hairs were of shorter length, I went through with the shaver.  After a few passes, my mini-beard/mustache was gone, and my skin was smooth again.  There was some minor skin irritation on the first shave, but it did deliver a clean shave.  The 2nd and 3rd shaves seemed to deliver similarly good results with less skin irritation.### PROS- Relatively close shave.  Minimal skin irritation- Quiet- SmartClean base system charges and cleans the shaver.  Utilizing the included SmartClean cartridge, it'll clean the hair out from the head, preventing it from clogging.  It also keeps the head lubricated.- Can also be cleaned manually with water, though they advertise that the SmartClean system will clean it better.- Travel Lock -- On my old shaver, I've encountered times where my shaver would turn on while in luggage.  This shaver has a lock that prevents it from inadvertently turning on.- "Wet" and Battery indicator- Charges full in less than an hour- Trimmer works well- Includes travel carrying pouch.### CONS- Expensive consumables cost.  At the time of this review, the replaceable shaver head costs nearly $50 (to be replaced about once a year).  The SmartClean cartridge should cost about $12/each.- LARGE charging base.  Though the base seems to work well in my limited use, it is large.  With limited bathroom counter space, this is proving a bit problematic.- Trimmer is a separate attachment.- Battery indicator only shows that its low.  No percentage indicator.

The Hamilton Beach breakfast sandwich maker is fairly compact, and is an ideal kitchen appliance for those that make breakfast sandwiches often.  Rather than having to toast a muffin/bread and fry and egg, this device can do all that with relative ease.  And best of all, its easy to clean -- less pans/devices also means less to clean!Though the device I got is intended to make one sandwich at a time, they do have a two sandwich version.  A single sandwich maker should be suitable for most, as it takes only about 5 minutes per sandwich.Since receiving it, I've used it several times to make my own version of the classic Egg Muffin sandwich.  English muffins seems to be the most ideal bread as its relatively small in size.  I attempted to place a bagel in, but the bagel I had would not fit without some trimming.All in all, a decent product that can save you some time in preparing a hot breakfast sandwich.

Most of us have some fat that we'd like to hide away.  For me, its at the belly/waist area.  These seem to ride up a bit high on me, covering up over  my belly button, but does seem to do its job of shifting the fat around, giving the appearance that I have a flatter belly.  It is a snug fit as expected, but relatively comfortable.  Wearing these allows me to wear some slim-fitting shirts again, so for that, I do like it and can recommend.

This is the second Drive Medical transport wheelchair/rollator that I've owned.  I really wanted to like this product.  It has some nice features.  However, in addition to getting around, the whole point of this product is SAFETY.  On that note, I don't believe this is a safe product to use, and would advise AGAINST purchasing this product.### THE GOOD- This unit is lightweight.- Has a storage compartment under the seat- The footrests can be flipped out to use, and easily flipped back in when not in use.- The armrests can flip-up for use and flip-down when not in use.- The backrest can be moved to face the front or back, allowing the user to use the device as a chair in the rollator mode (facing backwards), or be pushed in the transport chair mode (facing forward).### THE BAD- No seatbelt- When "folded up" for storage, it will not stand up on its own.  It needs to be propped up against an object/wall to stand -- and even then, isn't stable.- The handles can be "removed" for storage/transport.  However, as the brake lines are attached, you'll need to carefully pack it.- The padded handles started breaking apart very quickly.  I purchased this unit, and brought it on ONE trip, and already the padded handles are falling apart.### THE UGLYI purchased this for the flexibility of use as a walker as well as a transport chair.  Especially when in transport mode (having a person sit on the seat while being pushed), this unit is very prone to tipping forward.  As shown in the photo I've uploaded, as the chair is being pushed forward, the bulk of the front wheels swivel back.  When the front wheels hit a bump, it makes it VERY easy to tip forward.  This happened to me, causing me to fall forward out of the chair, and the person pushing me to fall forward as well.  Thankfully, neither I nor the person pushing me was hurt.IF you decide to purchase this unit, be aware of this problem and exercise lots of caution when pushing (or being pushed).

I've been using this desktop air purifier for about three weeks now and have been pleased with the performance.  I've been using this in a small office.  I've been suffering a bit from allergies, and this purifier has seemed to help a bit.It is relatively compact, having the footprint of a laptop.  It has three speed settings -- low, medium, and high.  At low, it is hardly noticeable.  At high, I can hear it, but it doesn't bother me much.  I usually leave the unit on low, and it seems to be doing a good job.Like most air purifiers, this contains a relatively inexpensive air filter that will need to be replaced from time to time.  Though I haven't had to replace the filter yet, its always good to research into maintenance cost of these units (how much it costs to maintain, and upkeep).  At the time of this review, if you replace the filter itself, it can be found for as cheap as about $3/filter (when purchased in multipacks) -- not bad for once or twice a year.This seems like a quality air purifier that is best suited for a small room.  I would recommend this unit.

Based on the reviews, I purchased four of these luggage locks for a trip.  The instructions on how to set the combination seemed simple enough:-----1. Adjust dials so the preset factory combination of 0-0-0 aligns with the markers2  Hold cable tip (A) and move toward left to remove from lock  (Cable tip A is on the side with the combination dials)3. While pushing in button (B) turn the dials to any combination you choose  (the button B that its referencing is at the bottom of the lock)4. Release button (B), insert cable tip (A) back into the hole, push down and move all the way to the right5. The lock is now ready to be used with your combination.  To change the combination again, repeat steps 2-4-----Though the instructions are pretty easy, I ran into a problem at step 3, where it states that the button should be pushed while changing the combination.  I had unknowingly released the button while changing the combination -- this caused the combination to change to the number that it was on when I had released the button -- OOPS.  Pretty annoying to say the least on a newly purchased lock -- as I was in a rush, I was not in the mood to try all the different possible combinations.  That leads me to a tip:HAVE SOMEONE HELP!  Two sets of hands will make it much easier to set.  Have one person hold the lock and use a pen or other item to push in the button (it'll be difficult to press the button down with your finger).  Have the second person toggle the combination dials to the new combination that you want set.I was prepared to return the lock, but wanted to see if there was a work-around -- My lock was still open, I just needed to figure out how to reset it.  It seems the only workaround is to actually hack the lock itself and exploit a flaw in these types of locks.  This was bittersweet -- I was happy to be able to figure out the combination I had accidentally set, but now know how UNSECURE this lock is.  After reading about the flaw itself, I was literally able to crack the code within 30 seconds.Though this lock will be a deterrent to the opportunistic thief, it will not keep your stuff safe from a determined criminal.  Had I known before how easy it is to accidentally set the wrong combo, and how easy it is to crack the code, I would not have purchased this lock.  Due to those reasons, I cannot recommend this lock.

This is one relatively nice shredder.  When purchasing shredders, theres a few key things you need to consider:1)  What size of paper are you shredding?2)  How frequently will you be shredding?3)  How large are the stacks of paper will you be shredding?4)  How small (secure) do you need the documents shredded?5)  Besides paper, what else do you need shredded?  Staples, CD/DVDs, credit cards?After answering those questions, you should be able to narrow down your search to find yourself the shredder that best suits your needs.For this AmazonBasics 6-sheet high security micro-cut shredder, it can shred up to the standard 8.5" width paper without folding (some larger shredders intended for offices can manage 11" width at the mouth without folding).  It has the capacity to shred 6-sheets of paper at one time, for up to about 3-minutes continuously before it needs a short break. AmazonBasics has larger capacity versions available, but this unit should serve most basic needs.  The one essential feature that everyone should look for in a shredder is how small it can slice and dice the paper to -- this unit slices to 5/32" x 15/32" sized pieces which is pretty small (a good thing!).  The smaller the cuts, the more difficult it is for those with malicious intents to tape up your shredded documents.  This particular unit will also allow you to shred credit cards -- I placed one of my old credit cards through the shredder's dedicated credit card slot, and it was able to shred through it with ease.Beyond the those primary features, this shredder includes a manual reverse (to remove paper jams), and a 4-gallon waste bin.This is one quality shredder that performs very well for basic home use.  It did not jam once in my few weeks of use, though I expect that it will eventually.  I would highly recommend this shredder to those that are looking to shred bank statements, important documents, and the occasional credit cards.

Pregnancy tests aren't cheap... My wife and I have been trying to have a baby, and the price of all these tests can add up.  We have been using some very inexpensive tests that come in bulk.  My wife just performed a test with the cheap brand, and now with this Clearblue to confirm the results -- negative.This Clearblue Easy Plus Pregnancy test cannot be any easier to test.  Hold the test on the contoured end, place the other in the urine stream.  After a couple seconds, the end in the urine stream will turn pink, letting you know that the test is working.  After a few minutes, the results will appear -- either a + for positive (pregnant), or - for negative (not pregnant).

My family and I have been taking SmartyPants-brand vitamins for the past year and have really enjoyed it.  We have taken the regular SmartyPants vitamins, the ones with more fiber, and the kids in the family have taken the kids version.  We like these in part because of the taste.  When it comes to vitamins, the focus should be on the nutritional benefits, not the sweet gummy taste.  However, just like with the kids, the gummy acts as our motivator.This Prenatal vitamin has most of the essential vitamins needed to promote health of the baby and mom.  As noted in the nutritional facts, this product does lack Iron -- you should consider taking a supplement to make up for that.  Though my wife isn't pregnant yet, when her OB recommended that she start taking prenatal vitamins, we looked to SmartyPants first and have been happy with our choice and would recommend this to prenatal to expecting moms.

I received the 1,500 PSI model for review.  I've never used pressure washers before, but was interested in what it could accomplish.  For my washing needs, I previously utilized my standard garden hose -- not too effective.  This is obviously leaps and bounds better than a standard garden hose.The GreenWorks GW1501 1,500 PSI model is one of their smallest units, and is suitable for basic washing needs.  It is relatively portable with a small handle on top to bring around easily.  However, keep in mind that you will need to have it plugged in to a standard power outlet, so a long extension cord may be necessary.  Hooking everything up was pretty easy without instructions.  In a matter of a few minutes, I was up and running, spraying down my dirty neglected front steps, and even gave my car a rinse.  It did a decent job of getting dirt washed away, but I needed to hold the unit a bit close to get enough power to wash things down.This unit seems ideal for small jobs, and I'm now searching for more things to pressure wash.  I would recommend this for those with very basic needs.  If you plan to use it more regularly, I would likely recommend purchasing the more powerful units.

I purchased this piece of luggage in 2011.  I travel a few times per year.  By the 2nd or 3rd trip, the zippers were going bad, and even ripped.  On another, the handle is stuck in the closed position.  The spinner wheels were about the only feature that I liked about this piece of luggage.  If I had to do it all over again, I wouldn't buy this.

This is one lovely cast iron grill pan!  Like all cast iron cookware, this is heavy.  But this pan, with its beautiful blue enamel coated exterior, isn't just all looks -- it is very well made.  One nice feature of the pan is that the handle is stainless steel -- the use of this reduces the transfer of heat to the handle.  Additionally, it has a "helper" handle on the other end of the pan to make it easier to lift the heavy pan.  Before using any new cast-iron pan, you'll want to season it.  Following some basic instructions I found online, I did the following:1.  Wash the pan with soap and water (generally shouldn't do this, but OK if you are going to season it)2.  Apply a light coating of cooking oil onto the pan using a paper towel3.  Place the pan in the oven upside down on the center rack.4.  Place a sheet of aluminum oil on the bottom rack below the rack to catch dripping oil.5.  Bake in the oven at about 375' for an hour.  After an hour, just let the pan sit and cool down completely before removing.After those steps, you should be able to start using your new pan.Over the past few weeks I've been using this regularly, and though its heavy, it has been nothing but a pleasure to use.  I highly recommend this pan for its good looks and features.

This is the second pressure cooker that I own, the first being the Instant Pot IP-DUO60 7-in-1 Programmable Pressure Cooker, 6Qt/1000W, Stainless Steel Cooking Pot and Exterior, Latest 3rd Generation Technology.  I found this pressure cooker easy to use.  Here are some of the pros/cons of the Elite Platinum, with some comparisons:Pros:> Stainless steel pot (the Instant Pot also has this)> At the top of the lid, there is a knob that can be twisted to release the pressure.  When you flip the lid to wash the inside, the knob stays attached.  On the Instant Pot, the pressure release mechanism comes off.  Its better to have it stay attached so it doesn't get lost.> Delayed start -- You can set the pressure cooker to start within a 24-hr period.  This is great to have things all ready to cook in the pot in the morning or the night before, set the timer, and have it start cooking while you're on your way home from work.  The Instant Pot does not have this feature.> Detailed and clear instructions.  I was up and running very quickly.  The learning curve may have been lower based on my experience with the Instant Pot.  The Instant Pot took me a bit longer to learn.> Relatively inexpensive (as of this review, it is about $40 cheaper than the Instant Pot)Cons:> To start cooking, it requires pressing more buttons than the Instant Pot.  For the Elite Platinum, if you want to Saute, you would need to press the Saute (the light turns on), then press start.  On the Instant Pot, you would just need to press the one button and it starts.  (this is a minor con, as it takes just an extra press or two, but something to get used to)All in all, this is a decent pressure cooker and I recommend it.

I've been reading this to my 3.5 yr old nephew for the past few weeks and he's been enjoying it.  From the story itself to the illustrations, he's become more interested about bugs.  The author does a good job of relaying some real tidbits about bugs and keeping the story engaging.  I'll certainly be looking into other books in the series for my nephew.

I had tried using the Huggies pull-ups training pants for my 3.5 yr old nephew, but they seemed a bit tight.  These seem to fit much better on him.  They've been "used" a few times, and after a few weeks of use, we haven't seen any leakage yet.  Additionally, it hasn't caused any rashes or left any marks from the elastic band that some other diapers have left before.  Hopefully this is a product that won't be needed soon, but its nice to know that if its still needed, GoodNites has larger sizes available.  This is a good product, and I recommend it.

These are some stylish storage boxes that is intended for small items.  The items arrives flattened.  Upon opening up, you place the hexagon-shaped bottom into it, and it becomes a sturdy container.The hex box seems ideal for jewelry, office supplies (pens/pencils), toothbrushes, etc., and placed in either drawers, desks, or even the bathroom counter.  Though it is a bit small, it can fit a decent bit of items.  For me, I intend to place them on the my desk and fill it with office supplies as it would seem like a waste to place a nice container hidden in a drawer.  It may seem a bit pricey for what amounts to a mere storage container, but it is stylish and serves its purpose.  SOFI also has other shape/sizes available to offer.

These are some good training pants.  I had used some of the boys training pants with my nephew, and these work just as well with focused protection on where girls need it.  The idea behind these training pants is that once the pants get a bit wet, it turns cold within seconds alerting the child to go to the bathroom.Training kids to potty train can be a bit hectic, but these certainly help.  It does not seem to hold as much liquid as the old diapers, but its not supposed to.  As with the boys Pull-Ups training pants, I found these to run a little bit small.  Similar to the boys version, these pull-up training pants feature velcro straps, making it easy to change your child without having to completely remove their underwear, pants, socks, shoes, and whatever else they may have.If you have a child that needs help getting potty trained, these training pants are worth a try!

These are excellent training pants for toddlers.  I got these to use with my nephew.  The fit is a bit on the small side, but with the elastic bands, we managed to get it on him for a snug fit -- I would recommend ordering a larger size.  (If your child outgrows the 3T-4T for this, try the GoodNites line as they are targeted at bigger boys.)  Pulling the pants up/down has never been a problem for my nephew, and he had no trouble with this.  Though these are marketed as night time, they of course work during the day time too (with exception of the glow-in-the-dark feature).  In the several nights these were tested, and he had put it to "use," there were no reports of leakage!Sidenote -- My nephew loves the Disney characters design -- so much so that he's not ashamed to show it off to everyone!

New Chapter makes some high quality vitamins.  When it comes to your children, you want to give them the best  This postnatal vitamin may just be that -- the best available.  Prior to the birth of our child, we used New Chapter's prenatal vitamins; after the birth of our child, we switched to their postnatal vitamins.  These multivitamins provide the essential minerals and vitamins to both mom and baby.  However, this multivitamin is a bit lacking in a few key vitamins such as calcium, iron, and magnesium -- I would recommend taking an additional supplement.  We like this multivitamin because it is easy to digest with no aftertaste.  However, taking 3 a day is a bit of a pain.As always, you should speak with your doctor to see what he/she would recommend as every person's body/needs are different.As you no doubt have noticed, this vitamin is expensive.  At over $1 per day, not including other supplements you need to take for what this lacks, it is one of the most expensive out there.

Based on the other reviews, I had some high hopes for this flea and tick treatment.  The treatment seems to be working well.  However, I was disappointed for the following reasons:The one end of the applicator is supposed to be used to part the hair.  This was rather ineffective -- it would be easier to use your hands.  If there were some sort of bristles like a comb, it would be much more effective.Additionally, the mouth of the applicator is pretty wide.  When applying it to my dog, the meds flowed rather quickly, making a mess and spreading all over.As I mentioned, the treatment itself works pretty well.  However, the review is for the entire product (including the applicator), not just the treatment.  he applicator has room for improvement. If Adams were to fix the applicator, I would bump up the rating to a 4 or even 5 star product.

The design of the bottle is really nice - sleek, comfortable, and best of all, easy to clean.  I like the bottle markings so I know exactly how many ounces in feeding my infant.  As far as i can tell, it's really helped nipple confusion so that mom can take a break, and dad can help with the feeding sessions.  Despite its small size, I envision using it late on for juices when my child can hold the bottle.

This is a simple yet beautiful bracelet. When looking at it in person, the heart shaped opal is shining and impressive. The bracelet looks better in person than the photo Amazon provides.  The sterling silver is solid and good quality. The clasp is easy to open and close by myself with extra safety snaps on the each side.  The clasps are secure enough that I have no fear that it'll fall off even if I wear it during a swim.As with other pieces of jewelry from the Amazon collection, it comes with an elegant black jewelry box.  It‚Äôs a perfect gift for the woman you love.I measured the bracelet, and the advertised size is spot on, 7.5".  It was a bit too loose for my wife.  If you don't have one of those garment tape measures, I'd advise wrapping a string around the wrist and measuring the string with a ruler.

The Arkon Magnetic phone mount works wonderfully.  This mount works like few others out on the market today.  Instead of the traditional clamps that hold the sides of your phone, this one works by placing a THIN magnetic piece on the back end of your phone/device.  Once its on, it will stick to the magnetic mount.The great thing about the this is that it works well with my cell phone case.  I can stick it between my phone and my case with no issues -- it also makes it not noticeable at all.  This is a huge plus as my previous mounts had trouble holding my phone + case in place (I would constantly have to remove my case to keep it in the mount).  Additionally, all you have to do is place it on the mount with relative ease instead of having to pry the mount clamps onto your phone -- this is effortless with the Arkon magnetic mount!The one drawback I've found is with certain features of the phone that gets engaged when it comes in contact with a magnet -- such as "car mode."  That isn't entirely the fault of the mount, but something to keep in mind as it can get annoying.All in all, this is a good solid mount.

Kenwood is a brand that I would associate more with stereo equipment than anything else.  The brand has been around for quite a while.Before I started using this machine, I used a basic toaster oven.  The kind that has a metal tray that pulls out when you open the front door.  The machine was cheap, and served its purpose -- to toast.This toaster itself features a single wide slot to toast, and is similar to other toasters where you lower the bread in vertically.  The slot is wide enough for two standard slices of bread.  The slot's can be adjusted using a lever on the bottom right side that allows the slot to accommodate larger/thicker breads if necessary (e.g. bagels, croissants, panini, etc.).One type of sandwich I always loved making in my toaster is grilled cheese sandwich.  Though it is possible to make a grilled cheese sandwich in this toaster, you'll need to make some adjustments.  Instead of using two slices of bread with some cheese in the middle, I needed to make sure that the end that went into the toaster first was "folded" so that the cheese wouldn't melt and drip down.  The same can be said with most types of sandwiches with any types of filling -- take care in putting it into the toaster, as you don't want your fillings dripping/falling down into the toaster.  Clamping down on the bread with the lever does help to keep things in place a bit, but things inevitably will fall into the toaster's crumb tray.  The crumb tray pulls out from the front for easy cleaning.The toaster has four pre-set buttons for toast, croissants, panini and bagels, and a single cancel button  You can easily pull up whatever it is you're toasting to see the toasting progress and lower it back down without stopping/cancelling the toasting process.  If you decide that your item is toasted the way you want it, just press the cancel button and the unit/heating elements shuts down pretty quickly.  There is also a knob on the side that you can dial from 1 to 5 to adjust the amount of toasting time.In my testing, the results were pretty good.  However, I'm the kind of person that likes to set it and forget it.  I love the look of this toaster and the features, but I dislike having to make adjustments in the way I prep the food to prevent dripping.  Perhaps I've been spoiled by my cheap toaster oven?  That aside, this is a nice toaster, and I would recommend it, especially those looking for a toaster to do the basics.

This beautiful sink couldn't come at a better time.  I'm in the process of building my new house, and the sink has been placed in my kitchen.As the product title indicates, this is an undermount sink.  For those that do not know, it means that the sink is mounted below a surface -- such as a countertop.  In my case, I have installed this below a granite countertop and it looks great.  This particular sink is one large single bowl measuring about 31" x 18".  Kohler makes other size variations to suit your needs.The key differentiating factor between this sink and most on the market today is Kohler's "Innovation Preserve" feature which Kohler claims makes this sink scratch resistant.  Unconvinced, I put this to the test myself.  I brought out several knives, forks, and other utensils/instruments that I figured would be able to cause some scratches.  None seemed to do the trick.As you will notice from the product page, compared to other sinks this one is expensive!  However, anyone that has owned a stainless steel sink will attest that its prone to scratches.  If scratches is something that may bother you, the added expense may be worthwhile.  Fortunately for me, I won't need to worry about scratching my beautiful sink.

Avery makes excellent products -- from labels to dividers to any customizable printing products..If theres something you need labels to do, Avery likely has something for your needs.I recently reviewed a similar product from Avery, the Avery Write-On Dividers for Classification File Folders, 5-Narrow Bottom Tabs per Set, 2-Hole Top Punched at the Top of Each Page (13164).  The product you're looking at on this page is very similar to the other one with the exception that the tabs are on the side rather than the bottom, and these have bigger tabs.This classification divider product is ideal for those that use the two-pronged/two-hole punch folders at the top. The two holes are reinforced to prevent the divider from tearing. This pack includes 5 dividers to create one set, with big write-on tabs on the side to properly identify each section.  The write-on tabs are certainly easier than attempting to squeeze little labels through plastic tabs.  This is a good product, and I highly recommend it.

These are some great plastic index dividers that appear to be far stronger than your typical index dividers.  The dividers have clear diagonal-cut pockets that allow you to stuff a fair amount of paper (I stored about 20 sheets without a problem).  The package includes a total of 8 dividers and some clear printable labels that you can print onto from your computer to label the indexes.  One of this product's selling points is the ability to affix all 8 labels onto all the dividers at once -- I had no problems doing this, but its not a big deal for me either way as slapping on 8 individual labels wouldn't be too difficult.I would recommend this product to those that want some durable index dividers with pockets.

Anyone familiar with office products know that Avery is the standard when it comes with labels and various printable media.  This classification divider product is ideal for those that use the two-pronged/two-hole punch folders at the top.  The two holes are reinforced to prevent the divider from tearing.  This pack includes 5 dividers to create one set, each with a narrow tab that allows you to write-on a title for the section.Til now, I thought there were only the 3-hole letter-sized dividers with the tabs on the side.  These dividers are well made and come in handy (but at a relatively hefty price).  On the product itself, I would rate it 5 stars.

I've been using this beautiful leather case for the past week and have come away with some mixed impressions.  This case has temporarily replaced the case I had been using for 3 months -- the iPhone 6 Case, MaxboostÆ [Vibrance Series] iPhone 6 (4.7) Case [Lifetime Warranty] Protective SOFT-Interior Scratch Protection Metallic Finished Base with Vibrant Trendy Color Slider Style Hard Cases for iPhone 6 6S (4.7 inch) (2014) - Italian Rose / Ch....On the positive side, this case feels like its very high quality.  It is very lightweight, the leather has a nice feel to it, lined with what feels like suede so it won't scratch your phone, snaps on to the phone easily, and is easy to grip.  It also came with a screen protector, which is often purchased separately.On the negative side, the case doesn't offer too much protection.  If you view the product images by the manufacturer, the top and bottom of the case as well as the sides for buttons are not enclosed by the case -- it is "open" towards the screen side.  This allows dirt to be trapped into the small "channels" on the sides of phone.  The case overlaps the other channel areas offering protection.Additionally, it does not appear to offer much protection for the screen.  The sides of the case, the lip, does not extend beyond the screen.  If the phone were to be dropped flat on the screen, or even simply placed on a desk, the screen will come in direct contact with the surface.  If the lip was to extend beyond each of the 4 corners of the phone slightly, it would offer a bit more protection.Although I like the look and feel of the case, I still prefer my original case.  Unfortunately for me, I use and abuse my phone a bit, and this case doesn't offer the sort of protection I need.  If looks are important to you, and you aren't worried about your phone being damaged from drops, then this case may work well for your needs.

I have bought two other versions of the smart pants vitamins and with this third type I can honestly day that I highly recommend this product as well as their entire line of vitamins.  Their guns are ready to take unlike those huge tablets that gets lodged in your throat.  I have noticed that the daily serving size ranges from 4 per day for the kids vitamins to 6 per day for the adult vitamins.  Even so, I have taken all six at one time and was able to chew and swallow then no problem.  Great to leave I your nightstand and take even if you don't have water (no guarantees you won't get cavities if you do it this way though)Great product. Keep it up Smarty Pants!

I will love LEMISHINE til the end of time.  We have such hard water, I need to add this to every single load. It makes all the difference.  Before I discovered it, I'd soak my glasses in vinegar about every 6 weeks because they were so milky.
This does not hold together well enough to work.  I've made 10-12 trays now, and no matter what I do, there's always a flat spot (at least a centimeter.)

I bet all reviews start with this;I hate that I have to use this product but... (thanks to an anti-seizure medication I've been on for 5+ years, probably 1/3 of my hair is now gone for good.)I've only tried one other brand (Bosley) so I don't have much to COMPARE this to, but I can tell you this is as good of a product as Bosley (which has been around for a long time and seems to have a loyal following.)  However, after being sold a counterfeit version of Bosley, I decided to try something else.  Enter Cuvva.This doesn't hide my problem entirely, not while still being able to make it look natural. The hair loss is too great.  I mean, the photo Cuvva has of their before and after shows the man with 2 different hairstyles (if it's even the same man.)  This is not a miracle cure. I've had to work a lot on my hair, adding product (besides this type) I've not used since the 80's, blowdrying my hair so this works well.

First off, why not 5 stars?  -- Simple; I'm afraid the microphone is going to break. I've seen both of my boys and my fully grown-up adult aged husband all toss these down when they're frustrated at their games. A friend told me my boys aren't the only ones. It's not even that the mic feel like it will easily break, but with it sticking out during talk, and these are tossed onto the floor (or left on the floor to be stepped on.)  Other than that, I've got no reports of bad from my actual 3 users.Here's what I do have from them:(1) the lights are 'cool'(2) the headphones are very comfortable for long term(3) the headphones make my ears sweat after too long(4) likes that the mic doesn't have to be in front of his face - that it still picked up his voice(5) the sound is good*(6) likes that he can change the cord from side to side(7) wishes it would work on XBox360 also(8) shocked these don't come with a case, wondered if one is available specifically for these*I verify the sound is decent. I listened to music (yes, with the adapter you can use these on a regular headphone jack like on an iphone or computer.)  However, I did not test at loud volumes, something I think gamers hear a lot of just by nature of the games (explosion, tires squealing, fighting, etc) Still, none of my boys mentioned a loss of sound quality.If these can handle the wear and tear of a couple of competitive teens and their dad -- it might be a sign that we need to invest in another pair. The headset feels sturdy, just need to wait and see on the microphone.

I'm a BIG fan of Tess Gerritsen, having read all of her printed works.This story was a departure from her typical medical thriller.  Gerritsen has written outside that realm, but she most definitely has excelled in the medial thriller/mystery genre. Her voice is so natural and comfortable to read. She developed the characters well, and relatively quickly. Playing With Fire is a particularly interesting book as the story takes us between two different times, and two different groups of characters (and 2 different main characters.)  *This was slightly annoying because you'd really be getting into one part of the story and the chapter would end and you now have to read about what happened 65 years ago to someone else. Gerritsen is not usually a tease, but for this story it was almost necessary (looking at it from hindsight.)  The old story, though a terrible ending, is still actually quite beautiful in it's own right. It *did* make me cry. The modern part of the story very much had the feel of a typical Tess Gerritsen book, her voice, just without all the medical stuff (there was a teeny bit but absolutely nothing like we usually see.)I kept wondering if there was a supernatural thing going on with this story, which urged me forward to find the answers. As a fully vested reader, I HAD to know how things would turn out for both my characters and absolutely devoured this book over the course of 2 very busy days (in between everything I kept picking up the book.)There was a bit of romance. Adventure. History. Music. Psychology.  I know a Tess Gerritsen fan will like this book, but I think she's going to draw in more fans here than her normal readership.  This is a special story.

Our " puppy"  has gone through 3 of these in the year and a half that we've had him.  He's 3 1/2 now.  And these KONG brand of stuffies for animals has really shown a great durability.  I worry about my completely stupid dog eating the filling from a toy. He would absolutely do it. He is that dumb.  I know I am not alone.  The KONG stuffies will break and start to lose their stuffing, but you have time.  Each limb is sewn on separately, and sewn well.  All of the sections are sewn separately so even if something came open it wouldn't release much.My dog loves his pink elephant stuffie almost as much as a rawhide twist. Almost.

I'm not brave enough to try these myself, so here's what my 4 dogs said;Yea, nothing.  They don't talk.  But they do get excited when they see or hear the big heavy paper bag that holds their favorite bones... All 4 of my dogs enjoy these. I like the limited ingredients. They are easy enough for ME to break down into smaller pieces for my small, elderly chihuahua (she can eat about 1/4 of one at a time.) My 20lb mix can eat one and it's the perfect size for his mouth.My dogs just are not " picky"  eaters. I can't say there is a more favorite flavor than another in here. But again, they like them, and I like the ingredients -- so it works for us.

Devoted fan of nearly 30 years would sooner die than write something negative about the best band in the world. But it also occurs to me I don't even know how to praise them anymore. The Mission has been the soundtrack to my life for decades, for most of my life. How do I express why I've done that?

Ok, so I've been using these for a couple of weeks. Not heavy usage yet -- it's just too early to give a great review like that. I'll come back in September to update after a bit more substantial wear and tear.Meanwhile -- I grabbed these because they are adorable. Period.  Good enough reason sometimes. But they're more like a vinyl than plastic, so the flexibility is there. Preference perhaps, but as long as my papers are in the binder as well, they should remain relatively flat. I don't need super rigid folders.I've only gotten one package, and have been trying to make my upcoming yearly lesson plans and attendance and badges and etc etc all fit into one main binder. I've had papers in and out, over and again many times lately.  And as I said, this is far from heavy use, but I think the flexibility of the folders will help keep them from ripping or splitting (and being sharp.)Complaints - I wish I had more choice in patter/color variety (ie all pink, or all chevron)I wish the price wasn't so high. Will have to keep an eye out for sales.I wish the front pocket was a little higher up to hold papers in more securely when I've 'stretched out' the pocket in the future.All in all, I like these and despite the shortcomings, I will be ordering more (when on sale, of course.)

I wanted to love this grill because I love the smaller one - which we own - but it's small and I muse about how nice it would be to have the bigger version of our grill so my family of 6 can eat together.Let's start with "6 servings." This grill is sizeable, but you can't put 6 sandwiches of artisan type bread on this grill. When you use larger pieces of bread the surface is only able to handle 4 sandwiches (with extra room.)  Can't attest to plain sandwich bread, but I think 6 pieces of that should fit? But I was able to make 6 (1/3lb) burgers and get them on at the same time without issue.  Depends on what you're making, but there's an idea for you about how much can fit on the grill.Temperature control. First of all, I made a label for the front/top of my grill with the temperature ratings. I don't want to have to keep referring back to the book. I've used the grill 4 times now, and I'm only getting good grill color when I've pre-heated the grill for more than 25 minutes.  Not exactly an electricity saver. And that was on MAX temperature. So now I know why they didn't automatically put temperatures on the appliance... probably don't need them as most things will need to be cooked on MAX.And then I have a problem with this grill, a physical problem that is a drawback.  I have fairly standard kitchen counters, but the cabinets prevent the George Foreman grill from opening all the way. And there's no locking mechanism to hold the grill open like that. So as I'm loading it I either have to stand there and hold the grill open with one hand and try to load it with the other, or open and close it for every item going in because it's too tall and the cabinet is in the way. The included cord is very short and does not allow for use where this won't be a problem. Now, the grill opens wide enough that I have full access to the grill plates - so if you have a kitchen situation like that, at least the food fits.We live in Phoenix, so this is still better than walking outside to grill something quickly. Outside IS an oven here in the summer... As much as this grill makes me sad and it's far from perfect, we'll still use it plenty.

I have not even used this yet and it already deserves 2 stars... Received it today from Amazon. This was not a repackage, it was still factory sealed. Shipping box looks good, but the George Foreman box the grill came in was more banged up than the Amazon box. And so I have a broken plastic handle. It's broken enough that I can't see it staying attached for too long. Aside from the sharp edges hazard, it won't affect the grill performance I don't think.Next issue is that the directions kind of sucked. No parts list of what should be there. There's a diagram... That's small and black and white and so everything looks attached or not different from anything else.  Worthless. There's no differentiation between upper and lower leg in the diagram. You have to read the directions. The grill base frame is loose on one side, it wiggles almost a whole cm.  Directions say to attach the grill base frame to the grill base with the included screws.NO screws were included. And it would have been nice to have a parts list so I knew I couldn't do this without a trip to the store for screws first.I'll add to the review after I can get it working. But this thing will need to rock my world now to get a decent review. I did have an indoor grill many moons ago and loved it. So I'm not writing this off yet.

Love lipliner. It's darker than I hoped for, but it actually still works fine with an additional couple of seconds of work. Looks super cute with a lighter pink lip color, gives dimension and definition. And helps me makes my lips look fuller.

I can't read, but that's still hinky advertising. Picture of a pink sponge but they sent blue (I see now it says it's blue...but I wanted pink, like in the picture.)The actual sponge is rectangle and not the curved shape of this sponge (which is what I usually get, the pink curved Scotch Brite sponges.) And it was huge!  Too big for my average sized woman hands to hold without ruining my nails. So I had to cut it in half.  Works fine, but its blue and my kitchen is pink.

This book was quite a good read, better than most books I've read this year.The story began immediately. Right out of the gate, you were headlong into one aspect of this storytelling (not the boring, descriptive set-up too many authors expect you to trudge through.)  Unfortunately, the ending else just basically stopped. Within 10 pages the story went from action and fast paced to resolved and over. Hence 4 stars...So as I said, off like a bat out of you know where. Love that.Having not read the authors previous book, I was at a disadvantage on characters. A lot of characters in this book are thrown at the reader all in a very short time and that was a bit much (having not read the other book.) Also, there weren't as many physical descriptions of the characters by the author. Both of these things slowed me down in the beginning.I was impressed at the prologue and epilogue. The author seemed to be genuinely grateful for the help he got, more so than probably any other prologue I've read before.This story was FAST. Full of conspiracy, full of bad government officials and corruption and greed. Shootings and chases.  Kidnappings, international travel, priests and nuns and spies, and more. (It's hard to write a review without giving up the story.)  Some was plausible. There was one incident that was repeated - which I wasn't expecting, nor did I like in the realm of storytelling.Most characters had their own perspective and voice, and that's how I like most of my stories.If you like a very fast paced book, and can grasp a little techie information, this is a great story.

I love this!!!!! We just tested it out (it arrived this morning.) Now, for as long as I can remember I've used a Black & Decker Brew n Go system. I still have zero complaints about that. In fact, these function identically. The Mr. Coffee brand comes with a much nicer travel cup. It's tall and insulated well. The top has a spout cover, too. And what I really like is the especially narrow footprint. It fits in my windowsill. A whole appliance, plugged in and working, in my small windowsill.For this coffee maker, it's the ultimate in simplicity and earth loving. Brew only a 16oz cup at a time, or less. No cups or pods or any of that. There's a reusable filter basket. You don't have to tip anyone. You'll probably spell your name correctly. Oh, and it brews wicked fast. From the time you hit start (there's only ONE button) to having your cup full is about 2 minutes.My daughter will probably want one of these for college next month. But my high schooler isn't sharing. So I'll be buying another one in the next couple weeks.

I haven't decided, after 1 day and 3 quick recipes, if I don't like this blender or if there's a learning curve to using a blender without sharp blades.As a test, I made 3 of the recipes in the Black & Decker book. Photos are here somewhere for you to see.Let me begin with the peanut butter. The blender ran so long to get it smooth (about 1 minute, then a scrape down, and then a second minute) and it started stinking like the motor was getting really hot so I stopped. We never got it quite smooth enough for what we were aiming for. I actually checked the fire extinguisher, in case I needed it, but it was low so I decided not to make it creamier just in case. (And frankly, turns out the crunchy version was great!)Made salsa. This is where I am not used to this electronic pulse and have a learning curve. I was pressing pulse like I've done on my food processor. You know, push and release. Not so hard. But it's not the same on this Black & Decker blender. All of the ingredients were turning into a salsa smoothie on the bottom of the jar with nothing from the top coming down. After a decent amount of frustration I finally figured out to properly PULSE you need to basically touch the pulse button like it's radioactive. So fast then finger off the button before you even realize the machine did anything. Seriously, between this salsa and a couple different smoothies, this took practice to push it so quickly. Our first batch is more blended than the recipe calls for because of learning how to use the pulse function, but you can still see our salsa doesn't look bad.And then smoothies. This worked fine using the personal blending system.  I learned on the first one that the banana sticks to the side of the jar and doesn't drop down on it's own - so plan to make arrangements to give the bottle a smack to release sticky foods when using the little jar.A big drawback for me is the lack of removable blades from the main unit.  It was pretty hard to clean that thing after making peanut butter, trying to get up in there under the 'blades' was a pain. Luckily the blades aren't sharp. Still, might be just the change I'm not a fan of.Oh, and it's a plastic pitcher. Not glass. Might make a difference to you... I like that so it's not so heavy.  I can teach my kids how to make a smoothie and not worry about heavy glass or sharp blades.

Having great luck with this brand.  I am one of those people who is "allergic" to mosquito bites.  The smallest bite I get is the size of a nickel and lasts for 3 days. Right up front:  If you buy this book because you like thrillers, hard sci-fi, and mind-tweaking visions of the future, you WILL get your money's worth.  Author Suarez is no hack, but rather has extensive knowledge of both computer gaming, and the capabilities of cyber warfare.  Mix in some futuristic weaponry (all of which has either had proof-of-concept initial testing or fits well within the realm of feasibility), some impressively thought-provoking moral and ethical complexity, and some truly perceptive rumination about where technology can and will be taking commerce and human society, and what emerges is a rollicking techno-thriller burns through preconceived notions of the future like a plasma torch cutting through aluminum siding.  So why not five stars?Well, truth be told, the writing could be spiffed up.  Considerably.  Initially taut, the book develops some plot stutters about two-thirds of the way through.  Characters in the book tend to be more suited for a graphic novel, barely reaching 2D status, much less fully fleshed out 3D personas.Bottom line?  A brilliant conception by an author whose intellectual capacity and imagination outstrip, at least in this first novel, his literary skill.  Regardless, a tale that is evocative, provocative, and a helluva fun ride.

I use headlamps frequently.  In Central Oregon, the winter days are short enough that if I want to run, it's in the dark.  I tend to push hikes on either end of the day, showing up before dawn, or getting back after dusk.  The Icon deserves it's name: it's simply terrific.  The batteries last a stunningly long time, and the light output, in several of it's many modes, is outstanding.  The rheostat function, which allows me to smoothly increase/decrease the light output to fit the circumstances, might seem like a useless "bells and whistles" add on.  It isn't:  low level is perfect for me reading my Kindle or book in bed without disturbing my wife, higher levels are great for trail running in the dark hours, medium light level perfect for running on paved paths/roads.  Down sides?  Only one that I've noticed. The light can be tilted up and down, but Black Diamond erred by not giving a greater range of motion in terms of tilting the light downward.  Works just fine for ambulation/skiing/biking, not quite so well when one is stationary and trying to focus on something in one's hands.  Hopefully the next iteration will incorporate a fix for this.  Meanwhile, this sweet instrument fits in the "Wow!" category.

The Great Silence, the deafening LACK of contact from intelligent aliens that the Drake equation says ought to be swarming our galaxy (and the universe, if not multiverse), bothers me mightily.  And it bothers astrophysicist David Brin mightily, too.  The Great Silence is a boon to those skeptical that there is life other than on Earth, those who (modern day anti-Copernicans?) believe on some level that our home planet really IS the center of, and the only example of, sentient life that God and/or physics has managed to create.  Existence is Brin's lengthy and thorough exploration of the possibility that humans are NOT the universe's sole example of a sentient species, enriched and spiced by vigorous conjecture about the future of artificial intelligence (AI).A pertinent bit of biography regarding David Brin: he's an author with a mission.  Successful authors ply their craft for quite a variety of reasons, ranging from personal profit to polemics, from sheer love of wordsmithing to sheer love of self.  And a few write to try to change the world a bit.  Henning Mankell, the terrifically successful Scandinavian mystery writer, for example, spends a good deal of his creative energy, a significant part of his time, and no little amount of his money on promoting the social good as he perceives it.  Brin fits easily into the "change the world a bit" category, as a quick visit to his website will confirm.  An optimist (and a carefully reasoned one), Brin is not afraid to touch what was long a third-rail in anthropology: in his opinion evolution appears to be GOING somewhere.  In Existence, Brin makes a nuanced and sophisticated case, absent of sentimentalism or species chauvinism, that the universe is unfolding itself in a fascinating way.  Humans, should they choose to thread an endless procession of catastrophe needles, just might get to play a role in this.  The sophistication and depth of Brin's approach to this notion is the stuff of a five star novel.  Worthwhile as the book is, though, it doesn't shine with five star luminosity.My favorite creative writing teacher in college would have handed Existence back to Brin with an A for content, and a C+ for writing. One mild to moderate detraction is the liberal cut and paste approach that Brin used (maybe as a labor saving device)to graft previouly published material into Existence.  The result falls short of seamless. Secondly, the characters don't play second fiddle in this space opera, at best they're part of the stage crew.  Much like Kim Stanley Robinson in his latest hard sci-fi opus, 2312, Brin seems to frequently place the plot and characters in cryogenic suspension while he expounds (albeit entertainingly) on theories, conjectures, and technological tours de force that he has clearly been ITCHING to talk with us all about.So....an "A" and a "C+" averages out to a high "B", does it not?  The book is a must for those of you that were nerdy enough to download the SETI program that enlisted millions of home computers to (unsuccessfully) help search for evidence of ET's (yes, I was one of those nerds).  The additional bonus of Brin's conjectures about the future of AI makes this an almost mandatory read for the hard sci-fi buff.  But if you're into a story that flows synchronously, or into narratives that explore the intricacies of human relationships and social intercourse, and don't care all that much about the Great Silence (you really ought to!), you can pass this one by.

Kevin Mitnick's digital universe (maybe more accurately called his playground) is composed of 0's and 1's.  On...off.  Binomial.  Would that the world of ethics could so easily be reduced to the binomial valuation of either good or evil.  Ghost in the Wires, Mitnick's marvelous memoir of his rise, fall, rise in the cyber world of hacking is breathtaking from a technological point of view, and endlessly challenging and deeply complex from an ethical point of view.I would guess that most people that pick this book up want to feed on Mitnick's audacious and brilliant run as one of the world's premier hackers, and such readers will not be disappointed.  Mitnick's penetration of well-defended company data bases, almost at will, is a tech feast version of a groaning table loaded almost to breaking point with delicious main courses, side dishes, and fantastic sweets.  The book would succeed on that basis alone.  But there are other aspects of the book that raise it above the run of the mill memoir.From the vantage point of the semi-aged (I'm 60), this book is a marvelous societal record of the kudzu like advance of technology into every aspect of our lives during the past half century.  What did hackers do before there were computers to hack? Phonephreaking, i.e. manipulating the phone service (largely in the attempt to get free long distance) is what they (and I, as a college student in the 70's) did.  I'm a technophile, and largely welcome technology into my life, but I can say that Mitnick's memoir, as he moved from phonephreaking through his first contacts with computer systems, to the development of the internet, through the dawn of the personal computers, and on to today's Wi-Fi in every coffee shop environment, was both fascinating and sobering.A good memoir gets us inside the mind of the author, and Ghost in the Wires does just that, often with disturbing effect.  Mitnick's self-portrayal varies from accuracy when he describes himself as addicted to hacking, no more able to pass up an opportunity for a major hack than a heroin addict can pass up his/her next dose, to self-delusion when equates the fact that he did not use his hacking for financial gain with never having done any harm.  Mitnick uses the term "social engineering" hundreds of time throughout the book, a term he uses to glibly cover the lying, the leveraging of trust to betray the confidence of those that he was scamming, the habitual and callous manipulation of humans that were acting with the best of motives, that he used to enable his hacking.  One can almost share Mitnick's glee when he used his ability to manipulate humans that were pompous fools or jerks, but in truth Mitnick's techniques of "social engineering" were MOST effective on humans that were helpful, trusting, and doing their best to aid another human being that seemed to need assistance.  So is Mitnick nothing more than a brilliant tech guru that is also little more than a common criminal? In a binomial ethical world, maybe yes.  But in the real world, Mitnick is the embodiment of the Coyote in Native American folklore, the Trickster that pops up in different guises in mythologies all over the world.The Coyote/Trickster, in mythology, has an essential job:  challenge, over and again, the existing system.  Probe it, exploit it.  Find the weaknesses in a system, and expose them.  Few love the Coyote/Trickster, particularly those that are left to clean up the messes being caused (in Mitnick's case, police, company investigators, the FBI, the Secret Service, Mitnick's own family).  Sociologically, though, the argument can be made that the Coyote/Trickster is ESSENTIAL to the wellbeing of any given system.  When provoked by individuals such as Mitnick, the system learns, grows, strengthens itself. In the past, people inoculated themselves with cowpox, which made them a little sick, in order to prevent themselves from getting smallpox, which could kill them.  Mitnick, a human vaccine of sorts, did cause disruption.  Expensive disruption, if one adds up the man hours and the emotional toll the search for him took.  He also taught the cyber "immune system" an enormous amount about how to defend itself better.  Mitnick now works actively to improve that immune system, surely one of the best societal integrations of a Coyote that I've encountered.Does any of this justify Mitnick's actions?  Well.
