That question is what elevates this book from a "Gee whiz, look with I did, and look how smart I am" tale of self-aggrandizement to what it is in fact:  an important tale of our times, to be digested carefully, thoughtfully, and thoroughly.

It takes only modest talent to sketch out a good yarn, regardless of the fictional genre chosen.  An author has to reach deeper to give dimension to the characters in his/her yarn, and deeper yet to reflect on the complexity (both the nobility and the barbarity) of human nature.  In Speaks the Nightbird, author McCammon reaches deep, and comes up with a rich and rewarding tale.The tale, set at the very end of the 17th century in Carolina territory, involves a combination of elements that is almost sure to please:  legal drama, pirate treasure, murder mystery, a bit of international intrigue, young love, and, front and center, a young, beautiful, intelligent woman accused of witchcraft.  Guilded by a wealth of historically accurate detail that McCammon spent over two years researching, the language, the clothing, the social structures, the medical practices, and the overpowering influence of religion at the time, move the plot beyond bare bones to being fully fleshed out with the muscles, sinews, and beating heart of a high quality body of work.In the age of anti-heroic literature, where award winning novels can be read from cover to cover without discovering a single character that one really cares about, Speaks the Nightbird is a refreshing departure.  One DOES care about the characters, and takes pleasure in the successes of those that deserve rooting for, as well as in the stumbles of the villains.I generally don't enjoy historical fiction, and it was only through a bit of a fluke that I picked this story up in the first place.  Regardless of your favorite fictional genre, though, it's hard to imagine that McCammon's literary skill and strong factual and observational integrity will fail to entertain and inform those that begin to turn the pages of Speaks the Nightbird.Flaws?  The author will never be accused of being a man of few words.  In an interview regarding Speaks the Nightbird, McCammon notes that he had to rewrite the first part of the book "because it was too long".  The current length of the first part of the book indicates that the original version must have bordered on interminable.  Secondly, rich as many of the characters in the book are, the portrait of the woman accused of witchcraft, despite her central role, remains curiously wooden.  Way too much about her beautiful black hair and her dark-toned Portuguese skin, way too little about the inner workings of her mind.  The author's descriptions of sex (including an act of bestiality) and violence are quite graphic at times, sure to offend some readers.None of these flaws change the final verdict:  this is one fine tale. The ending invites a sequel, and McCammon has followed with at least 3 sequels to this tale since 2007.

What a Plant Knows is a rare and beautiful piece of science journalism. Author Daniel Chamovitz's writing threads a needle with an aperture so fine that it is only rarely successfully accomplished: in elegantly simple language that is accompanied by a gentle sense of humor and deep integrity, he guides the reader to a new door of knowledge in a fashion that guarantees one will step through it.  And once he/she steps through it, the reader's appreciation of what a plant can sense and remember (yes, remember, in a very specific sense) will be irrevocably altered.This is not a dry and dusty tome.  Though the phrase "I read it in a single sitting" more commonly applies to fictional thrillers (e.g. The DaVinci Code), it's applicable occasionally in science writing, and it's applicable to What a Plant Knows.  Chamovitz, is a natural born teacher.  When the reader wants to know "How the heck does a plant know which way is up, and which way is down?", Chamovitz refuses to plop the final answer out in one paragraph, instead, teasing the reader along the actual historical pathway that elucidates what we now know.  And in so doing, he brings the full beauty of any given aspect of plant biology into focus, but ALSO brings to light the beauty and power of science that is well done; science done by people with a careful but insatiable need to know; science done by people whose need to be accurate exceeds their desire to prove their own theory right.Chamovitz has the startling belief that the unvarnished truth is more fascinating than hyperbole, and hence What a Plant Knows is completely absent the hype and goofiness of The Secret Lives of Plants.  You won't, after reading this book, find yourself crooning your favorite songs to your tomato plants (plants, Chamovitz convincingly demonstrates, really are deaf).  But despite the fact that Chamovitz eschews sensationalism, what he says about the sensory life of plants, and what a plant can "know" and "remember" (the author very carefully defines what he means by those terms) is indeed both fascinating and sensational.The book is just plain fun.  Besides getting to learn terrific words like statoliths (essential for a plant to know which way is up, which is down), Chamovitz ups the relevancy factor multiple notches by linking the knowledge he presents to the reader with real life applications.  He, for example, lets us know just how it is that flower growers get boat loads of chrysanthemums to bloom just in time for Mother's Day. Growers of Northern California's inhalable cash crop use this knowledge in what they call their "light dep" (light deprivation) season.Plants, front and center, are the rock stars of this fascinating book.  But also in starring roles are the folks that quietly, carefully, and with determination, track down the truth about the way our world works:  scientists.  They look good in this book. And so does science.  Chamovitz's gentle, firm, funny, exploration of what tricks that plants have up their sheaves is full of integrity and passion.  Treat yourself to it.

My.  My, oh my!  You'd have to be one nano-hearted, micro-visionary, "gone are the days of my youth" human being not to tumble for this rollicking story of young adults taking on both the real and the virtual Universe at the same time.I won't bore you with the details of the intricate and mega-twisting plot, except to say that it is intelligent, and more fun than ten consecutive rides on the world's largest roller coasters.  And to say that all though the entire story is told through the eyes of a teenager, I (in my seventh decade of life), loved the entire story enough to neglect everything on my ever-lengthy "to do" list to devote full attention to finding out what the heck was going to happen next.I will leave you with a thought, though.  In an increasingly fragmented society, one in which traditional methods of identifying the values by which one lives one's life are increasingly discarded, one wonders, how DO young people learn to read their moral compasses.  And one way is by reading books like Ready Player One.  Honesty.  Integrity.  Loyalty.  Respect for all regardless of ethnic background or sexual preference.  Justice. Sharing of wealth.  Kindness.  Focus on who a person is, rather than what they look like.  A notion of romantic love NOT built solely on the yearning to exchange genetic material (i.e. sex).  Celebration of rowdy creativity, valuing education deeply, heck, even Shakespeare gets several nods.  And, in a theme rarely expressed in 21st century lit:  success comes by dint of very, VERY hard work, not by winning a lottery, or entitlement.But let me step away from all that philosophy:  Ready Player One is one fine adventure, an almost Arthurian tale with a private chat room instead of a Round Table, seasoned with intelligence, creativity, and delightfully basted in the values that would make the real world that we live in a finer place to be.

Two separate reviews in one, here: one for people that have read Kim Stanley Robinson (KSR) before, and one for those who have not.Review 1: For those that have read and enjoyed KSR in the past (e.g. veterans of the massive Red Mars, Blue Mars, Green Mars trilogy), the message is simple.  Get your hands on this book, kick back, and enjoy.  KSR is at his terraforming best here; the Solar System a fabulous playground for the relentless expansion of Earth's most potent primate species.  If you liked what KSR did with Mars, you'll find what he does with the rest of the Solar System breathtaking.  And, you'll get, almost as an afterthought, a plot involving the elements of murder mystery, romance, political intrigue, and thriller all in one.  2312, in several senses, outdoes the Mars Trilogy, and builds on it.  There is not a trace of succinctness in the entire book.  But, fan, you already knew that about KSR.Review 2:  Never read KSR?  KSR is a must read, if you think of yourself as a sci-fi buff.  Not doing so would be like claiming to be a fan of English literature, but not having read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice (or if length is a criteria, George Eliot's Mill on the Floss).  And if you're going to read KSR, 2312 is a wonderful place to start.KSR writes hard sci-fi.  Virtually nothing included in this deeply imaginative exploration of what mankind's expansion throughout our solar system might look like by 2312, is without scientific foundation.  KSR is a modern day polymath, with a knowledge base that is spectacularly broad, and not lacking in depth.  What you'll be treated to in 2312 is page after page (after page, after page, after page) of KSR's informed and spectacularly innovative vision of where the marriage of technology and the human genome is headed.  And if such speculation fascinates you, stop right here and order the book:  if anyone does it better than KSR, I haven't yet encountered them.Plot?  Ah.  You're one of those:  you want a STORY along with the spectacularly high-tech scaffolding.  Hmm.  Well, there IS a story here.  And a good one.  One that could have been related in about one third of the 576 pages in this book.  There is a romance, and a mystery, and an AI thriller that triggers recall of Asimov's I Robot.  KSR is an excellent writer, and his opening scene of going for a walk on Mercury as the terrifying, searing light of the oh-so-close Sun creeps over the horizon is flat out astounding.  But plot is not his predominant strength, providing in this book just enough cohesion to graft KSR's stunningly visionary prognostications together.  I liked the plot.  Enjoyed it thoroughly.  But if plot is your most-prized quality for choosing a sci-fi novel, on the stellar scale, think white dwarf rather than supernova here:  it sheds light, but won't vaporize you with its intensity.Overall?  KSR fan:  do it.  You won't regret it.  KSR on steroids.  New KSR reader:  great place to start, and if you're a sci-fi reader, you most definitely owe yourself a KSR novel at least once in life.

This is a gem of book: small, dense, multi-faceted.  I don't hold an advanced degree in cosmology or physics, extracting the book's information required some focus on my part.  It was well worth the effort.Author Lawrence Krauss sets the intellectual tone for A Universe From Nothing in the first lines of his preface, quoting Jacob Bronowski:  "Dream or nightmare, we live our experience as it is, and we have to live it awake. We live in a world which is penetrated through and through by science and which is both whole and real.  We cannot turn it into a game simply by taking sides." Put in as slightly different way, a way that Krauss repeats several times in the book, the job of humans with intellectual integrity is to accept the world as it presents itself through evidence, whether or not we like what the evidence shows.  Is this a foreshadowing that most will not like his conclusions?  I think not.  I loved what he had to say.A Universe From Nothing is a success on at least three levels: explanatory, exploratory, and exhortational.From an explanatory point of view, Krauss is a competent and good humored educator.  Though his prose doesn't, in my opinion, match the story-telling ability of Brian Greene in The Fabric of the Cosmos: Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality, or the engaging style of Richard Panek in The 4 Percent Universe: Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and the Race to Discover the Rest of Reality, it is more than adequate to lead a reader with a solid science base through the cosmology, particle physics, and quantum theory updates that are available to us in the second decade of the 21st century.  Krauss's succinct reviews of cosmic inflation, dark matter and energy, and quantum physics provide a solid underpinning for his theme that the universe does indeed appear to have come from "nothing", though what Krauss means by nothing is not the "nothing" that you grew up thinking about.In his exploratory mode, Krauss is just plain fun.  His explorations branch down at least two major pathways.  First, how do current discoveries and popular cosmological/quantum physics theories intersect with  theological/philosophical mullings over "How could SOMETHING possibly come from NOTHING?".  Second, leaving theology and philosophy aside, Krauss indulges in the pure pleasure of speculating about the different implications of contemporary cosmological and quantum physics theories.  He includes one of the finer, and more lucid, discussions of the anthropic principle that I have run across.  Krauss, who also wrote a book on the physics of Star Trek, deftly manages in these explorations to demonstrate that science well done is entrancing, and regularly capable of producing crops of awe-inspired goose bumps.Krauss is also unabashedly exhortational.  He makes the point repeatedly, and throughout the book, that any scientist, any human that claims intellectual integrity, must accept the universe as it presents itself, rather than as one would like to find it.  Those cosmologists that liked the notion of curved universes must yield to evidence that the universe is flat.  Those who thought the world was only 6000 years old, much yield to geology and cosmology that tags an extra 13 billion years (and loose change) on to that total.  We humans, including Einstein in his day, keep trying to bend the world into a comfortable shape.  Krauss, in effect, says "Hey, kick back, enjoy the ride, it's all fantastically interesting, even if it isn't what you wanted!".  Filled with a passionate love for science, Krauss exhorts us to be dispassionate in the face of properly accumulated evidence.This would not be a complete review without mentioning Krauss's thinking about God and the cosmos.  Krauss does not deny the possibility that there is a God (though his personal belief on the matter seems clear).  He forcefully denies, from the preface to the epilogue, the need to invoke digitus Dei (the finger of God) to explain the universe(s) that we are a part of.  The universe, according to Krauss, simply doesn't require divine intervention to come into existence, nor to continue its existence after it spontaneously generates itself in a fashion concordant with quantum physics.  Thomas Jefferson said, in speaking as the founder of the University of Virginia "A professorship of theology has no place in our institution".  This was not an attack on theism, it was a ringing endorsement of the notion that when trying to explain the world that we live in, one should rigorously pursue natural explanations, to the exclusion of supernatural explanations.  Reliable knowledge about the universe we live in, felt Jefferson, will come through science, not theology.  Krauss could not agree more heartily.Finally, after reading this book, few will think of the concept of "nothing" in a way that has even remote resemblance to prior conception.  In a sense, the book calls into question even the notion of "nothing".  And though Krauss doesn't explicitly discuss it, the distinction between "something" and "nothing" takes a serious hit in his narrative.  How's that?  Well.  That would be a spoiler, would it not?

I'm an intermittent King reader.  Started with Carrie when it was published, railed at King's inability to pull epics like The Stand together for a satisfying ending, and gradually drifted away from all contact with him.  But the premise of this book was a fine one, and I stuck my reader's toe in the pool, liked the temperature, and jumped in.  Loved the swim.Steven King has been through quite a bit in his life, including his near fatal car versus pedestrian accident a few years ago.  He has a long term marriage, and some real authority on what love is.  He was once a full time teacher, a heroic job by anyone's standards.  He has known poverty and he has known great wealth.  And by virtue of all that, in 11-22-1963 he instills what can only be called wisdom into the tale.  Yes, there are the trademark squirm-fests, when describing gore and the emission of various body fluids/solids.  But they are subdued.  Yes, there are the thinly veiled pokes at religious obsession, but no rants.  Yes, at times one wishes that King was forced to write the way that chess masters sometimes play speed chess, with only so many minutes allowed for moves.  And yet....in 11-22-1963, it all works.It all works because Stephen King LIKES being human.  He LIKES America.  He LIKES women that are smart and strong.  He likes to imagine, and he believes that the actions that we take in life make a difference, maybe a huge difference.  I'm going to remain solidly non-spoiler here:  this is one of King's best works in years, it's a work for him to be proud of.  More thought-provoking than scary, it'll leave a mark on you.  A good one.

Kayt Sukel's brief, succinct, humorous, and thoroughly scientific book about love, sex, and relationships is well worth the price of admission.  Though a trifle technical in spots (you'll become more familiar than you perhaps want to be with terms like ventral pallidum, ventral tegmental area, caudate nucleus), Sukel's skill as a science writer, and warmth as a human being, will keep you from running permanently aground on technical lingo.Dirty Minds is no small achievement.  Though providing excellent and cogent results of contemporary research on emotion and the variety of forms of love (ranging from immediate sexual gratification to life time partnerships), Sukel never denies the mystery and wonder of the actual experience of being in love.  Or in lust.  Or simultaneously both.Sukel is more careful than most, when presenting the results of provocative studies, to provide abundant qualifiers, and careful instructions about the dangers of over generalizing.  Nevertheless, when one is done with this book, one will never listen to a friend obsess about his/her new love without thinking about the neurohormonal storm, and the highly fired up parts of the friend's neuroanatomy that are contributing to the (usually) temporary loss of sanity that the friend is in the grips of.  In the same way that the steadily increasing knowledge about what, on a hormonal and neuroanatomical level, leads to depression and subsequent treatment options, Dirty Minds allows either the victim of one of Cupid's arrows, or the witness to a friend or family member similarly pierced, to actually take an informed course, if one is required or desired.Without being sensationalistic, Sukel raises ethical issues.  As the neuro chemistry/anatomy of love (all forms) becomes increasingly clear, it also becomes clear that "treatment" might be available for the lovesick.  Are we ready for either a very effective Love Potion #9, or a very effective ANTI-Love Potion #2?  If your teenager was in love with an undesirable person, would you consider slipping a medication that could end that obsession into their soft drink?  Not idle speculation, based on the research Sukel presents.Finally, kudos to Sukel for her humility, her openness about her own experiences, and her simple and warm celebration of the human experience.  Her writing is a wonderful example of what happens when you merge competent science with liberal arts skills.

Professor Rebecca Stott's latest book has a misleading title .  No matter.  The final product is brilliant, highly entertaining, deeply thought-provoking, and astoundingly informing; an intellectual/academic feast from beginning to end that is equally accessible to those who favor the liberal arts and those who live for scientific discourse.  But it's not all that much about Darwin.  What's it about?  The Wikipedia comment on Darwin's Ghost just about nails it:  "(Rebecca Stott) has now completed an epic account of the history of evolution before Darwin which documents a 2,200 year history, a tale of heretics and free thinkers who were prepared to risk public censure or even imprisonment by asking questions that challenged religious orthodoxies."  The point?  This is not a book about whose shoulders Darwin (and/or Alfred Wallace) stood on when they came to their virtually identical concept on the origin of species.  It's about the pitched battle between religion and science on issues geological, astronomical, and most especially, biological.Stott has written at least two novels hallmarked by suspense, and has a reputation for being able to blend science and the arts in a way that does credit to both fields.  Her wonderful ability to merge her literary and historical skills with solid science reporting results in a book that reads like a historical novel, but is backed by 75 pages of references.  Though Stott starts with Aristotle, and follows up with some little known theorists (e.g. Arab thinker Jahiz, ninth century C.E.), and includes an interlude with Leonardo da Vinci (eat your hearts out, Lyn Margulis and James Lovelock: da Vinci had the concept of Gaia centuries before you were zygotes!), it is not until the French Enlightenment that the figurative cannon fire explodes on many fronts.  Or as polymath/heretic Diderot put it "It is raining bombs in the house of the Lord".The churches of the 18th and 19th (might one include the 20th and 21st?) centuries, both Catholic and Protestant, were not to be pried easily from the account in Genesis in which God creates each of the species, and gives man dominion over the earth.  As a growing chorus of voices (well detailed in Darwin's Ghosts) began to sing the notion that species evolved, were mutable,  possibly came from a common ancestor, Stott summarizes the responses of the major religions, and the European governments that often functioned as theocracies:  "It struck at the heart of the Christian religion, clerics declared; it contradicted the  biblical account of creation; it sullied the idea of a benevolent God who had designed the universe for the enjoyment of man;  it belittled the position of man in the universe; it challenged belief in man's divinely granted dominion; it contradicted biblically based estimates that the earth was around 6000 years old.  It was not to be supported."  Eminent writers, philosophers, scientists often lost all social standing, were often financially ruined, and were sometimes imprisoned.  Joseph Priestly, famous for isolating the element oxygen, had his estate ransacked, and returned to find graffiti stating "For God and King" in the ruins of his home.Darwin's Ghosts also chronicles the remarkable adaptations that evolved out of this persecution:  revolutionary ideas were couched in epic poems, in fictional discourses, in anonymously published books that had been smuggled to Holland, printed, and smuggle back into the countries where they were banned.Darwin's Ghosts is not a perfect book, though with editing that was just a hair more discriminating it would be a legitimate Pulitzer Prize candidate.  Chief amongst the flaws, though a charming flaw it is, is author Stott's seeming inability to relinquish ANY of the fascinating gems she discovers in her research. .  One gets the sense that as Stott did her extensive research, she became the literary equivalent of a hoarder.  The chapters are JAMMED with factoids, including who was sleeping with who.  Fascinating though it might be on some level, knowing exactly what kind of plants are in a scientist's garden (for decorative, not scientific, purposes) teeters on the "too much information" fulcrum.Overall?  Professor Stott notes that in 1844, a literary critic reviewed a book suggesting radical new ways of looking at biology and geology called Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation, by brilliant writer/publisher Robert Chambers.  The critic wrote " We have found so many great results of knowledge and reflection that we cannot too earnestly recommend (this book) to the attention of thoughtful men".  To eliminate the double negative, I earnestly recommend this book to the attention of thoughtful men and women everywhere!

Beautiful cone shaped bottle with a silvery label: kudos to the product container designers.  How about the product itself?  Mixed emotions.  Pure water, about a cup of coffee's worth of caffeine, reportedly without taste. Is this a product that will cause a market stampede?Most likely not.  If you need a caffeine boost with zero calories, but don't like coffee or tea, there are a host of products already saturating the market.  These range from NoDoz tablets, to energy drinks (which do come in zero calorie varieties) to the many diet colas and sodas (Diet Coke, Diet Pepsi, the potent Diet Mountain Dew, Diet Dr. Pepper) all of which are significantly cheaper per dose of caffeine than Avitae, and all come with flavor, to boot.As far as I can tell, Avitae's only claims to fame are that it has only two ingredients (water and caffeine), and that it is tasteless (literally, not metaphorically).  My experience: it does have a very faint, but real, slightly bitter taste.  Not unpleasant, but noticeable if you're paying attention.I was ready to write this off as another oddball marketing excursion, but for the following anecdote.  Last weekend I drove 400 miles down from Oregon to meet up with my brothers for a 100 mile bike ride in California (The Chico Wildflower Century).  The ride was the easy part, staying awake and alert on the 5.5 hour drive home afterwards was the tough part. Despite a Venti Starbucks latte, about 3 hours into the journey home, I began to feel a bit drowsy.  Reaching over to my duffel bag, I fetched the Avitae, cracked it open, sipped it over the next fifteen minutes.  Results? Perfect:  I felt alert, comfortable, zero stomach distress (sometimes coffee gives me some rumbles), and I cruised on home without incident.  One anecdote does not constitute adequate data, but there you have it: worked for me!

The origin of this book is a simple one:  The editor, John Brockman, tossed out the question "What scientific concept would improve everybody's cognitive toolkit?" to over 150 contemporary thought leaders, and recorded the results.  Brockman has worked for decades to bring thinkers together, under the premise that great things happen when cross-disciplinary exchanges of brilliant thinking take place.  Bacteria, because they are so profligate in exchanging genetic information across species, are astoundingly capable of arriving at new and adaptive solutions to environmental (including antibiotics) challenges.  Brockman, I'm guessing, would be comfortable with the notion that in posing annual questions to leaders in the fields of many different disciplines he is increasing the adaptability, creativity, and problem solving capabilities of the human race.  This Will Make You Smarter is excellent evidence that he may well be correct.  Bacteria have something to teach us.Almost everyone gets a say here: astrophysicists, sociologists, environmentalists, historians, microbiologists, newspaper columnists, particle physicists, philosophers, and a host of notables in other disciplines.  The result is a truly provocative treasure heap of notions that just might do what the title of the book claims.  The book is a bucket of pearls:  succinct (for the most part!) notions with real punch are the order of the day.  John Brockman's website, Edge.org, aims to represent cutting edge ideas, and the included authors often are forced to create neologisms or resurrect arcane vocabulary (e.g. Interbeing and apophenia) to express their thoughts fully.This book is not a quick read.  I left it at my bedside and knocked off a few every evening, often with a new concept, or an improved version of an old one, caroming around the confines of my cranium as I drifted off to sleep.  Some ideas seemed both verbose and obtuse. Most seemed refreshing and useful.  My favorite was also the shortest of all the selections, almost haiku like in intensity.  In its entirety, here is Susan Fiske's (Princeton Professor of Psychology) essay:  "The most important scientific concept is that an assertion is often an empirical question settled by collecting evidence.  The plural of anecdote is not data, and the plural of opinion is not facts.  Quality peer-reviewed scientific evidence accumulates into knowledge. People's stories are stories, and fiction keeps us going. But science should settle policy."As several previous reviewers have noted, this book is available free online at Edge.org.  Why spend ten bucks? There is one reason that you might want to consider:  it's a book that you'll savage with your pen, assaulting the pages with highlighter ink, filling the margins with thoughts, and littering the essays with circles and exclamation marks.  You'll pull it down off your bookshelf regularly, every time you want tangible evidence in your hands that human beings do, on occasion, have some REALLY good ideas.

172 Hours on the Moon (original title: Darlah) is a product of Norwegian author and pop icon Johan Harstad's fertile and darkly hued imagination.  Though it is miles apart in style and presentation from the typical American young adult sci-fi novel, for the reader that likes to step off the beaten path now and then, and isn't afraid of what dangers lurk, 172 Hours is your ticket to the moon and beyond.172 Hours is alien in more than one respect.  Written in Danish and later translated into multiple languages (including English), a slight mental shifting of gears is required to get into the flow of the book.  Similar to, but not as demanding as, the first few minutes of a movie with subtitles:  it's a distraction for a bit, and then you no longer notice it.  Give your mind's eye a moment to refocus and you'll be rewarded with the author's Scandinavian perspective on the world, a perspective that has made the Scandinavian mystery/crime novels such a sensation (e.g. The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo).This book is a chilling one, made all the more so by the author's habit of integrating historical fact into the narrative.  There really was, on 8/15/77, a radio signal received by an early version of SETI, that remains inexplicable.  Was the famous 6EQUJ5 signal, aka the "Wow!" signal, alien in origin?  Might Stephen Hawking be right when he warns that we shouldn't be trying so hard to contact aliens, because we simply don't know what their intentions might be?  And how about the concept of the doppelganger that is woven into the story?  Were John Dunne, Abraham Lincoln, Goethe, and one of Percy Shelley's friends all just imagining the exact replicas of themselves and others that they claim to have witnessed?  Was the case of Emilie Sagee in 1845 simply mass hysteria, or do doppelgangers actually inhabit our world (or in this case, the Moon)?Harstad adds to the reader's pleasure by a series of unique illustrations, as well as well-drawn descriptions of the life of young musicians that are trying to make a name for themselves.  Harstad is both a musician and a graphic illustrator, and the authenticity of his own experience enriches the portrayal of his characters.Harstad won an award for youth literature for this book.  If you're a teacher or a school librarian, should you add it to the collection you make available to your students?  Hmmm.  There is no graphic sex.  There is some moderately graphic violence.  If the choice were up to me, I'd make the book freely available with this proviso:  take the time to discuss the book afterwards with any student that reads it.  Death stalks these pages.  It is increasingly unlikely that we are alone in our galaxy.  When we stare up at the stars on a crystal clear night, should we feel a peaceful awe, or should we feel (along with Stephen Hawking) deep foreboding?  Singer Bonnie Raitt has a song with the reprise "Let's give `em something to talk about".  With this book, Johan Harstad has most certainly done that!

Ship Breaker, Paolo Bacigalupi's fast-moving eco-adventure set in the not too distant future, is high quality science fiction that fulfills the classical belief that art should both entertain and instruct. It's good stuff.  How good?  As good as Heinlein, Norton, and Asimov (all dead before the most likely readers of Ship Breaker were able to read a novel), and as good as any contemporary writer of young adult science fiction.  Doubtful?  Send your objections to the folks that have nominated Bacigalupi for, and often awarded him, a boat load of literary awards (including a Finalist National Book Award for this book).What makes Ship Breaker a stand out young adult novel?  Take all the standard (and much loved!) ingredients, including a small but tough protagonist, genetically augmented human/animal hybrids, cross-cultural romance, high tech whiz-bang, and the human struggle for survival in a post environmental apocalypse world.  Mix well.  Add moral conflict: loyalty versus greed, bravery versus common sense and/or cowardice, honesty versus self-serving deception.  Spice it with complex themes, such as an abusive father that raises the often relevant 21st century question of what does "family" really mean?  Is family a genetic relationship, or more a matter of human bonds with those who care for you, and put themselves at risk for you?  Simmer the stew long enough to allow the hero and heroine to figuratively and literally weather several storms, long enough for them to choose what type of humans they wish to become.  Consume the result, and sit back to enjoy that wonderful sense of satisfaction that comes from a creation that is both delicious and nutritious.A few months ago I asked an eighteen year old that had never been to a church in her life, and who professed little interest in whether or not there is a personal God "So, where do you get your values?  How do you choose how you will act, and what you believe in?".  She paused for a bit, looked thoughtful, and then said "Well, I listen to stories.  I read.  I watch movies.  I think about what I've read, or seen, and then I decide what kind of person I'd most like to be.".  Ship Breaker, though salted throughout with mild to moderate profanity, and laced with significant violence, is not just a good story.  It is a modern morality play.  Choices have real consequences.  Decisions aren't simple.  Bacigalupi acknowledges shades of gray in this world, but does not waver on a central theme:  how you treat others, and how you treat the planet that you live on, matters.  His characters grow by confronting their moral dilemmas, sometimes at mortal cost, rather than running from them.  If the eighteen year old girl I mentioned above were to read Ship Breaker, I'd be confident that what she carried away from it would be compatible with the moral values that many of us received through more conventional approaches.  And this, I'm thinking, is a very good thing.

I have a boneyard of bicycle tail lights strewn around my garage.  I commute year round in Central Oregon, 45 minutes each way.  In the winter months, when the sun comes up around 8:30 AM, and goes down by 4:15 PM, that means I'm riding in the dark, coming and going.  Though I choose my route carefully, there are a couple of "tight spots" along the way where I really want to be seen.  During the last year or so, a variety of truly bright tail lights have come out, visible during daylight hours from quite a distance.  The Cygolite Hotshot 2-Watt USB, in my mind, is the best.Is there a noticeable difference between a 2 watt LED and a single watt?  My wife, who overtakes me in her car on the way to work, says "YES!".  She notes that the Cygolite is easily the brightest tail light I've ever used.What's to like?  Easily detachable/attachable.  Multiple modes.  Very long life on a single charge, well over 24 hours even at the brightest setting.  Gotta love the USB rechargeable battery:  at the end of my work week, I pop the light off my bike, charge it (2-3 hours), pop it back on, good to go for at least another week.  No prying covers off, no batteries to dispose of.What's less to like?  If you belong to a group of night riders, you'll have to tone down:  this light is obnoxiously bright even to some cars, much less to a fellow rider right behind you.  The light intensity, in fairness, is very adjustable.  Mode selection is easy, adjusting the intensity of the light took me a bit of practice, and cost me a bit of frustration.I've been using this light for five months.  I'm loving its ease of use.  I'm loving that it's so bright that cars often give me far more room than I need to feel safe.  It's high daytime visibility is a real plus on my recumbent.  This item is a winner that has made my half dozen other tail lights obsolete.  Job well done, Cygolite.

This is a review for people that are NOT raving Elmore Leonard fans.  If you ARE a dyed in the wool Leonard fan, go ahead, get it over with:  draw down on me with your literary Sig Sauers and Glocks, empty your clips, and move on to the next victim that dares to give one of the master's books less than five stars.  But if you're new to Elmore Leonard, or have only sampled his prolific writing (over 40 novels) in the past, allow me to draw out my antiquated Colt six-shooter and take half a dozen shots at this patched together, moderately entertaining, barely deserving of the name, novel.Before my twitchy trigger finger lets loose on the keyboard, let's get a few things straight, amigos.  Elmore Leonard at his best has only a few peers amongst American authors.  His gritty story lines often pack so much realism into the plot that you figure Leonard must have LIVED the stories, rather than just written about them.  Leonard's skill in writing dialogue has captured the attention and the admiration of some of America's best authors and critics.  Leonard, in stories like Get Shorty, defines the notion of cool with an exactness and ultra high definition that may well be unmatched in the literary world.  Step back, Ian Fleming and your poser character James Bond:  you don't deserve to be within a hundred yards of your average Leonard hero/antihero.But I'm not drawing my six-shooter out to plug Elmore Leonard: it's this cow-chip of a semi-novel that I aim to make dance in the dirt.  If you're an uber fan, go ahead and read it, so that you can say "I've read `em all!".  But the rest of you.....don't pile this one on your stack of "must reads".Round number one:  this isn't a novel.  Or if it is, it's the first posthumous novel published while the author is still alive.  It is so fragmented and disjointed that it reads like those perpetually unsatisfactory attempts to take the scattered pieces of a book that was in process when an author died, and stitch it into a pseudo-novel so that the family estate can hear the ching of the cash register one last time. In this case, Leonard seems to have used plot fragments from his TV series to attempt a coherent piece.  This is a disservice to the reader.Round number two: the crappy plot devices just don't serve.  The thrill of letting a hero get himself painted into a corner is all in the ingenious way that he/she escapes that doomed little piece of real estate.  Raylan Givens, our hero, does get painted into predictable (from a mile away) corners, or in this case plopped into a bathtub, but the escapes that Leonard hands us are lazy, unimaginative, and smacking of downright creaky deus ex machina.Round number three: Leonard is an excellent portrait artist, using words to bring to life fascinating and fully fleshed characters.  Which he does again in this book, EXCEPT in the case of our hero Raylan himself, who has no more depth than a 2D poster advertising the latest Western.Round number four:  Women in the book are divided into smart and beautiful pond scum, and less intelligent pond scum.  To qualify as an attractive woman in Raylan, you have to be gorgeous and dangerous.  Forget the sugar and spice recipe.  The ingredients are equal parts raw ego, evil goddess, sociopath.  Each of the women our hero Raylan considers sleeping with is self-centered to an extreme that relegates the word narcissistic to the category of euphemism.  There are other women in the book, such as low IQ prostitutes, and former low IQ prostitutes that have now moved on to being low IQ drug addict bank robbers.  One woman in the book has brains and ambition, and a lucrative gambling habit.  But not one has the cool, ethical, and heroic qualities of several of the male characters.  Come down with a moderate case of misogynistic flu, Mr. Leonard?  Ah, well.  It's been going around for a few millennia.Round Five: Macaroni and cheese is the main item on the menu.  The macaroni being some tried and true, but trite, appeals to the sensibilities of the honest working man.  In this case coal miners.  The cheese being the less than candid split of the world into the good guy laborers and the evil amoral management.  No denying the truth that some coal companies are equally adept at wreaking damage on the environment and on the lives of men.  The book Raylan tells an important story using an almost comic book format that seems more fit for a failed TV series than for engendering serious thought.Round Six:  Difficult tight rope to walk here, but what's life without risk?  Leonard, in this book, follows the lead of many fine, but aging, male authors before him:  the older the male author, the more they focus on sex.  Not just any sex (an aspect of human life that I'm a fan of), but a version of sex that seems perilously close to an old man's fantasy.  My favorite sci-fi writer, Robert Heinlein, drifted down this path in his later years.  In this world, young college students in their early 20's fall head over heels with middle-aged guys with fine cowboy hats and who answer questions like "Have you ever used that gun to kill anyone?" in the laconic affirmative.  Yawn.Cylinders empty, slight curl of smoke from the barrel.  Final thought?  Why read a book like Raylan in which gleams and sparkles of Leonard's vast talents peak out through piles of dross, when one can go back into his earlier career and read his writing in its full glory?  If you're a Leonard fanatic, you know you're going to read this book no matter what I say.  If you're less acquainted with him, but want a very fine reading experience, go back in time and experience him at his peak, rather than this trough.

Using simple and clear language (often in a playful way) and creative illustrations, Dawkins' words and McKean's art work contrast the simple and elegant beauty of what science has to say about natural phenomena with the murk and confusion of invoking the supernatural.Adults with a solid science education will not find much new in The Magic of Reality.  I didn't.  But what I can say with complete candor is that had I read this in middle school or high school, it would have chopped a good fifteen years off of the confusion I endured while trying to mesh my religious faith with my hunger for scientific explanations of natural phenomena.  My wife is a middle school teacher, and she covers much of the ground in this book with her sixth graders.  For young men and women who lack, as did I, school teachers as science oriented as my wife, this book offers a whoppingly good shortcut to achieving a science-based world view.As one would expect from a scientist of Dawkin's stature, the information presented is impeccably vetted.  But is it readable? Is it fun?  Brief story that gives a hint of an answer:  Noticing that I had my ADHD nose buried in this book for an uncharacteristically long time, my wife asked to see what I was reading.  When I tilted the book toward her to show it, she was intrigued by the illustrations, and took it from me.  She wouldn't give it back.  I had to choose between marital accord and other reading material.  I picked up my April issue of Scientific American. The next morning, before she was awake, I reclaimed my prize.The Magic of Reality is a serious and solid attempt to show that elegant scientific explanations of the phenomena that we experience every day are more beautiful, and more awe-inspiring, than the legends, myths, and religious explanations that are often substituted for more rational explanations.  Dawkins is a better scientist than he is a writer, and his prose lacks the dazzling punch of the selected articles in The Best American Science and Nature Writing 2011.  Nevertheless, the finished product is a wonderful accomplishment and a marvelous gift to young minds, or to older minds that retain a strong spark of youthful curiosity and a persistent bent toward inquiry.  Would that I could have read this when I was sixteen, instead of sixty!

Walk Two Moons, Sharon Creech's gentle and intriguing story that combines elements of mystery, romance, loss, and coming of age, won five literary awards, including the prestigious Newbery Award.  Turning the pages of this beautifully written tale, meeting the exquisitely drawn characters, absorbing Creech's rich and colorful prose, and being tantalized by a plot with more hairpin twists than the steepest mountain pass you've ever driven, one can easily see why the book has been so honored.The details of the plot are best left unsaid, as they can't reflect the richness of this story that is more a multi-layered parable than a young adult novel.  It is not the plot that is so unusual in Walk Two Moons, though its highly creative nature makes is delightfully unpredictable.  In the same way that one can have a grocery chain store apple pie out of a thin cardboard box and have a limited culinary experience, and then have a slice of apple pie prepared by a master chef that comes close to transporting one to a different dimension, it is Creech's telling of the story that makes the it a dramatically different experience.  And, truly, it's not a stretch to say that in the telling of the story Creech opens up new dimensions to the reader.Though I'm reluctant to discuss plot details, it is worth highlighting the highly effective device that Creech uses to unfold the plot:  a 2000 mile long road trip, moving east across the northern stretches of America.  In a car without DVD players, MP3 players, or even a radio, young narrator Salamanca spends the trip telling her grandparents her "Phoebe story".  The aging grandfather's inability to drive either fast or far gives the trip a pacing that allows the grandparents to hear Salamanca's story in full detail, and for them to give Salamanca in return a good deal of the story of their own lives, and the life of Salamanca's missing mother.  Sometimes Salamanca's tale holds center stage; sometimes the stops at some of America's most treasured destinations (e.g. Yellowstone, Mt. Rushmore) are front and center. But whatever is on the stage, the notion of a grandfather, a grandmother, and a granddaughter moving through the country with their ears filled with conversation, family history, and the accumulated wisdom of lives well-lived instead of a tinny jangle emanating from ear buds hooked to an electronic device creates a powerful sense of longing for deep human communication and connection.A small aside.  Creech taught children (and adults).  The classroom scenes in Walk Two Moons are grounded in the author's experience, rather than her imagination.  It is refreshing to read about teachers that suffer from an abundance of enthusiasm, and whose worst flaws spring from loving teaching too much, rather than too little.  I have the great fortune to be married to such a teacher, and feel honored by Creech's portrayal of one of life's most noble professions.Walk Two Moons is a beautiful tale.  Pandora had her famous box. When she opened it all the evils in the world escaped, leaving only one thing at the bottom of the box: Hope.  Sharon Creech's box is different than Pandora's.  Open it and you'll find that it is filled with contents more reflective of the world that we live in: objects and circumstances of great beauty mixed with circumstances and objects that are deeply painful.  Regardless of all other contents, Pandora and Creech both have the same object at the bottom of their boxes.

Regardless of what your taste in literature is, consider throwing down a slug of Gelasimov.  Thirst, his most recent book to be translated from Russian into English, may not intoxicate you, but it will alter your consciousness a bit.  If you read solely to cater to your dopamine receptors (i.e. for pleasure alone), it would probably be best to look elsewhere than to Thirst.  Thirst is not without pleasurable moments, but few would call it a feel good novel.So why bother with this short (just over 100 pages) and often grim and gritty novel?  Xenophilia and a taste for inclusivity, would be a couple of good reasons.  More on them in a moment.The story is not a complex one.  Taking place over a few weeks and told in the first person, the protagonist Konstantin and two of his Chechnyan War buddies spend a couple of weeks driving around Moscow looking for a fourth war buddy that has disappeared unexpectedly.  When the search is resolved, each of the members of the trio returns to his respective life, subtly but significantly deviated from the paths each had been on.Konstantin introduces himself to us while struggling to find the maximum number of vodka bottles that can be fit into his refrigerator.  "All the vodka wouldn't fit in the fridge. First I tried standing the bottles up, and then I laid them on their sides, one on top of the other. The bottles stacked up like transparent fish. Then they hunkered down and stopped clinking.  But ten or so just wouldn't fit."  Konstantin, who suffered terribly disfiguring burns to his face when the armored personnel carrier that he was in was attacked, is obviously a thirsty man.  What exactly he thirsts for is the subject of the novel.  And whether you like vodka or not, you would have to have a deeply Siberian temperament not to share a craving for what Konstantin thirsts for.Xenophiliacs, those that love stepping inside cultures that are foreign to their own, will treasure this dusty window pane view into contemporary Russia seen through eyes of young men.  The grayness of the social landscape recalls, but does not approach the intensity of, the colorless landscape of Cormac McCarthy's The Road.  As the trio drives around in an SUV for several weeks, the reader is treated to a kaleidoscopic view of urban life in today's Moscow.Gelasimov's pen is an inclusive one; all humans are invited to sit with him at his literary table.  Though the Chechnyan War and post-USSR Russia provide ample fodder for anti-government, or anti-corruption, rants, Gelasimov (as the mini-bio at the end of the book points out) keeps conflict on a personal level:  problems begin, and problems are resolved, one-on-one between humans.  Our failures and/or our successes occur at a personal level.  There are no rages against the machine in Thirst.  Rather there is a gentle and restrained insistence that forward motion is not a matter of revolution, overthrow, or political ideology, but rather a matter of human relationship.Humans can thirst for power, money, sex, status, alcohol.... the list is long.  The thirst that Konstantin attempts to slake is not in the above categories.  Identifying what will sooth his scorched and parched soul is the subject of Thirst.  Curious?  Read Thirst and enjoy.  Gelasimov may go down a bit rough, like a shot of hard liquor, but the subsequent sense of warmth is worth the price of an initial grimace or two.

I'm a heavy duty ear bud user, commuting an hour and a half per day on a bicycle while listening to audiobooks, listening to podcasts during long car trips, more audiobooks when on long training runs.  Ear buds have always been a source of irritation for me.  Often uncomfortable, often low quality sound, and worst of all, short-lived.  Maybe its something about the constant up and down of jogging with ear buds in place, but I've gone through dozens of earbuds because within a month or two, one earbud or the other cuts out.  Metal fatigue in the tiny wires?  Dunno, but real.I bought two sets of the Gogroove Ergonomic Earbuds a few months back.  My wife and I use them mercilessly, and in all kinds of weather conditions. No failures. Couple this with low cost and very good sound, and I'm thinking these earbuds just might be the best on the market.  Zero complaints, lots of pleasure:  Gogroove earbuds are one of the rare products that outperform expectations.

The SRAM X9 came as original equipment on my Bachetta Giro, and worked flawlessly until I took a goofy derailleur side dump in my driveway, bending the X9 beyond repair.  I purchased a replacement, found it easy to install, and have over a thousand miles of riding on it: zero complaints.  Shifts are smooth, crisp, and solid.  Not sure what else one can ask for!  Looks good, works well, endures weather conditions (down into the 30's) well... it's fits in the "good stuff" category.

At a conference I attended once, a young and fiercely idealistic CEO of a hospital stated his goal in life:  "When I lay my head down for the last time, when it is my time to die, I want to be able to look back over the years and know that what I did with my life, professional and personal, changed the lives of my family and friends, and the lives of the people that came through my hospital system, in a deeply positive way".  Blue Nights, Joan Didion's memoir/partial autobiography/memorial to her husband and daughter, is a sort of "Now I lay me down to sleep" narrative, delivered from the vantage point of 75 years of life on planet Earth.Didion's life pathway has been strewn with deaths of family members (husband and daughter) and significant friends, as well as with not a few health problems of her own.  There is an Arab saying "All sunshine makes a desert".  There has most certainly been rain in Didion's life.  A memoir such as Blue Nights offered the opportunity to see what oases of wisdom and tranquility could bloom in the desert when the water of tragedy is applied. Did Didion utilize this opportunity?  Viktor Frankl, a psychiatrist and neurologist that survived the Holocaust, said "Who is to give light must endure burning". Blue Nights offered Didion the opportunity to share light with her readers,  light emanating from the searing pain of personal loss that she suffered.  Most simply put, many cultures have come up with proverbs that reduce to this:  without pain, there is no wisdom.  Didion details the pain that she has experienced in life in Blue Nights.  Does she leverage that pain to bring her readers wisdom?  Does Blue Nights give light that radiates from the intense suffering that Didion has endured?  All humans eventually face death, both our own, and of those we love.  When the sunshine in Didion's life was obscured by the rain storms that befell her (and befall all of us), is it clear in Blue Nights that she used those floodwaters to nurture the growth of wisdom that we readers might vicariously access?  I would argue that in writing the beautiful prosody and intriguing autobiographical tale of Blue Nights....that Didion did not, or could not, answer those questions in the affirmative.Memoirs can be read for a variety of reasons, all of which are probably legitimate.  Read from the point of view of gaining an interior view of the thoughts, feelings, and experiences of one of America's great writers, Blue Nights succeeds.  Many psychologists and psychiatrists agree that loss of a child is the single most stressful event adults can endure, and Didion's formidable writing talents bring home such a tragedy with devastating force.  Blue Nights also succeeds on the "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" level.  Didion does compulsive name-dropping in this book.  At times, when she feels the reader might not understand the importance of the person she is has just mentioned, the story veers away from tragedy into a Wikipedia like segment on just WHY the person she is mentioning is such a luminary.  Such is the case when we become thoroughly informed about the importance of an organized crime figure whose table Didion sits at.  At best, such information seems like a bit of a non sequitur; at worst, blatant self-aggrandizement.Quintana Roo, Didion's adopted daughter who died at age 39, occupies a front and center position in the book.  I should mention that I have been a Joan Didion fan for 40 years.  I'll also say that in Blue Nights I felt that Didion's treatment of the agony of losing a child veered into frank melodrama, and cloying sentimentalism.  Didion's writing, long an example to me of startlingly insights and clear-eyed  analyses of the country and culture that she has grown up in, has seemed almost absent of sentimentality and melodrama in the past.  No longer is this the case.  It is true that sentimentality and melodrama sell well in the entertainment world.  Most would agree that neither are the hallmarks of excellence in art.Those that enjoy highly detailed accounts of celebrity lives will be entertained by Blue Nights. Readers actively pursuing the liqueur of wisdom that can be distilled from the crazy fermentation called life are not likely to find resonance with this book.  Some say that the definition of important art is that it both entertains AND informs.  Blue Nights makes it halfway there.

This spiffy item's claim to fame is that will keep your ears warm AND keep the sweat out of your eyes. By applying a soft, yellow, thin, water impermeable band to the part of the headband that fits against the forehead, the Halo people claim that sweat will be diverted away from the eyes. Ridiculous, I thought.  I bought the headband because I needed something for my chilly winter bike commutes, and similarly chilly Central Oregon winter runs. But it's so comfortable that I use it summer and winter.  Here's the kicker:  the dang thing actually works as claimed.  When I work up a sweat, the perspiration from my forehead comes down, hits the barrier, and then runs harmlessly off to the sides where it trickles down the side of my face, instead of into my eyes.Bonus! The material it is made of is the best sound insulation I've found yet for bicycling.  When I slip the Halo over my earphones and tap my iPod on: heaven.  It holds the earpieces securely in place whether I'm running or biking, and it substantially reduces the noise from the slipstream when I'm biking.  AND, it keeps my ears warm when it's cold, but breathes excellently when it's hot.  Bottom line:  Best ever headband/ear cover at a very reasonable cost.  Love it.  Wouldn't do without it, way up on the top of my mandatory clothing list when I'm gearing up to go outdoors.  I know nothing about the folks who designed and/or manufactured this, but they have the rare product that is truth in advertising.  Even a bit better!

If the style Jeff Jarvis uses to write Public Parts (a bit of a play on Howard Stern's book "Private Parts") is any indication, I'd imagine that Jeff was the kind of kid in school that was perpetually being told to get back to his seat and sit down, and to quiet down a bit.  But you know...it works.  Jarvis has much to say about the fantastic challenges to commonly held ideas of privacy that the massive hyperdrive toward connectivity in the 21st century poses.  His approach to getting it all out in this fairly short book is a bit frenetic, and his never-a-dull-moment journalism can be energizing, or off-putting, depending on your own preferences.  Jarvis's approach is far more the shotgun than the high-powered rifle, which allows him to encompass a wide pattern of topics.While Jarvis acknowledges that privacy has its uses, he is a gigantic advocate of openness, of public access to information, rather than containment.  He backs his advocacy with examples that range from the very personal level (where we hear about his urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction after his prostate cancer surgery) to the international level, where he argues that "governments should be public by default, private only by necessity".  Good governments, he says, are transparent.  Bad governments are invariably, and often lethally, private.  While conscious of the collateral damage that can occur with making some forms of information public, I think he would agree with the thought that when all is said and done, when all the dust is settled, when all the fires of public outrage die down, being public with information is a large net gain to society compared to a culture of privacy.Particularly enjoyable to me was Jarvis's review of the stages of increased communication that humans have gone through:  development of language, development of the written word, development of the ability to copy and distribute the written word (think Guttenberg), ability to cast the written word to millions of people simultaneously over the radio, ability to reach millions (now billions) over TV, and now the ubiquitous connectivity of Facebook, Twitter, e-mail, SMS texting, and whatever the newest iteration of ramped up communication will be.  And each time (at least once history was being written down), the naysayers and the prophets of doom predicted (only slightly exaggerating here) the end of society as we know it.  Which, of course, the prophets of doom were right about:  society has ---now and many times in the past--- come to an end as we knew it.  Few even wish it otherwise, Jarvis would guess.  Millenials, who often have little interest in NRA slogans, would resonate deeply with "You'll get my cell phone and my Facebook away from me when you pry my cold, dead fingers off my keyboards/keypads!"Flaws? Jarvis likes to use the word "I" and "my" quite a lot.  He's more attached to name-dropping than a smoker to nicotine.  Just in case you've forgotten that he has a blog, he reminds you of this fact with more insistence than the "Your headlights are still on" chime in your car.  Ping, ping, ping.  But don't let this ad hominem stuff distract you from this truth:  Public Parts will challenge you to think, and regardless of your convictions before you start the book, you'll find yourself with new perspectives by the time you end it.  If you don't have time to sit and read it, get the audio download version, and listen during your commute or during your daily (right?) exercise period.  Privacy, as we've known it, is dead.  How to handle information going forward will be a series of decisions we'll make as a culture and a country.  If you're in the camp that likes to make informed decisions, rather than shoot from the hip/lip, Public Parts is a fun, fast primer to get you up to speed.

I'm an all weather, any time of day commuter (9 miles each way)in Central Oregon.  For a good part of the year, I am either going to work, coming home from work, or both, in the dark.  Visibility is critical for me. This tail light delivers, powerfully.Let me make mention of an early misadventure with this light.  In the earliest versions manufactured, one of which I had, the light would unexpectedly turn itself off while I was commuting.  I reported this in my first review, Planet Bike contacted me, and provided me with replacement lights that had been re-engineered to fix what I had experienced.  I've tested my replacement lights for two weeks:  no recurrences of the self turn-off.This is not an ordinary tail light.  It's amazingly bright, when I'm riding in full darkness cars seem to be giving me an additional couple of feet of clearance compared to dimmer tail lights that I've used in the past.  I'm not sure yet how long a set of batteries will last, after two weeks of 1.5 hour/day use, the light (in strobe mode) is still going strong.Anything that could be done to improve the unit?  Well sure.  Make it rechargeable with a USB cable.  Otherwise, it's a solid winner, clearly the best light that I've used in 16 years of night time commuting.

Michael Lewis's Moneyball is not a homerun, but it's good for a couple of extra bases.  A triple if you're a baseball fan (maybe an inside the park homer if you're a fanatic!), a double if you're not.The book, which chronicles the 2002 Oakland A's season, absolutely does provide an intriguing inside view of the workings of major league baseball.  It struggles, though, from a paradoxical case of TMI (Too Much Information) and NEI (Not Enough Information).  And it fails to adequately expand its fascinating central premise into something that is slowly, but steadily, becoming incorporated into the way that smart companies do business:  throw out preconceptions, develop new and more meaningful ways of measuring performance, implement, measure, repeat the cycle.Baseball, Lewis points out, is a ship whose hull is so heavily encrusted with the barnacles of superstition and untested tradition that the speed with which it can move forward is significantly impeded.  Up until Billy Bean (whose fascinating biographical info is worth the read in and of itself) is saddled with a team with few stars and little money, the major league solution to the encrusted hull was to simply apply more horsepower:  more money, to buy bigger stars.  With that solution not available, Bean and a small but innovative crew, get down to the business of carefully scrutinizing what REALLY counts when the goal is to win.  Stealing bases is out.  A walk is as good as a single.  A batting average of .300 with a low on-base average is not as good as a batting average of .240, but a high on-base average.  In short:  science comes to baseball.The TMI:  though the book is a short one, it is repeatedly saddled with long descriptive scenes that serve more to show that the author had quite a bit of face time with baseball VIP's,  than they forward the thrust of the theories that the author (very valuably) wants to bring to light.The NEI:  the premise of the book, that baseball has for a century been shackled with assumptions about recruiting and strategy that are actually counterproductive (in terms of winning games), is a powerful and extremely thought-provoking concept.  But it's way too big of a concept for an author with a wide-ranging mind (see his book The New, New Thing) to limit it to baseball.  My field (I'm a family physician) is also deeply barnacle-encrusted with "expert opinion" that often obliterates good solid evidence to the contrary.  Faced with diminishing resources in the face of sky-rocketing healthcare costs, the best outfits in healthcare are applying precisely the same principles that Michael Lewis details in Moneyball:  develop MEANINGFUL measures of performance, retool to obtain those meaningful measures, be willing to trash popular healthcare myths if the evidence doesn't support them (e.g. breast exams and prostate exams do NOT save lives, routine physical exams are largely useless, prostate and breast cancer screening, in the best studies done to date, may have caused more harm than good).Lewis, in Moneyball, uncovers this:  most businesses operate on principles that are time-honored and  so ingrained that when you attempt to deviate from them, you are ridiculed at best, and fired from your job at worst.  But then someone like Steve Jobs or Mark Zuckerberg comes along, insists that there is a different way of looking at things, and the rest is history, much to the detriment of Microsoft and My Space, respectively.

All diet books cater to these notions:  you'll lose weight fast, it'll be easy, and only THIS diet book has the proper secrets to success. The 17 Day Diet fits those criteria.The difference between a quality diet book and a scam is that some leave the reader properly informed about the foods that make us thrive and have a normal body weight (South Beach Diet, Zone Diet, 17 Day Diet), and some are based on fantasy premises, such as that your blood type makes a difference, your ethnic background makes a significant difference, or your astrological sign makes a difference. The 17 Day Diet is a quality diet book.The keys to sustained weight loss (30 lbs. or more, maintained for longer than TWO YEARS, not six months, or one year) are established by good research.  You don't need to buy a book to accomplish the requirements: proper diet, and physical activity.  I'm a family physician that lost more than 30 lbs. 16 years ago, and have kept it off.  I did it by following the research based information noted long ago in a Scientific American article.  And I'll give you the info for free in two parts:Food:  Eat fresh fruits and vegetables, lean meat and fish.  Stay away from the white stuff (bread, pasta, rice, potatoes, sugar).  Even more simply put by Michael Pollan in his books:  Eat food.  Not too much.  Mostly vegetables.Exercise:  Here's the rough part: people that have lost 30 lbs. and kept it off for more than two years AVERAGE an hour of physical activity per day.  Lots of ways to get this done, often creativity is required.  I have patients that are long-haul truckers and traveling salesmen that, against formidable odds, are thin and healthy. They have found ways to get this one hour of activity in (often by splitting it into smaller intervals several times/day). I had to begin riding my bicycle to work every day (45 minutes each way).  I do it year round (even have studded snow tires for my commuter bike).  You can find a way. Don't use weather as an excuse to skip your activity. There is no such thing as bad weather, there are only improperly dressed people, say the Scandinavians.  I'm Irish, but I believe them.There you have it.  Where does this leave 17 Day Diet?  IGNORE the wonderful testimonies posted by Amazon readers regarding their weight loss.  Come ON....you've heard all this stuff before, with each diet book that has come out, with each diet that you've tried.  Write these folks claiming marvelous success back in two years, and you'll find that the only ones that have succceeded are the ones that have adopted what I suggest above.Bottom line:  The 17 Day Diet is one of the "good" diet books, because Dr. Mike provides excellent nutritional advice, and insists that you stay active.  His particular hook, his innovation, is that you keep the body's metabolism "off balance" by shifting back and forth between metabolic food groups.  None of which contain baloney, though the advice is.  Try the book, stick to it, you WILL lose weight.  Stick to it for two years, and you'll keep the weight off.  Why? Not because of any diet secret here, not because of keeping the metabolism "off balance", but because if you follow Dr. Mike's advice, you'll be eating fresh fruit and vegetables, lean meat and fish, dramatically reducing the "white stuff" in your diet, and exercising regularly.The 17 Day Diet is also distinguished by the upbeat and friendly tone of the author.  Any doctor that goes out on a walk with his patients twice a week (as Dr. Mike does) is quite literally walking his talk.  Kudos to the author!One last note: the author does refer, somewhat obliquely, to a relatively new hot topic in weight loss medicine.  The type of bacteria that colonize your gut MAY affect your ability to lose weight.  The author recommends probiotics to shift your intestinal flora.  Current research is more suggestive that when you eat a healthy diet, your gut flora evolves to deal with healthy foods, whereas junk foods encourage intestinal flora that promote obesity. In other words, if you want healthy gut bacteria, eat right, as opposed to taking probiotics.  This research is intriguing, but preliminary, and not established.

Diamonds with flaws are still gemstones, still have enough density to scratch through layers of most other earthly materials, and still refract light in dazzling ways.  If one uses a jeweler's loupe to inspect a diamond closely, the flaws can be distracting and distressing.  The remedy is not to look too closely.  A proposed approach to State of Wonder:  enjoy the density and the fascinating refractions, but leave your literary jeweler's loupe in your pocket.In this book, Patchett spins her own ten days of experience in the Amazon into a tale whose slowly moving course has many tributaries feeding its river of narrative.  The convincing realism of Patchett's description of the primeval rain forest environment, given her brief actual stay, is a powerful testimony to her powers of observation.I'm certain that I will not be the first to observe that State of Wonder is very loosely analogous to a modern day Heart of Darkness.  The protagonist, Merina Singh, sets aside her comfortable Minnesota MD/Ph.D life as a pharmaceutical company employee to journey up the Amazon.  Dr. Singh has a two-fold mission:  bringing closure to the death of a colleague, and assessing progress on a drug that her company has invested millions on.Patchett uses the literal journey of Dr. Singh to take multiple adventures up offshoots of the plot, including an examination of the soul (or lack thereof) of the pharmaceutical industry, the inevitable (often tragic) consequences of contact between cultures with widely divergent levels of technology, the notion of a "fountain of youth" that only affects one organ system (men, eat your heart out), and the many different types of love that we humans have for one another.  If one enjoys moving along at the pace of a canoe, paddle dipping first on one side of the boat, then on the other while one contemplates what unfolds at each bend of the river, State of Wonder is a very edifying excursion.The gem like qualities of this book include the images and thoughts that linger long after the book is laid down.  The philosophical and ethical dilemmas raised by Patchett seem legitimate, relevant, and important (sure to raise eyebrows, if not hackles, in a book group).  Patchett's sure, steady, experienced, and competent hand on the prose of the novel is a pleasure and a tonic.The flaws in the gem?  To dwell on them would be picayune, as they are outshone by the quality of the story.  In an interview published on the Amazon website, Patchett says "All the adventure I need I can dream up in my kitchen. I love writing outside of my own experience, making imaginary worlds."  There are inherent limitations to such an approach.  I'll leave it at that.

When information on a topic is scarce, even a flawed presentation of the material is valuable and appreciated.  Scott Carney's The Red Market, a bit short on coherence, and significantly longer on shock value and home grown philosophy and ethics, is a valuable, quick, and easy read.  Its deficiencies, though, keep it from having the depth and power of books like The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacksand The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer.The Red Market has very real value.  Dead or alive, the human body has value to those amongst the living.  Whether it be medical/nursing schools desperate for cadavers and skeletons needed to adequately educate students, individuals looking for a surrogate mother to carry a custom ordered embryo through a pregnancy, or someone in need of an organ for transplant, the urgency of the potential buyer has historically (and currently) often overwhelmed legal and ethical constructs that are ill-suited to cope with demand.  Carney's explorations into grave robbing, the marketing of blood products, the commercialization of organ donation, the abuses (including outright kidnapping) that can occur in the adoption industry, and the surrogate pregnancy farms where women are treated little better than farm animals kept in stalls, are eye-opening, thought-provoking, and often likely to stimulate both the gag reflex and moral outrage.  So far, so good.But The Red Market also has very real flaws, including a flirtation with being good old-fashioned yellow journalism.  After wading through three-quarters of a book devoted to lurid (and accurate) examples of what happens when human bodies are treated no better than any other animal might be in a butcher shop or packing house, using language that evokes urgency/emergency, Carney pauses.  Pauses to admit that if you do get a kidney for a transplant, or blood products, or an adopted child, or a child born to a surrogate mother, the odds are 90% or better that you're getting a legitimate product, from legitimate sources.  No one should ignore the plight of the 10%, and it is often investigative journalism such as Carney's that begins to focus bright light on problems that sorely need attention.  But magnitude is an important quality when assessing a problem, and the relatively late-coming information that the huge majority of trade in human body parts is legitimate is a definite pin to what seems portrayed as a crisis sized balloon.Carney is at his weakest when philosophizing and/or moralizing about the ethical dilemmas that face the human race in its pursuit of health, longevity, or parenthood.  Rather than present the dilemmas clearly, and subsequently let the reader contemplate possible solutions, Carney has his own pre-packaged moralizations to bestow on the reader.  His ruminations come across with more indignation than substance, often with a lack of depth that seems almost akin to having been too lazy to tap into the marvelous ethical and philosophical debates that swirl around the topics that he includes in The Red Market.The bare bones:  The Red Market has high value when illuminating the actual and potential abuses that occur when a mixture of raw determination and wealth on the part of the buyer of humans, or parts of humans, collides with the poverty and desperation that is fertile soil for exploitation.  When it comes to conclusions to be drawn, however, I'm guessing that either the reader, or the reader's book group, can fairly easily outdistance the author's own conclusions.  If I desired preaching, I'd go to church instead.  But I don't.Addendum: an excellent article on the red market by science writer Yudhijit Bhatacharjee titled The Organ Dealer can be found at Discover magazine (where it was originally published) or in The Best American Science and Nature Writing 2011, where it is the lead story of the book.

Books that combine an excellent review of quantum physics with a provocative world view should probably merit a baseline three stars, and this one does.  That said, The Beginning of Infinity does not seem to have the makings of a classic in the genre.As numerous reviews have pointed out, this book is a David Deutsch "Theory of Everything", not in terms of uniting all four of the basic forces of physics (though in a sense he does that), but in the sense of expanding quantum physics into a theory that encompasses everything that we humans tend to hold meaningful.
