Thus the book includes attempts to show that an absolute standard of beauty, a system of ethics, and even systems of politics and (loosely interpreted) parenting and education can be derived from Deutsch's unique point of view.In The Beginning of Infinity, Deutsch goes to great creative lengths in an attempt to make quantum physics less mysterious and more comprehensible. In this he succeeds better than many other authors.  As an educated person that has made an effort to keep up over the last five decades with advances in science, but still regularly gets pushed into "I'm FAIRLY sure I understand what is being said" territory, I found Deutsch's explanations illuminating and very helpful.  Deutsch's explorations of the implications of the well-known single photon studies (leading many, but not Deutsch, to say that photons are "both particles and waves") are striking and deeply exciting.  Deutsch is an acknowledged leader in quantum theory and quantum computing, and when he discusses topics that he knows best, he seems to be on the most solid ground (as solid as anything can be in this quantum world!).  It is when he strays from his area of expertise that he begins to take on the colorations of many other great scientists that wander off into clouds of quirkiness when they leave their area of expertise.  Linus Pauling on Vitamin C, James Watson on race, Lynn Margulis on the cause of AIDS come to mind.When Deutsch jumps with all four limbs into philosophy, anthropology, politics, and education, he does so with a maximum of enthusiasm, and not a little combativeness.  Often defending his positions by preemptively consigning any and all opponents to an "ism" (e.g. empiricism, reductionism, rationalism, "isms" ad infinitum), Deutsch's arguments vary wildly between seeming shockingly superficial and too profound to easily grasp.  It is instructive, if you have the time, to watch the TED lecture (YouTube) that Deutsch gave in 2005:  it gives a sense of just how static his points of view have remained over nearly a decade.When Deutsch discusses Artificial Intelligence, he seems woefully out of touch with the literature that has emerged over the last five to seven years.  When he discusses why mankind is a species of animal that is different in kind, rather than degree, he ignores (and is often factually incorrect) when citing animal research data regarding non-human language capabilities and levels of consciousness.  When he describes humans as "universal constructors" and/or "universal explainers" (i.e. capable of infinite progress in both related arenas) his arguments often, again, seem out of touch with current research on neuroanatomy, consciousness, and far more in synch with the powerful drive we humans have to think of ourselves as unique in all the universe.Deutsch's estimation of the human mind's infinite capacity requires him to climb further and further out on epistemological limbs.  If one could compare Deutsch's science of the human brain to the field of astronomy, it would be fair to say that he runs a very significant risk of being a Pre-Copernican:  it's probably just not true that EVERYTHING with advanced computational capacity  revolves around the human mind, now and forever.Deutsch diverges almost imperceptibly, but very significantly, from much contemporary evolutionary/complexity/emergence theory when he uses the word "knowledge" in place of the word "information".  Whereas a fair amount of contemporary thought has been devoted to the emergent phenomena that occur as more and more information (down to and including the color and spin of quarks) coalesces in a process that started with whatever we think the Big Bang may have been, by using the word knowledge instead of information, Deutsch appears to coopt the evolution of information by establishing human ownership of it.  If information, starting in its most basic form (quarks? Superstrings?) evolves in increasingly complex ways over the life of the multiverse, then humans are simply a particular (in this case, primate) manifestation of an inevitable process that is independent of humans.  An evolutionary process that is akin, then, to what Kevin Kelly seems to allude to in his striking book What Technology Wants.  If on the other hand, "knowledge" is the key evolutionary factor, then humans (who translate information into knowledge and are the sole possesors of knowledge) are absolutely necessary for forward motion.  Motion toward infinity, Deutsch proposes, needs the current version of Homo sapiens (Deutsch distinguishes between current and past versions).  Which is an attractive proposal to me from an egotistical point of view, I'll admit.  But then....I read the morning paper.  And it makes me hope that the Multiverse, in all its Information, has more in store for the future than Mankind Uber Alles.

I'm a family physician, and I deal with cancer every day that I work.  I initially avoided reading this book for a variety of reasons.  Cancer is a distressing, depressing topic to deal with:  Why would I want to read a moderately lengthy book about something that I've had more than my fill of both professionally and personally (both my parents died of cancer, a year apart)?  I was wrong to avoid it, and when I did read it, found it to be deeply rewarding on two levels, a bit disappointing on a third.Level One:  Medical history.  The history of cancer, dating back to its identification in Egyptian papyruses, then tracing its course up to 2010, was entrancing.  Filled with fascinating anecdotes, descriptions of the lively cast of characters that tried to engage cancer over more than 3000 years of battle, and a clearly laid out scientific history that moves from theories about an overabundance of black bile to the intricate workings of suppressor genes and oncogenes, the book is simply a marvel of illumination.Level Two: A Cautionary Tale.  As the author chronicles the incredibly aggressive approaches that early surgeons and oncologists took toward treating cancers "liquid" (leukemias) or "solid" (lung, breast, etc.), one is rocked back on one's heels while contemplating the arrogance and brutality of early and more recent treatments.  How many of the hundreds of thousands of women that received radical mastectomies actually obtained a result superior to that which a simple lumpectomy would have afforded?  NONE, may well be the answer.  When lawsuits (and in some cases, laws) forced HMO's and other health insurance companies to pay for bone marrow transplants for breast cancer victims, the treatments killed more women than they saved, at the cost of many millions of dollars.  Mukherjee also brings to light case after case of medical pioneers that glimpsed truths about cancer, but then were subsequently mocked, persecuted, even run out of their professions for daring to have insight.  Mukherjee also gently, but clearly, points out the dangers of letting the American political process mandate the direction of research, often with tragic consequences.Level Three:  No author is perfectly effective at telling a tale.  Mukherjee is most effective as a historian and a science writer, less so when he tries to plumb the human aspects of an encounter with cancer.  The book begins and ends with descriptions of his relationships with patients with cancer.  These encounters seem a bit heavy on drama, and a bit light on the hard and somewhat mundane work one does while walking a patient through the course of their illness (be it a successful treatment or a failure).Summary?  This book is not just a good book. It is an important and rare book, both in its explanatory power regarding the disease of cancer, and in the lessons that such a thorough and unblinking history of medicine call forth.  It changed the way that I explain cancer to my patients, and it changed the way that I thought about my own profession as a physician.  Having read it, you will not be able to read the news (e.g. the recent recommendation that PSA not be used to routinely screen for cancer)through the same lenses that you used before.

There was a time, before iPods, Walkmans, TV, radio, record players, in which workers (usually women) that were assigned to long hours of menial labor would assign one amongst them to read a book to the rest. The Return of the Native, Thomas Hardy's sixth novel, would be a terrific choice for such a reading group.  Few in the 21st century have the leisure, or the inclination, to delve into a tale in which many pages might be given to the description of a natural scene, or to the intricate development of the personalities of the main characters of this book.  But if there were a modern reader that either had, or made, time to read this book at the deliberate and careful pace that is required to experience its depth and richness, that reader would be richly rewarded.  As was I.Thomas Hardy, better known for Tess of the D'Urbervilles, was one of the most influential of the English authors of the 1800's.  Both D.H. Lawrence and Virginia Woolf pay him homage and cite him as a source of their inspiration.  His stories can be explored on two levels, both levels very accessible to the moderately experienced reader, neither level involving a journey into the deep complexities of books such as Pinchon's Gravity's Rainbow or James Joyce's Ulysses.The first level of The Return of the Native:  it's simply a wonderful tale.  For the price of a tiny bit of patience, as Hardy's narrative begins to unfold the reader receives a rich story involving integrity, duplicity, humor, passion, selfishness and selflessness, nobility and narcissism, as well as the consequences of impetuous action and the rewards of patient persistence.  As a well told story it stands on its own and stands proudly, with or without the embellishment of scholarly opinion or critical review.The second level:  Hardy infuses the story with his philosophy of the relationship between nature and mankind, his criticisms of the tragic consequences of societally ordained values (Victorian values colliding with human desires and capabilities), and beautiful symbolism. For those who feel that plots are not the core of a novel but merely scaffoldings upon which to hang literary/philosophical schools of thought and layers of symbolism, The Return of the Native serves well as a cerebral playground.  This particular edition is a wonderful companion to those who delight in experiencing every nuance that can be brought to life.Taken at the first level, The Return of the Native is an absorbing tale complete with unpredictable twists of plot, human souls whose fates are determined by letters that arrive moments too late, and bouts of comic relief.At the second level, The Return of the Native is rich in philosophy, anthropology, even theology.Take both levels together, and you have what is deservedly called a classic.  The word classic makes many cringe.  No need to recoil from The Return of the Native:  this story is fascinating and rewarding for any who are patient enough to let its rich flavors and constructions emerge at a pace reflective of an era gone by.

In a twist on William Wordsworth's words, in my family, the child (my adult daughter) is often mother to the man:  she often introduces me to literature that is deeply enriching, and that I would have otherwise completed my trundle from cradle to grave without enjoying.  Such is the case with An Atlas of the Difficult World.Sometimes poetry packs density of thought so tightly that it becomes diamond-like in its ability to etch new messages on the glass windowpanes that we view life through.  Such is the poetry of Adrienne Rich.  Rich writes at one point that writing comes from the marrow of the bone, and her bones are not quiet ones.  Hematopoesis is the process that bone marrow uses to form the complex elements that make up the blood that runs in our veins, and the literary hemotopoesis of Rich generates a wealth of elements that include a vibrant femininism, a spelunking expedition into the nature of our human and national soul, a compassion for the disenfranchised, and a steely eyed clarity, a blowtorch intensity, that incinerates hypocrisy and preciousness.It would be easy to make a list of the brilliant lines in Rich's poetry, and one can certainly try to patch together a meaningful review of this book.  But the last poem in An Atlas of the Difficult World is, for all intents and purposes, Rich's own review of her book, and I cannot match her eloquence:"it will not be simple, it will not be longit will take little time, it will take all your thoughtit will take all your heart, it will take all your breathit will be short, it will not be simpleit will touch through your ribs, it will take all your heartit will not be long, it will occupy your thoughtas a city is occupied, as a bed is occupiedit will take all your flesh, it will not be simpleYou are coming into us who cannot withstand youyou are coming into us who never wanted to withstand youyou are taking parts of us into places never plannedyou are going far away with pieces of our livesit will be short, it will take all your breathit will not be simple, it will become your will"Quantum sufficit.

Though pleasant to handle, and a bit of a conversation piece, this knife comes up a bit short.  Literally.  For a good sized loaf of bread, it's simply not long enough to span the width of the loaf.  Though reasonably sharp, it is not exceptionally so.  A metal knife, generally less expensive, serves better.

This compact and easily packable book is by no means a replacement for more comprehensive bird, wildflower, or tree identification handbooks.  That said, it is amazing how much high quality information is packed between the front and the back cover.  My wife and I used it on a recent road trip from the eastern borders of Washington and Oregon to the Pacific coast.  Whether we were at 8000 feet in the Eage Cap Wilderness, along the Columbia River, or on the beach at Cape Disappointment, it was amazing how frequently this field guide was useful in identifying flora and fauna that we encountered.  The geological sections added to the pleasure.Overall, it fits well in the "If you like nature, but are allowed only ONE book to take with you on a road trip or backpacking outing, which book would you take?" category.

Written in 1819 by Sir Walter Scott, Ivanhoe is a novel that is, by some critics, credited with the revival of modern interest in the Middle Ages, and the principals of chivalry.  But...that's probably not why you'd be interested in reading it.  Ivanhoe contains a fascinating portrayal of the very gradual merging of the Saxon and Norman cultures after William the Conqueror prevailed at the Battle of Hastings.  But, again, this probably isn't the reason that you might be induced to pick up a book you've often heard of, but have never been tempted to read or listen to.  Arguably, Ivanhoe's most admirable and intriguing character is Rebecca, a young and beautiful Jewish woman.  Scott leverages Rebecca's travails into a thoughtful and powerful exploration of the oppression of women, and the brutal discrimination against medieval Judaism.  And....I'm guessing that's not why you'll make room on your "to be read" pile for an almost 200 year old novel.But here's why you might want to take an "I'll read fifty pages, and if I don't like it, won't read the rest" approach to the tale of Ivanhoe:  it's an intelligent, rollicking, swash-buckling, humorous tale of beautiful damsels and men with sword arms like tree trunks, couched in semi-medieval language that is so lush that you'll find yourself going around for days afterwards talking like the yeoman of yore that lived with Robin of Locksley in Sherwood Forest.  Get those fifty pages under your mental belt, and you won't put it down.  Why?  Because it has it all:  magnificent battles, truly good guys fighting truly bad guys, corrupt priests and abbots, arrogant noblemen, estranged fathers and sons, Robin Hood, Richard the Lionhearted, Knights Templar, the evil King John and his nefarious henchmen.  But wait! There's more: accusations of witchcraft, a Lazarus scene, mortal wounds, near mortal wounds, and hearts that break or burst from love and/or anguish.  Ah, for a world when right makes might, instead of the 21st century might makes right.  Oh for a century where bromances were based on shared adventure and combat rather than epic bouts of drinking or the mentality that the Jackass movies are based on.Through all of the above, Sir Walter Scott's witty, careful, and exquisitely crafted sequences of dialogue give a glimpse of the beauty of human discourse (or, intercourse, as Scott refers to it) before we began to communicate in tweets, twitters, text messages, instant messages, and Facebook comments.Ivanhoe, one should know, is barely about the character Ivanhoe. Fine young man of courage and honor that he is, the plot swirls and thickens while Ivanhoe is largely indisposed for one reason or another.  Though the book wouldn't have sold had it been named properly (it should have been called "Rebecca"), the reader will find the struggle between an ultravirile Knight Templar with dishonorable intentions and Rebecca, beautiful in mind, body, and soul, more absorbing than Ivanhoe's own contribution to the plot.So.  Ivanhoe is an important novel, but beshrew that, kind sirs and ladies:  read it and dream of castles that have pennants on the battlements, Dark Knights that save the day, the clash of swords, the shattering of lances, fire-breathing war horses, and excellent archers that can split a wand at a hundred yards.  To heck with you, Rhett Butler and your Southernb belles:  life for real men doesn't start until the clank of arrows bouncing off one's suit of armor in the full riot of battle reaches a crescendo, and Sheffield forged swords bounce off Spanish made suits of chainmail.  Scarlett, step aside for Rebecca, the Jewish physician of legendary beauty, intelligence, and resolve that comes to Ivanhoe's aid.  Sir Walter Scott knows how to create characters of heroic proportion, and the reader that takes the time to pick up Ivanhoe will reap the benefits of his ability to tell a tale for the ages.

To heck with you, Rhett Butler and your Southern Belles:  life for real men doesn't start until the clank of arrows bouncing off one's suit of armor in the full riot of battle reaches a crescendo, and Sheffield forged swords bounce off Spanish made suits of chainmail.  Scarlett, step aside for Rebecca, the Jewish physician of legendary beauty, intelligence, and resolve that comes to Ivanhoe's aid.  Sir Walter Scott knows how to create characters of heroic proportion, and the reader that takes the time to pick up Ivanhoe will reap the benefits of his ability to tell a tale for the ages.

Written in 1819 by Sir Walter Scott, Ivanhoe is a novel that is, by some critics, credited with the revival of modern interest in the Middle Ages, and the principals of chivalry.  But...that's probably not why you'd be interested in reading it.  Ivanhoe contains a fascinating portrayal of the very gradual merging of the Saxon and Norman cultures after William the Conqueror prevailed at the Battle of Hastings.  But, again, this probably isn't the reason that you might be induced to pick up a book you've often heard of, but never been tempted to read or listen to.  Arguably, Ivanhoe's most admirable and intriguing character is a Rebecca, a young and beautiful Jewish woman.  Scott leverages Rebecca's travails into a thoughtful and powerful exploration of the oppression of women, and the brutal discrimination against medieval Judaism.  And....I'm guessing that's not why you'll make room on your "to be read" pile for an almost 200 year old novel.But here's why you might want to take an "I'll read fifty pages, and if I don't like it, won't read the rest" approach to the tale of Ivanhoe:  it's an intelligent, rollicking, swash-buckling, humorous tale of beautiful damsels and men with sword arms like tree trunks, couched in semi-medieval language that is so lush that you'll find yourself going around for days afterwards talking like the yeoman of yore that lived with Robin of Locksley in Sherwood Forest.  Get those fifty pages under your mental belt, and you won't put it down.  Why?  Because it has it all:  magnificent battles, truly good guys fighting truly bad guys, corrupt priests and abbots, arrogant noblemen, estranged fathers and sons, Robin Hood, Richard the Lionhearted, Knights Templar, the evil King John and his nefarious henchmen.  But wait! More: accusations of witchcraft, a Lazarus scene, mortal wounds, near mortal wounds, and hearts that break or burst from love and/or anguish.  Ah, for a world when right makes might, instead of the 21st century might makes right.  Oh for a century where bromances were based on shared adventure and combat rather than epic bouts of drinking or the mentality that the Jackass movies are based on.Through all of the above, Sir Walter Scott's witty, careful, and exquisitely crafted sequences of dialogue give a glimpse of the beauty of human discourse (or, intercourse, as Scott refers to it) before we began to communicate in tweets, twitters, text messages, instant messages, and Facebook comments.Ivanhoe, one should know, is barely about the character Ivanhoe.  Though he is a fine young man of courage and honor, the plot swirls and thickens while Ivanhoe is largely indisposed for one reason or another.  Although the book wouldn't have sold had it been named properly (it should have been called "Rebecca"), the reader will find the struggle between an ultravirile Knight Templar with dishonorable intentions and Rebecca, beautiful in mind, body, and soul more absorbing than Ivanhoe's own contribution to the plot.So.  Ivanhoe is an important novel, but beshrew that, kind sirs and ladies:  read it and dream of castles that have pennants on the battlements, Dark Knights that save the day, the clash of swords, the shattering of lances, fire-breathing war horses, and excellent archers that can split a wand at a hundred yards.  To heck with you, Rhett Butler and your Southern Belles:  life for real men doesn't start until the clank of arrows bouncing off one's suit of armor in the full riot of battle reaches a crescendo, and Sheffield forged swords bounce off Spanish made suits of chainmail.  Scarlett, step aside for Rebecca, the Jewish physician of legendary beauty, intelligence, and resolve that comes to Ivanhoe's aid.  Sir Walter Scott knows how to create characters of heroic proportion, and the reader that takes the time to pick up Ivanhoe will reap the benefits of his ability to tell a tale for the ages.

Viewing a 3D movie without wearing the special glasses required yields a blurry, migraine inducing image.  Razor-sharp focus of plot and theme in Victor Pelevin's genre-busting Omon Ra may not be entirely achievable, and it's a fair bet that the author's Buddhist background led him to deliberately include paradox (a literary koan) in the weaving of this kaleidoscopic tale.  A bit of background does, though, sharpen the images that blast through this novel enough to allow the emergence of a rock-you-back-on-your-heels trip to a mental outer space that many readers (including myself) have not yet explored.Pelevin, Russian-born in 1962, earned a degree in electro-mechanical engineering, then went on to study creative writing.  A student of Buddhism, the right-living (reportedly he neither drinks nor smokes) Pelevin was witness in his 20's to the rise of glasnost and perestroika and the ascendance of hope in the emergence of a Russian national culture that would be based on openness and justice.  By his early 30's, Pelevin was witnessing the disintegration of Russia into a culture that combined the worst elements of capitalism run amok and gangsterism as a form of government.  Two pillars of Pelevin's life, science and Buddhism, are at their hearts a search for purity and truth.  Juxtaposing them with the soul-destroying conformity of the receding USSR empire and the insurgent raw materialism of the new Russia didn't result in creative tension, one might guess, but rather a rupture of spiritual/psychological tectonic plates whose 9.0 Richter scale creative shock waves Pelevin (to the reader's benefit) captured in Oman Ra, his first novel.Oman Ra is science fiction only in the sense that Brave New World is. Sci-fi fans addicted to space opera, technophilia, or alien encounters:  stay away.  Just as easily categorized as political satire, existential literature, surrealism, or historical fiction, Pelevin packs all these genres into a 154 page vehicle, where they sit cheek by jowl, sometimes uncomfortably.  Cram your way into this rover, though, and you're in for a wild ride that rivals Hollywood's best chase scenes.  Pelevin's imagery is nothing short of brilliant.  From Oman's (the protagonist) father lying drunk on a couch under a reproduction of Michelangelo's Creation of Adam, to the use of an unsteerable, virtually blinded bicycle powered moon rover as a metaphor for existence, Pelevin draws sharp intakes of breath and scores mental TKO's from the first pages to the last.  From the absurdity of preparing for walking into a lunar vacuum by stuffing lubricated tampons into ones ears and nostrils, to the haunting image of humans as stars  that twinkle in empty space, seen by each other, but separated by unbridgeable interstellar distances, Pelevin never lets the reader quite recover equilibrium.  The first page is intriguing.  The last paragraph of Oman Ra may be the most precise literary expression of existentialism ever written.Though immersed in the absurdity of life, Pelevin's role as editor of a magazine that deals with issues of science and religion indicates that he may still be looking for answers, still plumbing for meaning.  Gertrude Stein once said "There ain't no answer.  There ain't going to be any answer.  There has never been an answer.  THAT's the answer."  I suspect that if Pelevin agreed with Stein, his tectonic plates would settle down, and the creative shockwaves would diminish.  We, the readers, though, would suffer for it.

It's a fair bet to say that most readers of Gail Holstein's Waking the Ancients will read the last page, close the book, and think "Wow.  I've never read anything quite like THAT before."  It's also a fair bet that many readers will find it a page-turner, likely finishing this brief (184 page) novel in just a few hours.  What's much less clear is whether the reader will be glad that they've had the encounter with Waking the Ancients.Under the influence of a mysterious and charismatic ex-anthropologist, an American family that has all that our society can offer, accompanied by a runaway teenager and a successful African-American female bank executive, retreats into the wilderness of the Arizona's Mogollon Ridge to reclaim the purity, simplicity, and spirituality of the lives that ancient Native American tribes of the Southwest reputedly experienced.There is one scene in the novel that became emblematic when trying to capture the essence of Waking the Ancients.  A teenage girl, living for the first time completely off the land, attempts to make a fur vest for the clan leader by stitching together the skins of various small animals that have been caught and eaten.  Lacking any skills as a seamstress, and not having the necessary tools for completing the project well (e.g. scissors, needle, thread) the finished product is lumpy, misshapen, and not functional.  Holstein's book has an uncomfortably close metaphorical relationship with this failed garment.  It is an odd mix of a hyper-reverence for Native American culture,  some nods to feminism and environmentalism, a bit of social commentary (especially regarding the superficiality/complexity of modern American life), some mysticism, with an analysis of the psychological dynamics of cults thrown in for good measure.  Sautee the whole mix with a discomforting sexuality in which a plethora of male faults and/or brutalities are repeatedly tolerated as long as hard abs, low body mass index, and "mountain biker butt" physique are part of the mix. With its numerous loose threads and inconsistent construction, this garment/book simply doesn't achieve a level of coherence that leaves the reader either with a sense of having a good time going along for the ride, or having any important takeaways from the reading experience.Will you finish the book if you finish the first chapter?  I'm betting you will.  If you use it as a book club selection, will it stimulate discussion?  Almost certainly.  Some feel that true art both entertains and instructs.  This book gets less than half way to art.

The child in me (my wife says that aspect of me never became "inner") was entranced by this book.  Nine pound flightless parrots that smell like honey, play peek-a-boo with humans, and growl like puppies? Adult or child, one wants to know more!In simple, and yes, somewhat childlike language, this book details a story that has happened many thousands of times in recent centuries:  A prevalent animal or plant species encounters humans and the animals that accompany us (dogs, cats, rats) and is subsequently reduced to extinction, or near extinction. The beauty and intelligence of the Kakapo make their story more poignant, but no more tragic than countless other similar tales.  What is powerful about Kakapo Rescue is the fusion of breath-taking photography and the careful, non-judgmental telling of the impact our human presence has had on other living beings.  Young and old readers are invited to contemplate how once thriving species (whales, passenger pigeons, kakapo) can be moved from almost innumerable abundance to catastrophic reduction by human action, AND they are invited to contemplate how dedicated, skillful, and committed humans can begin to undo the harm that has been done. The story of individuals, governments, and corporations banding together to nurture a devastated species toward recovery is powerfully hopeful. Regardless of age, a message of hope sometimes seems more a call to action than repeated and relentless tolling of disaster.Dr.Suess attempted to tell the story of our human impact on the Earth to children and adults in whimsical form; Kakapo Rescue tells it in stunning photos, simple and accurate prose, and in age-appropriate scientific language.  Much as I admire Dr. Suess, as a young person I would have far preferred this fascinating book to any fictional allegory.Shortcomings?  Hmmm.  I hungered for more detail, more examples of the intelligent behavior of these birds, a more developed portrait of what it is to be a Kakapo.  That said, this is one fine book for both the young, the young at heart, and any lover of nature, regardless of age.

This product seems to be a definite cut above average.  When dumped into water, it dissolves quickly and completely.  Raise the resulting mixture to your lips, and you're in for a treat.  I had the pomegranate flavored mix:  very slightly effervescent, very tasty, mildy sweet with just a touch of tartness.  As with many sports related drinks, the EBOOST comes with a long list of difficult to establish claims.  I can't state that I smashed any personal records after drinking it, but this much is true:  it was pleasant to drink, rested easily in my stomach, and gave me a mild and pleasant boost in energy.  Placebo?  Who knows, and since it felt good, who cares. I liked it better than any of the other drinks that I've tried over time, and if the price is reasonable, will be using more of it.

It's way more fun to learn something from fables, or listening to well told stories, than having to listen to a sermon, and Fish! takes a stab at the former approach.  It doesn't quite get there.There's no argument that humans who can't choose their circumstances CAN choose their response to these circumstances.  FISH!, though, is a pat, overly simplistic response to the very real problem of how to endure jobs that seem meaningless and repetitive.The author of the book leads a young and vulnerable (single mom, trying to support a family) woman through the steps required to turn a "toxic waste dump" of a job situation into an urban garden of delightful working conditions.  The book makes it sound like a piece of cake.  In reality, the scenario in which a new boss (or an old boss) rolls out a new way of doing things designed to improve productivity and enjoyment in the work place is the eternal fodder of sitcoms.I'm not being cynical, here.  My job involves counseling people that are deeply dissatisfied with their jobs, and the cures are far more complex than changing one's attitude and making the work place fun.  Sometimes, jobs really ARE meaningless, and demeaning.  In which case the cure is to take the steps necessary to change one's job.  Sometimes inertia has left one in a job that is far below one's capabilities, and distant from the creative talents that light us up when we use them.  And sometimes, one works for an employer that has created abusive working conditions.  In the above circumstances, FISH! seems to me to be a sort of "opiate of the masses":  read this book so that you'll feel better about being in a place that you should probably try to find a way to leave.That being said, the book does have some pearls.  If you have a job that is not abusive, that offers decent pay and good stability, there is content here than can make the workplace something far more tolerable, and even enjoyable. Worth the price?  Hmmm.  Consider getting a copy from your local library instead of buying it.

The people most enthusiastic about this product are probably too young to write their own reviews: young kids LOVE the Tykelight.The product performs as advertised, emitting a soft but plentiful amount of light (in a variety of colors) when lifted off its charger base. It glows all night after a single charge, and recharges quickly  It is easy to operate, the three year old that I gave it too mastered the ability to change the colors as well as set the timed phaseout (it can be set to fade out in 20 minutes) with no trouble at all.Esthetically, the creators hit on something very pleasing.  The soft looking shape is a crowd pleaser; both adults and children seem fascinated by it, and reluctant to part with it.  The white surface doesn't seem to soil easily, but if it does, it wipes down without any problem at all.Me?  I felt a bit goofy at age 58 being entranced by this simple toy, but actually felt a twinge of regret when I removed it from my night table so that I could give it to an adopted grandchild.  The fascination and delight that the recipient demonstrated with the Tykelight did make up, almost, for my loss.

Sometimes a book is so good that I'd like to simply say "Don't bother with what I have to say, just go read it". Julia Whitty's Deep Blue Home fits in that category.  But for those that need a bit more convincing....Deep Blue Home is a collection of 32 science and nature essays that are provocatively named (The Very Air Miraculous, Bone Rafters, The Tempest from the Eagle's Wings), and even more deeply provocative and evocative in the reading.  Lowering her creative bucket into the well of her own scientific training, her wide travels, her multiple professions, her life experiences, and the richness of human mythology, Julia Whitty brings up into the light a payload that is astoundingly rich in content, content that is potent enough to alter the world view of those who choose to drink it in.Whitty's style of prose can be compared to, well, probably to NO other writer.  Her graceful, seamless, and fluid blending of hard science, love of nature, wry humor, keen observational skills, and all things good that come from estrogen, bring forth a book that powerfully delves into the relationship of mankind to the world that we dwell in.  At times Whitty's dramatic use of metaphor can be almost overpowering, such as this description of  being in a boat off the coast of Newfoundland:  "Yet our comforts are largely forgotten, in this numinous theater when white eyelids of fog open to undress the nudes of the landscape: the loins of an Irish-green fjord, a hank of blond kelp bound to the seashore and tongued by waves, the clattered bones of a ghost village sagging to driftwood.  In one blink of mist a muscular cliff materializes, tagged with the orange tattoos of crustose lichens hundreds of years old."  At other times, her language is more suited for an article in Scientific American, such as when she gives a detailed description of the aerodynamic design of fish-eating bats, whose high aspect wing ratios allow them to fly low and slow, carrying heavy payloads of fish.Dreamy and magical descriptions of enormous sea turtles methodically chomping their way through clusters of jellyfish give way to graphic (and also magical) descriptions of the life-giving journey of a whale carcass on its way to the seafloor, where it will nourish a carcass dependent community for decades.Each of the chapters is illuminating, and many are startling.  But lest we forget that nature is not a series of zoo-like exhibitions to be viewed in tidy parcels, but rather an inextricably woven web of interdependence, Whitty ends Deep Blue Home with a descent into a Baja California cave that is richly illustrated with Lescaux-like pictograms.  Antelope, octopi, whales, tuna, deer, sardines, pelicans, mountain lions, eagles, and humans swirl around each other in the cave's murals.  And over them all is a depiction of an event that occurred in 1054: a supernova that was visible during the daytime. What is it that Whitty sees in these ancient murals?  She sees a dark mirror of the human past:  "On convex walls darkened by soot we read the broader perspective---of disparate exploded realms of sea, air, land reassembling into wholes.  We see the numinous interplay among whales, pronghorn, sardines, lynx, eagles, sea turtles.  We see ourselves and know that we are part of the landscape, the seascape, the airscape, and can never be apart from them."  This is something we once all seemed to know, and have somehow often forgotten.  Deep Blue Home, once read, will never let you forget again.

Any review of this book would have to start by mentioning that it is part of Osprey Publishing‚Äôs ‚ÄúCampaign‚Äù series. As such it is only about 96 pages long, roughly a third of which is composes of illustrations of one type or another. Hence if one is looking for a tome on the subject it is not the book.The book itself is very well researched and filled with incredible detail on very minute activities surrounding the landing itself, taking of strongpoints, etc. A lay reader or one only interested in only a high level analysis would probably be overwhelmed. Hence the book is really geared for the specialist or the knowledgeable looking for great detail. In that regard the book is wonderful (thanks to its meticulous research).The book follows the typical Osprey ‚ÄúCampaign‚Äù format and covers the opposing side‚Äôs commanders, armies, goals and how the campaign played out. The only critique this reviewer has is that the book lacks a discussion/analysis of how this particular campaign fitted into the context of the other Overlord campaigns (i.e., Utah, Sword, Gold, Juno beach landings). There is no discussion of how this fitted into the puzzle with the other landings. In addition, there is no discussion of the extremely challenging logistical problems this landing had to overcome and to succeed. There is no discussion of underwater pipelines or man-made ports created near the landing zone. Despite these weaknesses this is still a solid book worth a four star rating and well worth reading for any serious reader albeit the lay reader may be overwhelmed by its level of detail.This reviewer would like to conclude that pointing out that this book, along with its sister ‚ÄúCampaign‚Äù books on the associated landings of Utah, Sword, Juno, Gold (and the airborne landings) can be purchased, in a very cost effective manner (as opposed to separately) in Osprey‚Äôs one volume book ‚ÄúOverlord : The D-Day Landings‚Äù. In addition, this one volume book has a very good introduction that brings together an analysis and discussion of all four landings in terms of commanders, armies, overall goals, etc. that the individual books in the series leave out.

Any review of this book would have to start off with the fact that it was originally published as a large Osprey publications book. These are normally compilations of previously published Osprey series books but this one is not (albeit most of the illustrations have appeared in previously published Osprey series books).  The book is a new publication that has been published from scratch.The author, in the last paragraph of the introduction of the book (p.9), lists what he attempts to do in the book. It is as follows:‚ÄúThis book is not only a history of the various elements of the Luftwaffe. It will also paint a detailed portrait of the men and machines who fought and served with the German Air Force from its origins to its defeat‚Ä¶.This book will seek to explain ‚Ä¶. Not only the Luftwaffe‚Äôs central role in Germany‚Äôs Offensive then defensive war plans, but also how the individual aviator, ground crew, and soldier played his part in these plans, both in victory and defeat‚Äù.Does the book do this? The answer depends on who the audience is. For the layman at the introductory or slightly above that level, yes. For the specialist or one with intermediate and above knowledge on the subject the answer is no. The reason is that the book does not present any new insight or in-depth analysis. The overview is from a pretty high level perspective on each of its major topics, covered in each individual chapter (i.e., organization and manpower, bombers, fighters, ground attack and maritime activities). The coverage on various aircraft and aerial campaigns, for example, is high level and not very detailed. Nowhere close to what one would find on various Osprey publications on these topics. Hence the specialist and knowledgeable reader would be disappointed. However, for the layman with limited knowledge of the topic the book provides a very decent introduction to the topic in one book. The book covers all the topics (albeit very succinctly). These include all the Luftwaffe‚Äôs major aircraft, campaigns, doctrine and tactics, overall strength and human elements (i.e., training, etc.), from the pre-war period to the end. In addition, factors contributing to strategic success and failure are covered (but only on a high level manner).Hence, for the specialist or very knowledgeable this book would rate a 2 or so star but for the layman without such knowledge it would be a four star. Considering that the book is written for the layman, however, the book is worthy of a four star.

This is a relatively short book, at only about 150 pages. The author makes no use of primary sources ‚Äì only secondary. In addition, there are no footnotes hence the reader does not know what sources were used to come up with quotes, damage reports, etc. Thirdly, the book does not provide anything new to the literature, either in terms of analysis or historical facts. This is the book‚Äôs most serious shortcoming. It greatly diminishes any value this book may have for anyone who has read on the battle to any degree. The book also lacks a detailed technical discussion of the vessels involved (Graf Spee and the 3 British cruisers) as well as any in depth diagrams/illustrations of the vessels. All and all, very disappointing for a book published by an authoritative press such as the Naval Institute Press.The subtitle of the book, ‚ÄúThe Grand Delusion‚Äù, is clarified for the reader in the end of the book. According to the author, from the German perspective this was Langsdorff‚Äôs (the Captain of the Graff Spee) attempt to fight a ‚ÄúGentleman‚Äôs War‚Äù. From the British it was the belief that the battle rubber stamped the wisdom of then current British naval strategy centering on surface ships and warfare. Not exactly, in this reviewer‚Äôs opinion, either a deep and profound observation or ‚Äúgrand delusions‚Äù.On the positive side, the book is of value to the novice (as opposed to the knowledgeable or the specialist). It provides what is a very good introduction to that audience. Hence, in short, this is a book that would be a four star for a novice but only a 2 or so for the knowledgeable.

Any review of this book would have to start off by mentioning the fact that it is part of Osprey Publishing‚Äôs ‚ÄúRaid‚Äù series. As such it is relatively short, at only 80 pages in length (very roughly a third of which consists of illustrations of one type or another). Hence if one is looking for a tome on the subject this is not it. Instead the book is geared to those seeking more of an executive summary. A second thing that should be mentioned is that there is a great deal of overlap between this book and a previous Osprey book, ‚ÄúFort Eben Emael: The key to Hitler's victory in the West‚Äù. Although that book was in Osprey‚Äôs Fortress series, the bulk covered the raid per se. This reviewer would say that there is, very roughly, an 80% overlap between the books. Hence if one has read the first he would get little out of reading the second. Not to say that there are not differences. There are. For example, the Fortress book mentions that three-quarters of the machine guns on top of the Fortress were inadvertently knocked out by the gliders during their landing. The Raid book cites one or two. The most important difference in the books, in this reviewer‚Äôs opinion, is the depth devoted to the shaped charges that were so important to knocking out Eben Emael‚Äôs guns. The Raid book provides short coverage while the Fortress a much more in-depth discussion, including illustrations that show how the charges work. As stated previously, there are differences between the two books but there is a very large overlap between them.The Raid book, on its own merits, is excellent. There is a very good discussion of how important knocking out the fortress was to the overall German strategy and how it fit into Belgium and France‚Äôs defense plans (these were so important to France that France paid for 80% of the costs of the fortress). From the German perspective there is a very good discussion of the paratroopers, their training (in general and for this particular operation) and how the operation went. The only thing missing, albeit slight, is an illustration and discussion of the gliders themselves. From the Belgian perspective there is a discussion of the physical characteristics of the fort, the garrison (understaffed, not very high on morale) and serious command and control issues between the fort‚Äôs command and Belgian higher command elements. Some of these problems were, to a large degree, responsible for the German‚Äôs ability to take key bridges around the fort intact. The book also includes a discussion of the ancillary paratrooper operations undertaken to capture these bridges (in the Fortress series book there is no such discussion).The author, Chris McNab, concludes that key factors in the German success were excellent training and tactical flexibility, surprise and the shaped charge weapons used to destroy the fort. On the Belgian side one key factor contributing to defeat included the inability of the Belgian high command to foresee the event, despite the fact that paratroopers were used in Norway the Belgian high command know about this. The top of the fortress, where the German gliders landed (and stopped only a few meters from their goals) could have destroyed by placing a few anti-glider obstacles on the fort. Other factors contributing to defeat included poor moral of the garrison, the fact the fort was undermanned, the fact that higher level officials outside the fortress gave orders that required reducing key garrisons positions at the worst possible time (troops that should have been on the top of the fort were instead wasting their time destroying documents in administrative buildings when the landing occurred) and the fact the garrison did not have enough fighting infantry to counter such as landing (as opposed to men to man the fortresses guns, administrative personnel, etc.).  Despite this the Belgian garrison performed quite well considering the circumstances. Nevertheless, after the war, an official military enquiry on the matter blamed the garrison and its commander and, naturally, said nothing of higher level officials who were so responsible for this defeat.All and all an excellent book for anyone interested in investing 2 hours or so of their time.

This book has one theme. That is that the world‚Äôs most powerful nation, the US, has historically and institutionally had the goal of becoming and staying a world hegemon. As evidence he cites the policies of the administration of the US (i.e., President Bush‚Äôs) at the time the book was published along with the history of a variety of neo-con thinkers and intellectuals who have influenced them. He posits that the hegemonic goals of this administration have been, in his view, mainstream in the US. Dr. Chomsky states that Vice-President Cheney‚Äôs 1% policy, whereby any nation that even threatens the US by 1% needs to be acted on in one way or another (i.e., destabilized, attacked, etc.). He also mentions the neo-con‚Äôs views regarding trying to keep any power from arising that may threaten US hegemony economically, militarily or politically (i.e., a policy of permanent hegemony). In addition, Dr. Chomsky makes the claim that the US invasion of Iraq had its roots in US foreign policy, both historically and institutionally.Unfortunately the view that the neo-con‚Äôs and Vice-President‚Äôs 1% policy, permanent ‚Äúhegemony‚Äù and the US‚Äôs invasion of Iraq are not ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù policies held institutionally by governmental institutions such as the Departments of State and Defense, leading thinkers and officials in government, academia and the press, contrary to Dr. Chomsky‚Äôs assertions. These views are only held by a tiny fringe of decision makers and influencers of policy, the neo-cons. This group in no way constitutes US ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù thought in foreign policy. This is clearly evident by the fact that the State and Defense Departments and the intelligence services, as institutions, were opposed to these policies. That is why the Bush administration had to form groups such as Douglas Feith‚Äôs and Paul Wolfowitz‚Äôs Office of Special Plans, to by-pass the conventional intelligence services and their analyses. That is why there were perpetual leaks to the press on Iraq that were intended to undermine that administration‚Äôs arguments in favor of an invasion. Henry Kissinger and John Measheimer works, that oppose the neo-cons views on all these topics are the ‚Äúmainstream‚Äù, not the neo-con‚Äôs. Hence to state that these views have been historically driving US foreign policy and are the institutional ‚Äúnorm‚Äù is ridiculous. This is the biggest problem with this book and its Achilles heel.Not that this is the only problem. There are an infinite myriad of others. For example, he also explicitly claims that many of the world‚Äôs problems such as pollution as poverty, for example, are caused to large degree by this hegemony. The question this view begs is, why? Why would poverty and pollution be much reduced even if there were no single hegemon in the world? Dr. Chomsky, unfortunately, provides no answer. He just asserts it. This is another very serious problem in the book. Many assertions with no attempt to provide an analysis or explanation. For example, he states that the main reason why Eastern European nations supported the US invasion of Iraq (in many cases even sending troops such as was done by Poland and Georgia) as US pressure. Apparently it did not occur to Dr. Chomsky that these nations desperately needed US support in preserving their independence from Russia. The imperialism practiced by the Soviet Union does not enter the formula for their diplomatic actions in Dr. Chomsky‚Äôs world. Nor, for that matter, is there a contradiction in his views that capitalism is the main driving force for imperialism and that nations that did not have capitalist systems (i.e., Soviet Union, China) engaged in some pretty serious imperialist ventures of their own in Eastern Europe and Tibet.Other assertions that Dr. Chomsky makes also are not provided with a logical justification. For example, he blames the US for the crimes committed by Indonesia in East Timor. The Indonesians engaging in these crimes against humanity, naturally, are not to blame. Also unsaid is the fear the Australia and the US of East Timor falling into the Eastern camp. It never occurred to Dr. Chomsky that the West‚Äôs recognition of East Timor coincided with the collapse of the Soviet bloc was more than just a coincidence.Unfortunately this whole book is filled with an almost infinite number of such unfounded assertions. Between these and its inability to support its also unsupportable view that neo-con‚Äôs views have been the standard US world view held by US institutions, policy makers, the press and academics, this book is worse than worthless. Normally this reviewer gives books he has read to the library for others to enjoy or to get something out of. In this case the book is going straight into the garbage can.

This book starts off with a story on the author‚Äôs grandfather, a successful engineer and immigrant from the old country. The author tells the tale of how, many, many years ago an innovator had to not only come up with a successful idea but, more importantly, due to capital requirements stemming from a large number of factors (i.e., high fixed costs involved in manufacturing in particular), had to find a ‚Äúpartner‚Äù in large business who basically relegated the inventor to the sideline. The most a successful innovator, unless he was from a ‚Äúmoneyed‚Äù family or had connections, was to hand over de fact control of his invention to a larger partner. Those with even good ideas could never succeed unless they were able to find such partners.Today, according to the author, things have drastically changed. This is so, in a nutshell, for two reasons. One is that manufacturing technology has advanced to the point, cost wise and in terms of user friendliness, where production runs can be relatively small and yet still be (relatively) cost efficient. There is no longer, as in the past, the required use of very expensive molds, etc. that would make small production runs prohibitively expensive. The author discusses the main tool that enables this, the 3D printer, as well as electronic kit components. He spends quite a bit of time discussing this technology (for example the large variety of 3d printers and how they work and with what they work [plastic, wood, metal, etc.]). For the engineer working in the field or even the enthusiast this is not very enlightening. However, for the layman who is interested (either in terms of just curiosity or considering actually bringing a project to life), this would be very enlightening.The author then goes on to discuss the business model that can best be used, in his opinion, to bring to market an idea that requires manufacturing and/ electronic components and know-how. That model is the ‚Äúopen source‚Äù model. The author describes the many benefits of this model. This includes (not all inclusively) free labor and ideas provided by potential or actual users, the creation of ‚Äúword of mouth‚Äù marketing, testing the size of the market to see if it is large enough to justify entry, etc. All of this is interesting. However, there are problems with that the open source model has that the author leaves unsaid. I do not know if this is willful or whether he just believes that some of these potential problems are not at all significant. A major one is that the use of volunteers, as opposed to employees, insures that people are supplying the needed know how throughout the entire product development and manufacturing phase. After all, employees need to work to be paid. Volunteers, on the other hand, can just leave or stop in an instant. In many cases without a seconds notice. Anyone who has worked in volunteer organizations knows this. In the author‚Äôs model this is even more of a problem as the volunteers are linked via the internet and do not even know each other. This puts a significant dent on projects that have development phases that are more than very short periods of time. A big problem, even if the author does not mention it.The author also discusses financing. He again emphasizes internet based ‚Äúopen source‚Äù as opposed to more traditional ‚Äúangel‚Äù investors (whose use would imply capital dilution) or bank financing that would require capital being tied up as collateral and interest payments. However, the author does not point out how difficult it is to use Kickstarter and similar internet sources to raise capital. They are not the panacea he makes them out to be.The author then provides 3 case studies that show how effectively the open source manufacturing and financing model can be used to help start up entrepreneurs. All show how successful the model has been. Unfortunately no statistics are provided regarding the percentage of entrepreneurs for which this road has been successful (as opposed to failing them or the use of more traditional methods such as partnering with large companies or ‚Äúangel‚Äù investors).In short, the book has plenty of weaknesses. However, it also has plenty of strengths, especially in regard to small entrepreneurs interested in bringing their idea to market. For this reason alone it is worth reading by such people or even by those with just a passing curiosity.

Any review of this book needs to start off by stressing the fact that this book is really geared to the specialist. This is defined as either that group very knowledgeable on the minitua of German armoured tactics or those with actual military experience in the field (i.e., armour operations), even if on the modern battlefield as opposed to that of the Second World War. It also needs to be stressed, as if the subtitle of the book ‚ÄúGerman Small ‚Äì Unit Armour Tactics in WW 2‚Äù is not enough of a give-away, that the book emphasizes tactics and other factors (i.e., training, maintenance) at individual tank level, platoon level and the platoon - compny nexus. The book is definitely not geared to high level tactics and strategy (basically any activity over and above the battalion level).The books covers small scale operations on a very thorough level. It has chapters on: offensive operations, defensive operations, unit/march maneuvers (both in rear areas and combat areas), reconnaissance, command and control, logistics and maintenance, combined arms and operations (emphasizing front line cooperation with infantry, engineers, artillery and air support), life in a tank, training and a chapter contrasting tank tactics then and now (this last one is too brief).Each topic is covered in an extremely technical manner and just about every detail, no matter how minute, is covered in very great detail. For example, complete lists are provided for how communications should be sent from tank to tank (in a platoon environment), platoon to company, etc. These include content of communications as well as the order that content should be transmitted. It is that detailed of the book. Considering that it has been written by a current German officer this is no surprise. Hence it would be of interest to primarily the specialist as opposed to the layman. The specialist will find it a gold mine and for those currently (or recently serving in armoured vehicles) one sees how little things have really changed, to a very large degree, in 60 years.Despite these weaknesses, the book does have a few weaknesses that need to be pointed out. They are as follows:a) The translation is rough. As a result, many times, the reader needs to reread passages 2 or 3 times to understand what the author is attempting to convey. This is not surprising considering the author‚Äôs native language is German and not English. A translator should have been hired to, at the very least, fine tune the text.b) There are many maps, diagrams, etc. but all are in German. In addition many leave much to be desired in terms of quality. The book should have hired illustrators to draw high quality maps/illustrations to show what many of the poor quality maps/illustrations cannot clearly show. Apparently the budget was so limited none could be hired. The use of original training materials, etc. is a very nice touch to the book but many times something that was better drawn would have much better assisted the author in conveying his views.c) A few stories from actual troops to illustrate the tactics stressed in the book would have been nice to have included.d) Some technical specifications on tanks and how and why the physical characteristics of the vehicles changed over the course of the war would have been nice too.Despite these relatively minor problems, that can be easily overlooked, this is all and all a book that is very highly recommended for its niche intended audience.

The below is a review of the unabridged cd (not audible) version of this bookSedera's last few books have left much to be desired. The main reason for this is that he has transgressed from his normally witty, humorous, sarcastic and pathos filled stories in a variety of ways. In his ‚ÄúSquirrel Seeks Chipmunk: A Modest Bestiary‚Äù, for example, he attempted to be scatalogical and crude. Unfortunately it did not work. Comedians like George Carlin and Richard Prior were able to pull this off. Unfortunately Sederis cannot. Not a surprise considering that his humor is not, at its core, of that nature.In this new book Sedaris goes back to his early books such as ‚ÄúHolidays on Ice‚Äù, ‚ÄúNaked‚Äù and ‚ÄúSquirrel Seeks Chipmunk: A Modest Bestiary‚Äù and back to, in essence, what made his humor unique. Finally he returns, once again, to his original witty, ironic and, most importantly, pathos filled roots. Hopefully he will continue on this course in the future.The CD audiobook is very well read by Sedaris himself. His reading captures his irony, wit and sarcasm very very well. This has typically been the case with all of his previous audiobooks, even the mediocre. Hence this reviewer highly recommends the audiobook instead of written version of this work. The audiobook captures Sedaris in his purest form.

The below is a review of the unabridged cd (not audible) version of this workThe first place to start in any review of this book is to stress that it not a novelized version of this historical work. Instead it is a poetic version. Hence for those not inclined to poetry it is not the version to purchase. Those appreciating poetry, instead, would find it very engrossing. The story also assumes, as it did of its audience millennia ago, that it be knowledgeable regarding ancient roman mythology and history. Without this knowledge the listener (or reader) would not understand the nuances, allegory, context and meaning of this story to the Romans (or at all for that matter).Hence, in short, this book is geared towards and would most be appreciated (and very appreciated at that) by those who BOTH love poetry and are very familiar with Greco-Roman mythology and roman history.Last but not least a few words about the audio version of this work per se. The reader of the book does an excellent job both in terms of the dramatic and poetic nuances. This reviewer has read many audio books and can say, unequivacly that it is in the top 5% of what he has listened to. For this reason this reviewer highly recommends the cd audio version of this book as opposed to the written version. The audio version, as opposed to the written version is also more in line with what Virgil had in mind. Readers should remember that this work, like Homer‚Äôs, was intended to be presented in oral form, usually over a campfire, as opposed to read.

Many years ago James Dunnigan, a military analyst, published a book entitled ‚ÄúHow to Make War‚Äù.  The first edition was published in 1982 and the last in 2003. The book was intended as an introduction to land, air, sea, nuclear and chemical warfare and logistics for laymen. It provided a very good overview of weapon system and comparative national strengths in these areas. The book was intended as a high level introduction hence there was little discussion of these weapon systems from the perspective of individual users. This was the greatest weakness of the book in this reviewer‚Äôs opinion. Nevertheless, this reviewer still highly recommends the book, as the introduction it is intended to be, for a lay audience.Tools of Violence is, basically, a compliment to this book (that is also geared to a lay audience). It is a compliment in that it covers the gap that Mr. Dunnigam‚Äôs book does not cover, the direct face-to-face impact of these weapons both on those on the receiving end as well as the users. The book provides a ‚Äúhuman‚Äù face to the weapons systems discussed by Mr. Dunnigam. In addition, it provides an update to how the weapons systems have evolved since the last edition of ‚ÄúHow to Make War‚Äù. The book provides a discussion of not only the newer aspects of the same weapons systems but also developments in new directions in weapons (i.e., electronic high velocity beam weapons) that were not even imagined when the latest edition of Mr. Dunnigam‚Äôs book was published. ‚ÄúTools of Violence‚Äù does all of this very well and in a manner geared to layman. Hence for this audience this book is highly recommended.The book does have a few weaknesses that prevent this reviewer from giving it a 5 star rating however. One is that it does not provide an analysis or discussion of relative national strengths in the fields of air, sea and land warfare as Mr. Dunnigam‚Äôs book does. There are very few illustration of the weapons themselves or maps or other illustrations showing doctrinal use in the field. The book is primarily geared to land warfare. Even the emphasis on sea and air warfare is primarily from the perspective of ground support as opposed to, for example, air superiority. This is not a surprise as both of the book‚Äôs authors have had extensive field in that arena as opposed to the air or sea.  The book also does not provide historical perspective on how these weapon systems have developed, over and above the very recent past (in nearly all cases).Lastly the book does not cover, in enough detail, the ridiculous exponential cost escalation over the years in these weapons systems. As defense ministers in the most advanced nations have stated, they would not be surprised that in a few years if the entire budgets of air forces, for example, are spent on a single squadron. In addition, the implications of exponential costs are not examined or analyzed with respect to R&D and the development of future weapons systems. In the past there have been multiple variations of hardware developed to the prototype stage (i.e., 3 or so types of fighter superiority aircraft in the US) before a final version has been selected. This has mitigated against the failure of the development of any one particular system. Due to escalating cost this will probably not be possible in the future, hence there will be a far greater risk of not developing successful platforms (with serious national security implications). This may also result in next generation systems that are not significantly more advanced than previous generations, in an attempt to reduce this risk. None of these very serious implications are even mentioned in this book.Nevertheless, despite the above mentioned problems, this book is still highly recommended as an introduction, geared to laymen, on modern warfare. Four stars.

Artillery played a key role during the First World War. Few would dispute this. Yet there are very few books that have focused on artillery, per se, during the war. This is clearly evident by the fact that even in the 20 or so page bibliography of this book, just concentrating on artillery during that period, there are barely any books focusing exclusively on it. Hence this books fills a significant gap in the literature. The book also does this quite well.The book is arranged in chronological order, with each section of the book being dedicated to a year of the war. The reader sees how doctrine and technology, at least in Germany, Britain and France, advanced (other nations are barely mentioned). The reader sees why the advances that were made were made. In Britain, the most advanced nation in terms of artillery doctrine, technology and use, the reader learns that organizational flexibility and cooperation between and within civilian and military parties was crucial and key. In addition, there were institutional factors that assisted in the diffusion of both doctrine and knowledge (i.e., the British high command regularly published guides incorporating the latest advances, for example). In Germany these were lacking. In that nation tactical front line experience was the driving force. Unfortunately, for the Germans, there was little institutional dissemination of doctrine and knowledge. Hence advancements were kept isolated in the units that developed them and in the men who developed them. There was also little of the military-civilian cooperation that so assisted the British in the development of their cutting advances technologies, particularly in the fields of ranging for counter battery fire. Man power losses also played a major role in the use and development of artillery. As the major powers were running short of men they sought to use artillery as a substitute, as much as possible, for manpower.Even with all the doctrinal and technological advances made in artillery warfare, however, losses were still significant. Even towards the end of the war, where Allied artillery proved far superior to German (including both superior allied firepower that could be brought on the German front line and counter battery fire), it was still normal, in contested battles, for allied casualties to amount to about 40% of attacking force‚Äôs initial strength. Hence blood was still an important ingredient in victory.Despite this very good analysis, the book still suffers from some problems. They are as follows:a) There is practically no discussion of artillery warfare outside the Western front‚Äôs trench environment. There is little discussion of artillery use on the Russian and Italian front and practically none on Ottoman fronts and areas Austria-Hungary fought in outside of the Russian and Italian fronts (i.e., Serbia). This is a major weakness.b) A second major weakness is that there is practically no discussion of the nexus between gas and artillery. For those interested in filling this gap this reviewer highly recommends Osprey publishing‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorld War I Gas Warfare Tactics and Equipment‚Äù. Despite the fact this book covers gas warfare in general (as opposed to just artillery delivery methods) and is very short (only 64 pages), it does an excellent job in filling the gap that ‚ÄúArtillery in the Great War‚Äù leaves.c) A third major weakness is that there is not enough discussion and analysis regarding the very important issue (as even the authors the book imply) of industrial production. This is clear by the fact there is not a single table in the entire book on artillery or shell production. There should have been a stand-alone chapter on this topic or, at the very least, the equivalent in terms of text in the book.d) The book is also weak on discussing observation techniques. As a supplement this reviewer highly recommends Osprey publishing‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorld War 1 Battlefield Artillery Tactics‚Äù. This book, like the previous Osprey book on gas mentioned above, is very short but nevertheless fills this gap (as well as others in this book).e) The book has very few maps. In addition, with respect to the very few maps there are there is little integration between text and the maps. Hence an opportunity to illustrate doctrine and use topologically is missed.f) One last weakness, albeit minor, is there are few illustrations. Some illustrations would have proved worth a thousand words in illustrating the concepts of creeping and box barrages as well as illustrating many other points in the book. For example an illustration on creeping barrages would have clearly illustrated why poor quality control in ammunition production early in the war prevented this tactic from being widely used at that period. Some photographs on the major and commonly used artillery pieces would have been nice too. The previously mentioned Osprey book ‚ÄúWorld War 1 Battlefield Artillery Tactics‚Äù does an excellent job at filling this gap.Despite the above mentioned weaknesses this book still very highly recommendable. For those seeking to fill the gaps mentioned above (a through f), this reviewer recommends the previously mentioned Osprey books ‚ÄúWorld War 1 Battlefield Artillery Tactics‚Äù and ‚ÄúWorld War I Gas Warfare Tactics and Equipment‚Äù. Despite their brevity and the fact that they too, like ‚ÄúArtillery in the Great War‚Äù, are too highly focused on the Western Front‚Äôs trench environment (with very little discussion on their topics outside this) they fill the gaps of this book well.
