Old Earth touches upon arguments between science and religion in developing the story and provides what is a fascinating exploration for an alternative theory of the history of our planet.  The term mesmerizing is quite applicable to the book as wr  ell as the concept of thought provoking.

Tom Bettany was formerly an agent for MI5 but walked away from the job several years ago. He supports himself by doing low level jobs just to earn enough to eat and have a place to sleep.  The book opens as Tom receives a voice mail from a woman that he doesn't know advising him that his son Liam has been killed in a fall from the balcony of his apartment.  Apparently Liam was smoking dope and lost control, falling off the balcony.  Tom leaves his job at a meat packing plant in France and returns to England where he is from to try and find out what really happened to his son.  He meets with mob bosses, the head of MI5 and encounters not just the reasons for his son's death, but a much wider plot.  Tom uses all of the tradecraft he learned as an agent to get to the bottom of what really happened to Liam.  "Nobody Walks" is an action novel, moving quickly from one point to another.  Herron brings the reader rapidly into the who what why and where of the plot and keeps him there.  It is a book that is to probably read in a few evenings and enjoy the action.  The characters are not fleshed out as one might hope for since they populate a very different segment of society that most of us are accustomed to, but this does not detract from what is a very readable book.  Well done, and quite enjoyable

Possibly the final book about the individual nicknamed The Condor beginning with the 1974 novel "Three Days of the Condor."  That book was made into a motion picture starring Robert Redford and concerned a man that worked for the CIA reading books looking for illegal codes or information that should not be in print.Condor is still working reading books when his employers name him as a traitor for releasing information to the enemy and order his death.  Condor runs evading the hit men hunting him.  On his path to escape the unjust fate that condemns him he allies himself with several people.  First, is a woman, young enough to be his daughter who is a CIA agent and who helps him due to not believing that he is guilty of any crime, than a lady who he admired but never approached.  Merle, the second lady is dragged into the action when her apartment is taken over by Condor and the young agent to hide in.  Finally involved is the man that is supervising the hunt.  As with the other books involving Condor action is super fast and carries the reader along at breakneck speed.  Grady introduces a factor at the ending which while not absolutely necessary for the story makes for another insight into the world of spycraft.  The author has allowed Condor to age and show infirmities and disabilities associated with the period of life he is depicted as being in.  This factor makes for a more realistic approach to the descriptions and reactions of the Condor.  A good read and one that will keep the reader moving along with the action and conditions described.

Dutch Shaw is a former soldier that had seen action as part of a special operations command direct action team. This hard hitting novel tells it like it is when soldiers are deployed into a war zone. They experience moments of calm in which there is horse play, kidding around and the comadre of men at war. Then they are ordered into action against an enemy that has experienced fighting for centuries against assorted enemies. Wives and children of the enemy are just as suspect as the men that enjoy a seemingly peaceful life while waiting to go into action. Ritchell describes several sorties against a poorly defined enemy. Children are part of the forces arrayed against these special forces, and are killed as self protection. Women are just as much the foe as the male guerrillas that exist to kill the Americans as invaders of their country. Dutch Shaw is a team leader in one of these groups and goes into action burdened by the recent loss of his grandmother who actually raised him and was his only living relative. Ritchell makes us privy to Shaw's thoughts and reactions while on station. We see the wounds and death of his own men, plus the pictures of an enemy that has no behind the lines mentality. The Knife is one of the most hard hitting novels of men in a different kind of war. The action and thoughts of the combatants enter the mind of the reader and allow him or her to see the reality of what is the lot of men involved in guerrilla action with no heroics and no apparent victory or defeat. A different literary adventure, and an eye opener.

Michael Sears worked on Wall Street for 20 years and  is therefore more than qualified to bring us a novel involving white collar crime in the financial world.  His main protagonist, Jason Stafford, has appeared in two previous thrillers and is presented as a person with flaws but very well equipped to work on problems associated with the complex world of high finance.  Jason served two years in prison for insider trading while working for a Wall Street firm. Now, not able to return to his trade, he is dedicating himself to helping others  who find themselves involved with problems within his previous field.  Stafford is a complex individual fleshed out very well by Sears.  He is a single father raising an autistic son and involved with a woman he is falling in love with while attempting to rebuild a life changed radically by prison time.  Philip Haley, an engineer whose company is close to developing a biofuel breakthrough, has been indicted for insider trading based on the projected increased value to be derived by the development.  He asks Jason to help him prove his innocence and convinces him that the accusation is false. Stafford does take the case and finds himself involved not only with a white collar criminal accusation, but with murder and hitmen attempting to do so.  Sears is extremely good at fleshing out his characters and allowing the reader to see them as human beings that are real and react  to situations as most normal people would.  He holds the reader's attention by building towards a logical climax. The one flaw that I noticed is the use of overlong descriptions of various details which are extraneous to the plot and not essential in moving the action forward.  While the novel has an overage of these details they should not cause the reader to lose interest in the action.  An interesting and basically well written book, excellent characterizations, and one that delves into a world that most of us know little about but with descriptions that do allow the reader to understand what is involved.

Pierre Boulle noted author of books like "The Bridge on the River Kwai" and "Planet of the Apes" passed away in 1994.  Among his other works is a dystopian science fiction novel of a world controlled by pure scientists retranslated and published again.  Boulle postulates scientists from all over the world getting together and deciding that all the problems that exist on earth are due to leaders who do not understand what they are doing. That they are men and women with no grounding in science and lack the perspective of what people really need.  The physical scientists propose that they take over all governments on earth and have the current leaders step down and just enjoy life without the stress of governing.  Said and done, the scientists quickly choose a  president by a method of formal testing, along with advisers and other officers.  All governments are disbanded and countries are consolidated into a world wide organization.  The scientists begin working on eradicating the pressures of disease, strife and conflict quickly allowing all mankind to work less and have more.  The required workday is cut to about 2 hours with plenty of time for recreation and rest.  The new leaders, the physical scientists, believe that they have achieved the optimum conditions for all the planet's inhabitants and everyone is happy with the new status quo.  In a short time it is noted that the rate of suicides has gone up and it is quickly determined that these are due to the lack of challenges for the people.  The scientists decide that they will provide games to entertain similar to those held in the ancient world.  Namely fights to the death between trained individuals.  This works for a short time until the rate of suicides again climbs.  The answer, of course is to increase the participation and number of fatalities in the games.  Continuing on to staging great battles based on real incidents  fought throughout history.  Namely massive assaults such as the D-Day invasion of Normandy and the world war I battle of the Marne.  While the tone of the book is tongue in cheek and has some similarities to "Animal Farm" it can also be taken as a serious condemnation of allowing any group to achieve absolute power without normal checks and balances on it.  It was true while Boulle was alive, and just as true today where philosophies of one group are forced on others causing strife and war.  If the book had received more publicity at the time Boulle wrote it it has the potential to be part of works like "1984" and "Animal Farm" and taken it's place as a classic example of power run amok.

The Chinese Government is always anxious to come first with an original idea to lord it over the U.S.  Mr Reilly sets up a very unique scenario that depicts a wonder the Chinese have labored over for 40 years.  It is an immense, highly original zoo featuring creatures that trace their origin back through time and are depicted in the legends of many peoples throughout the world.  In an afterward Matthew Reilly indicates that he was fascinated by Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park. There is a similarity to that book, but we are not dealing with dinosaurs by any means.  The Great Zoo is quite original and the rapid fire action that it is replete with is peculiar to this book.  A group of VIPs and Journalists from the U.S. are invited to tour the Zoo in order to set up publicity to attract tourists.  Among the group is Dr Cassandra Jane "C.J" Cameron and her younger brother.  C.J. is a writer for National Geographic as well as an expert on reptiles.  The visitors are assured that they will be struck with wonder at the collection housed by the zoo and brought in to see it with a lavish care and luxurious accommodations befitting the group of  VIPs. Safety measures are described as the latest technology available to control a population that is free to roam loose in the huge area available to them.  Things, of course, run out of control during the VIP visit with mayhem and violence let loose on the staff of the Zoo, as well as the VIP visitors.  In these descriptions Matthew Reilly proves to be a master of setting up a plot that is filled with constant and violent action.  The reader is pulled along from one crisis to another.  And the admonition that the book can't be put down is as true as can be.  The center of the action is C.J. who goes from place to place and scene to scene coming up with instant answers to the problems arising for the group trying to escape the dangers of the zoo. The ending comes with a sigh of relief for a reader caught up in the action.  The book is well written, original in it's depictions and the plot brings us into an ending which is logical and satisfying.  A sequel could be developed, but the current book is a great stand alone as is.

What would cause a man to escape from prison one day before he is to be released?  A perplexing question seeing that if caught escaping he faces another 20-25 years behind bars.  Audie Palmer does just that.  After 10 years in jail, subject to constant physical and mental harassment, and without telling anyone Audie escapes.  He was imprisoned after being caught at a holdup of an armored car carrying seven million dollars in which four people were killed.  He pleaded guilty to participation in the crime and a plea bargain sent him away for the 10 years.  During the robbery he was shot in the head by police arriving at the scene but survived after months in the hospital.  Michael Robotham in a mesmerizing novel answers the questions posed and treats his readers to an excellent read.  The seven million dollars stolen from the armored car never reappeared and Audie is suspected of knowing where it is.  Moreover, the cash is old bills, unmarked and destined for destruction by the authorities as a normal activity to keep the money supply clean. This means that it is easily spendable and untraceable. The armored car company has a contract to collect these bills from several banks at set periods and transport them to the site where they will be burned.  Robotham fleshes out the characters involved in his book quite well.  Audie is a complex individual with a very high I.Q. who thinks things out and does not act rashly.  We meet the authorities chasing him and learn to understand their motives in what is happening.  This is definitely a book to finish in one sitting in order to satisfy the interest in what is really happening.  Easily a five star novel and one that, if the reader has not read a book by Michael Robotham yet,  will make sure that his future writings are anticipated and obtained.

Eve Hardaway, mother of one, and just deserted by her husband decides to take the trip of a lifetime leaving her child at home.  She goes to the jungle in Oaxaca in the southern part of Mexico to enjoy rafting and hiking in company of a few other tourists. They are staying  at a small resort run by a Mexican couple.  She is immediately flung into the adventure of her life when she spots a man living alone in the Jungle near the resort area.  While peering at him, she finds a camera, picks it up and takes it with her back to her group.  She also finds a prescription bottle with the name Teresa Hamilton on it.  From this chance sighting and the picking up of Hamilton's property Hurwitz accelerates the pace of the book to breakneck speed.  The man she sighted does not want to be seen by anyway and begins a campaign against Eve's group involving murder and terror.  A sudden violent storm wipes out all roads and in effect closes down the area leaving Eve and her group at the mercy of a dangerous predator who proves that he will stop at nothing to keep his presence there a secret.  The group realizes that he has already killed Teresa Hamilton and they are at his mercy with no way out or any means to call for help due to the damage caused by the storm.  The book leads the reader through a maze of secrets and terror.  A definite all nighter with answers seeming to elude everyone and leading to mayhem and all powering fear.  Who is the man living there?  What does he want to do?  Questions that Hurwitz answers logically while keeping the reader glued to the book.  Good book, great plot, well fleshed out characters and Greg Hurwitz continues his record of engrossing fiction.

Thayer has written several other books featuring his detective Armond diPino who operates in New York.  This novel opens with DiPino working in a relative's store in San Francisco in order to fully recover from a gunshot wound received in another book.  Why in San Francisco and working in a relative's store is beyond me but there he is.  He has relatives conveniently living in Frisco and gets involved in helping them out of a criminal conspiracy involving human trafficking.  Along the way he meets several women including Emily an ex love who is filthy rich and involved with the family in the plot.  Perhaps if I had read the other DiPino books I might have a better understanding of what is going on in this one.  But I didn't and won't.  This novel is helter skelter and leaves the reader pretty confused with what is going on.  Especially when DiPino's partner from New York appears in California to help out.  Wonder if his supervisors know that he is not in New York during these trips. Does he magically have jurisdiction in San Francisco?

Linwood Barclay consistently delivers excellent reads featuring ordinary people caught up in extraordinary circumstances. No Safe House is not an exception.  The reader is caught up immediately by the rapid opening of events based on murders of seven years before the opening of the story.  Terry and Cynthia Archer were saved from death by a man who is a known killer in his own right and live with the memory.  Cynthia pursued by her demons of the past moves out of her home leaving Terry and their daughter together.  Grace, the teenage daughter, is rebellious fighting the overbearing supervision of both her parents based on the horrendous events of the past.  She gets mixed up with a boy who has criminal tendencies.  The young man convinces Grace to accompany him on a break in of a home in order to take out a luxury car for a joy ride. Things immediately go wrong and the boy is shot to death by someone else entering the house at the same time as they do.With this set of events occurring the Archers find themselves mixed up in a wider and wider conspiracy involving several distinct groups, all apparently trying to find certain valuables in different houses.  The ending is typical Barclay, logical and bringing together all events in a satisfying conclusion.  But wait, there is an unexpected development at the very end which ties together several loose ends which were not very apparent prior to bringing this out.  Well done, another all nighter by a master, and the only question is when will we get another one from Mr Barclay..

Daniel Trent and his fiancee are partners in the unusual business of guiding families of kidnapped victims in dealing with the kidnappers.  They have the expertise to help the families understand what the kidnappers really want, and what amount of money they will accept to return the victim unharmed.The action of this very fast and taut novel is set in Marseille France.  Aimee, Daniel's fiancee has just advised him that she is pregnant when she mysteriously disappears.  Daniel knows that she has been in contact with Jerome Moreau,a wealthy potential customer for their services to sell him a policy to protect him and pay a certain amount if he is kidnapped.  Daniel proceeds to follow Jerome to find out where his fiancee is when he becomes a witness to Jerome's kidnapping as he is driving to his home with his wife.  Daniel contacts the wife indicating that he knows about the kidnap policy and is obligated to help them recover Jerome.  Events move rapidly as clue after clue  to Jerome's location surface with no success.  Ewan is a master at keeping the reader up all night biting his or her nails while devouring the book.  The ending could set up a situation allowing a followup book to appear, and if so I would expect anyone reading this to grab it and get into it immediately.

Carcaterra  comes up with a unique novel  very out of the ordinary. It sets up a war between worldwide organized crime and terrorists. Vincent Marelli, known as the Wolf, is the leader of a huge crime family who in spite of his best plans to protect  his family sees his wife and two girls killed.  Besides himself with the loss he decides to exact a terrible vengeance on the people that killed them.  He places the blame on terrorists, and selects one active band to start his campaign on. His way is to convince other crime families around the world to help him indicating that besides  exacting his revenge these people are in the business of murder for murder's sake and infringing upon organizedcrime's territories.  Vincent finds that his closest ally is run by a former lover of his that has taken over her father's gang in Italy.  In the course of the action they move close together and except for the fact that neither really trusts the other move towards their goal.Leaders of both the terrorists and the members of the crime families are very well fleshed out and the reader comes to understand why theydo what they do, and what motivates them in addition to the huge amounts of money they make.  Vincent and Angela, his ex love, movecloser to a reconciliation which may occur if another novel with them involved is written.  The descriptions of the terrorists and the crime family draw a similarity to the Godfather and the sympathy the reader attains with them.  Well done and very absorbing .

I recently read the second book in this series and was fascinated by the theme, the descriptions and the plot.  I, therefore, accepted this book from the publisher and was as fascinated as with the other.  The theme is actually one that should be labeled Science Fiction which it incorporates very well with logical action and motives.  The opening depicts a young Mayan girl living in what is now Belize about 1100 years ago coming upon a cache within a tree when fleeing a Jaguar hunting her.  She climbs the tree finding a control panel which in desperation she operates and enters a passage which opens into a chamber containing marvels unknown to the world.  She uses the tools found that she masters and becomes a priestess to her people, and sets up a diary of her actions and discoveries.  Shifting to present day, the diary is translated and gives enough information to direct a team of UN investigators to go to the area and attempt to open the chamber.  The problems encountered by the team consisting of Mary Ellen Rollins and Dr John Morgan are logical and don't depend on any super human abilities of the two.  They find a way into the chamber discovering marvels placed there by aliens that visited the earth about 180,000 years ago.  Interludes in the story indicate that these aliens are still monitoring our planet, and it is unclear if they are benevolent or enemies.  Representatives from China become aware of the tree and the material within it.  They decide that they must be the ones to acquire it, and attempt to steal it using advanced cloaking technology and weapons.  The book is engrossing, a fast read and is notable in that it uses "normal" situations stretched only with materials that are currently being developed in the world as well as the devices left by the aliens.  I will, certainly read the other books in the series, and recommend this as an interesting and well written book.

Buckell was raised in the Caribbean before he returned to the U.S.  His novel provides an insight into the politics and problems of the islands that are currently mainly tourist areas.  It is set a little into the future and brings the islands into a setting that has made them economically much different than they are today.  They have improved their infrastructures due to the finding and selling of large oil deposits in their offshore waters.  Most important, an agency termed the Caribbean Intelligence Agency was formed by a consortium of the islands' governments, trained by the CIA and British MI6.  It consists of highly trained and capable agents fighting the enemies of the Caribbean.  Prudence (Roo) Jones was an agent of the Caribbean group until he built himself a personal fortune,retired and decided to dedicate his life to beach combing and traveling on his boat.  Events that occurred prior to this novel's opening made him the caretaker for his orphaned teenaged nephew.  He is immersed in making sure that the boy goes to school and takes an interest in making sure that his nephew grows up to be a good citizen and adult.  A message is received from a former colleague marked "You will get this if I am dead"  Roo had worked with that man while both were agents of the Caribbean Intelligence Agency and were firm friends.  Roo goes after the package indicated in the message in the interest of following through on their friendship.  Shortly after the message arrives a beautiful young lady knocks on his door announcing that she is his  deceased friend's sister.  While Roo knew that there was no sister he goes along with her to try and determine what she is after.  Buckell creates an atmosphere of constant action both with bad guys coming out, and several hurricanes starting up in a Caribbean whose weather patterns have greatly changed.  The book retains the reader's undivided attention and is definitely an all nighter as the various blanks are filled in including the young lady's intentions and definitely setting up the next book in this series.  Excellent read.

Thorp, the author of Nothing Lasts Forever, which was made into the movie "Die Hard" gives us a short novel filled with excitement and the fast moving action of the other book. Sam Merrill, a young Coast Guard Lt Commander comes upon a ghost yacht filled with a fortune in gold, money, and contraband and becomes a national hero for his find. As a reward for the discovery the US government sends him and his wife Amy on an all expense paid trip to the Bahamas. Enjoying themselves and their 15 minutes of fame, Sam and Amy become turned on their heads when out of the blue, they are attacked by terrorists who succeed in kidnapping Amy. From a dream situation Sam finds himself in the nightmare of finding and rescuing his wife. The reasons for the attack on them while on vacation become apparent when his search takes him to Cartagena Columbia and into the lair of an international drug ring. Action follows action as the reader is catapulted into the nightmare with the Merrills and caught up in a rapidly moving stay up all night book with back and forth action and reaction between all sides. A definite must read and one which again stamps Thorp as a writer to welcome again and again as his books come out.

A continuation of Sakey's novel "Brilliance" in which we learned that beginning about 1980 approximately 1% of the population was born with gifts formerly only dreamed of.  Some were very high level geniuses, some could sense the inner most thoughts of people they came in contact with, move around virtually unseen or make fortunes predicting the movements of the stock market.  There arose a divide between the "Brilliants" as they were termed and the remainder of the populationdeepening over  the 30  years that followed.  Present day and the opening of this book finds a terrorist organization composed of Brilliants launching attacks against the normal population crippling three cities by preventing communications, deliveries of goods to stores, no answers to 911 calls for help and fanatics among the group actually burning people alive.  Nick Cooper, introduced in "Brilliance" is a Brilliant, working for the U.S. government, opposed to the people launching war against the normals volunteers to help the president combat the revolutionaries.  He works against them as the country moves inexorably towards civil war with the revolutionaries determined to change the status quo even if it means destruction and devastation of the nation.  The ending abruptly sets up a third book in the series and like book one leaves the reader either awaiting the next book or uninterested in continuing.  Sakey is a master writer and the middle part of "A Better World" is well executed, but leaving the reader trying to put pieces together.  Well written, but spoiled by abrupt beginning and ending which brings the expectation that the whole would be better if written as one long novel.

This is the third book by Shaara about the Civil War in the west.  I feel that it is the best so far, reading almost like a novel rather than a dry history of battles fought by people long ago.  Shaara has come up with descriptions of factual events that he imparts interpretations to making them come alive to the reader. The Union army of the Cumberland under the command of William Rosecrans captures the rail hub at Chattanooga.  Pursuing the fleeing Confederates Rosecrans loses control and is beaten at Chickamauga Creek causing him to retreat back to to Chattanooga.  The Confederate commander Braxton Bragg is confident of destroying the Union forces but is shown as a major  cause of dissension among his subordinate officers.  Abraham Lincoln has become disgusted with Rosecrans and removes him from command appointing Ulysses S  Grant to become the officer in charge of the entire Union army.  Grant, in turn, puts General George Thomas in charge of the forces at Chattanooga, and orders troops commanded by William Sherman and Joseph Hooker to meet up  with the army at Chattanooga creating a huge force poised against the Confederates.  Backed by historians studying the period Shaara describes Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederacy as a man devoid of ability to properly evaluate the people reporting to him and one of the possible causes of the south losing the war.  For example there is documentation of officers under Bragg writing to Davis requesting change in the position of the General commanding; that is Braxton Bragg due to his inability to plan proper military operations. Davis does not listen and leaves Bragg in command setting the stage for a northern victory at Chattanooga.  The descriptions of the battles fought is, as always, done very well by Shaara.  Men are sent to fight often by leaders who are not knowledgeable of what is going on and are the cause of death and suffering of those forced to follow their orders.  The descriptions of conditions of the battlefields speak of a lot of research in journals and newspaper reporting of the period being described.  The next book in this series, which might be of Sherman's march through Georgia and to Atlanta is set up very well by the author and creates interest in that project.

Plenty of room for my dogs food and water bowl and it has a lip all the way around that helps to trap all the water drops from spilling onto the floor.Very durable. grips the floor and helps bowls stay in place (my dogs used to slide bowls all over the floor)I'm so happy to have this food mat, great product.I received this product with a promotional discount, and my reviews are always my own and honest, regardless of the price I paid.

I took one before bed and noticed that I felt much better the next morning. I have chemical depression but refuse to take big pharmasudical drugs for personal reasons. This is a wonderful natural alternative for mood enhancement.dose is just one capsule.**I received this product with a promotional discount, and my reviews are always my own and honest, regardless of the price I paid.

It took me over 2 and a half hours to install this mount, it's extremely heavy and I constantly wonder if my wall is going to give out (I really hope not). I REALLY wish it wasn't so stiff. it doesn't more freely as I'd hoped instead I often find myself going behind the tv to apply as much force as I can to get the arms to open back to a position where they can lay flat then have to push on the sides of the TV so hard I feel like I'm going to break it and hear it cracking.I have a 60 inch TV. So I had to use all the extra bracket pieces.Directions are not the greatest, I ended up watching online videos and learning things that were not displayed in the written directions.Now that I have it installed, I'm happy my TV is mounded I just truly wish I had selected another mount.No I don't think I'd recommend this mount for a 60 inch TV

This is exactly what I was looking for a pillow case that was tough enough to stand up to the constant abuse that is having three children and three dogs. Everyone loves cuddling the pillow on the couch with is so it's not too rough, the saying "love you more" is great because it's something we say at home often.the zipper is small and hidden, I'm very satisfied with this throw pillow case.

I have very picky dogs and I was please to find a probiotic that they finally don't stick their noses up at.They eat them with joy and that makes me pleased. I noticed much less  gas in my 40 lb Shepard mix.I'm very pleased with this product and so are my dogs.*I received this product with a promotional discount, and my reviews are always my own and honest, regardless of the price I paid.

They really are not kidding when they say premium.This is by far the nicest back seat organizer I've ever purchased.It's luxuriously thick so it also helps pad the back seat for feeling my toddlers kicks.The pockets are self sustaining, meaning they are so sturdy they hold their cup shape even empty.There are many zippered packets that have large openings.I honestly can't say anything bad about this car organizer, I love it.*I received this product with a promotional discount, and my reviews are always my own and honest, regardless of the price I paid.

I like the LED option because it reminds me that the diffuser is turned on, which keeps me from leaving the diffuser on overnight or when I leave the house. The diffuser is very strong and will make my entire house smell amazing. The design of the diffuser is like a volcano and a dry vapor comes out of the top of the volcano top and turns my house into an aromatherapy spa.I absolutely love the easy to use design and the sleek look of the diffuser, not only does it diffuses my essential oils but is also a beautiful decoration in my house. I use this product everyday and wash the diffuser after every use. The diffuser is very light weight and easy to clean and store. I wish it had an auto off function because sometimes I fall asleep to the diffuser. Overall, this is my favorite diffuser and I use it all the time. The materials feel sturdy and I know it will last me many more years!

My sister was so excited when she got them and put them on and immediately began to turn off the lights and show us her dance moves!When the lights are off, the little LED lights are very powerful! The gloves fit my sister very well, but on me fit a little big. She has bigger hands so I think these gloves come in a larger size. The gloves have to be readjusted once they are placed on and can be a bit difficult to take off due to the wires located at the top of the fingers of the gloves. The gloves have an on/off button which also controls the color and movement of the LED lights. The gloves come with several modes and colors for a better light show effect.I am very glad I purchased this for my sister! Whenever she goes to a concert or rave, everyone asks her where she got her gloves because they look so awesome. The lights are potent and since the lights are located on the fingers, light shows look intense and beautiful. These are such a cool gift idea for ravers and dancers.

I purchased item because my husband is a huge gamer and needed a new headset. I was very thankful that I was able to purchase this product during a one time promotional period. The price of the headset is great, for such a comfortable and nicely packaged item! I was very surprised with the sleek and modern look of the packaging and the gaming headset for only $13.99! This review is written in my own words and experiences.The headset includes the speak-in microphone, mic port cable and the comfortable headset. The sound is great and the microphone also works very well, with clear sound. I have to re-adjust the cable sometimes to get clear sound, but it usually works without a problem. The headphones were a little smaller than I expected, but they fit well and I can barely tell I have them on sometimes! My husband was very excited when I gifted him this headset and uses this all the time while playing with his brother online. My husband even mentioned getting another set so him and his brother can play and communicate together.This is a great headset for any gamer. The sound is clear and the headset looks great when it is on. I would buy this again, it is such a great bargain for a comfortable headset. The volume control is easy to use and the microphone can be adjusted to fit anyone!

I absolutely LOVE this vibrator. I purchased this product after buying the Ladygasm Cici 1, which was OK but does not compare to the Cici 2 which for me is absolutely amazing. From the moment I layed eyes on this vibrator I knew I was going to love it! I purchased this item using a one time promotional code, this review is written in my own words and experiences. This vibrator is my absolute favorite!The Ladygasm Cici 2 did not come in a pretty red box like the Cici 1, I loved the discreet packaging of the Cici 1. This vibrator comes in a vacuum sealed plastic bag, which makes it hard to store because the vacuum sealed bag is disposable and does not help to store the vibrator. This vibrator is 6.5 x 2.4 x 2.8 inches, dark pink color and is very soft. I love the uniform softness of the vibrator! One of my major complaints of the Cici 1 was the small size of the clitoris simulator and of the vibrator overall. The Cici 2 fixes both of these problems! The size of the vibrator is perfect! The clitoris simulator feels so good and is the right size! The vibrations are strong, yet very quiet and can be changed by the click of a button. The vibrator has two buttons which are labeled (Cici 1 is not labeled), one is the power button and the other one changes the vibration mode. The vibrator comes with various vibration modes which makes it almost impossible to get bored with the vibrator.This vibrator makes it so easy for me to climax due to the combo of the shape of the vibrator, softness and the rhythmic vibrations! My husband and I enjoy this toy together and I even use this toy when I am home alone. The vibrator is very discreet and lightweight. It can be taken anywhere and easily stored. The Cici 2 also includes a stand for easier storage but does not include any batteries (2 AAA). I would highly recommend this vibrator to any couples or singles out there who are in need of a highly stimulating and quiet vibrator. I absolutely love this vibrator and would buy another in a heart beat!

If, like me, you've experienced storm-induced power outages that have dragged on for several days, you will likely be intrigued by the nightmare scenario that Ted Koppel poses in this important book.  What, he asks, would happen if an enemy state, terrorist organization or even a rogue hacker were able to knock out one or more of the three power grids that keep the lights on in the United States?  And what if this outage went on for weeks or even months?Koppel uses meticulous research into the inner workings of the electrical power industry, including interviews with prominent executive and Government officials to make a convincing case that a well-planned cyber attack on our power grid is a risk that our leaders need to take more seriously.  And he explains how difficult and expensive it would be either to prevent such an attack or develop a suitable response strategy.Even so, Lights Out is far from bleak or fatalistic.  Rather, Koppel uses examples (individual efforts to stockpile and prepare their families for such emergencies, the Morman Church's impressive infrastructure, and England's preparations for German airstrikes in World War II) to show how any efforts toward preparing for extended periods of power outage are likely to pay meaningful dividends.  Hopefully Mr. Koppel's warning will be heard and a combination of individual preparedness efforts and Government initiatives will begin to chip away at this daunting vulnerability.

This potholder/oven mitt features an attractive, colorful red-and-white design that will brighten up your kitchen.  They are less bulky than the ones that have been hanging around mine for ages, though the sleeker design seemingly came at the expense of some loss in heat resistance.  While perfectly sufficient for most uses, be careful about using them to handle something super-hot for an extended period of time.

The Sea Beach Line seized my attention from the opening pages, offering a Jewish perspective on crime fiction. Its hero Issac (Izzy) Edel, ejected from college for drug-related activities and drawn to New York City on a quest to find his estranged father, Alojzy, narrates the novel with an honest voice, that‚Äôs somehow both naÔve and streetwise in equal measure.Alojzi, a street-smart tough-guy who has spent much of his life operating at the fringes of the law, has disappeared from his latest gig as a street vendor and is presumed dead by the hustlers and gangsters who knew him best. Izzy, however, has good reason to doubt the motives of Alojzi‚Äôs buddies and believes his father may still be alive.  After discovering Alojzi‚Äôs inventory storage room and a sketchbook telling his life story through a jumbled collection of portraits, Izzy feels compelled to take over his father‚Äôs bookselling business and figure out the significance of the faces in the sketchbook.  Believing that the secret to his father‚Äôs disappearance lies with a gangster named Timur and his hatchet man, Roman, Izzy allows himself to be recruited deeper and deeper into their service.  Matters are complicated by Izzy‚Äôs budding romance with an enigmatic young lady named Rayna, who bears a striking resemblance to one of Alojzi‚Äôs sketches and is on the run from a family who may be abusing her.  A subplot involving Izzy‚Äôs sister and her fianc√©e add additional complexity to this morality tale.Throughout the novel, Ben Nadler includes obscure references to Jewish novels, folk tales and customs, which often relate metaphorically to Izzy‚Äôs experiences.  Although I‚Äôm not Jewish and would have found even more meaning in these references if I understood them better, The Sea Beach line is an exceptionally well-written and captivating novel that will appeal to anyone who appreciates great writers like Michael Chabon and Dennis Lehane.  In the right hands, I could see this novel being adapted into a terrific movie.

The three Axe products in this gift box--body wash, deodorant and spray-on scent--pack enough punch to keep any active male smelling fresh and clean.  The body wash is perfect, lathering up well and leaving just the right amount of residual earthy scent.  The fragrance, though pleasing in the same earthy way, is extremely strong and long-lasting, so a single quick spray to the chest is all I would recommend.  The deodorant, while leaving a pleasant scent, is not as effective at reducing sweat and odor as my go-to product (Mitchum), making it the weak link of the three.  This would make a great gift for an active teenage boy who may not otherwise be motivated to stave off his body odor.

Dawn of Deception, billed as the first installment in a trilogy featuring park ranger David Nbeke, builds a thrilling plot around the real-world criminal enterprise of poaching elephants and rhinos.  Author Dan Fletcher effectively sets his novel in Kenya‚Äôs Massai Mara Reserve during 1996, providing insights into the political turmoil in the country and using authentic details to make his novel come to life.  This thriller employs a classic cat-and-mouse structure, pitting David against Peter Abasi, the corrupt Commander of the General Service Unit (a powerful Kenyan paramilitary organization).  David‚Äôs efforts to unravel the truth behind this poaching conspiracy are aided by investigative reporter Aaron Bernstein and complicated by his romantic involvement with Caitlyn, a veterinarian whose willingness to assist David places her in danger.  The action and suspense level pick up in the last third of the novel, as the extent of Abasi‚Äôs evil deeds comes to light, building toward a page-turning finale.  Be warned that this a violent novel, with graphic descriptions of torture and combat that are not for the squeamish reader.As Dan Fletcher completes this trilogy, I expect he will improve on some aspects of his writing.  In Dawn of Deception he tends to ‚Äútell‚Äù rather than ‚Äúshow,‚Äù often including superfluous phrases telling us what the characters are thinking or feeling.  The pacing is also uneven in the early and middle stages of the story, where some passages overwhelm the reader with details and can be somewhat hard to follow.  More care also needs to be taken in the editing process, as the number of typographical errors exceeds what you would expect in a published work.  These issues aside, Dawn of Deception is an entertaining read and promising start to the David Nbeke series.

The cognitive benefits of high-dose B-12 vitamins have been touted by many, and so a product like this may be worth trying.  The tablet dissolves within a minute on your tongue and leaves a pleasing, fruity flavor in your mouth.  I can't say, however, that I've noticed any change in my mental alertness or an improvement in sleep quality after using this daily for the past few weeks. So when I finish this container, I'll rely on my daily multi-vitamin for B-12 support, at a much lower dosage.

With the plethora of Apple gadgets in my household demanding frequent charges, having a number of fast, easy-to connect chargers is critical.  This one works as advertised, and the ninety-degree connection angle makes it easy to hook up to your device.  I only wish it came with an adaptor to allow you to plug into a household power outlet in addition to your computer port.

The ice-crushing set-up for this blender works well, allowing you to prepare slushy-style drinks from regular ice cubes, and the small motor has more power than you would expect. I have not yet tried the blender set-up, however, as the unit I was sent did not include the blender container, the directions instructing you to find a tall narrow container to use for blending.  I also found the instructions regarding the three set-ups (ice crushing, chopping and blending) to be somewhat difficult to follow.  Another shortcoming is that there is no case in which to store the components.

From the first page of this crime novel, you know you're in sure hands.  Thomas Cobb writes with the same pared-back style as Lehane and Leonard, yet somehow making the setting of dying northeastern town, Lydell, and the lives of its inhabitants so real that you truly feel what it would be like to live there.  Lydell is a place of little opportunity, so when rookie policeman Ronny Forbert pulls over a group of local troublemakers in a routine traffic stop and their ringleader, Matt Lafariere, ends up being killed by a hit-and-run driver while resisting arrest, Forbert finds himself in a desperate struggle to preserve his reputation and livelihood.Matters are complicated by the close connections between the key players in this small-town drama, revealed through a number of well-placed flashbacks.  Forbert, it turns out, used to run with Lafariere's gang, until Forbert ratted him out for arson and town police chief Gordy Hawkins took Forbert under his wing and offered him a job.  Forbert's girlfriend also happens to be Lafariere's old flame, and her father the Town Attorney.  These factors, enable Martin Glendenning, a local politician with a corrupt agenda and dislike for Hawkins, to incite the townsfolk against Forbert despite evidence of his innocence.Cobb's novel had me until the final chapters, as he did a masterful job at escalating the tension and stakes and made be really care about his complex and flawed heroes, Forbert and Hawkins.  A poor ending, however, can diminish even the best of novels, and regrettably that was the case with Darkness the Color of Snow.  For me, the careful character development and psychological dissection of Forbert went out the window, either because the author wrote himself into a corner or wanted a shocking, unpredictable ending.

With Racing the Rain, John L. Parker has completed an addictive trilogy of running novels, all featuring miler Quenton Cassidy.  The first, Once a Runner, which takes place during Cassidy's days at Florida's fictitious Southeastern University, amassed a cult following that propelled it from the realm of the self-published to a deal with a major New York publisher.  The second installment, Again to Carthage, chronicled Cassidy's return to competitive running after years spent practicing law, fleshing out Cassidy's irreverent character and providing many insights into how training and racing remain central to a world-class athlete's persona, even into middle age.Racing the Rain is an origins tale.  Beginning in Cassidy's elementary and middle school years, when he first becomes aware of his speed and endurance in foot races with his classmates, and continuing through his high school years, when Cassidy's running takes a back seat to basketball, the reader comes to appreciate how friends, mentors, rivals, and personal demons all play a role in shaping the personality and drive necessary to become a competitive distance runner. As the father of an eighth grade running prodigy, who is similarly obsessed with basketball, I loved the way in which Cassidy's commitment to running was tested by this powerful distraction.Those looking for a novel dominated by training and racing scenes may be disappointed, particularly during the middle chapters that describe Cassidy's friendship with Trapper Nelson (known as the Tarzan of the Everglades) and his efforts to break into the ranks of varsity basketball.  There are also the usual campy conflicts between Cassidy and a member of the school faculty (this time the villain is his middle school track coach who later becomes the varsity basketball coach).  But those with the patience to appreciate how these influences kindle Cassidy's competitive fire will be rewarded by his glorious return to running in his senior year of high school and will discover the origins of Cassidy's bond with his future Southeastern teammate, Jerry Mizner.Thank you, Mr. Parker, for showing us once again what it means to be a runner.-Kevin Joseph, author of The Champion Maker

This protein bar goes heavy on the fiber, though the salted dark chocolate flavoring makes it surprisingly palatable.  I see it as a good breakfast bar or between-meal snack, but the protein content is not what many would want for muscle-building purposes.

The OtterBox Defender offers the highest protection possible for your HTC One phone.  It features a rubberized backing and plastic screen cover, along with a belt clip that comes in handy for a phone that's already too large for many pockets.  The only downsides are its bulkiness and the bare-bones directions that make it somewhat frustrating to install.  (For a less-bulky option that provides robust drop protection, you might prefer the Otter Commuter, though it doesn't come with a belt clip.)

Stephanie Clifford‚Äôs first novel, Everybody Rise, offers a fascinating view into the rarified lifestyle of the old-moneyed, East Coast families who summer at mansion-sized ‚Äúcabins‚Äù in the Adirondack mountains, whose daughters still attend debutant balls and are too busy with social events to bother with paying jobs, and whose sons prep at the exclusive Ivy-league feeder schools on their way to making gobs more money at New York hedge funds.  Through the eyes of protagonist, Evelyn Beegan, daughter of a ‚Äúnew-money‚Äù plaintiffs‚Äô lawyer (bearing certain similarities to John Edwards), Clifford shows how enticing this elite lifestyle can appear and how tempting it is to invent a fake persona (complete with phony background details) in order to show you belong.  Using her own prep school alumni network and job as marketing lead for an exclusive networking Website called ‚ÄúPeople Like Us‚Äù to worm her way into these elite social circles, Evelyn is on the verge of the lifestyle she and her mother crave, until her mistruths and father‚Äôs legal entanglements threaten to undo everything she believes to be important.  Once you get past the first chapters, which throw a lot of characters and insider dialogue at you without much context, and come to terms with Evelyn‚Äôs unbelievably bad choices, which seem somewhat out-of-character from the sensible way she is initially portrayed, Everybody Rise will hold your interest and make you grateful that you‚Äôre not trying to run in these treacherous social circles.

Extremely light-weight and simple to operate, this D-battery-powered lantern is ideal for use during power outages, evenings on the patio, or late-evening fishing trips.  The three levels of brightness can be controlled at the touch of a finger, and even the lowest setting is strong enough to illuminate a small room.  This is a wonderful product, and I plan to buy one for my father to replace a kerosene lantern he's been using for the past 50 years.

A first novel by writing-instructor Elena Delbanco, The Silver Swan provides an entertaining literary foray into the rarefied world of the professional string musician.  Protagonist Mariana is a promising cellist until her career is cut short by the onset of stage fright and demands of her ailing father, revered cellist Alexander Feldmann.  When Alexander bequeaths his priceless Stradivarius cello (known as the Silver Swan) to former student Clause, instead of fulfilling his promises to Mariana, her struggles to come to terms with this shocking decision are complicated by her romantic attraction to Claude.  And as Mariana discovers the tangled web spun by Alexander's decades-long affair with another married woman, she's pushed to the outer limits of her sanity.Though the plot is predictable in many respects and the ending is somewhat anti-climactic, Delbanco writes beautifully and insightfully about the demanding lifestyle of the word-class musician.  And the way in which she recounts the complex relationship (father-daughter and teacher-student) between the narcissistic Alexander and the overly-eager-to-please Mariana really draws you into this story.  Overall, the novel came across as an autobiographically-inspired piece of catharsis for the author, and I look forward to a second novel in which she is able to construct a plot and characters that stand on their own.

This knife-flashlight combo is a great tool for use around the house, while camping, or as part of an emergency survival kit.  The retractable blade is sharp and sturdy, and the plastic handle is water-friendly and easy to grip.  I envision using this as a box-cutter and for other manly cutting tasks beyond the pale of kitchen utensils.  The light will make it a great tool to have on hand during power outages or for outdoor use after sundown.  The only reason I have knocked off a star is my initial frustration in locating the mechanism for retracting the blade; including a simple set of directions in the package, explaining that the metal stopper behind the blade must be pushed to the left to retract the knife, would be most helpful.

Revenge of the Krelim is marketed as a "gripping, tightly-plotted tale of espionage", and its hero, Malko Linge, is touted as France's answer to Fleming's James Bond.  Gerard de Villiers apparently penned 200 of these Malko Linge spy novels before his death in 2003 and is considered the most popular writer of spy novels in French history, with plots torn from the headlines or even presaging them.Sounds really compelling.  Unfortunately, after two or three chapters, I was disappointed by the awkwardness of the prose, on-the-nose dialogue, barrage of clich√©s, and gigolo antics of Linge.  If there had been a compelling, suspenseful plot, I may have been willing to overlook some of these shortcomings as byproducts of poor translation from the French version published in 2013.  But I'm sad to report that the plot was eminently predictable and largely devoid of suspense.  At bottom, it was nothing more that CIA operative Linge's efforts to fill in a few missing details to round out the file on an assassination and cover-up orchestrated by Vladimir Putin's regime, during which he had to dodge a couple of attempts on his life and accommodate several gorgeous women who couldn't keep their hands off him (described in overly-explicit detail).It may be that this novel is unrepresentative of the quality to be found in the rest of the series, but I've had my fill of Malko Linge.

This conditioner has a light, foamy texture coming our of the bottle and applies easily.  It has a mildly pleasant scent and really coats your hair with its conditioning ingredients.  You need to spend extra effort rinsing it out, however, as it may otherwise leave your hair looking greasy and matted down.  For that reason, I don't think I would buy this over less expensive conditioners that rinse more easily.

This comfortable, attractive throw-blanket is a household favorite.  It's large, warm, and the sherpa side as well as the silky front side feel terrific on your skin.  My only misgiving is the American flag design, which invites technical violations of 4 USC Section 8 (Respect for flag).  Even though the flag law is not enforced--doing so would violate the First Amendment right to free speech--this is a product that commands respectful use, preferably within the confines of your home.

I can't say that I have an uncomfortably itchy scalp, so I'm probably not ideally-suited to review this product.  But like most people, I find that my scalp does itch on occasion.  Applying this product at one of those times produced a pleasant cooling sensation, along with an overpoweringly-minty smell, though I'm not convinced that the root cause of the itch was treated in any meaningful way.  So I suspect this product may be a novelty item that temporarily masks symptoms better treated by a shampoo.

Adam Mitzner's Losing Faith rivals the best of John Grisham.  As a lawyer, I have high expectations for a legal thriller, and this one exceeded them on all accounts.  The action gets underway quickly, when super-lawyer Aaron Littmann is blackmailed into representing Nikolai Garkov, a high-profile Russian mobster with terrorist ties.  Littmann, chairman of one of New York City's most prestigious law firms and a seemingly devoted husband and father, has one vulnerability: he's had an affair with Faith Nichols, the federal judge assigned to Garkov's case.  And Littmann quickly learns that Garkov will expose the affair, along with the fact that he unethically tried a previous case before Faith while they were still lovers, unless Littman pressures Faith to acquit Garkov.Unlike many thriller writers, who quickly lose their way after setting such a tantalizing hook, Mitzner develops the plot brilliantly. The blackmail scheme morphs into something far more serious, exposing Littmann to the possibility of life in prison unless he can somehow clear his name.  Mitzner manages to increase the suspense without relying on far-fetched plot turns or thinly-developed characters, all the while maintaining an admirable degree of realism and precision in his treatment of legal issues.  The novel culminates in a nail-biting trial, in which Littman seeks to overcome damning evidence pointing toward his guilt, and in doing so, ignores the advice to negotiate a plea deal that he's provided to many of his supposedly innocent clients in similar circumstances.If you are fan of legal thrillers, Adam Mitzner is a writer who deserves a spot on your bookshelf next to Grisham and Lashner. Losing Faith has my highest recommendation.

This digital scale is attractively-designed and offers an accurate weight reading.  It also includes additional features that allow up to four different users to manage their weight.  After following a series of easy steps to enter information on your sex, height, age, and level of physical activity, the scale provides each user's BMI and calorie count required for maintaining current weight.  With the abundance of more sophisticated fitness and calorie monitoring products on the market, I'm not sure how useful these additional features will be to the serious dieter or fitness buff.  But these are handy features for those seeking a simple way to monitor their weight.

This psychological suspense novel employs a unique narrative structure.  Chapters alternate between Rachel's narration of events immediately preceding and following a murder, and Megan's narration of earlier events.  A third narrator, Anna, provides another perspective on some of the post-murder happenings.Rachel, driven to alcoholism by her inability to become pregnant and her failed marriage to Tom (now remarried to Anna), experiences a blackout on the night of the murder, preventing her from recalling something critical that she observed and calling the reliability of her other memories into question.Setting-wise, this novel is also unique.  Much of the action takes place on or in the proximity of a commuter train that Rachel rides to and from work, and continues to ride even after being fired.  While the train motif enhances the unity of the story, it also tends to fuel the use of coincidence, as the same group of characters repeatedly run across one another in close proximity to the train.The closed setting, alcohol-fueled despondency of Rachel, and dysfunctional relationships that pervade this novel make for a rather dark and creepy reading experience. And while the author takes great pains to dissect the psychological motivations of her characters, she does so in a way that strains the limits of what is believable and bogs down the action just when it starts to accelerate.So this novel was kind of a mixed-bag for me.  I appreciated the creative structure of this psychological suspense novel, but felt that it dragged in places and that the characters' motivations ultimately lacked the believability one expects from this genre.

This soft rubber flying disc is a fun variation on the classic Frisbee design.  Adapting your throw takes some time and patience, however, as this disc is considerably heavier than the traditional design and tends to slip from your fingers when you try to throw it too hard.  But after a while you will learn to tilt it upwards more upon release and add some extra rotation to hold the trajectory.  The other unique feature, a hole in the center, allows you to catch the disc by poking through your finger tips.  My main issue with the design is that it doesn't seem conducive to long, accurate throws or good hang time, though maybe it's just that I haven't yet put in enough time to hone my technique.

The primary features that distinguish this from a basic corkscrew are the attractive walnut handle and retractable foil-cutting knife.  The foil cutter works like a pocket-knife, and is sharp enough to dislodge a bottle's foil with a single swipe.  The corkscrew also has a solid heft to it, making it feel at home with high end cutlery.

This is a solid entry into what I would characterize as the lighter-end protein bar market.  With only 210 calories and 10 grams of protein per bar, this is not a supplement that provides the large protein infusion sought by muscle-builders.  Instead it offers a good balance of fiber (5 grams) and vitamins, made quite palatable by a rich chocolate coating, though there is a slight aftertaste that's mildly off-putting.  I've enjoyed it as part of my post-run breakfast, finding that a cup of strong coffee is a good way to cut the bar's sweetness and aftertaste.

Ben Metcalf is well known in literary circles as an accomplished editor and writing instructor, and Against the Country is being touted as the masterpiece novel that he's been toiling at for years.  I appreciate the central idea of his work, an attempt to debunk the popular myth that country living is less corrupt and more wholesome than an urban existence.  But the way in which it's executed (a series of short, interrelated, essay-style rants against growing up in rural Virginia during the 1970s and 1980s), does not facilitate great story-telling.There are certain groups of essays that begin to form engaging pieces of a story line (notably, the narrator's school bus-related rites of passage, anecdotes revealing a love-hate relationship with a complex, abusive father, and a bizarre series of interactions with the chicken coop's dominant Rhode Island Red "B.F."), yet too many hard-to-decipher rants are interspersed throughout for my liking.  (Be forewarned that Metcalf writes in incredibly long, convoluted sentences, which require all the focus and attention you can muster just to maintain a tenuous connection to the material.)If you have a taste for the darkest of comedies, a mistrust of all things rural, and don't mind stretching your brain to its outer limits, you may want to give this unusual book a try.  But if you're looking for some light, good-natured entertainment, this one's not for you.

A protein bar must strike an appropriate balance between nutritional content and taste.  This one does not.  It tastes simply awful, and the experience of trying to choke this thing down is worsened by its rubbery texture and yellow-brown color.  I cannot recommend this product, even for the most iron-stomached of health fanatics.

This facial cleanser has a mildly-gritty texture and brown color that gives the impression of a fine mud or silt.  It applies smoothly, a small dab lathering to cover your entire face, and washes off easily.  This product cleans pores well and leaves your face with a fresh, clean feel.  I would recommend this for use once or twice per week, as it is a bit abrasive for daily use.

Under Armour claims to have redesigned the running shoe from the ground up, fabicating the Speedform Apollo in a clothing factory for better fit and avoidance of inside seams.  These marketing claims are justified from my experience with this shoe.  Aside from a tongue that tends to look bunched up when the shoe is tied (though still feeling comfortable), these shoes truly do fit like a second skin, holding the foot in place and reducing blisters.  They are also incredibly light-weight, rivaling a racing flat.  It's a firm, minimalist ride, however, so if you're used to running in a highly-cushioned shoe, you may need to shorten your runs, especially on hard surfaces, until your legs acclimate.  One beneficial effect I have seen is that the shoe has helped increase my stride rate from 165 to 175, as the firm ride does not allow for overstriding.  And once you are acclimated, you will find yourself running faster times over short and longer distances, with your legs feeling fresher than you expect afterward.

Mark McClusky's survey of the scientific influences of sports performance offers a comprehensive look across a number of subjects that other recent books have handled individually and in greater depth.  For example, The Sports Gene offers a deeper look at genetic contributors to performance, and other books examine performance enhancing-drugs and data analytics in more detail.  Consequently, the text moves from subject to subject without putting forth a remarkable thesis beyond the rather-obvious observation that science is affecting the way athletes approach their sports, in much the same way as it is affecting other aspects of our lives. For me, the most groundbreaking portions were those that discussed how science is allowing athletes to train more intelligently and specifically to hone those skills sets unique to their particular sports. That said, the writing style is clear and engaging, and the author makes good use of interesting anecdotes and studies to support his observations.  So I would recommend this book for someone who has not read extensively on these subjects and wants a good, general overview of the intersection between sports and science.

Endgame will feel familiar to Hunger Games fans:  twelve teens are pitted against one another in a violent contest.  Here, though, the stakes are elevated, as the twelve Players fight not just for personal survival but for the survival of an ancient lineage that each represents. To further prime the pump, James Frey has embedded a real-life contest within the framework of the novel, promising a treasure trove for the reader who can solve the puzzle and locate it.Puzzle and booty aside, the story itself is a fast, action-packed read, if you can get past the micro-chapters, clipped prose, comic book-style action, and unanswered questions about why Endgame exists in the first place.  We know there is an alien agenda driving it, and that these are the same extraterrestrials who helped ancient civilizations build Stonehenge and the pyramids, but Frey has deferred the specifics for the next books in the series.It will be interesting to see whether Endgame catches fire like the Hunger Games. I suspect its success may hinge as much, or more, on the allure of the puzzle as the story surrounding it.

This novel got off to a promising start.  A young black man (Deesh), imprisoned as a murder suspect, meets a young white woman (Jan)with information that may lead to his acquittal. The author then flashes back, using alternating chapters narrated by Deesh and Jan, to tell the story of how three former high school basketball stars, now working on the fringes of the law, get ensnared in a crime connected to the seedy world of racehorse gambling.Unfortunately, the novel's early excitement and promise fade through middle chapters that are too introspective.  Introspection can be effective in a crime novel if done well, but many of these literary musings come across as forced and awkward, grasping for themes and connections that don't flow naturally from the story itself.  Though there are bursts of action, often the characters' decisions lack plausibility.Other reviewers have criticized Mark Wisniewski's decision not to bring the plot lines together until the very end.  For me, this was not the root cause of the novel's flatness, as the author was seeking to link the disparate worldviews of the two narrators through themes rather than plot points, a risky narrative structure that can be powerful, but only when executed to perfection.  Unfortunately, the thematic connections between Deesh's and Jan's experiences were not established convincingly enough for this novel to come across as much more than two interesting novellas.To be fair, there are some beautiful passages in here, and I have no doubt that Mark Wisniewski is capable of writing great novels in the future.

This K'nex set kept my two sons (ages 9 and 12) occupied for quite some time.  They are more accustomed to building from Lego instructions, and at first, found the K-nex instructions harder to follow.  But they gradually warmed to the challenge and enjoyed both building and playing with the finished product.  There are several cool weapons in the set, making it one that can be used repeatedly for creative battle play.

Dark Spies, fourth in Matthew Dunn's Spycather series, is a solid spy thriller, featuring a good blend of espionage know-how and page-turning suspense.  Its hero, Will Cochrane, has strong appeal as a spy who follows his own moral compass, even when doing so puts his career and life in jeopardy.  Dunn sets the hook early and hard, forcing Cochrane to choose between a CIA order that he allow a fellow agent to be executed in furtherance of a national security project called Ferryman and his gut instincts that she doesn't deserve to die.  Cochrane's choice puts him on the run and forces him to make his way from Norway back to the United States, where he hopes to expose the truth about Ferryman.As the plot unfolds, numerous twists and turns emerge, several of which veer out of the zone of plausibility.  So my main criticism of Dark Spies is the author's willingness to compromise plausibility in his quest to ramp up the thrill quotient and ratchet up the suspense.  In future novels, I would prefer him to make more of an effort to maintain a realistic feel.

If you're looking for a multi-purpose beverage that wakes you up, includes a dose of vitamins, throws in some fiber, and quenches your thirst, Acute is worth trying.  As others have observed, the drink has a sweet fruity flavor (reminding me of canned peaches), but without the carbonation of similar products.  The caffeine content is less than a cup of coffee, but other ingredients (like the taurine found in Red Bull) combine with the caffeine to provide a noticeable energy boost that lasts several hours.  The biggest drawback is that it gives me a slight jittery feeling, though not nearly as pronounced as Red Bull.  I drank one before my morning run today, in lieu of my usual cup of coffee, and felt as if it elevated my heart rate a bit more than usual during the first mile or so, which will make me think twice about drinking this immediately before vigorous exercise.

For a 45-watt bulb, this produces surprisingly strong light.  I have been using this in my bedside reading lamp, and it kicks off just enough light to read by, without being hot or glaring.  I'm assuming it offers the energy saving that's advertised, and time will tell whether it longevity claims hold up.

This transformer toy is an improvement on prior versions, insofar as the transformation between robot and car is much faster and smoother.  (My nine-year-old was able to figure it out in minutes.)  When in car form, the toy functions surprisingly well, rolling as smoothly as a regular toy car.  The problem with these kinds of toys, however, is that they don't facilitate creative play as well as toys such as Legos that allow the kids to build and rebuild them.

This young-adult novel caught my attention because of its marketing claim to be a story told entirely in lists.  In some ways, it's unfortunate that it sometimes takes a gimmick like this to attract attention in today's crowded literary marketplace.  For while the list-driven structure of the novel is notably unique, the chapters where the lists more closely resemble the traditional literary form and the well-drawn personalities of the characters are what make this coming-of-age story so compelling.Comprised of lists that range from a few words in some instances to the length of a regular novel's chapter in other places, the 640 pages fly by in a surprisingly seamless flow.  (The shorter lists often provide a comic relief between the longer, dramatic lists.)  The narrative is powered by the compelling personality of teenage protagonist Darren, a slightly-overweight "everyboy" who's struggling to find his way in the world.  Among the challenges he faces are the revelation that his recently-divorced father is gay, his confusing attraction to an eccentricly-artistic girl named Zoey, and the realization that the older brother he so admires has fallen into a druggy haze during his freshman year at college.As its unusual title suggests, this novel is not so much about plot as about discovering what's unique in ourselves and others, and respecting these seemingly insane differences. And by the end of the novel, Darren begins to make more confident choices about his budding musical career, his relationship with Zoey, and the way in which he relates to his fractured family members. There are lots of good lessons packed in here that would benefit teenagers and adults alike, and this unusual novel should find a broad audience.

Following in the comedic tradition of National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation, The Santa Claus, and Elf, William Hazelgrove's Real Santa is a sure bet to join the ranks of classic Christmas tales. For fans of Hazelgrove's other novels, George Kronenfeldt fits within the familiar mold of his other protagonists: the middle-aged father who takes up a quixotic cause in an effort to restore some semblance of order to the chaos of his professional and family life.The story opens in the run-up to the Christmas season with George receiving news that he has lost his job as a civil engineer and that his daughter Megan's caustic fourth-grade teacher has made comments that make her doubt the existence of Santa Claus.  George, a Christmas fanatic who is still scarred by his father's premature revelation of the truth about Santa Clause, decides he must prove to Megan that Santa is real by staging something so convincing that she can film it on her phone and post it on YouTube.  What follows is a madcap, no-expense-spared project to hire a sketchy movie producer and enlist the engineering genius of his father to help him put real reindeer on his roof and navigate his chimney with a bag full of presents.  As Christmas eve approaches and the obstacles to success mount, George also encounters an enigmatic fellow who may or may not be the real Santa Claus.Although the ending, which crosses into magical realism, feels somewhat out of character with the rest of the story, this is a Christmas tale after all, and a thoroughly enjoyable one at that.-Kevin Joseph, author of The Champion Maker

"Never trust a skinny cook," some say, and this apron is sized from that very perspective.  Roomy enough for foodie men and featuring a unisex design geared toward wine lovers, this product will have wide appeal.  The material, a heavyweight cotton, should wear well and stand up to multiple washings.  So it you're in the market for an apron that can be used by any chef who wields a spatula in your kitchen, this one is a smart choice.

This sleek cordless vacuum has many design features that make it easier to use than the clunky plug-ins that have long dominated the market.  Easy to assemble and charge, this product includes a detachable handheld unit for cleaning elevated areas and also works well as a floor sweeping device.  I find this vaccum particularly useful in my kitchen, where I'm constantly waging a war against crumbs that fall to the hardwood floor from my boys' incessant snacking. With its swiveling head, unencumbered by a cord, the vacuum is able to reach under tables and chairs with ease, making it a cinch to keep the kitchen floor clean.  It's so fun to use, that my nine-year-old son has been using it to sweep up after himself without me nagging.  What higher praise can I offer?

As a fan of The Fourth Realm Trilogy, I was eager for the opportunity to review the latest work from the enigmatic John Twelve Hawks.  For readers new to this author, there has been considerable media swirl over the years regarding Hawks's decision to keep his real identity anonymous, even to his agent and publisher. It seems that the same mistrust of governments and corporations that pervades his fiction writing has also shaped the way he chooses to live.  And for me, that makes his novels all the more compelling.In Spark, Hawks narrates through the first person viewpoint of a seriously-scarred man.  After barely surviving a motorcycle accident, Jacob Underwood's near-death experience has left him with a condition called Cotard's syndrome, which makes him believe he's become a type of living dead, nothing more than a life force or "spark" floating in a body or "shell" with no meaningful connection between mind and body.  This condition manifests itself in strange behaviors, like an aversion to any physical contact with people, a refusal to consume solid food, and the inability to experience or perceive most human emotions.  It's little wonder, then, that Underwood, a highly intelligent computer programmer whose condition makes him incredibly focused on completing assigned tasks with ruthless efficiency, is recruited as an assassin for a shadowy corporation.What follows is a novel so well-plotted and unique that I guarantee you won't be able to tear yourself away.  As Underwood takes on the most challenging assignment of his career, he begins to undergo a personal transformation in his outlook on the world.
